DOC.HEAD: Committee Recommends Approval of Hepatitis Treatment
DOC.TEXT: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee on Tuesday unanimously recommended approval of interferon alpha as the first treatment shown to be effective against hepatitis C, an FDA spokeswoman said. Interferon alpha, a substance produced naturally in the body that can be made in large quantitities by genetic engineering, has already been approved for treatment of hairy-cell leukemia, Kaposi's sarcoma and genital warts. The drug does not cure hepatitis C, also known as non-A, non-B hepatitis and is not universally effective, but studies have shown that it can alleviate some effects of the disease, said FDA spokeswoman Faye Peterson. Committee members also recommended long-term followup of hepatitis patients after the drug receives formal approval. Hepatitis C is a chronic disease that sometimes leads to cirrhosis and cancer of the liver, which often are fatal. As many as 200,000 people get hepatitis C each year in the United States, at least half from unknown causes. Known causes include blood transfusions from infected people, sharing of infected intravenous needles by drug abusers and, according to some studies, sexual relations. The drug is manufactured by Schering-Plough Corp. under the brand name Intron A. The advisory panel also recommended against FDA approval of granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor, or GM-CSF, one of a new family of complex proteins that regulate production of blood cells. GM-CSF is critical in the production of white blood cells. Committee members agreed that more research on the drug is needed before it can be approved for use in cancer therapy and other diseases that have impaired the body's ability to fight infections, Peterson said. The drug, also genetically engineered, is being tested on patients whose bone-marrow transplants failed. The panel recommended the FDA allow continued use of the drug for patients with this life-threatening condition. The drug is made by Hoechst-Roussel Pharmaceutical Inc. The body produces GM-CSF naturally, but in very small quantities. Its gene was identified recently and the drug now can be produced through genetic engineering, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Defeats GOP Attempts to Diminish Labor's Campaign Clout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-8: ``Meanwhile, 16,'' new votes on public financing and campaign rollovers; CORRECTS Nickels to Nickles in following two grafs; DELETES last four grafs to trim. Stands for AMs.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate defeated Republican attempts Tuesday to diminish labor's clout at the polls _ usually on behalf of Democrats _ as part of a bill to clean up the way federal election campaigns are financed. On largely party-line votes, Democrats defeated amendments to strip unions of their tax-exempt status if they stay in politics and to allow their members to demand refunds of any dues spent on elections or lobbying. Republicans claimed the votes demonstrate their contention that Democrats' campaign finance reform bill and its spending ceilings is a ``partisan charade'' that will assure a veto by President Bush. ``We might as well as go on to something else,'' said Senate GOP leader Bob Dole of Kansas. ``So far this campaign reform bill only reforms Republicans,'' Dole said. ``We like reform, but ... it's got to be reform that applies to both sides.'' Meanwhile, 16 Democrats joined Republicans in defeating an effort by liberals to have the government pick up 70 percent of a candidate's general election costs through a new $2 checkoff on individual income tax returns. Democrats had stripped the provision from their bill last Friday but Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., tried to put it bank in Tuesday night. His amendment was defeated 68-30. Also defeated on a 49-49 tie vote was an amendment by Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., that would have prevented candidates from rolling over any surpluses in their campaign accounts for use by their House and Senate offices or for future campaigns. Instead, McCain's measure would have required that any surpluses be turned over to the government. Democrats did go along with one Republican amendment, by Sen. Don Nickles of Oklahoma, to prohibit senators and House members from using their free postage privileges for mass mailings during the calendar years they are up for re-election. Nickles cited figures showing that uses of the congressional mail frank nearly double in election years. For example, they went from $53 million in 1981 to $100 million in 1982, from $72 million in 1983 to $110 million in 1984 and from $63 million in 1987 to $113 million in 1988. Also approved was an amendment by Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, that would prohibit companies more than 50 percent foreign owned from forming political action committees to raise funds for candidates. Bentsen, whose amendment was adopted by a 73-27 vote, said PACs of foreign-owned companies contributed $2.8 million to candidates in the 1988 election _ a 19 percent increase over 1986 and 5 percent of the total given by all corporate PACs. ``It creates inevitable pressures on (U.S.) employees to use their PAC muscle in ways acceptable to the corporate masters in London or Frankfurt or Tokyo,'' he said. ``American campaigns should be for Americans.'' Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., said Bentsen's proposal was moot since Democrats and Republicans in the Senate have now agreed to ban PAC contributions altogether in the bill. Nonetheless, he voted against it, saying the amendment would strip some 3,000 U.S. citizens who work at a Toyota assembly plant in his state of their political rights should the courts rule that a total ban on PACs is unconstitutional. ``It does not treat all of us citizens the same way,'' McConnell said. ``If you happen to work at Toyota in Kentucky you don't get the same rights as somebody who works at Ford.'' On a 58-41 vote, the Senate defeated a McConnell amendment to lift the tax-exempt status of unions and other organizations if they participate at all in election campaigns. Rejected earlier on a 59-41 vote was a Republican amendment that would have allowed the nation's 17 million union members to demand refunds of any dues not spent directly on collective bargaining or grievances. Republicans contended unions spend tens of millions of dollars of the estimated $3.3 billion to $5 billion in dues they collect each year to indirectly benefit their favorite politicians through voter registration, voter education and turnout programs. The National Right to Work Committee, a group that wants to outlaw agency shop contracts under which non-union workers must pay fees to unions, estimates that organized labor spends $330 million on politics in every two-year election cycle. ``If you don't do anything about this sewer money from unions, I don't think you have campaign reform,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. ``Ninety percent goes to Democrats even though 30 percent to 40 percent of union members are Republicans.'' President Bush announced a year ago that, as a part of any campaign finance reform measure, he wanted Congress to expand on a Supreme Court ruling to give workers a right to seek refunds of any union dues spent on politics. The court ruled in 1988 that a non-union technician who paid fees to the Communications Workers of America as part of an agency shop contract with AT&T was entitled to a refund of the portion not spent directly on collective bargaining.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Refuses to Indict Officers in Racial Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with dead youth's father appealing for calm. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `Spath met...
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury declined Tuesday to indict a white police officer in the shooting of a black teen-ager whose death this year sparked rioting in the New York City suburb of Teaneck. After announcing the grand jury's decision, state Attorney General Robert Del Tufo said he would empanel a new grand jury because of errors he said were made in the autopsy. The grand jury investigated the death of Phillip Pannell, 16, of River Edge, who was shot in the back by Teaneck Police Officer Gary Spath, 29, on April 10. Pannel's death sparked a night of racially motivated rioting in Teaneck, a New York City suburb. The shooting prompted mobs of angry youths to rampage in an area near the police headquarters in Teaneck, overturning cars and attacking journalists. Black community activists organized marches and the killing polarized a community that had prided itself on racial harmony. The dead boy's father, Phillip Pannell Sr. appealed for calm. He gave reporters what he called a message for the city's young people: ``I'm willing to give America another chance for justice,'' he said. ``I feel justice will be served. Chill out.'' After announcement Tuesday, lawyers from the NAACP and community leaders met Teaneck youths in the parking lot behind the police station, trying to calm them. Ted Wells, a lawyer for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, told the teens that calling a second grand jury was ``an extraordinary step.'' ``If there was a scam they'd give no indictment, shut up and bite the bullet,'' Wells explained. Spath met with reporters at his attorneys office and said: ``I'd like to thank the Lord, Jesus Christ, for carrying me on his shoulders. We've been praying for the Pannell family all along and will continue to pray for the Pannell family.'' The attorney general said the decision that a new grand jury probe is warranted is ``fortified by the fact that the grand jury which heard the case was seriously divided.'' The attorney general maintained that errors in the autopsy by the Bergen County medical examiner ``led to an incorrect conclusion concerning the possible actions of Mr. Pannell at the time he was shot.'' A key question before the grand jury was whether Pannell had raised his hands in the air and pleaded with police not to shoot, as some witnesses said, or whether he twice stopped and turned in a threatening way toward the officers. ``The mistake permeated and distorted the investigation and the grand jury presentation. The medical examiner has admitted his error,'' Del Tufo said. Del Tufo said the decision that a new grand jury probe is warranted is ``fortified by the fact that the grand jury which heard the case was seriously divided.'' Spath's attorney, Robert Galantucci, accused Del Tufo and Gov. Jim Florio of calling for another grand jury to curry favor with voters. ``It sends a bad message to police officers throughout this state. It sends a bad message to them, but they can't change the truth,'' Galantucci said. ``They shouldn't be playing politics with the grand jury system.'' The 21-member grand jury was to determine if Spath was justified in firing his .38-caliber service revolver, or whether he should be indicted on charges of manslaughter or improperly using deadly force. The grand jurors have been meeting once or twice a week since late April. They reached a decision late Tuesday afternoon and Attorney General Robert Del Tufo scheduled a news conference to release the panel's findings. The shooting took place when Spath responded to a telephone report of a youth with a gun. The grand jurors heard accounts from more than two dozen witnesses, including police, bystanders, and Pannell's friends. Among those testifying before the panel was Officer Wayne Blanco, who frisked Pannell moments before he was shot by Spath, according to The Record of Hackensack. Blanco testified that he warned Spath that he felt a gun in Pannell's jacket, according to the newspaper. But teen-agers with Pannell said there was no frisking before the youngster ran. The man whose telephone call alerted police about a youth with a gun backed the youths' accounts when he testified before the grand jury, the newspaper said. Because of the sensitivity of the case, it was transferred from Bergen County to a state grand jury sitting in Trenton, and it was handled by a deputy attorney general. Spath was suspended with pay.

DOC.HEAD: Challenger Rebuffed in Plan for Shooting Match with Congressman
DOC.TEXT: Republican Paul Jurgens wanted to match his pistol-shooting skills against the man he wants to unseat, Democratic Rep. Richard Durbin. But Durbin shot down the idea. Durbin turned down the invitation Monday, citing the press of congressional business in the week before the August recess, and he took a pot shot at Jurgens. ``Mr. Jurgens shot himself in the foot when he issued this challenge without even checking the congressional schedule,'' he said. Jurgens, who also mounted an unsuccessful bid against Durbin in 1988, had challenged the four-term congressman Monday to a shooting match to be held Wednesday during a national tournament in the community of Barry. Jurgens, an oral surgeon from Decatur, said he proposed the match not to ``see who gets the most bull's-eyes'' but to draw attention to his differences with Durbin on gun control. Both candidates generally support private ownership of guns. But Durbin has voted for some restrictions on the sale of handguns. Jurgens opposes such measures. Jurgens faces an uphill battle against Durbin. In 1988, Durbin carried nearly 69 percent of the west-central Illinois district. Jurgens, however, might have an edge with a gun. He said he hunts with a rifle several times annually and goes target-shooting with a pistol two or three times a year. Durbin said he has gone hunting but doesn't do so regularly.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Find Fossil of Ancient Lizard
DOC.TEXT: The first known remains of a giant lizard that may have dined on baby dinosaurs have been found in Mongolia, a researcher says. The 80-million-year-old skull and forelimb were a highlight of the first expedition to that country by Western paleontologists in 65 years, said Michael Novacek. The lizard, which apparently resembled today's Komodo dragon, was perhaps 8 feet long and may have been a juvenile, Novacek said. It may have eaten young dinosaurs or dinosaur eggs, he said. Its fossil remains were found in the Gobi Desert, near a dinosaur nesting site that contained eight eggs, he said. The Komodo dragon is the largest living lizard, reaching a length of more than 11 feet in Southeast Asian jungles. Novacek said the animal has been known to attack and consume adult humans. Novacek is vice president and dean of science at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. He and museum colleagues Malcolm McKenna and Mark Norell recently undertook the month-long expedition at the invitation of the Mongolian Academy of Sciences. The American researchers and Mongolian counterparts also found 100-million-year-old remains of shrew-sized mammals, which may shed light on the spread of the ancestors of modern mammals, he said. They also found two unusually well-preserved skeletons of protoceratops, a beaked dinosaur that grew 4 to 5 feet long, and one of an armored dinosaur called an ankylosaur, which grew 15 to 20 feet long, Novacek said. The fossils were about 80 million years old. The wealth of discoveries from the relatively brief expedition gives hope that further work will turn up much more material, he said. The museum and the Mongolian academy signed an agreement for three more expeditions over the next three years, he said. Mongolia contains ``a tremendous potential for exploration that you don't see in North America,'' with areas the size of Wyoming that have not been explored, he said.

DOC.HEAD: BUKHARA, U.S.S.R.: not listening.''
DOC.TEXT: For Soviet authorities, the geophysical crises are bad enough. But, in a land of limited freedom, ecology is also a central rallying point for politics. Regional leaders blame Moscow for their condition, and growing new popular movements demand action on a long agenda of problems: nuclear contamination from atomic testing in Kazakhstan, for example, and poor living conditions and child labor among cotton pickers in Uzbekistan. Their point is always the same: Outsiders' decisions devastate local lands and peoples. In a region that produces 90 percent of the Soviet Union's cotton, the word ``ecology'' symbolizes the challenge of preventing a monoculture from sucking their land dry. At the Madaniyat farm here, huge red letters atop the headquarters building declare: ``We want communism.'' Inside, director Mohammed Akhmadov says he is flexible. ``We feel the pinch, and we're adjusting,'' Akhmadov said, fingering a tattered paper listing water flow rates. In a decade, cotton production has dropped 10 percent. New land is planted in fruit trees and vegetables needing less irrigation. He said farmers use fewer and safer chemicals, and he expected once-serious health problems to stop. New freedoms allowed farm managers to be more commercially and ecologically effective. ``Words are not important,'' he said. ``What matters is production and making people's lives as good as possible. Who cares what system?'' Many people are far less optimistic. The day that Akhmadov spoke, a local newspaper reported that Uzbek collectives used 50 percent more chemicals than was safe. ``They only say they are changing,'' said Kovaleyev. ``There are quotas, plans to meet, and farmers stick to old ways. If we don't stop these addictions, much of Central Asia will be as dead as the Aral Sea.'' If some Soviet authorities insist the sea will be saved, old-timers seem to side with the pessimists. ``The fresh air, the fat fish, we will never see that again,'' a desperate old captain said into Yatsenia's camera. ``Now, we can only scratch by, with no place to go and nothing to do.'' Then he lapsed into a mournful Uzbek song of his beautiful, dying Aral.
DOC.HEAD: NEXT _ Part IV: Nationalist Stirrings
Actress Jill Esmond, First Wife Of Laurence Olivier, Is Dead
DOC.TEXT: Jill Esmond, the film and stage actress and first of the late actor Laurence Olivier's three wives, has died at age 82, her family says. Ms. Esmond, who appeared in such Hollywood films as ``The White Cliffs of Dover'' and ``Random Harvest,'' died Saturday at her home at Wimbledon in southwest London. No cause of death was given. Ms. Esmond was the daughter of the actor-manager and dramatist Henry Vernon Esmond and his actress wife Eva Moore. She studied at London's Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and made her London stage debut in December 1922, playing the role of Nibs in ``Peter Pan.'' In 1925, she played Sorel Bliss in Noel Coward's comedy ``Hay Fever.'' She met Olivier in June 1928 when she was playing in John Drinkwater's ``Bird in Hand'' and he joined the cast. They went to the United States, where they both made their Broadway debut in 1929, she in `Bird in Hand'' and Olivier in ``Murder on the Second Floor.'' After returning to London, she made her movie debut in the 1930 version of ``The Chinese Bungalow'' with the young Anna Neagle. She married Olivier on July 25, 1930, and the following January they appeared together on Broadway with Coward and Gertrude Lawrence in Coward's ``Private Lives.'' In 1932, Ms. Esmond appeared in Alfred Hitchcock's movie ``The Skin Game'' and went on to appear many times on screen. At this stage in her career, she was a far bigger star than Olivier. Many audiences felt that with her strong, proud features and dark, heavy eyes she was best suited to stern roles rather than comedy. At the end of 1935, she became pregnant. But on the very night she and Olivier were celebrating this, he met actress Vivien Leigh, who was later to become his second wife. In 1937, Ms. Esmond played Olivia to Olivier's Sir Toby Belch in Shakespeare's ``Twelfth Night'' at London's Old Vic theater. But by then their marriage had broken down under the strain of her husband's infatuation with Ms. Leigh and they were divorced in 1940. Olivier married Ms. Leigh the following year. That marriage ended in divorce in 1961. Olivier, whose third wife was actress Joan Plowright, died on July 11 last year at age 82. He became Lord Olivier when he was made a peer in 1970. In 1942, Ms. Esmond returned to Broadway in ``The Morning Star'' and appeared in a series of Hollywood films. In 1946, she returned to Britain, where she resumed her movie career. She made her last London stage appearance in ``Party Manners'' in 1950, and her movie career ended in 1955. The son of Ms. Esmond and Olivier, Tarquin, was born in 1936. Ms. Esmond never remarried.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Fire Victims Ran Toward Fire, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Six volunteers who died while fighting a forest fire last month inexplicably ran uphill toward the fire while others escaped by running down the hill, investigators found. ``I think they panicked,'' said a recent report by Gila County Sheriff's Sgt. Dan Alexander, who investigated the June 26 deaths. ``They should have gone downhill.'' The six victims were part of a volunteer firefighting crew from the Arizona State Prison at Perryville. Five inmates and a supervisor were caught in the fire when it went out of control during a windstorm. The fire, which started from a lightning strike in the Dude Creek area northeast of Payson, burned 28,500 acres of forest land, along with dozens of cabins and summer homes and the historic Zane Grey's cabin. The fire was on National Forest Land about 70 miles northeast of Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Intellectuals Say Romanians Must Accept True Risks of Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Andrei Plesu, philosopher and art historian, was a dissident outcast under the old regime. Now he is culture minister, with a spacious office and the freedom to talk about democracy and revolution. Since Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was deposed and executed in December, intellectuals like Plesu have become the conscience of Romania, wooed by political parties and foreign governments. They are divided on whether to support President Ion Iliescu's government, but united in believing there will be no return to communism in this nation of 23 million, which suffered the most violence in the breakup of the Soviet bloc. ``Tomorrow, if the government says all private institutions will be abolished, there would be a second revolution,'' Plesu said in an interview. ``That's what makes me optimistic about the future despite all the problems, all the difficulties that we are going to face.'' Many intellectuals worry about a government that, although freely elected, has resorted to some of its disgraced predecessor's tactics. Although the Communist Party is dead, its structure remains, they say. In June, Iliescu called loyal miners to Bucharest to stop anti-government demonstrations. They beat protesters, hunted intellectuals and ransacked the offices of critical publications in the worst violence since the revolution. Nonetheless, Plesu and others are convinced things have changed as the government takes its first steps toward a market economy. They see a difficult road to real democracy, however. Intellectuals were leaders in the struggle against Ceausescu. It was poet Mircea Dinescu, now chairman of the influential Writers Union, who announced Ceausescu's ouster on the state radio. Then came the landslide election victory May 20 of Iliescu, a former alternate member of the Communist Party Politburo, and the National Salvation Front, a loose grouping of workers, peasants, intellectuals and technocrats that took power during the revolution. Many Romanians think the Front is controlled by Communists. Intellectuals who feel Iliescu's triumph bodes ill for freedom blame other intellectuals who did not speak out strongly for democracy after the revolution. It was Romania's first free election in 44 years and writer Stelian Tanase now wishes the Group for Social Dialogue, an organization of dissident intellectuals, had gone on television for a few minutes each week to explain the basics of democracy and multiparty politics. ``Who knows?'' he said. ``It's too late to have regrets.'' Tanase edits an anti-Communist weekly called 22, which the miners tried to shut. The political campaign was marred by allegations of fraud and intimidation that forced many of the more than 50 parties to curtail electioneering. Iliescu's victory was not questioned, but foreign observers said his 85 percent landslide showed pluralistic democracy had not taken root. Plesu, Tanase and Dinescu belong to the Group for Social Dialogue, which was formed after the revolution and generally opposes the National Salvation Front. Two months ago, the Tomorrow Society was established to support the Front. Its prominent members include literary critic Eugen Simion and authors Marin Sorescu and Augustin Bazura. Romulus Vulpescu, a writer and theater director elected as an independent legislator on the Front list, said, ``I believe the Front is sincere and that it will truly seek to recreate the 1923 constitution, which was one of the most liberal in the world.'' Alexandra Cornelescu, head of the English department at Bucharest University, is a staunch Front supporter but concedes violence ``harms intellectuals' faith in the government.'' Tanase said: ``It's a long way to democracy and to a free Romania. It's very difficult, after a half century, to change in so short a time people's mentality. The people voted for continuity. They were under stress, frightened by possible changes. ``Democracy. That means risk, liberty, the possibility to lose or to win. The people don't want to take this chance. ... They're all frightened to lose their jobs.'' In Plesu's view, communism has spawned a bureaucracy and mentality ``that likes privilege or power, and which has no knowledge of Marxist thinking.'' He said the bureaucrats ``are opportunists,'' and change will take years ``because there are millions of them.'' A press that consists of 1,200 publications, most of them anti-government, doesn't help foster democracy because ``they are incredibly primitive, attacking without a point of view,'' Plesu said. ``They transform the liberty to say truth into the liberty to say anything.'' Thomas Kleininger, a mathematician who is vice president of the Group for Social Dialogue, said Romania has no history of united opposition. ``We are beginning from zero,'' he said. ``We have no tradition in fighting against communism.'' Romania had no counterpart to dissident playwright Vaclav Havel, now president of Czechoslovakia, or magazine editor Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who became Poland's prime minister. In part, that is because Ceausescu cleverly manipulated the intellectuals, dividing them and silencing critical voices. Intellectuals always were divided and isolated from much of society. Most sided with the monarchy or fascist leaders before World War II, and with the Communist dictators afterward, reaping material rewards denied those who resisted. Plesu and others suffered internal exile and house arrest. The more careful kept their heads down at non-controversial jobs, deploring the situation in private but keeping silent in public. The revolution transformed the intellectual hierarchy. Overnight, dissidents became heroes and Ceausescu supporters became the outcasts. Most dissidents initially supported the Front. Plesu became culture minister in the interim government and writer Dan Petrescu his deputy, but Dinescu and poet Ana Blandiana refused government posts. Blandiana and Doina Cornea, a former professor of French who was Romania's best-known dissident, left the Front in late January, accusing it of perpetuating totalitarian practices and breaking a promise to stay out of the elections. Kleininger, the mathematician, predicted the greatest conflict in the next two years would be between reformers and the bureaucracy. He said the Communist infrastructure will die only if the new government renounces its monopoly on power and promotes a real multiparty system and private enterprise. ``The important thing for us is to bring to the consciousness of men that freedom and initiative under harder conditions are more important than this feeling of security,'' Kleininger said. ``Like lions in the zoo, we never knew what it meant to be free.''

DOC.HEAD: Searchers Find Debris Near Where United Jet Split Open
DOC.TEXT: Navy searchers on Monday found debris on the ocean floor near where a cargo door tore off a United Airlines jet last year, killing nine people, authorities said. Searchers have yet to confirm the debris is from United Airlines Flight 811, said Lt. Col. Bob Anderson, a Navy spokesman. One object, wedged in the ocean floor, is believed to be a large piece of metal, which could be the 10-by-10-foot cargo door, Anderson said. The 224-foot Navy tug USS Narrangansett, using a small, remote-controlled submarine to search the ocean floor three miles down, recorded the location of the find 90 miles south-southeast. The tug was to return to Honolulu on Tuesday, Anderson said. The Orion submarine's sonar located the debris, but searchers were unable to obtain a picture of the find with the sub's video camera, Anderson said. The Navy will report the find to the National Transportation Safety Board, which will decide whether to try to recover the debris, Anderson said. The Boeing 747 carried 355 passengers when it left Honolulu International Airport for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989. Shortly after takeoff, a cargo door opened at 22,000 feet, tearing away a section of fuselage. Nine people were swept to their deaths and five others suffered serious injuries. The crew managed to return and land in Honolulu. The NTSB's inquiry determined that a faulty design of the door's locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit panel light to falsely indicate the door was locked. The NTSB blamed United, Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to correct problems with the door. The National Transportation safety Board has completed its inquiry into the accident, but has requested the search for the door with hopes its inspection will lead to better plane safety.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Prime Minister Reports Trinidad Accord Reached
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with further elaboration of how announcement made. Picks up 6th pvs, `The announcement ...' ^LaserPhotos POS4,5
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson and the chief negotiator for his Moslem extremist captors said Monday that they had reached agreement to end a 4-day-old hostage siege. Robinson, other Cabinet ministers and lawmakers were among 41 hostages reported held by the black Moslems, who stormed the Parliament building and the government television station on Friday in a coup attempt. Robinson suffered gunshot wounds in both feet. Word of the accord came in telephone call to Trinidad journalist Tony Fraser from inside Parliament and was not immediately announced to the nation. Selwyn Richardson, the justice and national security minister, said in the call that the agreement called for Robinson's immediate resignation, with elections to be held within 90 days. Richardson said the government granted amnesty to rebel leader Abu Bakr and his followers in the revolt, which has left at least nine people dead and led to looting on this island-nation of 1.3 million residents. The official said, however, that the agreement was contingent ``upon the safe return of all members of Parliament'' now held hostage. It was unclear when the hostage release might occur. The announcement came hours after government and military spokesmen said negotiations with the radical Moslem group had collapsed. Earlier Monday, security forces exchanged gunfire with the rebels at both the parliament building and the state-run television station, the two buildings were hostages were being held. Speaking from inside Parliament late Monday, Robinson said the agreement was reached after ``very difficult bargaining.'' The prime minister said he instructed Col. Joe Theodore, head of the Trinidad and Tobago Defense Force, to ``make necessary arrangements for the evacuation (of hostages and rebels) as soon as possible.'' Chief rebel negotiator Bilal Abdullah, speaking next on the telephone, said: ``I wish to totally corroborate what Prime Minister Robinson has just said.'' The rebels claim Robinson's government is corrupt and responsible for widespread poverty in this once oil-rich country. They claimed on Saturday to have wired Robinson with explosives and threatened to blow him up if a rescue attempt was made. Government spokesman Gregory Shaw said Robinson was shot in both feet and Richardson was shot in one leg when rebels stormed Parliament. Army spokesman Maj. Dave Williams reported that the Moslems were armed with AK-47 assault rifles, pistols and grenades. In the first official casualty count, Williams said at least nine people had died in the fighting since Friday. He said Anglican negotiator Knolly Clarke told him additional bodies were inside the parliament building, but it was not known how many. The two sides nearly reached agreement earlier Monday but a government official said negotiations stalled over conditions for releasing the hostages, who include eight Cabinet ministers. Shaw said 41 hostages were being held and about 100 rebels were involved in the siege. He said 16 hostages, including the government ministers, were being held in the parliament building. The remaining 25 hostages are all employees of the government TV station, he said. Among the dead were six rebels, two police officers and one civilian, Williams said. Six rebels were known to be wounded. Williams said three soldiers were wounded, none seriously. The State Department said Monday in Washington there are no plans for U.S. military intervention in Trinidad. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher refused comment on reports of U.S. military maneuvers in the area, but suggested a military solution was ruled out. Boucher said none of the estimated 6,000 Americans living in Trinidad and neighboring Tobago were reported hurt. He criticized Libya's involvement, saying the radical North African Arab nation trained Trinidadian insurgents. But he said no apparent direct link existed between Libya and the hostage-taking in Trinidad. Shaw and Williams called a news conference hours after a gun battle between security forces and rebels at the state-run Trinidad and Tobago Television complex. Williams said rebels fired on troops in an apparent attempt to escape the TV complex. ``We were fired upon; we fired back,'' he said. ``We won the firefight. They withdrew.'' Three buildings in the area were set ablaze, witnesses said. Sporadic gunfire also broke out at the parliament building, about a mile away, where the ministers were held. The army said no attempt was made to storm either building. Army chief Col. Ralph Brown said he did not think the hostages suffered casualties. Jamaica said Monday it sent 120 soldiers to neighboring Barbados to assist Trinidad if needed. Bakr, a former policeman who converted to Islam in 1980, founded Jamaat al-Muslimeen, which means the Moslem Group in Arabic, in 1984. The group is believed to number 250 to 300. Shaw said a 6 p.m. to noon curfew would remain in effect islandwide despite a ``significant diminishing'' in looting, which caused an estimated $50 million damage to downtown stores. In a statement read on state radio, U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Lucy Hall urged all American tourists in Trinidad to obey the curfew. Caribbean leaders gathering in Kingston, Jamaica, for a conference added regional security to their agenda because of Trinidad and Tobago. Heads of state and other government leaders from the 13 member nations will open the Caribbean Economic Community conference on Tuesday. Robinson easily won the 1986 parliamentary elections. Under the constitution, the next elections don't have to be held until 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: James Brown's wife was turned down as his sponsor for live-at-home work release because she, too, is a convicted felon. ``This is just one more thing to give us aggravation,'' Adrienne Brown said. ``The entire system is unfair. They're going to ride us into the ground.'' The soul singer's application for so-called extended work release was denied last week by the state Corrections Department because of Mrs. Brown's criminal record, department spokesman Francis Archibald said Monday. Mrs. Brown was convicted of possession of PCP in 1989 and was placed on five years' probation and fined $5,000. Brown was released from prison in April after 15 months of a six-year sentence for aggravated assault and avoiding police in a two-state auto chase in 1988. He lives at a work release center in Aiken. Mrs. Brown said her husband probably will remain there until he is eligible for parole in December 1991.

William Shatner is a captain on TV but a colonel in Kentucky. Shatner, Capt. James Kirk of ``Star Trek'' fame, has a 76-acre horse farm near here and has been designated an honorary Kentucky colonel. He and his wife, Marcy, live in Los Angeles but spend a lot of time at their Kentucky spread. ``I've acquired a Kentucky accent and I'm a Kentucky colonel. So I don't know what other qualifications you'd need, other than being born here,'' Shatner said in Monday's The Courier-Journal of Louisville.

The Muscular Dystrophy Association's poster child pulled the ol' two-fingers-behind-the-head trick during a photo session with Mayor David Dinkins and entertainer Ben Vereen. Six-year-old Ashley Antolak did her mischief in front TV cameras and newspaper photographers Monday. ``She's giving you ears,'' Dinkins joked to Vereen. Ashley, from Athens, Tenn., is the association's 1990 national poster child. Vereen will be a host of the Jerry Lewis MDA telethon over Labor Day weekend.

Roseanne Barr took another stab at the national anthem. This time, she inflicted less damage. During taping Monday of Sally Jessy Raphael's syndicated talk show, Barr and her husband, Tom Arnold, sang with Raphael and about 300 people in the studio audience. The star of ABC's ``Roseanne'' was booed Wednesday before a crowd of about 30,000 baseball fans when she screeched the national anthem at a San Diego Padres game. She topped off the performance by grabbing her crotch and spitting. ``I've apologized over and over about fifty times,'' Barr said. Hand over her heart, Barr laughed and sang softly during the taping. The show airs Wednesday.

Marilyn Quayle is following her doctor's advice and curtailing her schedule for up to six weeks after a hysterectomy, a spokeswoman says. The wife of Vice President Dan Quayle has received boxes of get-well messages and cards since the surgery last week. Mrs. Quayle celebrated her 41st birthday Sunday with her family. She returned home Wednesday, four days after the operation. Pap smears indicated Mrs. Quayle had a cell abnormality that could develop into cervical cancer.

Dudley Moore and Brogan Lane are splitting up after 2{ years of marriage. A divorce petition filed Thursday cited irreconcilable differences. The couple have been separated since July 15. It was the third marriage for Moore, 55, and the second for Miss Lane, 34. Moore chased Bo Derek in ``10'' and starred as a lovable lush in ``Arthur.'' Lane is a model and aspiring actress.

Rock 'n' roller Chuck Berry was released on $20,000 bail after surrendering on charges of marijuana possession and child abuse. The sheriff's office said Berry, who had been on tour in Europe, surrendered Monday. Prosecutor William Hannah said Berry was accused of making nude films of children. The 63-year-old duck-walking guitarist is known for such rock standards as ``Johnny B. Goode'' and ``Roll Over Beethoven.''

Pearl Bailey will stay in town for about a week to continue physical therapy after receiving an artificial knee, a hospital says. The 72-year-old singer left Pennsylvania Hospital Monday after replacement of her arthritic left knee with a metal and plastic joint July 11. She should be able to resume daily activities in six weeks, the hospital said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Organic Label Helps Give Farm Bill Environmental Flavor
DOC.TEXT: This year's farm bill may take the worry out of shopping for organic cucumbers. Other provisions apparently headed for adoption in Congress would stop exports of pesticides banned domestically, expand protection of wetlands and erodible fields and encourage farmers to cut their use of chemicals that can find their way into the water supply. The legislation, which sets agricultural policy for the next five years, has at its heart a set of support programs for crops and livestock. But this year's bill focused as never before on measures intended to protect the Earth and its waters, drafted under the watchful eye of lobbyists for environmental groups, farmers and the chemical industry. ``It is an environmentally conscious farm bill,'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., the Agriculture Committee chairman, said after the Senate passed its version, 70-21, last Friday.``It is one that allows us to do the things Americans want.'' The House is expected to finish work on its version this week. The effort to resolve differences between the House and Senate bills in conference committee, however, is going to have to wait for the outcome of budget negotiations. Those talks are likely to force a cut in planned spending on farm support programs in order to bring down the overall price tag, estimated at $54 billion over five years for the Senate measure. The Senate bill provides for a new official Agriculture Department ``organically produced'' label for meats, fruits and vegetables raised without synthetic chemicals. It is likely to be added to the House measure. Environmental activists who backed the provision, to be known as the Organic Foods Production Act, said confusion over what is or isn't organically grown has discouraged consumers and grocers alike, slowing a movement to cut chemical use in farming. ``People have been selling products they said were more healthful because they didn't use certain pesticides or fertilizers,'' said Janet Hathaway, a senior project attorney who follows the issue for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. But different rules on various chemicals apply in different states, with no rules in some states and very little enforcement in others, she said. Under the bill, a 13-member National Organic Standards Board would help draw up a list of substances that will be approved or barred for anyone who wants to call his operation an organic farm. States still could run their own organic certification programs, as some already do. Food still could be called ``organic'' on the label so long as at least half of its ingredients are organically produced, but the official USDA stamp would only go to 100 percent organic products. The Senate also agreed to prohibit exports of pesticides considered too dangerous for use in American farming. In what is known as a ``circle of poison,'' such pesticides sometimes have been found to return to the United States as residue on imported foods. The Senate Agriculture Committee said it also wanted to protect American farmers from unfair competition from foreign producers using U.S.-made pesticides that can't be used here. Other sections of the bill would authorize $250 million in research on how farmers could use fewer chemicals, direct the Agriculture Department to study how its grading standards offer incentives for excessive pesticide use and require, for the first time, that farmers keep records of pesticides they use. Still unresolved is a dispute over access to the pesticide records. The Senate bill would allow only certain government agencies to see them, but environmentalists hope the House will vote to allow extensive public access to the information. Both the Senate and House bills would expand programs to protect fragile wetlands and fields susceptible to erosion from farmers eager to expand their acreage. The bills also would enact new programs to preserve privately owned forests.

DOC.HEAD: Ballet Seeks Macho Men, Gets Couch Potatoes
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: In this city of bureaucrats, lawyers and computer nerds, how many good, old-fashioned macho men are left? You guessed it, folks. When the Kennedy Center announced auditions for ``macho he-men'' to perform as extras in the Australian Ballet's production of ``Spartacus'' this week, only 36 showed up. Worse, nearly half of them were politely ushered to the door as impostors. The audition fliers posted on bulletin boards at congressional offices, gyms and dance studios around town included a photograph of exactly the kind of guy the Kennedy Center was looking for _ a lean and mean Roman gladiator clad in a flimsy loin cloth, his rippling muscles straining to burst his leather chest straps. What shuffled into the rehearsal hall of the Kennedy Center Opera House on Monday evening fell roughly into two categories: health spa muscleman and your standard couch potato. They were short and tall, potbellied and trim, balding and longhaired, dressed in jeans, T-shirts and shorts. One wore a striped shirt and tie. Few seemed likely candidates for Hungarian choreographer Laszlo Seregi's balletic tale of a slave revolt in ancient Rome. One who didn't make the cut was Eugene Woodruff, 57, of suburban Annandale, Va., a supervisor at the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office who took his disappointment good-naturedly. Woodruff has been a supernumerary, or extra, with the Washington Opera a few times, mostly just standing around on stage, but never in a ballet. ``I'm not a dancer at all,'' he said with a smile. ``I don't take part in any strenuous athletics. For exercise, the only thing I do is rifle shooting. I also mow the lawn and saw some firewood.'' The lure for Woodruff couldn't be the money. The 19 extras selected to play Roman soldiers and slaves in ``Spartacus'' will receive $28 for four rehearsals and $40 for four performances starting Friday. The extras in opera productions are paid considerably less, but the pay for ``Spartacus'' is higher because there is ``lots of marching and escaping and running around on stage,'' said Steve Quinn, the Kennedy Center's liaison with the Australian Ballet. Colin Peasley, the touring ballet company's ballet master, chose 19 of the more athletic-looking candidates and began an intensive drill to whip them into shape as Roman soldiers and slaves. ``Left, right, left, right,'' he barked as the extras marched across the floor to piano music from Aram Khachaturian's score. Grabbing a wooden spear, Peasley said, ``These are held like you hold a thermometer, under your arm like this.'' He taught the neophyte guards how to sway without getting dizzy, and how to crouch without ``looking like you're sitting on the toilet.'' He held a Roman warrior's shield to his chest. ``You must be careful how you hold a shield or they begin to look like a handbag,'' he said. Woodruff enjoyed his past moments of glory in the operatic limelight, no matter how obscure, but he had no pretensions. ``I have no illusions about being a great actor,'' he said. ``I do it for the fun of it. It's a chance to do theater that's big-time, without having any real professional skills.''

DOC.HEAD: On 25th Anniversary, Panel Says Health Care Insurance Net Has Many Holes
DOC.TEXT: No one disagrees that Medicare and Medicaid have helped millions of Americans over the past quarter century, but critics say these two health care safety nets have developed too many large holes. ``When these programs were enacted, many persons expected that Medicare and Medicaid would ensure full coverage of all health care services for the elderly, disabled and poor,'' said Rep. Edward Roybal, D-Calif. Though ``much has been accomplished ... there remain many gaps and weaknesses in the programs,'' Roybal, chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging, said in a report released at a hearing of the panel on Monday. With health care costs rising twice as fast as inflation, the price of private medical insurance is getting beyond the reach of many, employers are trimming coverage and states are reducing their Medicaid rolls to cut costs. Though taxpayers spend more than $174 billion a year on the programs, an estimated 37 million Americans have no health insurance, and Medicaid covers only 42 percent of those living in poverty. And, Roybal said, 200 million people are underinsured for catastrophic or long-term illness. The 25th anniversary of Medicare and Medicaid, which were signed into law June 30, 1965, provided an opportunity for those who want to change the nation's health care system to highlight problems in the government insurance programs. But before the hard hitting began, Roybal and other members of the committee marked the anniversary with a large sheet cake, iced with white frosting and trimmed in red, white and blue. The celebratory mood turned serious as Roybal opened the hearing, outlining the major failings of the two programs. ``A national (health insurance) program is a must for this country,'' said Roybal, who has introduced a bill that would build Medicare into a federally based, nationwide program covering health and long-term care. The bipartisan Pepper Commission _ 12 members of Congress and three White House appointees _ has proposed building on the existing employer-provided insurance system and improving and expanding the Medicaid program. Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., chairman of the Pepper Commission, said the country has six to eight years to make needed reforms in the health care system. If nothing is done, ``people are going to rise up'' in protest, he said. Medicaid, a federal-state program that serves more than 26 million poor Americans, is in worse shape than Medicare, Rockefeller said. Eligibility differs from state to state, and reimbursement rates are so low in some places that some physicians refuse to treat Medicaid patients, he said. ``It is time to take the lessons we have learned over these 25 years and put them to use in finally building a universal health system,'' he said. Gail Wilensky, head of the Health Care Financing Administration, which handles Medicare and Medicaid, said any changes in the nation's health care system should build on the current system and should not strain the U.S. economy. ``If we decide to fill insurance gaps, we must do so in a way that does not lead to overwhelming financial gaps in the future. We must make sure that we do not create incentives that contribute to unnecessary utilization and overspending,'' she said. The Bush administration is conducting a review of the quality, accessibility and cost of the nation's health care system. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, who is leading the review, has not said what changes he will recommend, but he has rejected national health insurance as a solution.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Doesn't Foresee Riots If He's Convicted
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Should stand; trial in recess
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry says he doesn't foresee any rioting in the streets of Washington if he is convicted in his cocaine and perjury trial. ``We (blacks) have grown as a people in the last 20 years, and we are not going to destroy what we have brought back,'' Barry told reporters Monday after the prosecution and defense wound up their presentations of evidence. ``Those who talk about that don't represent me,'' said Barry. Barry said he didn't believe rioting would really happen. He scoffed at some local press reports on the possibility of rioting like that which happened in the nation's capital when civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968. ``Frankly, I really don't see (rioting) happening no matter what happens,'' Barry said. ``I want to say I have heard no serious consideration of anything like that.'' Testimony on the 14 criminal charges against the mayor lasted six weeks. The two sides called 44 witnesses. Barry's trial is expected to go to the jury Thursday, following closing arguments that are likely to last all of Wednesday, said presiding U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. Jackson said he is giving each side 2{ hours for making final arguments to the jury. Instructions to the jury probably will be given Thursday morning. Jackson said he is leaning toward dismissing the six alternate jurors following jury instructions. The six have been sequestered, along with the 12 jurors in the case, since the jury was seated in the case in mid-June. The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor charge of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his drug use before his arrest in an FBI sting operation last January.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Films to Highlight 1990 Festival
DOC.TEXT: Three American films form a ``small but robust'' core at the heart of this year's 47th Venice Film Festival, festival director Guglielmo Biraghi says. The festival _ Italy's most important annual film event _ features 21 films from 19 countries in the competition for the Golden Lion Award. The U.S. entries include Spike Lee's ``Mo' Better Blues,'' Martin Scorsese's ``Goodfellas,'' and James Ivory's ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge.'' The festival, which runs from Sept. 4 to Sept. 15, will be judged by an international panel headed by author Gore Vidal. Three other U.S. films will be shown outside of competition, including Warren Beatty's ``Dick Tracy.'' Other highlights of the festival include a retrospective of Soviet cinema from 1929 to 1935, a series of films in homage to cinema greats and several documentaries.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Gabor Says Jail Not All That Bad
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor says she slept on a horse blanket and the food was terrible, but her three days in jail for slapping a Beverly Hills police officer were otherwise fairly pleasant. ``I was very happily surprised,'' she said after her release Monday. ``Everybody was warm and nice and sweet. It was OK. The Beverly Hills police should come and take lessons from this police.'' There was that moment of terror. ``At first I was petrified. They even took my makeup away,'' she said. She scolded reporters for a weekend story that her husband, Frederick Von Anhalt, delivered silk sheets to the jail. ``I didn't have silk sheets. I don't even have silk sheets at home. I was on a horse blanket,'' she said. She declared the food ``terrible.'' Miss Gabor, 72, got 72 hours in jail for smacking a policeman during a traffic stop last year. A judge ordered the sometime actress and former Hungarian beauty queen to jail for failing to fulfill her original sentence, 120 hours of community service. Miss Gabor paid $85 a day to do her time at the El Segundo jail rather than have the county pick accommodations for her. She has also been ordered to pay nearly $13,000 in fines and restitution.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Sparks Debate Over Coroners' Research
DOC.TEXT: A coroner who dropped a dead infant head-first onto the floor as part of his research into skull fractures is being sued by the child's parents for $2 million in a case that has divided doctors over such practices. Some coroners say such research has been carried out in morgues for years. Others say the permission of the next of kin should be required. In the trial, which began last month, District Judge Hugh Brunson must decide whether state law allows coroners to conduct experiments not needed to determine the cause of death and whether approval from relatives is needed. No state court has previously ruled on the issue. But state Assistant Attorney General Chuck Yeager said in an opinion last year that the law does not authorize such experiments without the permission of the next of kin. Dr. Charles Odom, a deputy coroner for Lafayette Parish in southern Louisiana, was fired by his boss, Coroner Robert P. Thompson, who found out about the experiment on 4-month-old Christina Arnaud and informed the parents. Dwayne and Ellen Arnaud are seeking damages for emotional suffering. The trial, which is being held in Lafayette, 95 miles west of New Orleans, is in recess but resumes in August. The baby died of sudden infant death syndrome in 1986, and an autopsy was performed by Odom the same day. Odom held the baby by the heels and dropped it onto a concrete floor. Findings from the experiment were later used in a manslaughter trial in Hawaii in which charges against a father accused of killing his child were dismissed. Odom, now an assistant medical examiner in Dallas, testified in the Hawaii trial that he believed the experiments on the infant and on another baby's corpse proved that children could die from skull fractures suffered during accidental falls from the arms of an adult. Testifying at the Lafayette trial, Odom said he regarded the experiment as proper and said such research is not uncommon. While the primary purpose of an autopsy is to determine the cause and manner of death, there is a secondary purpose _ ``to gain medical knowledge and use that medical knowledge in the service of the living,'' Odom said. Some doctors defended the practice. ``I think it's a good thing and a needed thing,'' said Dr. Terry Welke, Calcasieu Parish coroner. ``There's a lot of knowledge brought about by experimentation that is not allowed on the living. It's a good practice to allow it here.'' Odom and other medical examiners say that skin, bone, eyes, heart valves and kidneys are often removed from bodies and used elsewhere, with and without the knowledge of the family. Dr. Monroe Samuels, a medical examiner in Orleans Parish, said requests to experiment on corpses during autopsies are submitted regularly by medical schools and research centers in New Orleans. ``We would only do it if it did not deface or deform the body,'' he said. ``We do have requests for some surgical techniques, but those are only done with permission of the next of kin. We're not talking about ghoulish things like leaning on an arm to see how far it will go before it breaks or shooting a gun at it.'' Welke said that in his office, doctors have come in to practice techniques on cadavers before moving on to live patients. ``It's done basically because physicians are trying to enhance their knowledge,'' he said. ``If the practice is cut off, it would be a big problem.'' But Dr. Sylvan J. Manuel, St. Landry Parish coroner and president of the Louisiana Coroners Association, was one of a number of coroners who said they knew of no experimentation unrelated to the autopsy being done in Louisiana. ``I don't think any of us are doing it, or should do it,'' Manuel said. ``I don't think anything should be done without the permission of the family. If you're going to take something off the body _ a fingernail even _ you should have permission of the family.'' Jefferson Parish Coroner Robert Treuting testified that experiments such as the one conducted by Odom help doctors and researchers perfect operating techniques and find cures for illness. Treuting said orthopedists have practiced dissecting joints on cadavers awaiting autopsies, and researchers took some parts from a body to study hardening of the arteries. Pathologists have the right to do anything they want with the body, including keeping it, if there is a legitimate research reason, Treuting testified. But he said it would be callous for the survivors to be told of experiments because it would compound their anguish.

DOC.HEAD: Chiquita Accepts President's Proposal To End Banana Strike
DOC.TEXT: Chiquita Brands International says it has accepted a proposal by President Rafael Leonardo Callejas for a 25.4 percent wage hike to end a ruinous month-old strike by its 10,000 banana workers. There was no immediate reaction from the union to the Cincinnati-based company's announcement Monday that it would raise the basic wage by $62.50 to $308.50 a month. The union had ordered the walkout June 25 to back demands for a a 54.57 percent wage increase. Chiquita, which handles nearly two-thirds of Honduras' banana exports, at first refused to negotiate then drew the line at 14.33 percent. In an address to the nation on Sunday night, Callejas called the strike ruinous for Honduras' impoverished economy and threatened to take unspecified legal action if Chiquita and the union did not accept his proposal for a 25.4 percent increase. The strike has been marked by sporadic violence. Police said the latest incident occurred Monday night outside Chiquita's main office at La Lima, 200 miles north of Tegucigalpa, when two workers were wounded in a shootout. A police report on the incident gave no details. Strikers armed with sticks and stones have also fought during the past week with about 400 workers who wanted to return to work. Bananas is Honduras' principal export, earning the country about $400 million annually. Chiquita has been operating in Honduras since 1912 and currently exports 50 million cases of bananas a year. The rest is handled by Castle and Cook of San Francisco. Chiquita's announcement said the company incurred a loss of $14.45 million in production during the strike.

DOC.HEAD: Small-Town Jury Pool a Problem in Sensational Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Marc in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: When a big trial happens in a small town, finding an impartial jury can get complicated. It seems that everyone, from potential witnesses to prospective jurors, knows everyone else in the trial of Shirley Kinge, who faces charges connected to the slaying last year of a couple and their two children. Jury selection began last week, when 290 of 300 prospective jurors questioned were dismissed. One woman had taught nearly a dozen potential witnesses in her seventh-grade home economics class. One man's cousin lived across the street from Mrs. Kinge. Another woman said her son's best friend was dating the defense attorney's daughter. All but one prospective juror questioned said they had read and heard news reports about the slayings of Warren Harris, 39, his wife, Dolores, 41, and their children, 11-year-old Marc and 15-year-old Shelby. A new pool of 100 potential jurors was called to court Monday. By then, lawyers had agreed on 10 jurors for the panel, which will ultimately have 12 jurors and two to four alternates. Jury selection continues this week. The trial in Ithaca is expected to last at least until September, with more than 300 possible witnesses. The length of the trial, the number of witnesses and the notoriety of the case are making jury selection ``as difficult as it could be,'' said Judge William Barrett. The slain couple and their children were each bound and shot in the head the night of Dec. 22 at their home in Dryden, near Ithaca in this county of 88,000 people. The bodies were doused with gasoline and set on fire. Mrs. Kinge's son, Michael, was a suspect but was killed in a shootout in February when police went to his home to arrest him. Mrs. Kinge, 55, was indicted on charges of arson, burglary, possession of stolen property and other offenses. She is accused of helping her son set the fires at the Harris house and using credit cards stolen from the family. One prospective juror's mail carrier may be a witness. Another worked for the same company as Harris. One volunteered in the election campaign of the district attorney, and another was the football coach for the sons of Mrs. Kinge's lawyer, William Sullivan. Aiden Payne, a home economics teacher in Dryden, had taught so many of the town's firefighters and police officers that Barrett asked, ``Is there anyone in Dryden you don't know?'' Sullivan said he was troubled by the extent to which potential jurors had followed the case and expressed opinions about it. District Attorney George Dentes would not comment on the jury headaches, but the judge said knowing about the case does not mean a person cannot be a fair juror. ``It isn't the fact that you've heard of it, it's your state of mind,'' he said. ``This trial is not about what's been written in the newspapers, it's about what's presented in court.'' A number of prospective jurors said they could not set aside their opinions about the case, but Barrett said they are in the minority. ``I have great confidence in our juries in Ithaca,'' he said. ``We'll find a fair and impartial jury. We're doing it carefully and painstakingly, but we'll get there.''

DOC.HEAD: AMA Cancels Computer Service for Lack of Interest
DOC.TEXT: After losing $4.2 million last year on an electronic information network for doctors, the American Medical Association is conceding that physicians aren't ready to be computer jockeys. The association plans to discontinue AMA-Net, its national medical information database, on Aug. 10 for lack of interest. ``It's a very regretful decision,'' James F. Rappel, AMA vice president for information resources, said Monday. ``We really have a product we don't have to apologize for at all.'' But he said a lack of computer literacy and personal computers and doctors' failure so far to incorporate the idea into their practices were to blame. Subscriptions to AMA-Net were touted as a way for doctors to keep up with latest on everything from drugs and diseases to stock prices and airline operations. The AMA has lost about $4.2 million on AMA-Net since it began offering it to its 280,000-plus members in early 1989, Rappel said. At the time, it was estimated the system would break even if 40,000 subscribers spent $15 to $20 per month using it. ``Although we got the number of subscribers we thought we would need, only 13,000 of them were using the service,'' said Rappel. More than two-thirds of the subscribers never even logged on to use the system, he said. ``The use of such a thing in a physician's daily practice _ it's not there yet,'' Rappel said. ``It will be. It's very close.''

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Oldest Veteran Dies at 105
DOC.TEXT: George E. Echols, who fought in France during World War I and was the nation's oldest known war veteran, is dead at the age of 105, the Department of Veterans Affairs says. The department said Echols died last Thursday at the VA Medical Center here after a brief illness. Echols' passing means that the oldest known American war veteran is now Nathan E. Cook, 104, who is also the only known living veteran of the Spanish-American War era, the VA said. Cook now lives at the Carl Hayden VA Nursing Home in Phoenix, Ariz. In addition to his Spanish-American War service, Cook served with the Navy during the Boxer Rebellion in China, the Philippine Insurrection, clashes on the U.S.-Mexican border and in World War I and World War II. Echols who was born Nov. 2, 1884 in Athens, Ga., served with the Army from June 16, 1914 to October 10, 1919. After receiving an honorable discharge, he re-enlisted and served an additional year. He was a graduate of Timothy High School in Athens and also attended the Jericho Baptist Institute there. According to the VA, Echols worked for a railroad after his Army service and was also employed by the Mexican Embassy here. Echols is survived by a stepdaughter, Annie Kent of Silver Spring, Md. A resident at the nursing home care unit since 1988, Echols once said that his personal secret to long life was ``trust and belief in God.''

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush, Regulators Agree on Some Points of S&L Case
With PM-Deposit Insurance Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil agrees with regulators on a host of facts in his savings and loan case while continuing to deny he had any conflict of interest. The younger Bush was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, which failed in December 1988 at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. In a document released Monday by the Office of Thrift Supervision, Bush and the regulators said they agreed on 110 points ranging from Bush's date of birth (Jan. 22, 1955) to complex loans and business transactions. The 34-page document, called a joint stipulation of uncontested facts, consists of information previously made public, according to the OTS and Bush's attorney, James Nesland. However, it pulls together details about Bush's oil exploration company and its relationship with Silverado borrowers Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters, as well as votes that Bush made as a director approving loans to the two men. OTS officials have accused Bush of conflict of interest in failing to disclose his business relationships with Good and Walters to the Silverado board. The joint stipulation, requested in late May by Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson, is part of the proceeding in the Bush case. Bush has been ordered to appear at a public hearing Sept. 25 in Denver before Davidson, who will then make a recommendation to OTS Director Timothy Ryan. In addition to the OTS case, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering filing a negligence lawsuit against Bush and other Silverado directors. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman told the House Banking Committee on Monday that the agency will decide ``in the reasonably near future'' whether to sue Bush and other directors of the collapsed thrift. The document released Monday traced the investments made by Good and Walters in Bush's company, JNB Exploration Co., which drilled a succession of dry holes in Wyoming and failed to become profitable. For an investment of $100, Bush acquired 23.4 percent of the business in January 1983. His active partners, geologists James B. Judd and Evans G. Nash Jr., held 23.4 percent and 15.6 percent, respectively, for investments of $100 and $66. The name JNB came from the initials of Judd, Nash and Bush. The ``silent'' partners were Walters, who invested $300,000 for a 12.5 percent stake, and Good, who made an initial investment of $10,000 for 25 percent. Good also guaranteed lines of credit for hundreds of thousands of dollars to JNB from Cherry Creek National Bank, which was controlled by Walters. In addition, Good personally lent Bush $100,000 so that Good could trade in a commodities pool on Bush's behalf. Bush was allowed to keep any profits that might be earned but was not required to repay the loan if the pool wasn't profitable. The venture was unprofitable and Bush never repaid the loan. In January 1985, Nash dropped out of JNB and Judd sold part of his interest to Bush. Good bought part of Nash's interest, raising his share to 33.7 percent. Walters withdrew from the partnership in August 1986. By late 1987, Good's share had jumped to 79 percent, while Judd had 7.4 percent and Bush held 12.5 percent. Bush was named managing partner, with authority for the management and operations of the business. Bush withdrew from JNB in May 1989. The document noted that Bush voted as a director to approve some loans by Silverado to Good and Walters but did not vote on others.

DOC.HEAD: Shanghai Enacts Stricter Birth Control Regulations
DOC.TEXT: Shanghai, China's largest city with a population of more than 12 million, will start fining couples who have a second child an amount equal to three times their annual income, an official newspaper reported. In most regions of China, current fines are 10 percent of income. Stricter birth control regulations to take effect Aug. 1 will end ``second-child'' privileges for farmers living in Shanghai's outskirts, for oil workers and for brothers and children of revolutionary martyrs, said the Xinmin (New People's) Daily report, which was seen in Beijing today. Couples in second marriages will be allowed to have a second child only if they already have one child between them, the paper said. The report said that couples who have an illegal second child will be fined three times the total of their average annual income for the two years before the birth. Couples who have a third or more children without permission will be fined four to six times their annual income, it said. Payment of the fines could be extended for only six years, and at least 25 percent must be paid within the first year, the report said. In most regions of China, current fines are 10 percent of income for up to 14 years after the birth of a second child. The average wage in Shanghai last year was 2,500 yuan ($530), according to the Municipal Statistics Bureau. China adopted a one-child per couple policy in 1980. The rule is widely observed in crowded cities, where women usually have jobs, but is widely ignored in rural areas where families are willing to pay fines in order to have more children to help on their farms. Shanghai already has China's lowest population growth rate _ 6.4 per 1,000. The national average is 14.2. The city says the stricter regulations are needed because current birth rates are exceeding previously set targets. The government has acknowledged that its target of limiting population _ currently estimated at 1.1 billion _ to 1.2 billion in the year 2000 is not attainable. Estimates for the number of Chinese at the turn of the century have climbed to 1.3 billion, about 20 percent of the total world population.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Cut Military Construction Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House, in a step certain to rile the White House, has approved an $8.3 billion military construction bill that slashes President Bush's request for overseas projects, including a new base in Italy. By a 312-82 vote late Monday, the House adopted the legislation that cuts $815 million from the president's proposal for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and $183 million from the amount Congress approved last year for fiscal 1990. Among the other expected issues of contention is deferral of $254 million for placing MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars and a cut of $37 million from the $92 million Bush sought for facilities for the B-2 bomber at Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri. While reducing funds for overseas projects, the bill leaves domestic work largely intact, and, in some cases, increases spending for projects in the home states of members of the House Appropriations subcommittee on military construction. The administration said it opposed the legislation, citing a $170 million reduction in money for the NATO Infrastructure Fund and a $226 million increase for the National Guard and Reserve. The action on a new facility in Italy also is likely to draw the administration's ire. The House banned the use through Sept. 30, 1991, of any U.S. money from the NATO fund for building a new air base in Crotone, Italy, for the Air Force's 401st Tactical Wing. Spain has said the wing of 72 F-16 jet fighters must be moved from Torrejon de Ardoz, and following negotiations with the United States, Italy agreed two years ago to provide a new home under NATO auspices. Lawmakers have questioned the wisdom of constructing a new base in Europe when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, responding to the lessening threat and budget constraints, plans to close others overseas and at home. ``The base agreement is outdated. It's yesterday's solution to yesterday's problems,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., who chairs the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations. House approval of the military construction bill came as Cheney's moratorium on new projects, issued Jan. 24, remains in effect until Nov. 15. In its report, the military construction panel criticized the ban as disruptive to the armed forces. Noting the possible U.S.-Soviet treaty later this year to cut conventional forces in Europe and uncertainty surrounding base closings, the bill trims $287 million from the president's budget for overseas projects. Among the cuts are a reduction from the Pentagon's proposed amount of $154 million for Germany to $33 million, a total of $33 million for South Korea from Bush's request of $83 million, and $10 million for projects in Italy from the administration's proposal of $45 million. But in North Carolina, home of the subcommittee's chairman, Democratic Rep. Bill Hefner, the administration proposed $106 million for military construction. The panel increased the total to about $130 million. Among the projects are $2 million for the Cherry Point Marine Corps Air Station Aviation Museum at Camp Lejeune and $394,000 for the organizational maintenance shop for the Army National Guard in Goldsboro. The panel's ranking Republican, Bill Lowery, is from California. The administration proposed spending $314 million for construction projects there, and the panel increased the amount to $352 million. Among the projects the panel added to the legislation were $9 million for barracks for the Army National Guard at Camp San Luis Obispo and $6 million for a computer center at the Monterey Fleet Numerical Oceanography Center. The panel also includes two other Californians, Democrats Julian Dixon and Vic Fazio.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,035.66, up 592.71 points, or 1.95 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Finds What May Be Jet's Cargo Door
DOC.TEXT: Navy searchers using a remote-controlled, deep-sea submarine said they found what could be the cargo door that tore off a United Airlines jet, hurling nine people to their death over the Pacific. A metallic object that could be by the 10-by-10-foot door was found wedged in the ocean floor Monday in 15,000 feet of water 90 miles south of Honolulu, near where the Boeing 747 ripped open last year, said Lt. Cmdr. Bob Anderson. The sub's sonar located the debris, but searchers were unable to get a picture with the sub's video camera to help confirm whether the debris is from Flight 811, he said. Searchers aboard a 224-foot Navy tug recorded the location and were to return to Honolulu today, Anderson said. The Navy will report the find to the National Transportation Safety Board, which will decide whether to try to recover the debris, he said. The jumbo jet carried 355 passengers when it left Honolulu for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989. Shortly after takeoff, a cargo door opened at 22,000 feet, tearing away a section of fuselage. Nine people were swept to their deaths and five others suffered serious injuries. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu. The NTSB inquiry determined that faulty design of the locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit light to falsely indicate the door was locked. It blamed United, Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to correct problems with the door. The NTSB asked the Navy to find the door in hopes an examination of it would lead to better plane safety. The search began Wednesday. The Orion submarine searched 24 square miles of the ocean floor.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Communist Leader Zhivkov Refuses to Appear Before Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Deposed Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, under investigation for abuses during more than 30 years in power, says he will not appear before Parliament this week to defend his record. Zhivkov, who is under house arrest, earlier had requested to speak to lawmakers to ``tell the Bulgarian people the truth'' about his tenure. The 78-year-old Zhivkov was ousted Nov. 10 in a Politburo coup by Communist colleagues who pledged reform, changed their party's name to Socialist and then won a parliamentary majority in June multiparty elections. He has been under investigation for abuse of power, misappropriation of state property and incitement to national hatred. Prosecutors have yet to file any formal charges, and no trial date has been set. In a letter read in the Grand National Assembly by Deputy Chairman Ivan Glushkov on Monday, Zhivkov said ``I do not want to be a toy in the hands of whatever political grouping.'' He cited what he said were arguments against his appearance prior to a possible trial. ``As (former) party and state leader I bear the greatest responsibility for that has happened in Bulgaria in the last decades, both good and bad ... I have made mistakes, but no crimes,'' Zhivkov said in the letter.
