Stoyan Ganev, a spokesman for the opposition Union of Democratic Forces (UDF), said Zhivkov was now posing conditions for his appearance. He added it was now unclear when Zhivkov would speak, but he did not think this would happen in the next few days. The session was broadcast live on state television. Also Monday, lawmakers failed for a fifth time to elect a new president despite a compromise offered by the Socialist Party to try to overcome the country's worsening political crisis. In the presidential vote, Viktor Vulkov, the leader of the mainstream Agrarian Party, a former ally of the Communists, failed to get the necessary two-thirds majority in Parliament despite the Socialists' decision to withdraw their candidate. Petar Maldenov resigned as president earlier this month after experts confirmed the authenticity of a video in which he called for the use of tanks against anti-government demonstrators in December. Socialist Party leader Alexander Lilov told lawmakers that his party, wihc holds 211 of 400 seats in Parliament, was withdrawing its candidate for president, Chavdar Kyuranov. Kyuranov, a 69-year-old ex-dissident philosopher, has received the most votes in the balloting so far but could not get the necessary two-thirds majority. With Kyuranov's candidacy withdrawn, there were only two candidates competing for the presidency. In the fifth ballot, Vulkov received 257 of 389 votes cast but fell short of the necessary two-thirds majority. Opposition candidate Petar Dertliev, the 74-year-old Social Democrat leader imprisoned by the Communists in the late 1940s, received 130 votes. The house postponed a sixth ballot until today.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Food Label Bill
DOC.TEXT: Nutritional labeling on packaged food would be more prominent and easier to read under legislation receiving unanimous House approval. The bill approved by voice vote Monday would require that specific information about nutritional value and number of calories be highlighted on food labels by larger type, bold type or contrasting color. It also would require that any claims about the food be consistent with government definitions. For example, if a product claims to be low in salt or light, the manufacturer must be using the standards set by the Department of Health and Human Services. The bill does not pre-empt state laws on health warnings, but it does supersede state laws on health claims, nutrition and ingredient labeling for the sake of uniformity. Similar legislation is pending in the Senate. The version passed by the House would require that labels state: _Serving size, or unit of measure customarily used. _Number of calories per serving and number of calories derived from fat. _Amount of each of the following nutrients: fat, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, carbohydrates, complex carbohydrates, sugars, dietary fiber and total protein. The measure won ``qualified support'' from the Center for Science in the Public Interest, which sought to allow states to supersede federal labeling requirements with their own tougher rules. Congress and the Bush administration have been moving along similar tracks in the first major reorganization of the nation's food-labeling system in nearly two decades. The Food and Drug Administration earlier this month proposed sweeping regulations that would require nutrition labeling for nearly all packaged foods and for fresh produce and seafood. Earlier, the agency proposed a set of regulations covering health claims.

DOC.HEAD: State Says Patients of Dentist With AIDS Could be Tested
DOC.TEXT: State officials said patients of a Florida dentist who may have given AIDS to a woman during a tooth extraction could be tracked down and urged to take an AIDS test. But the patients couldn't be told why. Florida law protects the identity of anyone who has AIDS, even from those who may be infected by that person, officials said Monday. The Centers for Disease Control last week reported a 21-year-old college student apparently got AIDS from her dentist even though he wore gloves and a mask. The agency said the case was the first in the nation in which a health professional apparently transmitted AIDS to a patient. Researchers could not positively say how the woman got infected, but the CDC did rule out sexual encounters or intravenous drug use. State health officials have refused to comment publicly on news reports that the dentist practices somewhere in Florida. Two sources, however, confirmed Monday that it was a Florida dentist. They spoke on condition they were not identified. Brian Ballard, Gov. Bob Martinez's chief of staff, said that if the case originated in Florida, the Health and Rehabilitative Services Department may, under the law, track down the dentist's patients and ask them to take AIDS tests. The patients would not be told, however, that their connection to the dentist was the reason they were asked to take an AIDS test, said HRS spokesman Steve Konicki. That same guarantee of confidentiality applies to anyone with AIDS to encourage them to disclose names of people to whom they may have transmitted the disease. ``Confidentiality is an important part of contact tracing,'' said state Rep. Lois Frankel, chairwoman of the task force that produced a 1988 Florida AIDS law.

DOC.HEAD: House Tries to Limit Electronic Equivalent of Junk Mail
DOC.TEXT: You say your fax machine is filled with pages of unsolicited mail and your telephone answering machine is beeping with automatic dialing messages? The House hopes it has found a way to limit the electronic equivalent of ``junk mail.'' By voice vote, the House approved legislation Monday that would authorize the Federal Communications Commission to set up a national clearinghouse for listing telephone subscribers who object to the endless faxes and unsolicited messages. ``This legislation empowers consumers and businesses with the ability to `just say no' to unsolicited telephone advertisements,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on telecommunications and finance. Under the bill, the FCC also would establish penalties for advertisers who fail to abide by the clearinghouse list. Solicitations by charitable and political organizations would be exempt from the ban. Consumers, either private individuals or businesses, could specify that they do not wish to receive advertising by fax machines or automatically dialed, prerecorded telephone solicitations. The legislation was crafted in conjunction with the FCC, the telephone industry and the direct marketing industry, Markey said.
DOC.HEAD: East Germany Agrees To Pay Israel Compensation for Refugees
DOC.TEXT: East Germany has agreed to consider paying Israel compensation for taking in thousands of refugees from Nazi Germany after World War II. The change was reflected in a letter, obtained Monday, from East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere to World Jewish Congress President Edgar Bronfman which said talks should be convened to discuss compensation for ``the burden caused to Israel with the absorption and integration of refugees from Germany.'' Previously, East Germany had agreed to pay reparations to Jewish organizations but not to Israel. Even with the change, East Germany cannot afford the large sum of money involved, and negotiations about the amount probably will take place next year after the East is united with wealthy West Germany, officials said. The united Germany will assume the financial responsibilities of the East once unification is completed by the end of this year. Talks on the subject between Israeli and East German officials broke down in Copenhagen on July 5 on the issue of reparations to Israel for absorption of the refugees, according to the Israel Foreign Ministry. At Israel's request, the World Jewish Congress then intervened with the office of de Maiziere, said WJC Executive Director Elan Steinberg. The letter from de Maiziere, said Steinberg, ``emerges as the voice of Germany's moral conscience.''
DOC.HEAD: Sonar Maker Pleads Guilty in Civil Suit
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer of sonar devices for nuclear submarines has pleaded guilty to two felony charges and agreed to pay $5.1 million to settle a civil suit alleging it overcharged the Pentagon for labor costs. Ametek Inc., pleaded guilty in federal court in San Diego, Calif., to two charges of making false statements to the government and was fined $110,000, the Justice Department said Monday in a news release. The company admitted submitting false estimates of labor costs to the Pentagon, officials said. The company, based in Paoli, Pa., also agreed to pay $5.1 million to settle a lawsuit brought under the False Claims Act, the department said. The suit, originally filed by attorney Alan J. Ludecke, charged that Ametek had inflated labor costs for making two sonar systems for the Los Angeles-class attack submarines and Trident missile subs, the department said. Under the terms of the settlement, Ludecke will receive $765,000 or 15 percent of the $5.1 million payment. The False Claims Act allows whistleblowers to bring lawsuits on behalf of the government. The Justice Department decided to take over the case and conducted its own investigation of the allegations first brought to light by Ludecke.

DOC.HEAD: A Coup Attempt Spoils A First Foreign Trip
With PM-Trinidad, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ A Houston couple who decided to celebrate their 30th wedding anniversary with their first foreign vacation haven't gotten the romantic island getaway they planned. ``I feel like I've been a hostage here,'' grumbled Melvin Hazel on Monday. ``We're eating a good meal and no one's pointing any guns at me,'' said his wife, Darlene, confiding: ``I have a lot of sense of adventure.'' They're among some two dozen Americans still stranded on this Caribbean island where Moslem extremists stormed Parliament and the state television building on Friday, seizing the prime minister and other officials. Some of the Americans have since left the island on one of a few packed flights by regional carriers. But most have been unable to leave. ``Doesn't the American government have any responsibility for us? They've shown no intention of helping us,'' said Nancy Schnair, here with husband Howard Schnair of Chicago on a planned combined business-vacation trip. Lucy Hall, U.S. Embassy spokeswoman, said American visitors to the island were being contacted and assured their government was concerned about them. ``We can't help them because we don't run any airlines,'' Ms. Hall said of American requests for help getting off Trinidad. She said some 2,100 U.S. citizens, the great majority of them residents, are on the islands. ``I just want to be somewhere else,'' said Chris Bigalkie, here on business as regional vice president of Drew Industrial Division. ``We don't have anything like this in Memphis (Tenn., his hometown).'' The Schnairs, another couple on a combined business-pleasure trip _ Martin and Joyce Beckwith of Boston _ and the Hazels of Houston spent much of Monday morning sitting on the airy veranda of the Hilton Hotel overlooking this capital city. They heard the volleys of gunfire and explosions and saw fire erupt from the state television complex, where rebels were holding hostages. Hazel, who works in construction, said he and his wife, with three children in their 20s, wanted to celebrate their 30th anniversary in style. They had once met some Trinidadians who sang the praises of their island, and they thought this would be the perfect place for a long-delayed second honeymoon. They arrived Thursday and spent Friday sightseeing. But when their taxi driver returned Friday evening to take them to dinner at a seafood restaurant as they requested, he advised them not to go downtown because of the violence. They scrubbed plans to visit sister island Tobago, and now are only anxious to go home. ``They really messed it up for us,'' said Mrs. Hazel.

DOC.HEAD: Stepfather Convicted of Murder in Toddler's Potty-Training Death
DOC.TEXT: The jury that convicted a man of fatally plunging his 2-year-old stepson headfirst into a toilet returns Wednesday to decide whether to send him to the electric chair. Thomas Coe, 23, was found guilty Monday of child abuse and murder in the death of Bradley McGee. The case led to reforms in the way Florida protects youngsters considered at risk of child abuse. ``He deserves death,'' Pam Kirkland, Bradley's foster mother for 14 months, said of Coe. ``Hopefully this will send a message that a child is not your property to mistreat or treat any way you want. It's a child and you will treat him right or else.'' The jury hears arguments Wednesday on whether Coe should be sentenced to death or to life in prison without possibility of parole for 25 years. Coe had testified he was ``irate,'' ``steamed,'' and ``out of control'' in 1989 when he dunked Bradley for soiling his pants during toilet training. The boy died the next day. The case generated a firestorm of criticism of Florida's Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, which was responsible for supervising Bradley. The boy had been under state care from the age of 4 months, when his mother abandoned him at a mall to a woman who sold pretzels. A state social worker later recommended he be returned to his mother and Coe. They had the child only two months before he died. The social worker, Margaret Barber, was convicted earlier this year of child abuse for her role in the case. She never told a judge about a psychological report that described the couple as ``infantile,'' ``explosive'' and unable to handle children. Bradley's death also led to a change in law to make a child's safety, rather than reuniting families, the top priority of HRS. The Legislature passed the ``Bradley McGee Act'' last fall allocating $79 million for hundreds more child-protection workers. Also, another law went on the books to protect foster children from being returned to abusive homes. Coe's attorneys urged jurors to convict him of a lesser offense, such as manslaughter, arguing that the dunking was merely punishment and that there was no intent to harm the child. Prosecutor John Aguero countered: ``There is no rational explanation for an irrational act. This was a senseless killing.'' Prosecutors said Bradley's slaying was the culmination of weeks of bizarre abuse at the hands of his stepfather. Medical experts testified that Bradley's body was covered with bruises, some of them up to two weeks old, when he died. Coe's wife, Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, testified that he often pushed the child's face into feces and ground his fist and cayenne pepper into the boy's genitals. Mrs. Coe admitted to sometimes aiding in abuse and beating Bradley with pillows just before he died. She pleaded no contest to murder and aggravated child abuse and is serving a 30-year prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Surges, Dollar Plunges
DOC.TEXT: Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index ended its seven-day decline with a surge of almost 2 percent today, while the dollar plunged against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average recouped 592.71 points, or 1.95 percent, closing at 31,035.66. The index had lost 2,176.03 points, or 6.58 percent, between July 20 and July 30. Traders attributed the index's sharp rebound today to a slip in long-term interest rates that had been discouraging stock investor's buying interest. ``Participants finally began to pick up underpriced issues after the consecutive drops,'' said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. Also fueling the rebound were rounds of index-linked large-scale arbitrage buying in an attempt to take profits from price gaps between the spot and the futures markets, he said. However, Umemori said today's surge was unlikely to reverse the market's recent downward trend because interest rates are still considered to be high. At 4 p.m. the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds stood at 7.530 percent, down from Monday's close of 7.605 percent. Their price stood at 85.50 points, up from 85.14. Stock trading was thin with an estimated 380 million shares changing hands on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 147.50 yen, down 1.10 yen from Monday's 148.60 finish. It opened at 147.75 yen and ranged between 147.20 yen and 147.75 yen. Dealers said the dollar fell as market players sold the currency because of pessimism over the U.S. economy, fueled by Friday's reports of slow growth in the U.S. gross national product in June. ``The dollar was especially weaker against European currencies,'' said Masao Kanemaru, a dealer with Fuji Bank. With Japanese interest rates going up, market players were less interested in the U.S. currency, he said. Financial markets believe that with the U.S. economy continuing to slump, the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower to help stimulate growth. Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, predicted the dollar's ``downtrend would continue unless there is a visible improvement in the U.S. trade deficit.'' About $12.97 billion changed hands in spot trading.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Airlines Supervisor Pleads Guilty in Maintenance Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A former Eastern Airlines foreman who pleaded guilty to falsifying maintenance records says he ignored vital repairs on orders from superiors. Elia Dragone on Monday became the first Eastern employee to plead guilty in what prosecutors describe as a conspiracy to overlook maintenance problems. Dragone, 29, of Jersey City, N.J., told a federal judge he altered log books, work cards and other records to make it look as if vital repairs had been done. He said the fraud was orchestrated by his superiors at the troubled airline to avoid costly flight delays and cancellations. Eastern and nine managers were charged last week in an indictment unprecedented in the airline industry. The indictment alleges conspiracy, fraud, falsification of documents and obstruction of justice. Dragone was named in 20 counts but pleaded guilty to only two in a plea bargain _ conspiracy and obstructing an FAA investigation. He faces five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count at sentencing Oct. 17. The New York Times reported today that a federal prosecutor is expected to issue a report criticizing Federal Aviation Administration officials who did not act on complaints from Eastern pilots and mechanics who said repairs were not being completed and maintenance records were being falsified. The report says FAA officials thought the complaints were related to a labor dispute in which they did not want to get involved, the newspaper said. Among those also indicted were Edward Upton, former vice president of maintenance and engineering, and Thomas Lewis, Eastern's maintenance director for the Washington-to-Montreal region. They and the other defendants are to be arraigned Aug. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Police Suspect Extremists in Burning of Three Nara Shrines
DOC.TEXT: Wooden buildings at three separate Shinto shrines burned down in western Japan early today in nearly simultaneous fires, police said. The fires broke out between 1:19 a.m. and 1:32 a.m. _ at shrines in the Nara Prefecture (state) cities of Kashihara, Yamatotakada, and Gose, police said. The shrines are widely identified with the history of the imperial family and prefecture police official said extremists opposed to the scheduled November coronation of Emperor Akihito may have been responsible. No injuries were reported, but six buildings were destroyed. Shintoism is Japan's indigenous religion based on nature worship, shamanism and elaborate ceremonial rites. The police official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said authorities had found several batteries and pieces of lead that could have been used to trigger fire bombs. Of the three ancient shrines, the Iwasononi Imasu Taku Mushitama Shrine in Yamatotakada City was most heavily damaged. Its main building and the hall of worship, totaling 212.5 square yards, were destroyed. Nara, the nation's capital between 710 and 794, has many sites related to the imperial family. Police believe that two other incidents, in which two stolen cars in Nara were bombed on the same day, may be connected to the fires. Groups including the Chukakuha (Middle Core Faction) and other radical leftist groups oppose the monarchy and have vowed to use violence to disrupt ceremonies connected with the coronation. The groups particularly oppose the coronoation's rice ceremony _ during which the new emperor is believed to commune with the gods. They claim it is a remnant of prewar nationalism. The ceremony is to be conducted 10 days after Akihito's Nov. 12 coronation. Chukakuha claimed credit for an arson attack that destroyed a Shinto shrine in Akita, northern Japan, in early July.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Do we need further proof of what happens when we allow so many people to be armed with so many guns firing so many bullets?'' _ Mayor David Dinkins of New York City after a 9-month-old boy was killed in his family's aparment by bullets fired through a door, the city's fourth victim of a stray bullet in a little more than a week.

``The guy got exactly what he deserved. ... That's what should happen to any owner that constantly makes decisions to hurt the club.'' _ Yankee fan Trevor Bickford of Westbury, N.Y., after owner George Steinbrenner was stripped of control of the team.

``If he could speak to me now, he would say: `We fight that battle against them and we bring them to justice and see they are properly condemned and found guilty of what they have done.' That is how we shall carry on.'' _ Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on the assassination of Conservative Party lawmaker Ian Gow by a car bomb.

DOC.HEAD: Monument to Hollow-Earth Philosopher Gets Restored
DOC.TEXT: OK, so John Cleves Symmes' theory that the world is hollow was a little weird. But his hometown's still proud of him. A 150-year-old stone monument to the philosopher has been removed from Symmes Park for restoration. The monument _ a pedestal topped by a 20-inch globe with openings at the poles _ is chipped and worn. ``We are dedicating the finished product as a bicentennial gift to the city,'' said Sonia August of a conservation group. The town was founded in 1791. Symmes' 1826 ``Theory of Concentric Spheres'' won popular backing in the 19th century and led to the formation of the Hollow Earth Society. He argued the Earth is made up of five spheres, one within the other, with openings at each pole wide enough for explorers to travel from one end to the other. The concept, he said, explained reports of open water around the northern ice rim, northward migration of birds and animals, and lights in the northern sky.

DOC.HEAD: Other Baseball Owners Punished
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES first reference to Bowie Kuhn.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Steinbrenner, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Owners who received major punishment from the commissioner of baseball:

Nov. 23, 1943 _ Philadelphia Phillies president William D. Cox banned for life by Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis for making ``approximately 15 or 20 bets'' of ``from $25 to $100 per game on Philadelphia to win.'' Cox was forced to sell his share of the team to Ruly M. Carpenter Jr. Nov. 27, 1974 _ New York Yankees principal owner George Steinbrenner suspended by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for two years following guilty plea to conspiracy to make illegal campaign contributions. Suspension lifted March 1, 1976, for good behavior. Jan. 2, 1977 _ Atlanta Braves owner Ted Turner suspended for one year by Kuhn for tampering with San Francisco Giants outfielder Gary Matthews. Suspension lifted on March 19 after Turner sued. Reimposed June 3 after suspension upheld. Suspension temporarily lifted on Nov. 18 for winter meetings and permanently lifted on Dec. 9 for good behavior. July 31, 1990 _ Steinbrenner forced to resign as general partner of the Yankees by commissioner Fay Vincent for associating with gambler Howard Spira. Steinbrenner is not allowed to take part in the day-to-day operations of the team.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bodyguard Convicted in Drug Agent's Kidnapping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deliberations resume noon EDT.
DOC.TEXT: A jury acquitted a former Mexican policeman of murder in the 1985 torture-slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena but convicted him of kidnapping and other charges. Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, 31, a bodyguard for drug traffickers, on Monday became the second defendant acquitted of murder in the case, which has strained relations between the United States and Mexico. Deliberations were to resume today for two other defendants, neither of whom is charged with Camarena's murder. Ruben Zuno Arce, a businessman and brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria, is charged with kidnapping and conspiracy, and Javier Vasquez Velasco, a former bodyguard, is charged of murdering two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing. Bernabe was convicted of kidnapping, racketeering and aiding the escape of Mexican drug lord Rafael Caro Quintero, whose Guadalajara home was the scene of Camarena's torture and slaying. Bernabe could get life in prison for the kidnapping and racketeering plus 10 years for the third offense at sentencing Sept. 24. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie ordered lawyers not to comment until all verdicts have been returned. The government alleges Caro was among those who interrogated and killed Camarena and his Mexican pilot. Prosecutors said the slayings were revenge for Drug Enforcement Administration raids on marijuana and cocaine plantations that cost the drug barons $5 billion in profits. Caro was convicted in Mexico. He is one of 20 people serving sentences there in the case. Bernabe, the only one of the defendants to testify during the trial, admitted he was a bodyguard for drug traffickers but denied any role in Camarena's abduction and slaying. He also was acquitted of conspiracy to kidnap Camarena and of racketeering in the kidnap and murder of Camarena's pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Last week, the jury convicted a Honduran drug kingpin, Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, of the Camarena kidnapping but also acquitted of the actual murder. The 31-year-old Camarena was kidnapped off a Guadalajara street in 1985. Testimony showed that the agent was taken to Caro's house, where he was tortured and interrogated by drug lords before being slain along with Avelar. Their bodies were found a month later on a ranch 65 miles from Guadalajara.

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Mellon Looking for Bagpipers
DOC.TEXT: Carnegie Mellon University is hoping to give the bagpipe a wee bit of respectability. The school this fall will offer a new music degree in bagpiping. ``We think we'll be able to legitimize the instrument, which when you think about it has been around a lot longer than some we use in orchestras,'' said Marilyn Taft Thomas, director of the university's music department. Vince Mulhern, a sophomore majoring in mechanical engineering, applied for the program, which will accept only two students a year. ``I was getting tired of engineering and this is intriguing,'' Mulhern said Friday. ``When my friends hear about this they laugh, but no one has said to me I'm crazy. Of course I don't know what they say behind my back.''

DOC.HEAD: Who Was That Honest Man?
DOC.TEXT: Bob Kessel has an honest stranger to thank for saving him from a $3,000 goof. Kessel unknowingly sold that much in jewelry belonging to his daughter for $15 at a garage sale. A newspaper ran a story about the mishap, and the man who bought the haul appeared Sunday on Kessel's doorstep. ``He said, `I've brought your jewelry back,''' Kessel said. ``I said, `I've had enough jewelry jokes for one day.''' The man, who wouldn't identify himself, refused to take either a $200 reward Kessel offered or the $15 he paid for the jewelry in the first place. ``The guy said that he's had this kind of thing happen before. If people don't try to get it back, it's a find for him. But if they realize they've made a mistake, then he gives it back to them,'' Kessel said. A gold coin and silver locket were not returned. Kessel said the man already had sold them.

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Second Hijacker Extradited
DOC.TEXT: The government today ordered a second teen-age hijacker returned for trial in the Soviet Union, saying Sweden could not afford to be known as a haven for hijackers. Acting Justice Minister Mona Sahlin said Soviet authorities have guaranteed that Anatoly Michajlenko, 19, will be tried only for the hijacking, the reason he was being extradited. She said the Soviets promised not to charge him with evading military service, which is not an extraditable crime in Sweden. Michajlenko was expected to be sent back within two weeks. He was among five young men who hijacked Soviet domestic airliners in June and early July, three to Sweden and two to Finland. All five asked to stay, saying they were political dissidents or fugitives from the Soviet army. Besides Michajlenko, Sweden has extradited one hijacker and is considering the case of another. Finland has said it will extradite one hijacker and is reviewing the case of the second. In ordering the extraditions, Swedish officials have said they believe democratic changes in the Soviet Union now make it possible for hijackers to receive a fair trial. Human rights groups, Soviet exiles and some Ukrainian politicians asked that Michajlenko be allowed to stay in Sweden on humanitarian grounds. Ms. Sahlin said after a special Cabinet meeting today that it was important that Sweden not become a destination for hijackers. She said the government will follow Michajlenko's case and, ``We believe these (Soviet) guarantees are satisfactory'' to ensure that he is treated as Sweden has asked.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Northwest; Along Lake Erie.
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell along Lake Erie and dampened the Northwest early today. The rest of the nation had mostly dry weather. Fog clung to mountainsides in Kentucky, Tennessee and Virginia, and along stretches of the New England seaboard. New Orleans also had fog. The Midwest and Plains had mostly dry weather, and the West was mostly cloud-free. It was raining early today at Cleveland and as far south as Pittsburgh. A thunderstorm tapered off to a drizzle in Buffalo, N.Y. Rain also fell along the western edge of the Rockies in Washington and Oregon. Today's forecast called for hot and humid weather along the East and Gulf coasts in front of a cold front extending down the Appalachians and inland, across the South to Texas. Scattered thunderstorms and showers along the front were expected to develop from Maine to Louisiana, but little rain was expected in many areas. Showers were likely over central and west Texas, and rains were again likely to cause flooding in the region. The forecast also called for dry weather across the Midwest, the central and upper Plains, and the mid-Mississippi and Ohio valleys. Temperatures were expected to soar into the 100s in the desert Southwest and hit the 90s as far north as Montana. Some relief was expected today in the Northwest, as a cold front was likely to usher in lower temperatures. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Depressed, Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that GNP figures were for second quarter, not June, Sub 12th graf, `Dealers said ... in June.' Pickup 13th, `The dollar...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower in quiet trading in Europe this morning, depressed by pessimism about U.S. economic trends. Gold rose strongly in thin trading. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 147.50 yen, down 1.10 yen from Monday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was still lower at 146.95 yen. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday: _1.6008 West German marks, down from 1.6085 _1.3585 Swiss francs, down from 1.3653 _5.3640 French francs, down from 5.3885 _1.8110 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8125 _1,172.00 Italian lire, down from 1,177.50 _1.1545 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1525 The British pound rose to $1.8496 from $1.8440 late Monday. Dealers said market players sold the dollar based on pessimism over the U.S. economy, following Friday's reports of slow growth in the U.S. gross national product in the second quarter. ``The dollar was especially weaker against European currencies,'' said Masao Kanemaru, a dealer with Fuji Bank. With Japanese interest rates going up, market players were less interested in the U.S. currency, he said. A trader in Milan, Italy predicted the dollar would soon test the 1.6000-mark level. She said negative sentiment about the dollar was persisting and was linked to the currency's interest rate differential against other currencies, as well as the slowdown in the U.S. economy. ``People have gotten tired of the dollar and dollar-based securities,'' she said. Gold in London was quoted at $371.10 at the morning fixing, up from $367.25 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $371.00, up from $367.50 bid late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $1.56 an ounce on Tuesday, to close at $369.42. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.84 a troy ounce, from $4.83 bid late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Armenia Defies Gorbachev Disarmament Decree
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers in Soviet Armenia say the republic is capable of policing itself and will not abide by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order that armed groups turn in their weapons and disband, a local activist said. Last Wednesday's decree was Gorbachev's latest attempt to stem more than two years of ethnic unrest in the southern Caucasus and Central Asian republics. The disturbances have claimed more than 400 lives, caused millions of dollars' damage and produced thousands of refugees. The Armenian parliament decided Monday that the Gorbachev decree ``contradicts the Armenian people's natural right to self-defense'' as outlined in Armenia's Constitution, as well as the U.N. Charter, said Ovanes Muradian, a spokesman for the Armenian National Movement. Soviet television said late Monday that the decree was being ignored, with few weapons seized and armed attacks continuing in Armenia. Soviet Interior Minister Vadim A. Bakatin said last week that military force would be used if the decree was disobeyed, but acknowledged problems could arise in implementing it without the republics' full cooperation. Muradian said Armenia's parliament voted to suspend Gorbachev's decree on the territory of Armenia and in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region, and that it also declared Armenia could police itself without ``outside interference.'' But the lawmakers said they were willing to negotiate with Gorbachev on the issue, Muradian added. The activist, speaking by telephone from Armenia's capital of Yerevan, gave no vote total for the resolution. Gorbachev's decree gave illegally armed militants 15 days to turn in their weapons or risk having them confiscated. It encompassed all groups that threatened lives, seized arms, assaulted soldiers or police, or attacked military or civilian facilities. Since June 4, battles between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks over land distribution have killed at least 212 people. Bakatin said that besides Armenia, illegally armed groups operate in Moldavia, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. The leadership of Georgia on Monday appealed to the public for order, citing an increase in lawlessness and activity by armed groups. Bakatin estimated 10,000 to 20,000 Armenians were involved in illegally armed groups, but said others put the figure at 40,000 to as many as 100,000. He said Interior Ministry troops would be sent to republics requesting them, and army troops could go in if a state of emergency were declared. Interior Ministry soldiers already patrol the Armenia-Azerbaijan border. At least 200 people have been killed, mostly over who should govern Nagorno-Karabakh, a mostly Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan.

DOC.HEAD: The Verdict Favors `Presumed Innocent'

DOC.TEXT: The weekend box office verdict favored the courtroom drama ``Presumed Innocent,'' which made its debut in first place. Starring Harrison Ford as a prosecutor accused of murdering a former lover, ``Presumed Innocent'' grossed $11.7 million, according to figures released Monday by Exhibitor Relations Co ``Ghost'' was No. 2, scaring up $11.1 million in its third weekend of release. The poorly reviewed ``Problem Child'' opened to strong business of $10 million for third. The killer spider adventure ``Arachnophobia,'' building on positive word of mouth, had ticket sales of $8.2 million for fourth. Plummeting 41 percent to fifth was Bruce Willis' ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder'' with $6 million. ``The Freshman,'' featuring Marlon Brando in a critically acclaimed parody of his ``Godfather'' role, made $4.2 million for sixth place. DOC.HEAD: Third World Spread Raises Estimate of Infection by 2 Million
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization today raised its estimate of the number of people infected with the deadly AIDS virus to at least 8 million, citing the disease's spread in Asia and black Africa. The latest estimate of 8 to 10 million infections worldwide is 2 million above the previous figure but within a range the agency has cited for some time. Particularly in Asia, the virus has been spreading much more quickly than expected, WHO said. The ``toll of HIV infection around the globe is worsening rapidly, especially in developing countries,'' Dr. Michael Merson, head of WHO's anti-AIDS program, was quoted as saying in a statement issued by the agency. HIV is the AIDS virus. In summarizing regional developments, the statement said the rate of new HIV infections generally was slowing in the developed world. But Merson warned against complacency, since the spread is still quickening in some industrialized countries. WHO didn't identify those countries. The agency said that in sub-Saharan Africa the estimate of HIV-infected people had doubled to 5 million from 2.5 million in 1987. Due to the disease's spread in rural areas, WHO said 1 in 40 adult men and women are now believed to be virus carriers compared with 1 in 50 estimated earlier. In Asia, the virus has spread rapidly among intravenous drug users and female prostitutes. At least half a million Asians are believed infected in an area where AIDS was virtually unknown two years ago. WHO said the virus' spread in Asia, Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa could force a ``dramatic upward revision'' of its prediction that 15 to 20 million infections will have occurred by the year 2000. The U.N. agency also said AIDS will kill at least 3 million women and children worldwide in the 1990s due to rising heterosexual transmission, six times more than in the 1980s. WHO has long said 5 to 10 million people worldwide are believed infected with HIV but has recently narrowed its estimates. Its previous figure, issued last spring, was 6 million to 8 million. The virus is transmitted through blood and other body fluids. Infection with the virus is different from developing AIDS itself, which destroys the body's immune system. There is no known cure. WHO lists more than 260,000 reported AIDS cases worldwide but says the actual total is two to three times higher.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Farmers Burn Seven Tons Of Irish, German Meat
DOC.TEXT: Scores of cattle and sheep farmers broke into a slaughterhouse and burned seven tons of imported German and Irish meat to protest foreign competition, police said today. The incident occurred Monday night in the Maine-et-Loire region of western France, two days after farmers in the area poisoned 94 sheep imported from Britain. Police said a group of farmers stopped a meat truck Monday morning that was empty of cargo but carried documents indicating meat had been delivered to a slaughterhouse in the town of Fosse-en-Tigne. In the evening, about 100 men entered the slaughterhouse and set fire to seven tons of meat in a cold storage room, police said. No estimate of the damage was given. The attack Saturday occurred at a farm in Deux-Sevres, where 206 British sheep purchased by a French cooperative arrived Friday for fattening before going to slaughter. The farm owner, Joseph Drouet, heard noises in his sheep pens and found 94 of the animals dead, police said. They apparently had ingested an insecticide. A caller claiming to represent local sheep farmers later telephoned media organizations to claim the attack in the name of Deux-Sevres herders. Sheep herders in the region have protested falling prices for months. They blocked the route of the Tour de France bicycle race July 2 and forced the riders to detour. Major farming organizations condemned the poisoning, but said sheep herders were suffering from the loss of income. ``It's absolutely necessary to give them some hope,'' said Raymond Lacombe, president of the National Federation of Agriculture Unions. The government approved $11.3 million in aid last week to sheep herders to help them weather the poor market.

DOC.HEAD: Bertha as `Minimal' Hurricane Gains on Canada's Maritime Provinces
DOC.TEXT: The government of Canada issued a heavy rainfall and wind warning for Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island today as Hurricane Bertha continued its steady pace over the open Atlantic. Forecasters said the minimal hurricane could reach the Canadian provinces by Wednesday, but some effects would be felt today because hurricane-force winds extended 70 miles from the center and tropical storm-force winds of at least 39 mph reached outward up to 350 miles. At 6 a.m. EDT today, Bertha was centered near latitude 38.3 north, longitude 66.0 west, said forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The hurricane was thus centered some 775 miles due east of Washington, D.C., or 450 miles south-southwest of Halifax, Nova Scotia. It was moving north-northeast at 13 mph and had top sustained winds of 75 mph. Bertha, the first hurricane of the 1990 Atlantic season, was expected to stay at the same strength, course and speed through early Wednesday, said forecaster Hal Gerrish. Bertha had been downgraded Sunday night to a tropical storm after it temporarily weakened, regained enough strength to push it just over the hurricane threshold of 74 mph. Earlier, Bertha kicked up the surf along Carolina beaches and sent gusts up to about 45 mph toward Bermuda. But it has spent much of its life in the open Atlantic after forming as a tropical depression off northeast Florida, and was never much of a threat.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Israeli Involvement in Lebanon Fighting, 10 Killed
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reported today that Israeli tanks fired on battling Shiite Moslem militiamen in south Lebanon, killing at least 10 guerrillas and wounding 15. An army spokesman refused to confirm or deny the report, but Defense Minister Moshe Arens warned that Israel would take a role in the fighting if the battles threatened Israeli interests. The daily newspaper Yediot Ahronot reported that Israeli tanks opened fire Monday on the village of Jarjou, a site of rival Shiite militia fighting just beyond Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in south Lebanon. At least 10 fighters of the rival Hezbollah and Amal militias were killed in the shelling and about 15 were wounded, the newspaper said. It did not cite sources for the report. In a statement published in Beirut today, Hezbollah also reported Israeli fire aimed at militia fighters Monday. It said three of its fighters were killed and two wounded. The firing came from an outpost of Israeli-backed militiamen, about a half-mile from Jarjou, the statement said. Both protagonists in the Lebanese dispute are enemies of Israel dating to the Jewish state's three-year occupation of south Lebanon, which began with a June 1982 invasion to drive out Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas. Israel carved out a 6- to 10-mile-wide ``security zone'' along the Lebanese border after it withdrew the bulk of its soldiers. The zone is intended to prevent guerrilla raids across the border. The fighting between Hezbollah and Amal erupted July 16, the latest stage in an intermittent 3-year-old battle to gain mastery over Lebanon's Shiite community. Some 186 people have been killed in these artillery battles and 560 wounded, by Lebanese police count. Much of the latest combat has occurred on the rim of the Israeli security zone. Arens told Israel radio ``there is a danger that the situation will get worse and endanger our interests.'' Earlier, Arens told Yediot Ahronot: ``If the combat reaches a point in which we see that our interests are endangered ... in other words when the situation becomes intolerable from our standpoint _ there will be no choice and we will get involved.'' A source in south Lebanon, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Israelis appeared to be warning the militiamen to steer clear of the border rather than signaling intentions to intervene.

DOC.HEAD: The Fans Love It, But Yankees Unhappy About Dancing on Steinbrenner's Grave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 pvs bgng, `Word of ...' with 3 grafs to tell how fans heard of news and to CLARIFY that fans did not charge on field. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `People were ...'. A version also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The cheers started behind the third-base box seats and grew louder as the news spread through the stands. Finally, it erupted into a 90-second standing ovation at Yankee Stadium. George Steinbrenner was out! ``The guy got exactly what he deserved,'' Trevor Bickford of Westbury, N.Y., said Monday night. ``That's what should happen to any owner that constantly makes decisions to hurt the club.'' In the dugout, the Yankees weren't so happy. ``The fans may have been cheering, but I wasn't,'' pitcher Dave Righetti said. ``It's sad. He really loved the idea of owning the Yankees, and now it's been taken away from him. It'll certainly be different not having him around here.'' Word that Steinbrenner had been busted by Commissioner Fay Vincent for dealing with a gambler came in the fourth inning as fans listening with portable radios quickly spread the news throughout the crowd. After the standing ovation, Detroit first baseman Cecil Fielder quieted the crowd with his major league-leading 33rd homer, accounting for the Tigers' only runs in a 6-2 loss to the Yankees before a crowd of 24,037. ``I actually thought people were running on the field from the third-base line, the noise was so loud,'' Yankees pitcher Dave LaPoint said. ``People were actually mean about the situation, and I guess venting their own frustrations,'' he said. ``It's a shame that the fans who were out there erupted and made a joke out of it. It upset a lot of us. The man was always generous to the players.'' Many fans, however, did not like the way Steinbrenner treated them. The man had hired and fired managers and criticized his own team in his 18 years at the helm. ``I've been a Yankee fan since I was a little kid and it really hurt me to see this team turned into a joke,'' said Frank Fedak of Monroe, Conn. ``He's ruined the morale of the team and the morale of the fans. I'm ready for a new owner.'' ``He's worse than Pete Rose. Pete Rose was only a manager,'' said Lori Waller of Farmingville, N.Y. ``Steinbrenner was an owner and should have taken his responsibility much more seriously.'' But John Rizzi, a fan from Rockland, N.Y., said of Steinbrenner's ouster: ``I don't feel this is right.'' ``We were dead for 10 years and he made us a winner again,'' he said. ``The next owner might not care at all or even take this club to Jersey.''

DOC.HEAD: Kollek Suspends Deputy Mayor Over Ad On Jailed Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Teddy Kollek has suspended his left-wing deputy for signing an ad supporting reserve soldiers who refused to serve in the occupied territories. ``I see the incident as ... a matter for harsh condemnation. There are few points deserving of national consensus that should be accepted by all of us and one of these is army service,'' Kollek said in a letter to Deputy Mayor Ornan Yekutieli, published today in the daily Haaretz newspaper. The ad, published in Haaretz last week, ``expressed respect for the courageous step'' of four reserve soldiers who served jail sentences for refusing to serve in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. More than 100 reservists have served jail terms for refusing to serve in the occupied lands since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. Kollek's spokeswoman, Bonnie Boxer, said the mayor, a member of the center-left Labor Party, suspended Yekutieli on Monday and ``asked him to refrain from representing the municipality until there is further discussion of the subject.'' The ad was signed by 43 members of the left-wing Citizens' Rights Movement, to which Yekutieli belongs. It was later denounced by the party's leadership. Haaretz quoted Yekutiel as saying the ad was a show of support for a party member who served a jail sentence for refusing to serve in the territories and did not advocate refusing to serve in the military.

DOC.HEAD: Gang That Planted Car Bomb Threatens More Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A letter bearing the name of West Germany's most notorious terror gang today threatened more attacks following an assassination attempt last week on a government official. The letter, delivered to news agencies in Bonn and Frankfurt, said the attack Friday on Interior Ministry official Hans Neusel was the ``start of a long fighting phase against the newly arisen Greater German-West European World Power.'' At the bottom of the five-page letter, written in German, was the name ``Red Army Faction.'' The group claimed responsibility for the attack on Neusel in a letter left at the scene of the crime. The note received today was dated Sunday. The gang's symbol, a star superimposed by an assault rifle, was missing. The group has often used the symbol on written claims of responsibility. However, the federal prosecutor's office said the letter appeared to be authentic. Spokesman Hans-Juergen Foerster noted that a similar letter was sent to news agencies several days after the assassination of Deutsche Bank President Alfred Herrhausen, who died in a November 1989 car bombing similar to the attack on Neusel. Neusel walked away with minor cuts after a bomb rocked his sedan as he was driving to work. Today's message said the bomb was meant to ``accomplish his certain death'' but that ``we calculated the amount of explosives too low.'' It also denounced the process of German unity as imperialistic. The letter vowed support for leftist terrorists in Spain, and called for the ``new building of a strong revolutionary movement'' across Western Europe.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0513 to CORRECT cycle designator
Ukraine Says Its Soldiers Should Serve at Home
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Defense Ministry said today that a Ukrainian resolution to keep its army conscripts from serving outside the republic could impair the Soviet Union's ability to defend itself. The republic's parliament on Monday adopted a resolution declaring that Ukrainians drafted into the Soviet army should not be used to quell ethnic violence in other parts of the country, such as Armenia and Kirghizia. Lawmakers of the country's second most populous republic addressed the resolution to the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. and expressed the view that Ukrainian conscripts should only serve in the republic, the Interfax news agency said. The resolution also said that Ukraininan troops attached to the republic's Interior Ministry should not be used to put down ethnic clashes in other republics. ``They appealed to the Supreme Soviets of Azerbaijan, Armenia, Kirghizia and Uzbekistan to provide law and order on their territories themselves,'' Interfax reported from Kiev. Asked to comment on the resolution, Defense Ministry spokesman Vladimir Nikanorov said, ``our approach to forming armed forces of the U.S.S.R. is that they must be a socialist, multinational, exterritorial, and professional army.'' ``From a military point of view, it is a step backward, it can lead to the ruining of the army's capabilities and impair the country's defense,'' he said. Furthermore, ``economically and technically, it is not really feasible. Politically, it can lead to transferring interethnic differences into military conflicts,'' he said. The Ukrainian parliament on July 16 declared that its laws take precedence over national law. The declaration said the republic had the right to set up its own armed force, currency, citizenship and banking system. The declaration said the republic's youth cannot perform military service outside the republic without the parliament's permission. The Ukrainian decree followed other republics, such as Russia and the three Baltic states, clamoring for more independence from central authority.

DOC.HEAD: Specialists Had Concerns About Potential Explosions in Hanford Plant
DOC.TEXT: Safety specialists had concerns about potential explosions in storage tanks at the Hanford atomic weapons plant since the 1970s, but authorities didn't acknowledge the problem until recently, an internal investigation revealed today. Concern about possible explosions because of hydrogen accumulation in some of the atomic waste tanks at the weapons plant in eastern Washington state surfaced last March when the Energy Department made the information public. But a report by the department's Office of Nuclear Safety concluded that a string of plant operators dating back 13 years were aware that flammable gas was being generated in the tanks and ``the significance ... was known as early as the late 1970s.'' Meanwhile, a safety advisory panel to Energy Secretary James Watkins suggested the department may not be taking the concern about the tanks seriously enough. ``The technical basis for the analysis from which the (Hanford) operator draws comfort about the safety of the tanks is weak, considering the potential consequences of an accident,'' the department's Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety said in a letter to Watkins. The findings were released today by the Senate Government Affairs Committee at hearings into the safety concerns over the storage tanks at Hanford and other weapons facilities. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, committee chairman, said the panel wants to examine what threat the tanks pose to workers at the weapons plants and to nearby populations. The committee has estimated a single tank could explode with the force of 36 tons of TNT and release significant radiation. The Hanford weapons facility has 177 nuclear waste storage tanks which contain highly radioactive byproducts from more than 40 years of plutonium production. Last March, the Energy Department said some of the double-walled tanks could explode because of a buildup of highly flammable hydrogen. While acknowledging a problem, the department repeatedly has said the likelihood is low of an explosion that would penetrate both walls of any of the tanks is low. But in the letter to Watkins, John Ahearne, chairman of the Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety, suggested the potential for danger is underestimated. ``The waste tanks are a serious problem. The possibility of an explosion of an unstable chemical or a flammable gas must be taken seriously'' because of the amount of radioactive materials that could be released, Ahearne wrote. ``Top management of DOE and the contractor is paying more attention to maximizing waste storage capacity and to minimizing potential leakage from the tanks than to achieving higher levels of tank safety,'' he continued. Ahearne said there is an ``urgent need to determine what is in the tanks, what are the risks and what actions should be taken to ameliorate the hazards. ... The operators have only sketchy information on conditions ins the tanks.'' In Olympia, Wash., meanwhile, Gov. Booth Gardner said ``there appears to be no immediate danger to public health and safety'' from a cyanide compound that is in many of the tanks. There had been concern last year that the compound may unleash a chemical reaction that would lead to an explosion. Concern about the cyanide issue prompted the later disclosure about the hydrogen buildup in the tanks. Since then the hydrogen problem has gained most of the focus and is considered the more troublesome.

DOC.HEAD: Probe Asked into Treatment of Former Contra Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Three members of Congress today asked for an investigation into alleged neglect of former Contra rebels and their families who remain in jungle camps along the Honduran border. Humanitarian aid for the U.S.-backed rebels, which had been provided by the Agency for International Development, has been made the responsibility of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., and Reps. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif., and Cass Ballenger, R-N.C., said the recent effort has been a failure and that many of the rebels now face starvation. The leftist Sandinista government which they had been fighting was replaced in elections this year by a U.S.-backed political coalition. ``We put guns in their hands, but now we can't put food in their mouths,'' Reid told a news conference. The three lawmakers called for an investigation by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, into why adequate aid is not being provided. A State Department official, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said the U.S. government believes that the rebels are being adequately cared for and denied that the United States had broken faith with the Contras. An estimated 30,000 to 40,000 rebels and family members remain in the jungle camps, the lawmakers said, many of them with war injuries. Infant mortality is high, they said. A supplemental money bill passed earlier this year included $35 million for continued humanitarian aid to the rebels as well as for repatriation of the fighters. The lawmakers alleged that people are being starved in the camps to force them back into Nicaragua, but only about 1,000 a month are being moved, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Ganz Cooney Steps Down At Children's Television Workshop
DOC.TEXT: Joan Ganz Cooney, who helped create the company that produced ``Sesame Street'' and other educational series, will step down as chief executive this fall, the Children's Television Workshop announced. Mrs. Cooney, who will become chairman of the executive committee of the company's board of trustees, will be succeeded by David Britt, who currently is president and chief operating officer. ``This seems to me the right moment in CTW's life and my own to make a change,'' Mrs. Cooney, 60, said Monday. ``I look forward to continuing to work with David and all of the other talented people at CTW.'' In 1966, Mrs. Cooney undertook the feasibility and planning study for the Carnegie Corporation which led to the creation of ``Sesame Street.'' She was elected president and chief executive officer when the company was incorporated as a nonprofit organization in 1970. She was elected chairman-CEO in 1988. Britt, 53, joined the company in 1971, following government service in Washington. In 1974 he became assistant to the president, and in 1988 he was named president and chief operating officer.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Leader Warns of ``Bloodbath,'' Calls for U.N. Observers
DOC.TEXT: A leader of Canada's Mohawks warned today that his group's land dispute with the government could ``produce a bloodbath'' and urged the United Nations to sent observers to monitor the situation. Kenneth Deer also told a U.N. human rights panel that the Mohawks have little confidence in Canadian authorities and their ability to control police in the standoff. ``There is always the possibility of a provocation or an accident which will produce a bloodbath between the two opposing forces,'' Deer said. He also appealed to the panel to recommend that an international delegation is sent to Canada to observe the situation and monitor any negotiations. ``We have confidence in the justice of our cause,'' Deer said, ``We have no qualms with an international observation team.'' His statements drew rare applause from the almost 300 representatives of various non-governmental organizations attending the meeting of the U.N. Human Rights Commission's Working Group on Indigenous Populations. Three weeks ago, police stormed a barricade manned by armed Mohawks at Oka, a village 18 miles west of Montreal. The Mohawks were protesting the proposed expansion of a golf course onto land they claim is ancestral. A provincial police officer was killed in the shootout, but it is unclear which side fired the fatal bullet. The government has said the bullet's caliber did not match that assigned to provincial police. Since the confrontation, police and Mohawk warriors have been manning opposing barricades. Police have also blockaded the entrances to Oka, and Deer said the police were limiting the amount of food that could be brought into the area. ``We are a peaceful people who have shared our lands but the pressure brought upon us at this point is unbearable,'' he said. He referred to Canada's treatment of its native population as ``the roots of the system of apartheid.'' ``It is for each of us to give respect and dignity to each other equally. Only then can the weapons of war be buried forever,'' he said. Canadian ambassador Gerald E. Shannon told the panel Monday that the federal government hopes that its purchase of the disputed land will lead to an early end to the standoff. Shannon said the federal government expects to conclude the purchase of the 67-acre plot this week for use by the Mohawks of the Kanesatake reserve. Deer said the federal purchase plan ``validates the action of the Mohawk people to defend their territory.'' But later he said that ``the incident at Oka is no longer about land. It is to break the spirit of the Mohawk people.'' ``But the Mohawk people will never surrender, never give up our land, our culture, our language,'' he said. ``It is our destiny perhaps to struggle forever.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Charged with Killing Nun and Three Police Officers
With PM-Britain-Blast
DOC.TEXT: Two men were charged today with planting a half-ton bomb that killed three police officers and a Roman Catholic nun. Henry McCartney, 26, and Tarlac Connolly, 29, both of Armagh, made no statement during their brief court appearance. They were remanded in custody until Aug. 17. A third man questioned in the case was released Monday, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Three officers of the Constabulary _ the police force of the Protestant-dominated British province _ died instantly when an estimated half-ton of explosives were detonated as they drove along a rural highway on June 24. The nun, Sister Catherine Dunne, was in an oncoming car, and died at a hospital shortly after the blast. A 25-year-old social worker who was a passenger in her car, Cathy McCann, was injured. The IRA claimed responsibility for the attack but said the nun's death was an unintended ``fluke.'' A detective told the court the two men had made no statement since they were arrested Wednesday. He said the case was based on forensic and circumstantial evidence. Sister Catherine was the first Roman Catholic nun killed in 21 years of violence in Northern Ireland. At least 2,800 people have been killed in the fighting, including 273 full-time or reserve police officers. The mainly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and to unite the privince with the Republic of Ireland under a leftist administration.

DOC.HEAD: `Unusual Event' Declared at Comanche Peak Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Comanche Peak nuclear power plant has experienced its third ``unusual event'' in four months with the release of non-radioactive steam into the atmosphere, utility officials said. Steam was released late Monday from the only operable reactor in the twin-reactor plant when a steam relief valve apparently malfunctioned and opened too wide, said Mark Manroe, spokesman for TU Electric. An ``unusual event'' is the lowest of four categories of emergencies defined by regulators. There never was a threat to the public, Manroe said. The reactor had not been in operation since Thursday, when it was shut down as part of the final test of its initial startup testing program, Manroe said. The $9.1 billion plant about 45 miles southwest of Fort Worth began generating power April 4 after a 10-year licensing battle. The plant had been scheduled to go to full power this week, but Monday's event may alter that timetable, Manroe said. ``We're not going to be in a hurry to (startup) now until we understand what happened this time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of New Homes Jumped 8 Percent in June
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes jumped 8 percent in June to their highest level in four months, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 581,000 units in June after gaining a revised 2.3 percent in May. The June figure was the highest level since February, when sales totaled 606,000 at an annual rate. The May increase was even stronger than the 0.4 percent advance first reported last month. Before the May increase, new home sales had dropped for five straight months. At the same time, inventories of new homes fell to a 7.5-month backlog at the June sales pace. That was down from 8.2 months in May and 8.4 months in April. The increased sales and lower inventories could stimulate renewed construction in an industry that analysts have said was slowed by high interest rates, consumer caution because of adverse economic news and a glutted market. The national commitment rate for 30-year, conventional fixed-rate mortgages ranged from 10.29 percent to 10.10 percent in June, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The rate had dropped to 9.98 percent by last Friday. The National Association of Realtors reported last week that sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million units. It was the first increase since a 3.2 percent gain in November. The Realtors reported today that its index measuring the ability of the typical family to purchase a median-priced existing home was 102.9 in June, down from 104.7 in May. That means a family earning the national median income of $34,250 in June had 102.9 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of a median-priced home costing $97,500. The median income means that half of the families earned more and half less, while the median price means half of the homes cost more and half less. In its report, the Commerce Department said the median price of a new home rose 1.6 percent to $129,900, while the average price advanced 2.1 percent to $152,900. Sales in the Northeast, which have been sluggish for more than a year, jumped 36 percent to an annual rate of 102,000 units. Sales in the South also advanced, up 13.6 percent to an annual rate of 243,000 units. Elsewhere, sales dropped. They were down 5.8 percent to an annual rate of 146,000 units in the West and down 4.3 percent to an annual rate of 90,000 units in the Midwest. For the first six months of 1990, new home sales have fallen 9.7 percent below sales of the first half of 1989 when they totaled 340,000 units.

DOC.HEAD: Ship Sails to Evacuate 100 Foreigners, 54 Killed in Fighting
DOC.TEXT: A cargo freighter left Colombo today to evacuate about 100 British and other nationals trapped in the rebel-held city of Jaffna, officials said. Military officials also said that at least 54 people have died in two days of fighting across the island nation. The ``Lanka Siri'' sailed for Point Pedro, the northernmost tip of the Jaffna Peninsula. Rebels have controlled the peninsula since the latest round in the 7-year-old civil war broke out June 11, military officials said. The freighter was expected to return Wednesday. Point Pedro is 12 miles north of Jaffna, headquarters of the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. The militia has been locked in fierce battles with government troops for control of the north and east. Most of those to be evacuated were Tamil expatriates visiting their homeland when the fighting started, the officials said. About 90 are British citizens and one is a Swiss national, the officials said. The nationalities of the others were not known and other details were unavailable, they said. Communications with Jaffna have been cut since the fighting broke out, and the only reports from the area have come from military officials in the capital. The evacuation was being supervised by the Red Cross, the officials said. Red Cross officials in Colombo and New Delhi, India, could not immediately be reached for comment. Meanwhile, in a battle today in northwestern Mannar, at least seven rebels and five soldiers were killed, the officials said. Elsewhere, gunmen killed 20 Tamil civilians in the northeastern village of Kantalai, military officials and residents said. It was not immediately clear who the assailants in Monday night's attack were. Earlier today, the officials said 14 Moslems were killed by the rebels in the Ampara district, south of Trincomalee. Moslems, who make up about 7 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, are often caught in the middle of the civil war between the minority Tamils and Sinhalese-dominated government. The rebels accuse them of siding with the army. In Jaffna, at least six rebels and two policemen were killed, military officials said. The deaths raise to more than 3,000 the number of combatants killed in the fighting. The outbreak of fighting in June ended a 13-month cease-fire that had interrupted the war for an independent Tamil homeland. Tamils say they are discriminated by the majority Sinhalese in jobs and education. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and the Sinhalese, who control the government and the military, comprise 75 percent. More than 14,000 people have been killed in the Tamil revolt since it began in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Allege Katyn Executioner Still Alive In Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Poland says a Soviet secret policeman who signed the order for the World War II massacre of Polish officers in the Katyn forest is still alive and should be interrogated, the PAP news agency reported today. Poland's Justice Ministry alleged that Pyotr Karpovich Soprunenko was a major in the NKVD, the precursor to the KGB, when he signed the list of 4,200 officers ordered to be executed at Katyn in the spring of 1940, PAP said. The ministry, in a communique Monday, said Soprunenko is living in Moscow, PAP reported. Justice Minister Aleksander Bentkowski of Poland has asked Soviet General Public Prosecutor Aleksander Sukhorev to interrogate Soprunenko in the presence of a Polish investigator, PAP said. In all, 15,000 Polish officers, the cream of Polish society called up from the reserves, were murdered after being interned at three camps when the Red Army occupied eastern Poland in 1939. For decades, successive Soviet governments maintained the massacre was committed by the Nazis. Only in April did authorities acknowledge, as Polish and Western historians had long contended, that the slaughter was by the NKVD at Stalin's behest. A mass grave in the Katyn forest near Smolensk was discovered in 1943. It contained the remains of more than 4,200 soldiers, and the remains of the others have not been found. In June, the KGB identified a park outside the Ukranian city of Kharkov as the likely burial place for 3,900 Polish soldiers. Investigators have suggested that the others were buried in mass graves north of Kalinin. Ukrainian officials have granted the Polish government the right to participate in the Kharkov exhumations, planned for September.

DOC.HEAD: Chimp Rescuer Had Feared Animal Drowned in Zoo Moat
LaserPhoto DT2 of July 30
DOC.TEXT: The man who saved a Detroit Zoo chimpanzee from drowning said he never feared for his own life as he wrestled the 135-pound primate. ``He was looking at me,'' said Rick Swope, a 33-year-old truck driver from Cement City. ``I think he knew that I was helping him,'' so Swope said he wasn't afraid. Swope was visiting the zoo Sunday with his wife, Cynthia, and their three children. ``We watched the chimpanzees for probably about half an hour or so and we were just getting ready to go when I heard a splash,'' he said. ``I just caught out of the corner of my eye this chimpanzee flying through the air.'' ``Everyone in the whole place was just standing around watching this monkey drown,'' Swope said Monday. ``When he went down the second time I knew I had to do something.'' Swope scaled the 4-foot fence and plunged into the cold, murky water. He reached the chimpanzee and pulled it back to the island. ``He was pretty lifeless,'' Swope said. ``When I brought him out of there I wasn't sure he was still alive.'' Zoo officials are unsure why the 18-year-old, 135-pound male chimpanzee jumped into the moat surrounding its 1-acre island home, said spokeswoman Pat Butkiewicz. Chimpanzees cannot swim and generally are afraid of water. In April, a week after the $7.5 million exhibit opened, a 20-year-old female chimp drowned in the 5-foot-deep moat. Zoo director Steve Graham said the exhibit would be partially closed while the design of the moat was being re-evaluated. Graham said Swope's rescue was brave but reckless, because chimps are three to five times stronger than humans. A zoo employee was trying to use a pole to save the chimp when Swope jumped in the water, officials said. Swope, who doesn't have any lifeguard or veterinary training, said he kept one arm around the chimp's stomach during the rescue. ``I thought maybe I could pump some water out of him,'' he said. ``When he got his strength back, I let him go.'' Swope's family each year visits the suburban Detroit zoo about 75 miles northwest of their home. He said chimpanzee exhibit is one of his children's favorites. ``They're happy it turned out the way it did, too. They're glad I went in and got him,'' he said. ``They wouldn't expect anything less from their dad.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Groups Call 1976 Court Brief `Profoundly Alarming'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with new Souter comment, picks up 6th graf pvs, In an earlier.
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter returned to Capitol Hill today for private meetings with senators and sidestepped questions about news coverage seeking to discern his views on abortion. ``There's nothing I'd wish to say,'' Souter replied when asked if he had any complaint about the media coverage. ``That's not an endorsement,'' he added. He was questioned as abortion rights advocates were calling ``profoundly alarming'' what they say is the latest glimpse of Souter's possible views on abortion. Asked whether he would be spending much time in briefings with White House aides before his Senate Judiciary Committee confirmation hearings begin Sept. 13, Souter said, ``I haven't worked out a schedule.'' Souter commented while posing for photographers before he met privately with Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, one of the committee's staunchest abortion foes. Souter was to pay a similar courtesy call to another anti-abortion committee member, Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., later in the day. Senators on both sides of the politically explosive issue say abortion will be discussed during the confirmation hearings. The latest attempt to determine Souter's abortion views was made by the liberal People for the American Way. The group, which supports abortion rights, released copies Monday of a 1976 brief in which the New Hampshire attorney general's office headed by Souter referred to abortion as ``the killing of unborn children.'' In an earlier case, argued in 1972 when Souter was the state's deputy attorney general, New Hampshire defended its strict anti-abortion law against a constitutional challenge by arguing, ``The maintenance of an unborn child's right to birth is a compelling interest which outweighs any rights of a mother to an abortion except when necessary to preserve her life.'' Richard V. Wiebusch, whose signature appears on the 1976 brief as an assistant attorney general, said today that Souter wasn't involved in the preparation of the case. ``I don't recall him looking at the language, talking to me about the argument or approving any line of argument,'' said Wiebusch, now a lawyer in private practice in Manchester, N.H. He said the brief did not represent anyone's personal view on abortion but was the result of the obligation of the attorney general's office to defend regulations adopted by a state social services agency. ``I chose the language,'' Wiebusch said. ``It seemed to me to be the best way at the time to make the case.'' He said he did not know Souter's opinions on abortion. The U.S. Supreme Court legalized abortion in its 1973 decision in Roe vs. Wade. ``The Senate should ask Judge Souter to address himself'' to the 1976 document, said Arthur Kropp, president of People for the American Way. He said the language ``suggests a clear sympathy for an anti-abortion viewpoint.'' Kate Michelman of the National Abortion Rights Action League added, ``Judge Souter's use of rhetoric commonly used by anti-choice extremists is profoundly alarming.'' But Rebecca Hagelin of the anti-abortion Concerned Women for America said the language used in the 1976 brief ``tells me absolutely nothing about how he is going to rule if given an opportunity to reassess Roe vs. Wade.'' ``This is an attempt by the opposition to create a lot of hoopla. Everyone seems to be grasping at straws,'' she said. ``As someone who is passionately pro-life, I'd love to know his views on this subject but it would be inappropriate to ask.'' Douglas Johnson of the National Right to Life Committee called the 1976 brief a ``very tenuous'' link to Souter and his personal views. Johnson said Souter ``is likely to answer (Judiciary Committee) questions in generalities and refuse to discuss specific cases that will come before the court.'' Abortion rights activists say such answers should be deemed unacceptable. The 1976 brief submitted to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, the court on which Souter now serves, argued that New Hampshire was under no legal obligation to spend Medicaid funds for abortions. ``Many thousands of New Hampshire residents find the use of tax revenues to finance the killing of unborn children morally repugnant,'' the brief contended. The nation's highest court in 1977 ruled that states have no legal obligation to pay for non-therapeutic abortions sought by women on welfare. The court in 1980 upheld a ban on federal spending for most welfare abortions. Anti-abortion groups expressed dismay last week when it was reported that Souter served on the board of a New Hampshire hospital and attended a meeting when it voted to allow abortions at the facility.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Chases Campers In California; Lightning Sets Fires In Northwest
DOC.TEXT: An 800-acre wildfire in southern California forced evacuation of campgrounds and picnic sites, and hundreds of lightning strikes started fires in the forests of Oregon, Washington and Idaho. About seven miles north of Santa Barbara, Calif., some 580 firefighters had surrounded about 50 percent of the 800-acre fire in the Santa Ynez Valley by early today. Total containment was expected by midday Wednesday, said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Earl Clayton. The cause of the fire, which started Monday afternoon, was unknown. No structures were threatened, but the blaze in brush and grass forced about 30 people to evacuate campgrounds and picnic sites Monday, said Forest Service spokesman Gary Self.
