A construction crew also evacuated the Gibraltar Dam, he said. About 1,500 lightning strikes lit small fires between the Willamette National Forest in west-central Oregon and the Wenatchee National Forest in central Washington on Monday as storms traveled along the crest of the Cascade Range. Elsewhere in Washington, near Kennewick, a range fire fanned by 35 mph wind blackened 1,200 acres Monday, and Interstate 82 was closed after several smoke-related accidents, authorities said. More than 400 firefighters battled the Canoe Creek fire in a steep canyon of scattered ponderosa pine and Douglas fir about 28 miles northwest of Chelan, Wash., in the Wenatchee National Forest, spokesmen said. In Oregon, the 360-acre Wake Butte fire, burning six miles southwest of Sunriver on the Deschutes National Forest, was 80 percent contained and was expected to be controlled by Wednesday evening, said U.S. Forest Service spokeswoman Ann Carlson. On the California-Nevada state line 10 miles north of Lake Tahoe, a fire of undetermined size in steep terrain of the Sierra Nevada sent an acrid pall of smoke over the Reno area, said Chuck Witte, of the Nevada Division of Forestry. Traffic was congested on nearby Interstate 80 during the night because of people slowing to watch the fire. Lightning started more than four dozen small fires during the night in western and central Idaho. More than 100 firefighters were scattered through the northern parts of the Boise and Payette national forests today, and over 200 more were being sent in, Forest Service officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Michel Guy, Former Culture Minister, Dead at 63
DOC.TEXT: Michel Guy, a former minister of culture and director of the annual Fall Festival in Paris, has died after a long illness, associates said today. He was 63. No details of his illness were immediately available. Associates said Guy died Monday. A follower of numerous artistic disciplines, Guy served as culture minister from 1974 to 1976 under Premier Jacques Chirac. He founded the Fall Festival in 1972 and served as its director every year since except during his stint in the Cabinet. The arts festival built a reputation for attracting avant-garde artists in varied fields and from diverse ethnic backgrounds. Guy also served as vice president of the oversight council of France's cultural television channel, La Sept, and on the administrative council of the arts festival held each summer in Avignon. There was no immediate word on survivors or funeral services.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility For Slaying of Close Thatcher Friend
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECAST lead to correct that statement did not specifically mention criticism of IRA; Insert graf after 7th, `However, the...' with more from statement. Pickup 8th pvs, `Gow was...
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army today claimed responsibility for killing lawmaker Ian Gow, a close friend of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and outspoken critic of the IRA. So long as Britain controls Northern Ireland, the IRA said in a statement, ``the IRA will continue to strike whenever and wherever the opportunity arises.'' Gow, 53, a Conservative Party lawmaker, was killed Monday morning when a bomb exploded under his car at his home in Hankham, southeast England. The IRA claim was made in a statement to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Rodney Lind, assistant chief constable of the Sussex police, told reporters today police were following up several leads based on tips from the public. Police recovered some components of the bomb, and checks were being made at ports in the belief the guerrillas may have fled by ferry to the continent, he said. Dressed in black, Mrs. Thatcher attended a service in memory of Gow on Monday night at the Anglican parish church in the village of Hankham, 60 miles south of London, where Gow lived with his wife, Jane. Gow was chairman of the Northern Ireland Committee in the House of Commons. The committee discusses the affairs of the province, where the IRA is fighting British rule, but has no power over legislation. However, the IRA statement noted that Gow was a ``close personal associate'' of Mrs. Thatcher. It also noted that he was Mrs. Thatcher's personal parliamentary secretary, and thus one of her closest advisers, during her first four years in power from 1979 to 1983. Gow was ``one of a small group of influential Tories ... who in the late 1970s formulated the British policy pursued in Ireland since the 1979 Tory election victory,'' the statement said. Gow was also a close friend of Airey Neave, the Conservative Party spokesman on Northern Ireland who was killed by a car bomb in 1979. The Irish National Liberational Army, an IRA splinter group, claimed responsibility for that attack. The Independent newspaper said today: ``The assassination of Ian Gow may represent an attempt by the IRA to cause personal hurt to Margaret Thatcher and goad her into overreacting to his death. ... His symbolic importance lay in his close association with the prime minister.'' The Gow and Thatcher families were close and often spent Christmas together. Looking somber and shaken, Mrs. Thatcher told reporters in London before leaving for Hankham that the slaying would make no difference to her Conservative government's fight against terrorism. Mrs. Thatcher attended the church service at Hankham with Mrs. Gow, the widow's two sons ages 20 and 22, and friends of the family. The group lit candles in Gow's memory. Jane Gow said in an interview with the Brighton Argus that her husband's death ``will not diminish our resolve to be as strong as he was in fighting this terrible wickedness.'' ``We want to share Ian's great courage in defying evil and terrorism,'' she said in the interview published today. Scotland Yard's chief anti-terrorist officer, George Churchill-Coleman, said Gow had been warned he was on a list of 100 lawmakers, judges and civil servants found in an IRA bomb factory in south London in December 1988. Gow resigned from Mrs. Thatcher's government in 1985 in protest over the Anglo-Irish Agreement signed Nov. 15 of that year. The accord gave the government of the Republic of Ireland, which is 95 percent Roman Catholic and lays constitutional claim to Northern Ireland, a formal consultative role in the running of the province. Gow sided with the province's Protestant leaders in opposing the accord, saying Northern Ireland should be governed like any other part of Britain. But he remained a staunch supporter of other government policies. The mainly Catholic IRA wants to unite the province with the Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey joined British politicians in condemning the attack, the fourth slaying of a member of Parliament since sectarian and political fighting erupted in Northern Ireland in 1969. The IRA has claimed responsiblity for a series of bombings in England, including one May 16 that killed Sgt. Charles Chapman at a army recruiting office. Other recent targets have included London's Stock Exchange, the Carlton Club, a traditional Conservative Party watering hole, the Stock exchange and a Royal Air Force base in northwest London. In Washington, the State Department condemned the killing and offered condolences to Gow's family. Mrs. Thatcher narrowly escaped an IRA bombing that killed five people at a hotel in Brighton during the Conservative Party's annual conference in October 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Body Found in Explosion Rubble
DOC.TEXT: The body of a man who had been charged with burglary in the past was recovered from the ruins of one of eight businesses destroyed in a weekend explosion that gutted a downtown block. The victim, Jeffrey E. Johnson, 25, was discovered Monday by investigators looking for clues to Saturday night's explosion, said Agent Jerry Turpen of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. ``He was lying in the grass with the building on top of him,'' Turpen said. The explosion in this city of about 13,000 about 10 miles north of the South Carolina border shattered storefront windows nearly the length of Main Street. Six people were treated at a hospital for cuts from flying glass, officials said. Public Safety Director Bobby Kilgore estimated losses at $500,000 to $1 million. Officials had not expected to find any victims because no one was reported missing after the explosion. ``We don't know what we have,'' Turpen said after the body was discovered. ``Our process will be a lot slower now because of the possibility that someone else could be in there.'' Investigators said they did not know whether Johnson was caught in the blast while walking by or was inside the building without permission and was blown out. He had been scheduled to appear in court next month on charges of breaking and entering, and he received a two-year suspended sentence for possession of stolen goods last December, authorities said. On Monday, about two dozen investigators from the State Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms sifted through debris in the search for the cause of the blast. Authorities also were looking into bomb threats that were recently phoned into several downtown locations. ``At this point we know of no connection, but we do know that at least three bomb threats were made,'' Turpen said. Mayor Lynn Keziah said Sunday that authorities suspected a gas leak may have been the cause.

DOC.HEAD: Power Outage In Chicago Cut to 1,000 Customers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd-4th grafs, `By this...', with 2 grafs to update number still without power. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `City officials...'.
DOC.TEXT: Residents making do with flashlights and city-supplied packages of food should have their electricity back by tonight, three days after a major blackout on the West Side, a utility spokesman said. Police said 230 extra officers patrolled the streets and directed traffic overnight, but there appeared to be no recurrence of the scattered looting that followed Saturday's blackout of 40,000 customers on the city's far West Side. By midmorning, only about 1,000 customers remained without electricity, said Glen Wald, a Commonwealth Edison Co. spokesman. Earlier, another spokesman, Peter Guck, said: ``We're anticipating having the whole episode cleaned up today. That's a lot earlier than we thought it might be. We tried to be conservative on the timing, but things went well.'' City officials delivered 2,200 food boxes Monday and sent out extra garbage trucks to haul away spoiled food residents cleaned out of their refrigerators. ``Many people had their refrigerators stocked on Saturday and lost a whole week's supply of groceries,'' said Alderman Jesus Garcia. ``They're very disappointed and need some help.'' The utility said it gave aldermen 2,600 flashlights and 1,500 packages of food that were distributed Monday night. The city's food boxes contained powered milk, baby formula, canned goods and other non-perishable items. Commonwealth Edison said it didn't want to duplicate the city's efforts so it sent out food for the next couple of meals _ meat, bread, milk and baby food. The blackout occurred after a faulty transformer exploded, sparking a fire that damaged a plant feeding electricity to a large section of the West Side. Police said 49 people were arrested Saturday night and 30 Sunday night during looting. Martin Martinez, co-owner of a grocery, said he lost about $30,000 when his store was ransacked. Four people arrested were regular customers, Martinez said. ``It makes me feel hurt, betrayed,'' he said. City inspectors fanned out through the area, condemning food at groceries and meat markets that had spoiled because of no refrigeration.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Noah Robinson of Embezzlement, Racketeering
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson's half brother was convicted on 51 counts of racketeering, tax evasion, fraud and other charges related to a plot to skim $650,000 from six fast-food restaurants he operated. Prosecutors said Noah Robinson and four associates told workers at the Wendy's restaurants to turn off cash registers in the early morning and use calculators to record sales. Those transactions were never reported to government or corporate officials. Robinson denied ever cheating the Internal Revenue Service, the state or Wendy's. ``It was my money,'' Robinson said. ``Why should I steal?'' Also Monday, the jury convicted Noah Robinson's brother, John, and acquitted an employee, Darrell Butler. No verdict was rendered in the cases of Noah Robinson's other brother, George, and Noah's secretary and girlfriend, Alfreda Vaughn. U.S. District Judge George Marovich told the jury to resume deliberations today on those charges. The four were charged with 30 counts of racketeering, tax evasion and fraud. A sixth defendant, a bookkeeper, pleaded guilty earlier to two counts of wire fraud. Noah Robinson, who has been in jail since last year, could be sentenced to a maximum 20 years in prison on the single racketeering count. Each other count carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison. A sentencing date has not been set. Robinson also faces trial on separate federal racketeering charges in connection with a street gang. Last year, he was sentenced in South Carolina to 10 years in prison for aiding a fugitive who had stabbed a witness to the slaying of an employee of Robinson's. Robinson and Jackson, a Democratic candidate for president in 1984 and 1988, have the same father, but Jackson has described their relationship as strained. Jackson was born to an unwed mother.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Ending Conference with Charges of Blame Over S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's governors were ending their summer conference today hurling partisan charges of blame for the savings and loan crisis. Democratic governors, meeting privately, approved a resolution calling for a special prosecutor to investigate the widening crisis, which is estimated to cost $300 billion or more in a taxpayers bailout. A Republican ad in the Mobile Register blamed congressional Democrats for the S&L problems and provoked an angry response from Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, chairman of the Democratic governors. He called the ad ``deceitful'' and ``the most outrageous distortion of the truth.'' He blamed Republicans for upsetting the normal spirit of bipartisanship at the governors' conference and said the Bush administration has failed to lead on the S&L crisis. ``I'm surprised this is in the Mobile paper while the National Governors' Association is meeting,'' Celeste said. The ad pictured 12 congressional Democrats, including resigned House Speaker Jim Wright. It was signed by the Republican National Committee in Washington. It said, ``You won't see these Democratic `leaders' around Mobile,'' and ``They're the guys who let the S&L problem explode into a $325 billion national crisis.'' Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown, in Mobile for the meeting, said the ads were a sign of ``absolute panic'' by Republicans over the S&L debacle A Republican governor, John McKernen of Maine, said Democrats have been trying to use the S&L issue and ``Republicans want to make sure people realize there's enough blame to go around.'' The ad was an escalation in the growing partisan rancor over the S&L crisis as the fall elections approach. Another RNC ad ran a day earlier. The ads apparently were provoked by a resolution pushed by Democratic governors, and subject to vote by governors of both parties, calling for a national commission to investigate the S&L scandal. The White House on Monday said it rejected that suggestion. The bipartisan National Governors' Association was adjourning after a final session to consider resolutions to install Washington state Gov. Booth Gardner, a Democrat, as the new chairman, and Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, a Republican, as vice chairman. In party caucuses, Democrats elected Colorado's Roy Romer and Mississippi's Ray Mabus chairman and vice chairman of their Democratic Governors' Association Gardner said Monday he planned to shift the governors' association's focus to health care problems _ including cost containment and broader access to care for the poor _ during his one-year term. ``The arena is moving toward the states,'' he said. ``Neither the administration nor Congress wants to deal with it.'' Governors in both parties voiced concern about the growing size of the S&L bailout, topping $300 billion by some estimates. But the policy statement of concern approved by the association's executive committee _ and up for a vote today by the full association _ drew quick rejection from the White House and a Republican charge of partisanship. ``We do feel it is unnecessary to create another bureaucratic body,'' Stephen Hart, a deputy White House press secretary, said in Washington. ``We think the best thing to do is to work quickly on the current caseload with the funds and the processes we now have in place which are working,'' Hart said. ``We feel it's not time to point fingers but it's time to get the money that's owed to the depositors back in their hands.'' The statement on S&Ls asks Congress and the White House to establish a national commission to investigate the crisis. It was pushed by Virginia's Democratic Gov. Douglas Wilder, who said the commission should find the failures behind the S&L crisis and a way to provide ``equitable recovery'' of taxpayers' money. Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina said Democrats would find plenty of blame ``in their own back yard.'' The governors also were voting on a new policy statement recommending a national education commission. The panel _ including six governors, four members of Congress and four administration officials _ would assess how states and the federal government fare in meeting the governors' goals for education reform. Governors in both parties were united in opposing an administration plan, worked out with congressional Republicans, to raise federal revenue by limiting the federal tax deduction for state and local taxes. Democratic governors, led by Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, planned to send Bush a letter strongly urging him to drop that plan. They said it would encroach on state tax bases and penalize the very states that raised taxes on upper-income people to pay for services and balance their own budgets.

DOC.HEAD: US in Race Against Time To Recover Missing in Laos
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A decrepit Soviet truck lurches down the highway to Vietnam bearing clay-grimed wreckage of a U.S. aircraft. The export of war scrap is an everyday scene in eastern Laos, bringing cash to impoverished villagers. But widespread scavenging of aircraft crash sites is hindering U.S. efforts to account for Americans missing from the Indochina War. U.S. planes flew hundreds of thousands of bombing sorties against Communist targets in Laos between 1965 and 1973 and some never made it back to home base. Their crews make up most of the 533 U.S. servicemen still listed as missing in action in the country. The United States began ground searches for the MIAs in 1983, and Washington recently has issued upbeat statements telling of improving cooperation with the Laotian government. But progress remains slow, partly because of the difficulty in coordinating searches with understaffed Laotian ministries. So far, just 36 sets of remains have been identified and repatriated. Vital evidence that would help identify crash sites is being carted away for sale. And its not just aircraft scrap _ but human remains, too. Still, Washington have faced fewer problems cooperating with the government in Laos, the only Indochinese country with which it has diplomatic relations, than in Cambodia and Vietnam. The first six sets of suspected MIA remains were returned from Cambodia last week. A total of 1,678 Americans are missing in Vietnam, 83 in Cambodia while six are missing over China's coastal waters. In 1987, a group of private U.S. citizens and Republican congressmen began distributing leaflets in Laos offering a $2.4 million reward for the return of any live American prisoner. The offer has done irreparable harm to search efforts, U.S. officials say. They say they have been swamped by sightings of live ``missing'' Americans, mostly by Laotian refugees who want to resettle abroad. More than 17,000 interviews have not yielded a single credible case. ``People figure that if someone is offering so much money for a live American they are also willing to pay for bones,'' a U.S. official said. Even though U.S. policy does not sanction financial rewards for MIA remains, a slick cottage industry has grown up turning out bones and bogus dog tag military identifications. These are offered to U.S. searchers through middlemen in neighboring Thailand. ``Some people were even willing to dig up their mother's grave,'' said one American expert who did not want to be identified. A genuine American skeleton might be split up into several sets of remains in the hope of more rewards, and that reduces the chances of identifying the remains, a U.S. official said. Provincial officials say they are willing to support fully U.S. efforts to find their missing. But even they admit there is a tradeoff. ``Many planes came down here. People know where they are,'' said Lahoun Maprayvong, an district official in the heavily-bombed southeastern province of Savannakhet. Washington must do more to rebuild what the bombing destroyed, he said. ``It is according to the agreement. If they want to know where the bones are, the local people need help,'' he said. ``We need hospitals and schools.'' The United States gives some assistance to the Laotian government in return for MIA cooperation. But in June, Richard Solomon, Secretary of State for Asian affairs, admitted that Washington had ``been unable to address (Laotians') humanitarian concerns in a meaningful way.'' Lahoun says some villagers are unwilling to reveal crash sites. He says it's because they have bad memories of the bombing. But there's money to be made from the gleaning of U.S. crash sites _ and that can make a difference in rural areas where annual per capita income is below $170. Villagers and traders have systematically stripped many crash sites of anything of value. This includes many key aircraft parts bearing serial numbers that would help identify its crew. Aircraft aluminum is recycled into buckets, cooking pots, spoons, traditional jewelry, even river canoes. Traders say the top-quality metal fetches high prices abroad. It is trucked to Vietnam and Thailand, with some sent on to Japan and beyond. But the trade is slowing down. One by one, crash sites are denuded. Some sites have only a few fragments of metal and bone left. Only in the most remote regions are there undisturbed sites, U.S. officials say. They hope easing Cold War tensions and gradually improving relations with communist Indochina will improve access and allow more widespread searches.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: Pilot Accused of Flying Drunk Had High Tolerance For Booze
DOC.TEXT: One of three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying while intoxicated had a higher tolerance for alcohol because he is an alcoholic, his lawyer said today. In an opening statement at the pilots' trial, attorney Peter Wold said Capt. Norman Prouse has been an alcoholic for many years, but he said Prouse performed flawlessly during a March 8 flight from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis. ``Being an alcoholic does not mean you are under the influence of alcohol all the time,'' Wold said. ``A person who consumes alcohol builds up a tolerance.'' Wold and William Mauzy, the attorney for 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, said they would prove their clients were not impaired during the early-morning flight by the alcohol they consumed the previous night. Mauzy told the federal court jury to concentrate on the smooth operation of the 91-passenger flight instead of on the pilots' drinking the night before and the results of blood-alcohol tests taken after the flight. Kirchner, of Highland Ranch, Colo., piloted the Boeing 727. The plane, carrying 91 passengers, left as scheduled at 6:25 a.m., less than seven hours after Kirchner, Prouse of Conyers, Ga., and flight engineer Joseph Balzer of Antioch, Tenn., were seen drinking at a lounge in Moorhead. Balzer's lawyer was to make an opening statement later in the day. In her opening prosecution statement, Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega said that there would be much evidence about heavy drinking the night before the flight. She said witnesses will testify that there was tension between the pilots and some bar patrons that threatened to erupt into violence. De la Vega said blood-alcohol tests taken after the flight showed that Prouse still had an equivalent of eight drinks in his system while the plane was in the air and that Kirchner and Balzer had the equivalent of three beers each still in their systems. ``All three defendants were in fact under the influence of alcohol when they were operating Flight 650 that morning,'' she said. A bar patron tipped the Federal Aviation Administration and Northwest that the crew was ``quite intoxicated'' and might be piloting an early-morning flight, according to court records. An FAA investigator has testified the pilots were late reporting to the departure gate and that they smelled of alcohol. While he was phoning for instructions on how to handle the situation, the plane departed. When it arrived at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, an FAA official made a citizen's arrest of the trio. U.S. District Court Judge James Rosenbaum has said the trial is expected to last about two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Eager Vacationer Builds Cabin on Wrong Lot
DOC.TEXT: A Norwegian man felled trees, hauled lumber and built a road up a mountain in a race to finish his dream cabin in time for summer vacation. He got it done at the right time, but in the wrong place. The Oslo newspaper Verdens Gang reported Tuesday that the man, who was not identified, missed his own land by 330 feet and built his cabin on a neighboring forest lot. ``I was astounded,'' Hallvard Oerjasaeter told the newspaper after he discovered the cabin on his land. ``I thought maybe I had the map turned upside down but no, it was my forest.'' Oerjasaeter said the builder apologized profusely but ``that doesn't help much. I didn't want a cabin on my property.'' Verdens Gang said the cabin, near the central Norway town of Oeyer, will remain empty until the builder moves it or persuades Oerjasaeter to sell him the land.

DOC.HEAD: China Raises Domestic Postal Rates for First Time in 40 Years
DOC.TEXT: China's domestic postal rates were raised Tuesday for the first time in 40 years, the official media reported. The announcement, carried in most of the official press, said domestic postal rates have been raised 150 percent, from .85 cents to 2 cents for a local delivery and from 1.7 cents to 4 cents for inter-city letters. It said parcel post charges also were raised 150 percent. Overseas rates, which are much higher, were not mentioned in the announcement. China's postal services have been running deficits since the 1970s because of the lack of adjustments in the rates, the English-language China Daily said.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Pravda Goes To Press For Soviet Homosexuals
LaserPhoto AMS1
DOC.TEXT: ``Gays of the World Unite,'' says the masthead of Gay Pravda, a newspaper which went to press in the Netherlands this week for distribution among homosexuals in the Soviet Union. The free, eight-page Russian-language publication contains news on gay movements in the Netherlands and France and advice on how to guard against AIDS by using a condom, said Henk Krol of Holland's Gay Krant newspaper. Gay Pravda, which looks similar to the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda, is being published jointly by Gay Krant and the French publication Gai Pied, Krol said Tuesday. Krol said 85,000 copies will be mailed to the Soviet Union, some in large packages, others in letters addressed to individuals. Several gay Soviet soldiers stationed in East Germany have offered to help distribute the journal, Krol said. Krol conceded that many copies are likely to be confiscated by Soviet authorities. But he said the newspaper was a gesture of ``solidarity'' with homosexuals in the Soviet Union, where homosexual relations carry a maximum prison term of five-years. ``We hope this will contribute toward the setting up of a gay movement in the Soviet Union similar to those in Hungary, Poland and the GDR (East Germany),'' Krol said.

DOC.HEAD: To Sit or Squat: Tokyo Teachers Clash Over Toilets
DOC.TEXT: Times change and so should toilets, one school board in Tokyo has said. But board officials in Edogawa Ward trying to phase-out Japanese-style ``squat'' toilets in public schools have met opposition from parents and teachers who believe the Western-style ``sit-down'' version is unclean. It would stand to reason that millions of Westerners can't be wrong, but Edogawa school board official Maoto Mori said Tuesday that while most Japanese use Western toilets at home, many would prefer not to use them elsewhere. ``The problem is that you actually place your (bottom) directly on a Western-style toilet,'' Mori said. ``Some people, especially women, have said they just aren't comfortable using such toilets in public.'' But Mori says there is nothing to worry about: ``Concerns about sanitation are completely unnecessary.'' To assure comfort for all, Mori said the board has suggested that for every seven toilets in each school, five be Western and two Japanese. Three schools in the ward will remodel their lavatories this year, he said. One does not sit on, or in any other way come in contact with, a Japanese-style toilet, which is a porcelained hole in the floor. Many Japanese even refuse to touch the flush lever of public toilets with their hands, using their feet instead. The Edogawa school board has decided to remove Japanese-style toilets in elementary and junior high schools because of growing popularity of the Western toilet in private homes. According to estimates made by Toto, Japan's main toilet maker, 80 percent of all toilets in Japan, and nearly 100 percent of all household commodes, are Western-style. Mori said opposition to the plan ``has not been that great.'' But the school toilet dilemma warranted top-of-the-page treatment Tuesday in the domestic news section of Asahi Shimbun, a leading national newspaper. Under the headline, ``Teachers Say Wait! to Western Toilets,'' was a cartoon depicting two smiling youngsters, one foreign and one Japanese, using the contending varieties. The accompanying article quoted a teacher in one Edogawa elementary school as complaining that though the Japanese-style commodes only needed to be cleaned once a week, ``that won't be enough'' for the Western model. It said the Education Ministry has set no national guidelines regarding which kind of toilet schools should use. A school board official in Koto Ward, Edogawa's neighbor, said schools there were sticking to their Japanese facilities, although schools have one Western-style toilet on each floor. He said Japanese toilets are better because they are easier to clean and ``generally preferred by women.'' Japanese toilets also tend to make for shorter visits, perhaps also a plus in the eyes of Japan's often disciplinarian school teachers.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats: 100,000 Iraqi Troops Massed on Kuwaiti Border
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with delegates meeting privately; Pickup 6th graf, `The Iraq-Kuwait...
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegations met today to negotiate a bitter oil and border dispute. Diplomats said Iraq had massed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border, more than triple the number originally estimated. The reported Iraqi troop buildup, including hundreds of tanks and armored personnel carriers, dwarfs the Kuwaiti army, which has a total of about 20,000 troops. Persian Gulf-based diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the troops have been concentrated along the border since last week, when Iraq began threatening Kuwait and accusing the small Persian Gluf state of stealing oil and conspiring with the United States. But they said the number of troops was at first difficult to determine. Delegates from the feuding countries first met in the presence of Saudi King Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah. Later, the delegation leaders met privately. Kuwait was represented by its prime minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, and Iraq by Izzat Ibrahim, deputy chairman of its Revolutionary Command Council. The media were barred from the meetings, and no details were released. The Iraq-Kuwait dispute broke out on July 17 when Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of driving down oil prices by producing far above the quota set for them by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Saddam said the quota violations had cost his country $14 billion because of low oil prices. Iraq also demanded compensation for $2.4 billion worth of oil it claimed Kuwait stole from the Rumailah oil field which straddles the border between the two nations. Iraq also said Kuwait should forgive some $15 billion in loans it extended to Baghdad during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war that ended in 1988. Saddam's tough talk and show of force helped win his country, and other price hawks at OPEC's meeting last week, an agreement to raise oil prices from $18 to $21 a barrel, as well as pledges that Kuwait and other quota violators would reduce their production. Kuwaiti and Iraqi officials agreed to meet in Jiddah after intensive mediation efforts by King Fahd and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. Kuwaiti leaders had insisted that Iraq pull back its troops before conciliation talks could began, but later dropped its demand. Kuwaiti officials are also asking that Iraq agree to demarcate the disputed border between the nations, a move Iraq has refused. Iraq has historically laid claim to all of Kuwait and has long coveted the Kuwaiti islands of Bubiyan and Warba, which command access to southern Iraqi ports. Diplomatic sources have said they expected Arab mediators to persuade the two sides to sign a treaty of non-belligerency as a first step to protracted negotiations on borders and compensation. In Kuwait, newspapers expressed hope that the Jiddah meeting would lead to ``a final just settlement'' of the Iraq-Kuwait dispute in a manner ensuring the ``legitimate rights of each of the two countries.'' Baghdad papers adopted a harsher line, stressing that the Jiddah meeting was an opportunity for Kuwait to ``perceive Iraq's demands and respond to its rights.''

DOC.HEAD: After Three Centuries, Rembrandt Gets First International Tour
DOC.TEXT: Rembrandt will get his first one-man international show next year, when 130 of the 17th century Dutch Master's works will tour Berlin, Amsterdam and London, organizers said Tuesday. Although Rembrandt's paintings have been on tour before, the September-May show will be the first touring exhibition devoted exclusively to the greatest artist of the Netherlands' Golden Age, organizers said. ``As far as I know there has never been a traveling exhibition on Rembrandt before,'' said Uwe Wieczorek of Berlin's Gemaeldegalerie, which is putting together the tour together with Berlin's Kupferstichkabinett, Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum and London's National Gallery. The Rijksmuseum held the largest previous exhibition of Rembrandt's works in 1969, with about 20 works on display. The announcement of next year's tour comes on the heels of a major exhibit of the works of the 19th century Dutch impressionist, Vincent van Gogh. The four-month Van Gogh exhibit, which ended Sunday, drew more than 1.2 million visitors to Amsterdam's Van Gogh Museum and the Kroeller-Mueller Museum in the eastern Dutch city of Otterlo. Wieczorek said the plan of the exhibition is to ``show paintings once attributed to Rembrandt that are now being attributed to his pupils and compare them to paintings which we are absolutely sure were Rembrandt's.'' He added that the Rembrandt exhibition will mark the end of two decades of research into the master's works by art experts. That research is expected to show that half of the existing 400 paintings thought to be done by Rembrandt were actually painted by others, Wieczorek said. The exposition will display 50 paintings, 40 drawings and 40 etchings by Rembrandt and 45 or so works by his pupils. Among the paintings to be displayed are ``Woman Bathing,'' ``Jeremiah Lamenting the Destruction of Jerusalem'' and ``The Mennonite Preacher Anslo and His Wife.'' Rembrandt, who lived from 1606 to 1669, is considered the greatest of the Dutch Old Masters who flourished in the 17th century. His style is famous for its masterful contrast of light and darkness.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Slashes Money for Star Wars, MX and Midgetman Missiles
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with nearly $2 billion cut in SDI spending, no research and development money for MX and Midgetman missiles. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Military Construction
DOC.TEXT: A House Armed Services panel today slashed nearly $2 billion from President Bush's fiscal 1991 budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative, lawmakers said. In a closed-door session, the subcommittee on research and development approved spending $2.9 billion on the anti-missile shield, commonly known as Star Wars. Bush had sought $4.7 billion for SDI in the military budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The full Armed Services Committee was meeting later in the day to put the finishing touches on its $283 billion defense bill, a reduction of $24 billion from the president's original request in January. The research subcommittee also eliminated $548 million Bush sought for the MX nuclear missile on railroad cars and $202 million in research money for the Midgetman missile. Instead, the panel set up an advanced strategic missile pot of more than $600 million for development of the next generation of nuclear missiles. The subcommittee also called on Bush to make a recommendation in 90 days for one new missile. The full Armed Services Committee is expected to approve the actions of the research and development subcommittee, which overwhelmingly adopted its portion of the defense bill by a vote of 17-4. Following the lead of the procurement subcommittee, which on Monday night eliminated all funds Bush sought for the B-2 stealth bomber, the research subcommittee approved enough funds to complete the program at the 15 planes under development. In addition, the research panel approved $238 million for the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney wants to cancel. The procurement subcommittee had added $165 million for the aircraft, which takes off like a helicopter but can fly like a plane. ``It's exactly where we want it to be,'' said Rep. Curt Weldon, R-Pa., a supporter of the V-22 Osprey, which is manufactured in his district. The congressman said the House Armed Services actions set the stage for bargaining with the Bush administration and the Senate on saving the aircraft from the budget ax. Following the lead of its chairman, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., the panel on procurement and military nuclear systems adopted a plan Monday to remove the money the Pentagon requested to buy two stealth aircraft. To meet the House-approved level for military spending in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the procurement subcommittee had to slash $11 billion from Bush's overall request of $73 billion. Among the major subcommittee cuts were $1.3 billion for a program to move the MX nuclear missile from fixed silos to rail cars, a $1.2 billion reduction in the classified request for the Navy's A-12 attack plane and costly restrictions on the C-17 transport plane. The panel requires Cheney to certify that the first successful flight of the C-17 has occurred. After that certification, the Air Force may seek to reprogram funds to buy two aircraft. The administration had requested $2.1 billion for the two planes and related items. The panel eliminated the $1.3 billion Bush sought for the AMRAAM missile. It was the costly and controversial B-2 bomber, however, that suffered the deepest cut. Support for the radar-evading aircraft has eroded in Congress, where lawmakers have criticized the cost of a single plane _ nearly $865 million _ in a climate of fiscal constraint and a lessening Soviet threat to the West. Aspin dealt a serious blow to the program last week when he announced his support for legislation that would end production of the aircraft, which is manufactured by the Northrop Corp., at the 15 planes under development. The chairman's decision came despite Cheney's revised program, which calls for a total of 75 of the aircraft, instead of 132, with two of the planes being finished in fiscal 1991, rather than five. The aircraft still has support in the Senate, where the Armed Services panel approved the administration's request. Bipartisan efforts are expected, however, to kill the program when the full Senate takes up the defense bill later this week.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Defeats GOP Attempt to Reduce Labor Clout
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOP 11 grafs new, picks up 3rd graf pvs, With a.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate's Democratic majority turned back a Republican attempt today to reduce the political clout of unions in presidential and congressional elections. By a 59-41 vote, the Senate rejected a proposal to allow the nation's 17 million union members to demand a refund of any dues their unions spend on political activities. ``If you don't do anything about this sewer money from unions, I don't think you have campaign reform,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. ``Ninety percent goes to Democrats, even though 30 percent to 40 percent of union members are Republicans.'' The Senate defeated a similar GOP-sponsored plan by a 63-35 vote in May, rejecting a proposed amendment a bill easing restrictions on federal employees' political activities. That bill was subsequently vetoed by Bush and the Senate sustained his veto. Today, four Republicans, Sens. Alfonse D'Amato of New York, Mark Hatfield of Oregon, James Jeffords of Vermont and Ted Stevens of Alaska, joined all 55 Democrats to defeat an amendment to a campaign finance reform bill. Bush said a year ago Congress should expand a 1988 Supreme Court ruling to give workers a right to seek a refund of their dues spent by unions on politics. ``No American, not one, should be compelled to give money to a candidate against his or her will,'' he said. On Monday, Democrats overrode unanimous Republican opposition to a provision in the bill that would provide $20 million in public financing to Senate candidates every two years to buy television advertising time. The Supreme Court ruled in the 1988 case that a Bell System technician who paid fees to the Communications Workers of America as party of an agency shop contract with AT&T but was not a member of the union was entitled to a refund of the portion not spent directly on collective bargaining. Hatch's amendment today would have extended that right to union members as well as non-members covered by collective bargaining agreements. Hatch said most union members do not know that their leaders are spending up to $150 million of their dues every two years on political activities such as voter registration. With a bipartisan compromise on campaign finance reform out of reach for now, Republicans appeared content to let Democrats have their way in the knowledge that President Bush will veto it. ``We are faced with a bill that everyone knows isn't going anywhere, since it's a spending-limits bill that President Bush simply will not sign,'' said Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. Sen. David Boren of Oklahoma, the chief author of the Democratic measure, acknowledged the bill will never become law without support from Bush and congressional Republicans. But he expressed hopes the two sides will sit down in September to strike a deal once the House has passed its version. Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he hoped to bring two Democratic proposals and a Republican alternative up for votes before the House begins a five-week recess on Friday. Democratic sources, however, expressed doubts it could be fitted into this week's schedule. House Republicans accused Democrats in that chamber of cynically writing a bill that would establish spending ceilings but also preserve corporate, union and trade association PACs in the face of a certain veto by Bush. ``This is a joke,'' said House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. ``All the reform groups in the country are going to be enraged at them, so they want to get it over with, take their beating and go home.'' In contrast to an abolition of PACs first proposed by Bush and Republicans in the Senate and now reluctantly also endorsed by Senate Democrats, both parties' bills in the House would retain PACs. House Republicans would reduce the contributions a single PAC can make to any one candidate from the currently allowed $10,000 to $2,000 for both primary and general elections. Both Democratic proposals in the House would establish a spending ceiling of $550,000 on House races. One would limit PAC contributions to half that amount and the other would limit them to 40 percent, but with up to $100,000 in public financing for each qualifying candidate. Reform groups considered a litmus test the Senate's vote Monday to provide party nominees for the Senate from $180,000 to $1.1 million each in government vouchers to buy broadcasting time if they abide by spending limits. ``It's a back-door attack on spending limits and a test vote to see where they stand,'' said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, which supports taxpayer financing of election campaigns. All 44 Republicans present voted for the amendment by McConnell, the leading opponent of the Democratic plan to strike from it what it called a ``food stamp voucher for politicians.'' Two Democrats, Howell Heflin of Alabama and J. James Exon of Nebraska, both longtime opponents of public financing, also supported McConnell's amendment. In addition to the public financing of TV ads, the Democratic bill provides discount mail subsidies to candidates abiding by the spending limits as well as funds to counter broadcast ads by independent groups costing over $10,000. Additional public financing would also be provided to candidates whose opponents exceed the voluntary spending ceilings. McConnell's amendment would have eliminated all those potential public sources of money in the Democratic bill. ``Underneath the hood, it's the same old lemon running on taxpayer financing and spending limits,'' he said. The Democratic-proposed spending limits on Senate races _ based on the size of a state's voting-age population _ range from slightly under $2 million in less-populous states, such as Nevada, Montana and North Dakota, to $10.3 million in the largest state, California.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Abortion Law's Husband-Notification Requirement Questioned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to update with testimony today, picking up at the 3rd graf previous, ``The case.''
DOC.TEXT: Testimony in the federal court challenge to Pennsylvania's restrictive abortion law today took aim at a provision requiring women to notify their husbands before getting abortions. Attorneys for a group of doctors and abortion clinics seeking to overturn key sections of the law tried to show that battered women would not take advantage of exemptions in the law from the notification requirement. Psychologist Lenore Walker testified that ``battered women are very reluctant to talk about'' physical or emotional abuse because that forces them to relive the painful experience. As for the requirement that husbands be notified of abortions, ``forcing a battered woman to notify her husband is like giving him a hammer to beat her,'' she said. Under the law, women would have to sign a statement for their doctor certifying that they had informed their husband, or that they had not because they feared bodily harm if they did so, because the husband was not the father, because the pregnancy resulted from spousal rape, or because the woman could not locate the husband ``after diligent effort.'' The only exception for the requirement of a signed statement would be in the case of a medical emergency. Ms. Walker also criticized a section of the law that requires a 24-hour waiting period for an abortion. Ms. Walker said forcing an abused woman to wait 24 hours before obtaining an abortion would be detrimental. The case, which opened Monday, is being watched by activists on both sides of the abortion debate because of its potential to present a challenge to Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 ruling that established the right to an abortion. The lawsuit argues that the abortion controls passed by the Legislature in 1988 and 1989 infringe on the rights of women. The measures require a woman to notify her husband before obtaining an abortion and wait 24 hours between visiting a clinic and receiving an abortion. Doctors must offer counseling to women seeking abortions, and minors must get the consent of one parent or a court order to receive an abortion. Portions of the law have been blocked by the federal court pending a ruling on the lawsuit. Only Guam, a U.S. territory in the Pacific, has adopted more stringent controls. U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett III is not expected to rule until the fall, and whatever the outcome, appeals are likely. Kathryn Kolbert, an American Civil Liberties Union attorney for the plaintiffs, testified Monday the law erodes privacy rights established under Roe. ``This act puts government in the operating room and at the kitchen table with women making decisions on abortion,'' she said. ``It questions the ability of women to make independent decisions.'' Other witnesses characterized the law as studded with provisions that might not be in the best interest of the patient's health. Senior Deputy Attorney General Kate L. Mershimer, representing the state, predicted the restrictions would be upheld. ``We think we have the evidence in the current Supreme Court cases to uphold the statute,'' Ms. Mershimer said. Some sections of the law are similar to those ruled unconstitutional by the U.S. Supreme Court in a 1986 Pennsylvania case. The state's 1988 law was largely an attempt to redraft many of the voided provisions. The 1989 law was passed after the Supreme Court, in a Missouri case, gave states greater leeway to restrict abortion.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Wynonna Judd, the daughter and lead singer of the Judds' mother-daughter country music duo, has announced her engagement to a songwriter. The singer, 26, is engaged to Tony King, who is best known as the co-writer of Ricky Van Shelton's No. 1 country hit ``I've Cried My Last Tear for You.'' King also is a guitarist and harmony singer for country singer Vince Gill. The two have not set a wedding date, spokesman Chuck Thompson said Monday. ``They're very, very happy ... ecstatic, as you might imagine,'' Thompson said. Judd and her mother are known for their hit records such as ``Grandpa'' and ``Mama He's Crazy.''

Actor Ed Asner on Tuesday compared giving the Khmer Rouge a role in a new Cambodian government with allowing the Nazis to form a new government. The actor, known for his roles as crusty newsmen on the television series ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ``Lou Grant,'' toured Cambodia last week with representatives of Operation U.S.A., a Los Angeles-based relief organization that funds medical training in the Southeast Asian nation. Asner said he became concerned about Cambodia when he realized the proposed transitional government recognized by the United Nations included the Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of people during its 1975 to 1978 reign. Vietnam installed the current communist government after invading in late 1978. The Khmer Rouge now dominate a guerilla coalition fighting the government. ``I don't know why the Vietnamese are more hated than the Khmer Rouge,'' Asner said.

Comedian Bill Cosby will be awarded an honorary doctorate degree from Rust College in November. The actor and star of television's ``The Cosby Show'' will be in northern Mississippi on Nov. 18 to receive his degree during Rust College's 124th Founder's Day celebration. Mayor Johnny Ford, the first black chief executive of Tuskegee, Ala., also will be given an honorary degree. Rust College is a predominantly black, liberal arts college founded in 1866. The school has an enrollment of about 950.

Singer Barry Manilow is searching for the perfect Lola and Tony. He is looking for a cast for ``Barry Manilow Presents Copacabana,'' an original stage production derived from his 1978 hit song, ``Copacabna.'' It's a story of two young singers falling in love as they try to make it big, and the evil Rico who comes between them. Manilow held open auditions in New York on Monday and Tuesday. He plans to move his hunt to the other coast later in the week, with auditions Thursday and Friday at Landmark Studios. Manilow is producing and directing the play, scheduled to open in Atlantic City, N.J., on Sept. 25. The story was made into a TV movie in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Conferes with Congressional Leaders on Budget
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New material, editing throughout with White House reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The White House expressed frustration with stalled budget talks and prodded Democrats today to come up with their own plan to reduce the $169 billion federal deficit. ``An agreement was made to simultaneously table proposals. We are ready. They are not,'' deputy White House press secretary Alixe Glen said after President Bush's latest round of talks with the leaders of Congress. ``That's where the level of frustration is coming in.'' Once the Democrats put a package on the table, ``we can continue to move forward, probably at a faster pace,'' she said. ``I don't think anybody sandbagged anybody,'' Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., the House majority leader, said after the hour-long Oval Office meeting. Gephardt said he did not think ``there was any reneging'' on the Democrats' part about putting proposals on the table simultaneously. Gephardt added, ``There may have been some miscommunication about what was supposed to happen.'' ``It's safe to assume that everyone is frustrated. ... We've been at this for 83 days,'' Ms. Glen told reporters. ``I think all sides would have hopes that we would have been a little farther along by this point.'' Gephardt said the two sides will decide ``in the next few days'' whether to keep negotiating into August or wait until September to put their plans for slashing spending on the table. If they decide to go ahead now, Gephardt said, it could mean keeping Congress in session or calling the lawmakers back from vacation to ratify a deal. Today's meeting took place against the backdrop of complaints from GOP leaders upset with Democrats for failing to propose a deficit-cutting plan. Details of Republican-favored tax increases began filtering out of the talks last week. ``The question is when is the best time to try to put together the final disagreements, to bridge them and then to put a deal before the American people and Congress,'' said Gephardt. ``There are good arguments on both sides for August, and there are other arguments for September. It will be decided in the next few days.'' If the negotiators wait until September, it will allow Bush and the lawmakers to take their summer vacations without embracing controversial packages of spending cuts and revenue increases. But pushing the showdown into September would bring the summit negotiators closer to the Gramm-Rudman deadline of Oct. 1, when automatic cuts would be inflicted on most federal programs if Bush and the lawmakers fail to produce their own agreement. Gephardt said the negotiations, now in their 12th week, have accomplished ``quite a lot,'' including the basic agreement to reduce the deficit by $50 billion in the first year and $500 billion over five years. In the aftermath of news reports revealing higher taxes and other unpopular elements of an administration budget plan, GOP leaders spent an hour with Bush on Monday discussing what their next step should be. ``I don't think the president has been nearly tough enough on the Democrats,'' Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., told reporters after Monday's session. ``All the Republicans advised him it was time to call their hand.'' Congressional Democrats said they feel little pressure to quickly present a deficit-cutting plan to Republican budget negotiators. ``Plans put forward by leaks never cause response requirements on the other side of the negotiations,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. The GOP leaders said that among the options they discussed was having Bush call a special session to keep Congress in town in August and force lawmakers to work out a budget deal. ``Keep them here, and turn the air conditioning off,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass. Canceling the cherished annual summer recess, however, would anger many members of Congress, some leaders acknowledged. ``The president doesn't want to alienate members when he wants to work with Congress,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. The administration plan includes higher taxes on alcohol and a limit on the federal tax deductibility of state and local income taxes. Congress' month-long recess is set to begin over the next two weeks. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. The talks began May 15.

DOC.HEAD: No Agreement on Forced Return of Boat People
With AM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The failure of Secretary of State James A. Baker III to forge an agreement with Southeast Asian nations on the fate of boat people leaves the refugees in danger of being pushed back out to sea. Baker ended a five-day tour of Southeast Asia on Tuesday, leaving Singapore for the Soviet Union for meetings with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. While Baker was in Southeast Asia, both sides had hoped a solution would be found for the 130,000 boat people _ mostly from Vietnam and Cambodia _ in refugee camps in the region. Southeast Asian officials say about 80 percent are non-political refugees and should be repatriated. The United States and Vietnam have refused to sanction the compulsory return of refugees who flee their homeland for economic reasons, rather than political persecution. Shortly before Baker arrived, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations comprising Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines and Brunei, declared their right to refuse temporary refuge to boat people. Malaysia has taken the lead, pushing off more than 8,700 people in the past year, according to refugee workers. At the association's annual meeting, Baker sought compromise but issued a veiled warning. Going it alone, he said in an apparent reference to Malaysia, ``would leave the nations of this region to reap a whirlwind of humanity without international support.'' Baker, however, agreed to create a new category for refugees who do not object to being sent home. He also offered to ``join with others in a new best effort to resettle or return all asylum seekers by the end of 1992.'' Boat people in the new category would qualify for repatriation after specified review procedures were completed and other conditions met, U.S. officials said. ``We appreciate these moves, but we in ASEAN think they don't yet go far enough,'' Indonesia Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said referring to the Southeast Asian association. In danger of collapse is the Comprehensive Plan of Action signed in Geneva by 35 nations in June 1989. That stipulates Southeast Asian countries should continue to provide shelter for all who arrive but boat people would no longer automatically qualify for refugee status. Instead, refugees would be screened to determine whether they had a justifiable fear of political persecution or were simply seeking a better life in the West. Economic migrants would be sent back home. In an attempt to break the stalemate, the European Community has offered financial incentives designed to encourage more voluntary repatriation and ease the burden of maintaining boat people in Southeast Asian Camps. The offer has been well-received, said Abel Matutes, EC commissioner of North-South affairs, and more details on the offer were to be given to the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees by October. It was not immediately clear when the offer was made.

DOC.HEAD: Temblor Rocks Southwestern Greece, No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake rocked southwestern Greece on Tuesday, but police reported no damage or injuries. The Athens Geodynamic Institute said the quake struck at 9:50 a.m. in the sea west of Filiatra on the Peloponnesus peninsula. It measured 5 on the Richter scale, and its epicenter was about 135 miles southwest of Athens. A police officer contacted in the region said there were no reports of damages or injuries. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A magnitude 5 quake can cause considerable damage in a highly populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Emergency Food Deliveries Resume in Uganda
DOC.TEXT: A United Nations relief agency resumed deliveries of emergency food to northeastern Uganda on Tuesday after a three-week suspension caused by an attack on a convoy. Appolo Lawoko, an employee of the World Food Program, said seven trucks loaded with 210 tons of corn headed for the arid Karamonja region under a military escort. The World Food Program stopped deliveries July 7 after unidentified gunmen killed a driver and seriously wounded two people loading the trucks. Only 1,173 of the 5,000 tons of grain the agency earmarked for Karamonja this year had been delivered when the attack occurred. Relief officials in Kampala say an estimated 220,000 people in the region are threatened with famine caused by a severe drought. In 1980, starvation caused by a similar drought killed thousands of mainly nomadic people in Karamonja, which borders Kenya in the east and Sudan in the north. The region is also home to remnants of insurgent groups who took up arms against President Yoweri Museveni after he seized power in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Murders Headed for a Record Year, Senators Told
DOC.TEXT: The nation's murder toll is headed toward a record high this year, with an 8 percent expected increase in the number of slayings that is attributable mainly to drug-related crime, the Senate was told today. ``If this pace continues _ and there is every reason to believe it will _ 1990 will be the bloodiest year in American history,'' said Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden, D-Del. The committee issued a forecast of 23,220 murders in America this year at the present rate. That is 2,000 or 8 percent over the 1989 toll. The total would also top the previous record high of 23,040 murders in 1980. Scarce supplies of cocaine in the nation's major cities have contributed to the carnage, causing drug pushers to fight each other for turf, the committee said. It also blamed the proliferation of assault rifles. ``These firearms have become the weapons of choice for drug dealers and the weapons of doom for law enforcement personnel,'' said a report prepared by the panel. It said a third cause is a fresh wave of teen-agers, the offspring of the so-called baby boomers, entering the high-crime years. The projected toll would make 1990 the third straight year of increasing murders in the United States. The murder toll actually dropped 18 percent between 1980 and 1985 but has increased 22 percent since then, the committee said. ``The nation is faced with an immediate peril and the situation is doomed to get worse unless we take action today,'' Biden said. He urged swift House action on a Senate-passed omnibus crime bill with a ban on nine semiautomatic assault weapons and the death penalty for 34 federal offenses. A hush fell over the hearing room as Dr. Lynn Richardson, associate chief of emergency services at Harlem Hospital Center in New York, told of a young woman rushed in several weeks ago. The right side of her head had been blown away by a slug from a high-powered rifle in an apparent drug-corner shootout. Doctors managed to save a 6 1@2-month-old fetus, ``the ultimate innocent bystander,'' she said. The woman died but the child is still clinging to life, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Increased After Rash of Robberies In Colonial Williamsburg
DOC.TEXT: Two tourists were wounded during the latest in a string of robberies in the city's restored colonial town. Patrols will be increased in the dimly lit area, police said Tuesday. Five armed robberies have taken place in Williamsburg's historic area since May, said police Maj. Mike Yost. He said patrols in the one-square-mile area will be increased from one police cruiser to three. The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation also has increased security in the area. The foundation maintains the restored buildings in the historic area, which is open to pedestian traffic. The tourists, Anne and David Edds of Swayzee, Ind., were both shot in the head during the robbery attempt Monday evening. Police said two teen-age boys accosted the couple, demanded money and threatened to shoot them. The youths fled after one shot the couple when no money was produced. Mrs. Edds was in satisfactory condition with a bullet lodged in her face at at Williamsburg Community Hospital, said W.M. McCracken, vice president of nursing. Her husband was treated for a bullet wound to the side of his face.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of New Homes Surge in June
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes surged 8 percent in June, the sharpest increase since November, the government said Tuesday in a report that many analysts said indicates the sluggish housing industry has bottomed out. ``We believe that the second quarter was the low point,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. He and other analysts said they expected continued but subdued growth in both new and existing single-family markets for the remainder of the year. The Commerce Department said new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 581,000 units after posting a revised 2.3 percent gain in May. May sales first were reported last month to have risen just 0.4 percent, the first advance in five months. Despite the increase in June, new homes sales for the first six months of 1990 have fallen 9.7 percent below sales of the first half of 1989 when they totaled 340,000 units. The June increase was the sharpest since a similar 8 percent gain in November. Analysts attributed the increase to lower mortgage rates, which they said should spur renewed interest in home sales for the remainder of the year. ``We expect mortgage rates to trend downward in the weeks ahead, which should boost sales of new homes as well as existing homes,'' said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. The Realtors reported last week that sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million units. It was the first increase since a 3.2 percent gain in November. The average rate for 30-year, conventional fixed-rate mortgages ranged from 10.29 percent to 10.10 percent in June, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The rate had dropped to 9.98 percent by last Friday. Nevertheless, Mark Obrinksy, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, and other analysts said they did not expect rates to fall much farther and they predict only a gradual increase in future sales. In addition to the ``psychological factor'' of single-digit rates, Richard Peach, deputy chief economist with the Mortgage Bankers of America, said favorable weather also enticed buyers in June. ``We had a very soggy April and May, particularly in the eastern part of the country,'' Peach said. ``When it's cold and damp, people don't like to go out and shop around for new houses.'' Sales in the Northeast, which have been sluggish for more than a year, jumped 36 percent to an annual rate of 102,000 units. Sales also rose in the South, up 13.6 percent to an annual rate of 243,000 units. But they dropped elsewhere _ down 5.8 percent to an annual rate of 146,000 units in the West and off 4.3 percent to an annual rate of 90,000 units in the Midwest. The Commerce Department said the median price of a new home rose 1.6 percent to $129,900. The median income means half of the homes cost more and half less. The average price advanced 2.1 percent to $152,900.

DOC.HEAD: First Gene Therapies Approved for Treating Fatal Diseases
DOC.TEXT: A federal committee today approved history's first use of gene therapy to treat fatal diseases. The Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee of the National Institutes of Health approved two procedures in which foreign genes will be inserted into the cells of patients who have one of two fatal diseases. The therapies are for treatment of patients with a malignant skin cancer and for children with an inherited immune system deficiency. ``This is an historic decision,'' said Gerard J. McGarrity, the chairman of the committee. ``What we have done today is add gene therapy to vaccines, antibiotics and radiation in the medical arsenal. ``Medicine has been waiting thousands of years for this,'' said McGarrity, the president of the Coriell Institute for Medical Research in New Jersey. The cancer therapy will involve putting a gene that causes cells to produce a protein called tumor necrosis factor into special white blood cells. These cells will then be injected into the patient and the tumor necrosis factor will attack the skin cancer tumors. The immune disease treatment calls for placing a gene into white blood cells of patients who are born without this gene. The gene in a normal person produces an essential enzyme for the development of the immune system. Children born without this gene have virtually no immune system or bodily defense against disease. The most famous patient with this immunity disorder was a boy in Houston, known only as David, who spent his whole life in a plastic bubble. McGarrity said that the 17-member committee voted unanimously for the cancer therapy and had only one dissenting vote for the immunity disorder therapy. Gene therapy has been controversial and a number of groups have resisted its implementation. But the vote today met almost no objections from people attending the open meeting. Some groups fear that gene therapy could be used to manipulate normal human development and create genetic abnormalities. Dr. French Anderson, director of the immune deficiency treatment program, said that abuses of this technique are guarded against by a torturous pathway to approval. He said it has taken more than three years and presentations to more than a dozen committees and hearings for the therapy to be approved. Despite difficulties, Anderson said the therapy ``is so powerful that it could be abused and there needs to be firm safeguards in place.''

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Child in Nine Days Killed by Stray Bullets; Arrests Announced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with arrests announced; Picks up 3rd graf, pvs, `Mayor David...'. SUBS 6th graf pvs, `The latest...', to delete now-redundant first reference to Rayvon Jamison.
DOC.TEXT: Three men were arrested and charged with murder today in the death of a 9-month-old boy gunned down a day earlier in a Bronx apartment, the city's fourth child shooting victim in just over a week. The suspects were charged with second-degree murder and possession of a deadly weapon, said Police Commissioner Lee Brown. A 9mm handgun allegedly used to kill the infant was recovered at the home of one suspect, he said. The arrests come less than 24 hours after the slaying of Rayvon Jamison, who was killed when someone fired seven bullets through the door of his family's apartment. Charged in the murder were Anthony Rupert, 18, and two cousins, Bobbie West, 18, and Mike Solomon, 22, all of the Bronx, said Brown. The attack followed a fight between Rayvon's uncle and several neighborhood men, authorities said. ``No remorse was shown by the three men'' when they learned of the child's death, said Detective Ellen Hale of the 44th Precinct. On Monday, mourners packed a church for the funeral of 9-year-old Veronica Corales, who was shot in the head as she slept in a family car after coming home from a family outing at an amusement park. Mayor David Dinkins seized on the slayings to call for a federal ban on all assault weapons. ``Do we need further proof of what happens when we allow so many people to be armed with so many guns firing so many bullets?'' he asked. ``Our children are dying. These young people, these babies, had the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, but their rights have been blown away. And for what?'' Rayvon, the latest victim, was in a walker when he was struck in the shoulder by two of seven shots pumped into the apartment, police said. Nine adults, including his mother, were home at the time. Rayvon's slaying in a working-class, black and Hispanic neighborhood in the Bronx was the fourth in New York City in nine days of a child hit by a bullet apparently meant for someone else. The three other slayings occurred in Brooklyn. ``It's crazy. You're not safe in your own house no more,'' said Ramon Garcia, who lives across the street from where Rayvon was shot. Veronica was struck July 22 by a stray bullet as she slept in her mother's lap in a parked car. Shortly after her funeral, an indictment was unsealed charging Dorian Daughtry, 22, a former minor league baseball player, with murder in the slaying. One-year-old Yaritimi Fruto was killed last week by gunmen who also killed her father. Ben Williams, 3, also was killed last week, when someone fired 18 shots through the door of his grandmother's apartment while he slept on a fold-out couch. There were no arrests in those shootings.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Retailer Buys Famous Toy Store Chain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `FAO Schwarz...', to CORRECT that Morse leaving company. A version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: FAO Schwarz, a symbol of kiddie chic in America for decades, has been purchased by the Netherlands' most prestigious department store chain, the Dutch buyer announced today. NV Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer, or KBB, said it bought FAO Schwarz for an undisclosed amount, and would use the American toy palace's prestigious name to expand its U.S. operations. ``FAO Schwarz is the pre-eminent retailer of fine toys in the world and we are committed to building on FAO's tradition of excellence,'' Arie Maas, Chairman of KBB, said in a statement. At the up-market end of KBB's Dutch operations is the Bijenkorf department store chain, which sells exclusive fashions, cosmetics and furniture, as well as elaborate toys. Its flagship store is a landmark in the center of Amsterdam, right across the street from the city's royal palace. Bijenkorf means beehive in Dutch. The publicly owned corporation said it had bought all of FAO Schwarz's 17 stores, including the two most prominent outlets in New York and San Francisco as well as stores in Boston, Chicago and Beverly Hills, Calif. The purchase includes the toy chain's catalog business. KBB's 1989 sales totaled $1.67 billion. FAO Schwarz, which was founded in 1862, has been privately owned by a group led by Peter C. Morse, chairman, and Peter L. Harris, president and chief executive officer. Morse is leaving the company, but Harris and the rest of the present management team are expected to continue in their roles after the acquisition. In its 100-plus years of operation, FAO Schwarz has become a toy retailing phenomenon known for lavish displays and elaborate presentations of new products. Among the cities with branches are Boston, Chicago and Beverly Hills, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: First Oil From 500,000-Gallon Spill Reaches Land
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The barges...', to CORRECT that tanker Greek-registered not Liberian.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
With PM-Exxon Inquiry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard said 500,000 gallons of oil leaked into Galveston Bay from two barges, 10 times its original estimate, and some oil floated ashore from a slick up to 15 miles long. None of the oil had yet touched environmentally sensitive marshes, the Coast Guard said. State officials talked with the Coast Guard today about using oil-eating bacteria on the heavy crude. Skimmer ships and floating booms were sent to the area. Some streamers of oil had reached the Gulf of Mexico, the Coast Guard said. The barges, carrying a total of 1.68 million gallons of heavy refinery oil, collided Saturday with the Greek-registered tanker Shinoussa while being towed by a tug through the bay. The tanker, while damaged, did not leak any of its 24,900 metric tons of jet fuel. Some of the oil had reached the Texas City Dike and Pelican Island and Redfish Island _ peninsulas in Galveston Bay _ this morning, the Coast Guard said after officials flew over this site. `Those areas aren't heavily populated with wildlife,'' Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson said today. ``There are other areas in Galveston Bay where there's a lot of wildlife and we're still concerned about those areas.'' The spill already has killed fish around Redfish Island and officials were worried about its impact on wildlife in marshes and bogs in the area. No oil-covered birds had been found yet. ``Any way that spill heads, it is going toward wetlands and estuaries, with unique species of herons, egrets, wading birds and nesting birds. And it is very probable that we are going to have impact on them soon,'' Nelson said Monday. Environmentalists criticized the cleanup effort, saying emergency officials wasted precious time getting skimmers and oil booms to the site. ``We're not happy with that either,'' Nelson said today. ``We're also not happy that it took two days to get skimmers on site, either.'' He blamed the delay on problems getting permission for skimmers from the Clean Gulf Co-Op, an organization of Gulf shippers, since the barge does not belong to the co-op. Texas Water Commission Chairman Buck Wynne and Blanton Moore, a representative of state Land Commissioner Garry Mauro, met with the Coast Guard today for permission to put oil-eating microbes on the spill. Mauro said the microbes were successfully tested on a spill after the June 8 explosion on the Mega Borg. Almost 4 million gallons of light crude spilled into the Gulf from the stricken Norwegian supertanker. The revised estimate of the size of the latest spill came after crews Monday finished removing oil from a listing barge, pushed it aground and determined how much oil was left in a second barge partly submerged in the channel. The second barge stopped leaking Monday evening, about 50 hours after the collision, they said. Officials estimated 48,000 gallons of oil leaked from the listing barge, meaning most of the oil came from the nearly sunken vessel. Divers today placed cable slings around the barge, which was sitting on a ledge. Nelson said the sling operation had to be handled carefully because a mistake could send the barge toppling into the 40-foot-deep shipping channel and more oil could spill. Thousands of feet of collection booms surrounded that barge. Any spill over 100,000 gallons is considered major, said the Coast Guard, which originally estimated 50,000 gallons had spilled.
