The spill forced the closing of the busy channel and idled nearly 60 ships in the gulf and at Houston's docks. ``It is holding up traffic and will continue to do that. It is unlikely that channel traffic will be opened up'' today, Nelson said. Nelson said the oil was not as toxic to wildlife as that spilled in the Gulf by the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg earlier this summer. But it is thicker and more ``environmentally persistent'' in its ability to stick to shorelines, he said. The Mega Borg spilled 3.9 million gallons.

DOC.HEAD: US Places Curbs on Exports to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The United States is placing new restrictions on exports of items to Iraq which could be used for that country's development of missiles or chemical and biological weapons, Assistant Secretary of State John H. Kelly told Congress on Tuesday. And he said the Bush administration also has under ``active consideration'' the step of returning Iraq to the U.S. list of nations which sponsor or support terrorism, which would carry additional economic sanctions. Iraq's threats against against neighboring Kuwait and its massing of troops along the two countries' disputed border are just the latest moves by President Saddam Hussein that cause ``grave concern'' in the United States, Kelly told the House Foreign Affairs Middle East subcommittee. ``Iraq is a major power in the region. This power carries responsibility with it,'' he said in a statement. Kelly's comments, the most detailed public explanation yet of administration moves against Iraq, came a day before the full Foreign Affairs Committee was to vote on much tougher legislation proposed by Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., imposing a range of sanctions on Iraq. The State Department has asked the Commerce Department to place restrictions on export of items with potential weapons uses that are much like the curbs already in place for nuclear technology, according to Kelly's testimony and to congressional sources briefed on the moves. The change would mean a license is required for any item that could be destined for a program of chemical or biological weapons development, or for use in developing missile delivery systems for weapons, Kelly said. New restrictions should be put in place within the next month, he said under questioning from the subcommittee chairman, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind. Kelly added that the sanctions, which stem from worries about the proliferation of destabilizing weaponry in the region and Hussein's threats to use them, would not have a major impact on bilateral trade. The United States sold some $1.3 billion worth of goods to Iraq last year, most of it farm commodities. The sanctions are being imposed under a law that allows the government to restrict exports in order to distance the United States from the activities of other governments which it finds objectionable. Asked whether the administration contemplates additional steps aimed at Iraq's alleged support for terrorists, Kelly said: ``We are reviewing that matter and we have that under active consideration.'' But he said the administration remains opposed to the Berman legislation because it would allow the president little flexibility to lift the sanctions unless he could certify that Iraq was meeting human rights, weapons proliferation and terrorism concerns. ``We believe what are needed are devices to modulate actions against countries, not meataxe approaches,'' Kelly told the subcommittee. Of the overall situation in the Middle East, Kelly said tensions are higher than a year ago. But asked by Hamilton if he were fearful of war, Kelly responded: ``If I were I don't think I'd want to say it before this body.'' Kelly also denied an assertion by Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., that sour personal relations between President Bush and Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir have hampered progress in the Middle East peace process. ``To personalize the relationship ... does a disservice to both governments,'' he said. But Levine contended that the situation is nonetheless real. ``There is no warmth'' between the two leaders, he said, adding that Bush often omits mention of Shamir when talking about his contacts with leaders in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Civil War Bogged Down in Rebel Infighting
DOC.TEXT: Hopes that Liberia's bloody civil war would end with a quick victory over President Samuel Doe have vanished as rebels hungry for power and vengeance fight among themselves. Rebel leader Charles Taylor, who had bragged in interviews that he would chase Doe from his presidential mansion in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, remains bogged down in fighting six miles away. Fighters loyal to Prince Johnson, who split with Taylor three months ago, have fought their way into the city center, where Doe remains in his fortified Israeli-built mansion, guarded by loyal troops. Doe has refused to resign. At one stage in the siege of the capital, the rebels suddenly withdrew from their positions around Monrovia, reportedly because Johnson's forces had attacked Taylor's men. ``Doe does not want to relinquish power. Charles Taylor wants power at all cost. Prince Johnson wants to get rid of both,'' said a senior Western diplomat who has been monitoring reports on the fighting from his Monrovia embassy. Liberia's 2.4 million people are the big losers. Since the civil war began the vast majority of casualities have been civilians. Doe's soldiers began the slaughter in northern Nimba County, where 100 rebels invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast on Christmas Eve. Angry at their inability to halt the rebel advance, frustrated troops turned on civilians of the Gio and Mano tribes, killing, raping, looting and setting homes ablaze. The two tribes form the main support base for the rebels. Initially, the guerrillas did not attack civilians and appeared to be ``the good guys'' in a battle against a corrupt and nepotistic government that brutally suppressed opposition. But this lasted only as long as they were moving through through territory populated by tribes friendly to their cause. As soon as the rebels advanced southward into territory populated by tribes that backed Doe, reports of the murder of civilians began to emerge. Most of those killed were members of Doe's tribe, the Krahn, or the Mandigo tribe, which also backs the government. Monday morning, government troops went on a rampage inside a refugee center in the capital and carried out one of the worst known massacres of the war. Survivors said 600 people, mostly women and children who had been trying to flee the violence, were killed. The U.S. State Department put the casualties at 200. The victims were from the Gio and Mano tribes. Doe denied reponsibility for the church atrocity and said it was carried out by rebels dressed in army uniforms. But survivors said they were attacked by soldiers speaking Krahn. The standoff in Monrovia bears an eerie resemblance to the 1985 coup attempt led by Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa. The general, whose forces included Johnson, took the entire city of Monrovia by surprise. But Doe and his troops emerged from the mansion and killed them. Soldiers subsequently killed thousands of Gios and Manos in Nimba County, setting the stage for the rebel invasion late last year. For a time it appeared the rebels would quickly take Monrovia. Western diplomats in the capital, whose governments had switched sides and now opposed the president, told reporters Doe's soldiers would flee at the first sight of rebels. That was six weeks ago. Instead, Taylor's National Patriotic Front has been unable to break the remnants of Doe's 72nd Infantry Battalion. As Taylor remained bogged down outside Monrovia, Johnson's men waded through a swamp last week to launch a surprise attack on Doe's forces in downtown Monrovia. The arrival of Johnson's men dashed hopes of a simple ending to the war. Taylor accused Johnson of being a tool of the United States, which he said was trying to stop him from taking power. Johnson said Taylor was a Communist on Libya's payroll. Taylor is of mixed Americo-Liberian and native African ancestry. The Americos, descendants of freed American slaves who founded the country, ruled Liberia until Doe took power in a 1980 coup. Doe's coup was hailed throughout the country because it ended the domination and subjugation of native Liberians by Americos who, like Doe's Krahn people, constitute only 5 percent of the population. Johnson is the son of Gio parents, and there were fears the ethnic background of the two men could lead to a new war.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Law Changes Urged to Attract Foreign Scientists
DOC.TEXT: The United States needs more scientists from abroad and must change its laws to attract them or it will see other countries get the advantage, American scientists told Congress on Tuesday. ``Some countries like Taiwan and (South) Korea have programs to repatriate their science and engineering nationals from the United States, offering them financial inducements, including cash incentives for repatriation, air fares and other benefits,'' said Karl Willenbrock, assistant director of the National Science Foundation. He said about a third of the advanced researchers in government laboratories are foreigners who were let in only on condition they return home when their projects are done. There is evidence that Asian scientists who have become U.S. citizens are going back to their native countries in growing numbers because of better opportunities, said Philip E. Schambra, director of the Fogarty International Center at the National Institutes of Health. Schambra said efforts of the 12 countries in the European Community to dismantle barriers among them are expected to create five to six million new jobs in service, research and development. This is happening just as scientists from Eastern Europe are getting a new chance to move, Schambra pointed out. Meanwhile, he said, Australia, New Zealand and Canada have policies to attract highly skilled immigrants. ``How we deal with this issue will to a large degree determine the pace of research progress on AIDS, cancer (treatment) and other public health priorities,'' he predicted. The laws the scientists want to change favor the admittance of foreigners related to people already in the United States. Family members accounted for 75 out of every 100 legal immigrants in 1987, while only four out of 100 came for jobs, said Ronald A. Tekely of the National Foreign Trade Council, an association of U.S. companies involved in world trade. ``It is obvious that our current immigration laws do not promote the immigration of highly skilled people, despite the shortages in certain occupations,'' Tekely said. Willenbrock said the United States is not producing enough scientists and engineers of its own. ``Increasingly, women and minorities will constitute a larger percentage of our work force and these groups historically have low rates of participation in the sciences and engineering,'' he noted. All testified before the subcommittee on Science, Research and Technology of the House Science Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Thatcher to Address Aspen Institute
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will help celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Aspen Institute, an organization designed to help global leaders focus on critical issues. ``We wanted the strongest leaders we could get,'' said David T. McLaughlin, president and chief executive officer of the institute. ``It's the first time two heads of state have come. We're absolutely delighted.'' Bush is scheduled to give the opening address Thursday at the institute and Thatcher, who arrives Wednesday, will give the closing address on Sunday. The theme of this year's symposium is ``Renewal: Leadership and Values for the 21st Century.'' The nonprofit institute is the brainchild of the late Chicago businessman Walter Paepcke, whose dream was to help refocus the world's attention on the cultural contributions of Germans at a time when its eyes were turned to the brutal horrors left by the Nazi regime. In 1950, he convinced humanist Dr. Albert Schweitzer to travel from his home in Africa to Aspen to help celebrate the 200th birthday of German poet and statesman Wolfgang Goethe. That was the seed that launched the $11 million-a-year institute. ``The principle thrust of the institute, then and very much today, was to bring together leaders from the private sector ... to really discuss some of the critical issues of our time,'' said McLaughlin, the former Dartmouth College president who has headed the institute since 1987. When Schweitzer arrived, he found a near ghost town with mud-paved streets and little else to offer. When Bush and Thatcher arrive this week, they will find an upscale, posh ski resort. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt and Supreme Court justices are among the speakers who have addressed the institute. Nearly 1,000 people will gather for this year's symposium, which will feature forums on the environment, education, eastern Europe, developing Third World countries and national health care. Bush and Thatcher are scheduled to meet Thursday, their fourth round of discussions in three months. Prior to her symposium address, Thatcher plans a whirlwind tour Friday of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, and the Strategic Defense Initiative National Test Facility and the North American Aerospace Defense Command in Colorado Springs. A number of current and former global executives will lead the symposium forums, including Paul Volcker, former Federal Reserve Board chairman; Rita Klimova, ambassador of the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic; Robert S. McNamara, former president of the World Bank Group; and Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. In the past 40 years, the institute has grown from its base in Aspen to include administrative headquarters at Wye, Md., and branches in Germany, France, Italy, Japan and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon, Crew, Coast Guard Focus Of Oil Spill Inquiry
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New material, editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety investigators today criticized Exxon Corp. for operating tankers with reduced crews who don't get sufficient rest. They said that situation existed on the Exxon Valdez, which spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince Williams Sound. The National Transportation Safety Board was voting today on the causes of the nation's worst oil spill. Its initial conclusions found that the captain of the vessel improperly handed over the helm to his third mate. The board said the mate's fatigue contributed to his inability to guide the vessel around ice. The board found that similar conditions of deck officers with inadequate rest exist on other Exxon tankers due to a company policy of operating with reduced crews. It also criticized Exxon incentive awards for crews who work long hours and said the oil company has ``manipulated'' shipboard reporting of overtime and workload. The 340-page report by the National Transportation Safety Board staff was getting a final review by board members before it is to be made public in several weeks. The board planned to vote on the probable cause of the March 24, 1989, spill. The panel considered a long list of conclusions and recommendations stemming from the disaster. Among the board's conclusions in the early discussion were: _ The decision by the Exxon Valdez captain to leave his third mate in charge as the tanker was being maneuvered around a massive ice floe was improper and went against Exxon policies and Coast Guard rules. _ Coast Guard rules on staffing ships do not adquately consider the workload. _ The Coast Guard has been ``unduly narrow in perspective'' in allowing Exxon ships to operate with inadequate crew, failing to consider the amount of work required in loading the ships before they go out to sea. Board Chairman James Kolstad said the accident was the costliest the board ever investigated. He said cleanup costs had so far totalled $2 billion. The investigation was aimed at greatly reducing the risk of similar accidents, Kolstad said. With one vacancy on the five-member NTSB, the possibility of a deadlock loomed on some issues, although reports normally are not brought to the final stage until members have had a chance to read them and discuss any disagreements with staff investigators. The report covers drug and alcohol testing of the crew, the Exxon crew's operation of the vessel, Coast Guard traffic control, standards for staffing tankers and Coast Guard facilities that guide them, and government and private emergency response to the spill, said board spokeswoman Drucella Andersen. It does not, however, cover the cleanup operation, which is an environmental matter, she said. Ms. Andersen said the board received no formal complaint or allegation about the blood alcohol tests taken on Joseph Hazelwood, the Exxon Valdez's captain, more than 10 hours after his ship broke open. Hazelwood's lawyers claimed last week that tests purportedly showing that his blood had a .06 percent alcohol content were botched and were followed by a cover up that denied him a fair trial earlier this year in Alaska. The Coast Guard standard for drunkenness is .04 percent. An Alaska jury acquitted the captain of being intoxicated but convicted him on one misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. A judge fined him $50,000 and ordered him to spend 1,000 hours cleaning Alaskan beaches. Hazelwood has appealed the verdict. Last week, the Coast Guard dismissed charges of drunkenness and misconduct against Hazelwood but suspended his license as a ship's master for nine months after he pleaded no contest to breaking Coast Guard rules. The violations included drinking within four hours before taking command of the vessel and leaving the bridge to his first officer while the tanker was headed for jagged Bligh Reef, where it split open. Safety board conclusions carry no legal force but are used as possible guidelines for congressional and other government action. By law, NTSB analyses and conclusions are not admissible as evidence in courts. Kolstad took charge of the investigation shortly after the spill and sent an eight-member team to look into various aspects of the accident and the futile attempts to stop the spread of the oil. Kolstad received some criticism from former board investigators for not going to the site himself. He said he did not want to add to the list of high-profile transportation and environmental officials drawing attention there. Two months after the Exxon Valdez ran aground, the NTSB held a week-long public hearing in Alaska, interviewing 27 witnesses and collecting 115 exhibits. The 987-foot-long ship has since been renamed the Exxon Mediterranean and has been undergoing tests for service on oil trade routes in the Mediterranean Sea or the Middle East. The Transportation Department, Congress and other agencies have looked into various aspects of the spill, but the NTSB conducts the official inquiry into all accidents involving planes, trains, ships, highways and pipelines.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility in Slaying of Conservative Lawmaker
LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army said Tuesday it killed a British lawmaker because of his friendship with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and his role in developing British policy on Northern Ireland. The group said that as long as Britain controls the province, ``the IRA will continue to strike whenever and wherever the opportunity arises.'' The statement was sent to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Ian Gow, 53, a close adviser to Mrs. Thatcher and a Conservative Party lawmaker, was killed Monday when a bomb exploded under his car parked at his home in Hankham, southeast England. Gow was chairman of a parliamentary committee on Northern Ireland that discusses affairs of the province but has no power over legislation. The IRA has been fighting British rule in the province for two decades. Police believe at least two people were involved in the bombing, and they may have made several reconnaissance visits to the village in recent weeks. Scotland Yard set up a telephone hotline Tuesday to take calls from anyone who may have seen suspicious activity around the Gow home. Rodney Lind, assistant chief constable of the Sussex police, said police were following leads based on tips from the public. Police recovered some components of the bomb, and checks were being made at ports in the belief the assailants may have fled by ferry to the continent. Mrs. Thatcher visited the Gow home to comfort Gow's wife, Jane. Later she attended a memorial service with Mrs. Gow and her two sons at the Anglican parish church in Hankham, 60 miles south of London. The Gow and Thatcher families were close and often spent Christmas together. The IRA statement noted Gow was a ``close personal associate'' of Mrs. Thatcher. It also noted Gow was Mrs. Thatcher's personal parliamentary secretary, and one of her closest advisers from 1979 to 1983. Gow also was a close friend of Airey Neave, the Conservative Party spokesman on Northern Ireland slain by a bomb in 1979. The Irish National Liberational Army, an IRA splinter group, claimed responsibility for that attack. The Independent newspaper said Tuesday: ``The assassination of Ian Gow may represent an attempt by the IRA to cause personal hurt to Margaret Thatcher and goad her into overreacting to his death.'' Mrs. Thatcher said the slaying would make no difference in her government's fight against terrorism. In a statement issued Tuesday, Mrs. Gow sent a message to the IRA: ``You will never win.'' She said her husband's death ``will not diminish our resolve to be as strong as he was in fighting this terrible wickedness.'' ``We want to share Ian's great courage in defying evil and terrorism,'' Mrs. Gow said. Scotland Yard's chief anti-terrorist officer, George Churchill-Coleman, said Gow had been warned he was on a list of 100 lawmakers, judges and civil servants found in an IRA bomb factory in south London in December 1988. Gow's death prompted appeals for increased vigilence by potential IRA targets. Currently, only politicians of Cabinet rank, ministers in the Northern Ireland Office and top civil servants qualify for 24-hour protection. Politicians, lawyers and others were urged to remove addresses and telephone numbers from reference books such as Who's Who, keep vehicles locked and in a garage overnight, leave front porch lights burning, avoid announcing plans in advance and check underneath their cars. The IRA has claimed responsiblity for a series of bombings in England recently, including those at London's Stock Exchange, a traditional Conservative Party club, and a Royal Air Force base in northwest London.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Asked to Reduce Sentences of Former PTL Figures
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge was asked Tuesday to reduce the prison sentences of two brothers convicted in the PTL scandal. David and James Taggart, top aides to PTL founder Jim Bakker, were convicted last year of evading more than $525,000 in income taxes on $1.2 million they took from the television ministry. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter last year sentenced David Taggart to 18 years and five months in prison. Potter sentenced James Taggart to 17 years and nine months. They are imprisoned in Alabama and must serve 8{ years each before being eligible for parole. Defense attorney Ben Cotten told Potter during a hearing that the sentences were too harsh because the Taggarts were not ``evil or mean-spirited'' and they had cooperated with prosecutors. He said the long sentences did nothing to deter other white-collar criminals. Potter, who said his decision would take a few weeks, disagreed. ``I think the length of the sentence does provide some deterrence,'' he said. ``I think the public recognizes this. If they see someone who's embezzled a couple of million dollars and get a couple of years in jail, they'd say he got a pretty good deal.'' The Taggarts testified against their former boss in his trial last fall. Bakker was convicted of 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy and sentenced to 45 years in prison. They did not attend the hearing Tuesday. Assistant U.S. Attorney Jerry Miller, who prosecuted Bakker, sat with Cotten at the hearing and told the judge the Taggarts' testimony was ``candid and straight-forward.'' Miller declined to give his opinion on the sentences because he did not prosecute their cases. Earlier this year, Potter reduced the sentence of former PTL executive Richard Dortch after he testified against Bakker and other defendants. Dortch, who was indicted with Bakker on identical charges, pleaded guilty to reduced charges before the trial and was sentenced to eight years in prison. Potter later reduced his sentence to 30 months.

DOC.HEAD: Doe Vows To Fight On, Rebels Reported Advancing
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads throughout to UPDATE with Doe vowing to keep fighting, reported guerrilla advances. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith and photographer Alistair Sinclair were among them.

President Samuel Doe today vowed to ``fight until the last soldiers in the Liberian army die.'' Guerrilla forces were reported advancing in the capital, taking over the embassy district. Rebels had taken over Mamba Point, where the U.S. Embassy and British Embassy are located, said the U.S. State Department and British Foreign Office today. The reported rebel advances come one day after government troops massacred hundreds of people in a Lutheran church compound in Monrovia. The rebels in Mamba Point were believed to be under the command of Prince Johnson. The main rebel force of his rival, Charles Taylor, remained bogged down in the city's eastern suburbs. ``The situation is that rebel troops of Johnson have moved through the embassy quarter without inflicting any great damage to the embassies,'' said a spokesman for the British Foreign Office in London. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said in Washington that:``The situation on the ground remains fluid. It does appear that the rebels are in control where the U.S. Embassy is located.'' Doe, in his first interview in a month, told the BBC that his troops were not responsible for Monday's massacre. ``I do not want to believe that the armed forces of Liberia would just walk into a church and kill innocent people,'' Doe said. He said rebels wearing army uniforms attacked the refugees. Doe telephoned the BBC from his executive mansion, where he has been holed up since rebel forces reached the city's suburbs more than a month ago. Witnesses said more than 600 people were killed when government soldiers stormed the church grounds before dawn Monday and slaughtered 600 people. Most were children and women, and many had their heads smashed open or blown to pieces by bullets. In Washington, White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said Monday that U.S. Embassy officials in Monrovia had confirmed that government troops slaughtered at least 200 people at the church compound. There was no independent confirmation of the 600 dead figure. President Bush today met with President Gnassingbe Eyadema of the West African nation of Togo, who told reporters he has been urging Doe since early this year to talk with the rebels. ``But unfortunately, we couldn't get ourselves understood,'' Eyadema said. ``Doe doesn't want to meet anybody. We think that if at the time the rebels had accepted negotiations, everything would have been right. They didn't accept that.'' Today, sources in the Ivory Coast capital of Abidjan said Liberian troops have bombarded a Christian radio station that was used by rebels, causing considerable damage. The sources, speaking on condition of anoymity, said the attack forced station ELWA off the air. The attack came after rebel leader Charles Taylor spoke out on it last week, they said. A spokesman for the Sudan Mission in Abidjan, Bob Arnold, said he could not confirm reports of the attack. But Arnold said the station's 10 Americans, staff and relatives, evacuated the facility last Thursday. Arnold said the Americans had all left Liberia. The victims in Monday's massacre belonged to the Gio and Mano tribes, which have supported the rebels seeking to overthrow Doe. Most of Doe's troops are from his Krahn tribe and the Mandingo tribe. It was not the first massacre of civilians in this 7-month-old war. On May 30, government soldiers attacked U.N. headquarters in Monrovia, where hundreds of Gios and Manos had taken refuge. They abducted about 30 men and teen-age boys, and most of the bodies were found later on a beach outside the capital. The rebels also have been accused of killing civilians. But none of the attacks has been on the scale of Monday's massacre. The Lutheran World Federation in Geneva said today it was ``horrified and deeply grieved'' by the incident, and it urged the United Nations to intervene in the civil war. The federation is an umbrella for 106 Lutheran churches worldwide. Relief workers feared many of the wounded would die. A spokesman for the Belgian group Doctors Without Borders, which is running the only field hospital operating in Monrovia, said Monday night they had not been able to get to the church. Refugees had sought protection at the church in late May after government soldiers attacked them at U.N. headquarters in Monrovia. Thousands of refugees fleeing the civil war are crowded into refugee camps in the capital. Their numbers have swelled recently as rebel troops have stormed the city. The rebels invaded in late December from neighboring Ivory Coast in a bid to oust Doe, whom they accuse of rights abuses and corruption.

DOC.HEAD: A Good Hunk Is Hard To Find in Nation's Capital
DOC.TEXT: Ballet master Colin Peasley came to town searching for some muscle-rippling hunks to perform as extras in the Australian Ballet's production of ``Spartacus,'' but he should have looked elsewhere. Washington has plenty of government bureaucrats, lawyers and computer nerds, but Roman gladiators are in short supply. Short sleeved shirts with plastic ballpoint pen protectors, yes. But loincloths? Forget it. The Kennedy Center circulated fliers around town announcing auditions for ``macho he-men'' to appear this week in Hungarian choreographer Laszlo Seregi's balletic tale of an abortive slave uprising in ancient Rome. Peasley was too gentlemanly to wince when 38 of Washington's finest examples of raging testosterone showed up Monday night. About half were muscular enough to stay, but the rest looked more or less like veteran couch potatoes. After whispered consultations with Maina Gielgud, artistic director of the Australian Ballet, Peasley politely showed the softies to the door. Then he began drilling the winners _ including an aerobic instructor, a government lawyer, a rock musician, a birthday balloon delivery man and a U.S. Park Service policeman _ to whip them into shape as Roman soldiers and slaves. Among those who didn't make the cut were white-haired Jules Renaud, 76, a retired Agriculture Department forestry expert who said his bride of five months had encouraged him to try out. ``You're an attractive man,'' she had told him. Another who took his disappointment good-naturedly was Eugene Woodruff, 57, of suburban Annandale, Va., a supervisor at the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office whose physique suggests he's no stranger to an evening in front of the TV set with a bag of nacho chips. Woodruff has performed as an extra in several Washington Opera productions, mostly just standing around on stage, and he was eager to try a livelier role in ``Spartacus,'' which requires a lot of marching and lunging and dashing here and there. ``I'm not a dancer at all,'' he said, grinning. ``I don't take part in any strenuous athletics. For exercise, the only thing I do is rifle shooting. I also mow the lawn and saw some firewood.'' As Woodruff walked out the door, Peasley was barking ``left, right, left, right'' to the 19 finalists as they marched across the floor to piano music from Aram Khachaturian's score. Grabbing a wooden spear, Peasley said, ``These are held like you hold a thermometer. Grasp them in the center and keep them under your armpit, like this.'' He taught the neophyte gladiators how to sway without getting dizzy, and how to crouch without ``looking like you're sitting on the toilet.'' He held a Roman warrior's shield to his chest. ``You must be careful how you hold a shield or they begin to look like a handbag,'' he said. The extras, or supernumeraries, will receive $28 for four rehearsals and $40 for four performances of ``Spartacus'' starting Friday. The pay is somewhat higher than the usual rate for opera ``supers'' because of the ballet's complex stage movements. The money wasn't the lure for Woodruff. ``I have no illusions about being a great actor,'' he said. ``I do it for the fun of it. It's a chance to do theater that's big-time, without having any real professional skills.''

DOC.HEAD: Terror Gang Threatens More Attacks in Europe
DOC.TEXT: A letter received Tuesday and signed by West Germany's most notorious terrorist group said the attack last week on a government official was the start of a ``long fighting phase.'' The letter threatened more attacks and urged terrorism groups to build ``a revolutionary hostile power in Western Europe'' to combat ``imperialism'' led by West Germany. It was signed ``Red Army Faction'' and dated July 29, the day after a car bomb attack on Interior Ministry official Hans Neusel. The group claimed responsibility for that attack in a letter left at the scene of the crime. Neusel walked away with minor cuts after a bomb rocked his sedan as he was driving to work. The latest letter said the bomb was meant to guarantee his ``certain death'' but ``we calculated the amount of explosives too low.'' The attack on Neusel was the ``start of a long fighting phase against the newly arisen Greater German-West European World Power,'' it said. The communique went on to denounce the process of German unification and vowed support for leftist terrorists in Spain. It further demanded that jailed leftist terrorists in Spain and across Western Europe be held together in common cells, rather than separated from each other. The Red Army Faction has frequently demanded its jailed members in West Germany be held together in common prison areas. West German officials have refused. The five-page letter, written in German, did not contain the gang's symbol of a star superimposed by an assault rifle. The group has often used the symbol on previous written claims of responsibility. However, the Federal Prosecutor's Office in Karlsruhe said the letter appeared to be authentic. Spokesman Hans-Juergen Foerster noted that a similar letter was sent to news agencies several days after the assassination of Deutsche Bank President Alfred Herrhausen, who died in a November 1989 car bombing similar to the attack on Neusel.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Vets Cope With War as Superpowers Try to End It
With AM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While the U.S. secretary of state and the Soviet foreign minister try Wednesday to bring peace to Afghanistan, Soviet veterans scarred by the Afghan war will be undergoing therapy nearby. Some of the 1 million Soviets who fought during the Red Army's nine-year intervention in Afghanistan are being treated at the Baikal Sanitorium, a 192-acre health resort overlooking Lake Baikal. The hilltop retreat, set among cedars and birch trees, is best known as the intended site of a 1960 superpower summit between Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and President Dwight D. Eisenhower. The summit was scrapped after the downing of American Gary Powers' spy plane. Three decades later, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will be meeting in the central Siberian city of Irkutsk, 43 miles to the northwest. They will try to agree on a formula for a cease-fire and a political reconciliation in Afghanistan, where Moslem rebels have been fighting the Soviet-backed government for 12 years. The sanitorium is one of eight nationwide treating Soviet veterans of the war that Baker and Shevardnadze will try to end. Capt. Anatoly Sadayev is still tormented physically and emotionally by the machine-gun attack that put a bullet in his leg while he served in Afghanistan from 1983 to 1985. ``I remember it as though it were yesterday, but I don't want to recall it again,'' the 34-year-old officer said Tuesday as he pedaled an exercise bicycle. Sadayev has undergone several operations on his leg and is receiving further treatment during a 24-day stay at the sanitorium. Trousers hide the scar, but he walks with a limp. A fixed pad on the bottom of his left sneaker helps him walk. In another room, a 24-year-old veteran was being treated for lower back pain. Medicated cloth patches were placed on his back. Aside from treatment of their physical wounds, the veterans also see psychologists at the center. Like some American veterans of the Vietnam War, some Soviet soldiers who fought in Afghanistan feel their countrymen do not appreciate their suffering. Sadayev is one of them. ``If you remember the film `Rambo,' where he says `I love my motherland,' well let my homeland love me as much as I love it, and then there won't be any problems,'' Sadayev said. Among the problems, veterans say, are the government's slowness in providing free medical care, counseling, proper housing and jobs. The Soviets began withdrawing their troops from Afghanistan in May 1988 but did not decide until October 1988 to set up rehabilitation centers. The Baikal Sanitorium was opened to veterans in March 1989. Sanitorium doctors have complained they are virtually cut off from foreign colleagues and therefore cannot learn from their experiences, especially from doctors treating Vietnam War veterans. They have no detailed, specialized programs for treating soldiers, who are mixed with other guests at the sprawling complex. ``Our task is to do everything so they and their families live normally, so they have everything, because they weren't guilty for that war and didn't want to be there,'' said Dr. Alexander Kitaisky, Baikal Sanitorium's chief doctor. Sadayev calls the Soviet intervention a ``mistake of history'' that cost more than 13,000 Soviet lives. But he doesn't dwell on the past. ``I am happy that I am alive. I continue to live. I have a family,'' he said. He is now studying law in the Russian city of Kurgan.

DOC.HEAD: Cadets Free To Quit Air Force Saturday Under New Policy
DOC.TEXT: Air Force freshmen who endured six weeks of basic training will get their first chance to drop out Saturday under a new policy to stem a rising early attrition rate. The new program forces freshmen to stick it out through basic training. The policy at the academy since its inception in the mid-1950s had been to allow freshmen to quit at any time. Last year, a surprising 149 students _ 11 percent of the freshman class _ to quit soon after arriving. The dropout figures led administrators to require this year's freshmen to stay until they had completed basic training. The only exception was for those with physical disabilities. Maj. Steve Daniels, director of research, said the academy wanted freshmen to build a sense of accomplishment by completing the rigorous basic training program. Many of those who qut early on in past years weren't at the academy long enough to know what cadet life is like, Daniels said. The class of 1994 had 1,210 men and 181 women when it entered the academy on June 29. Twelve men and eight women have left because of physical disabilities. Those who stay after Saturday will go through an acceptance parade on Monday. Academic classes for the cadet wing begin Aug. 9. The U.S. Naval Academy allows its cadets to resign anytime. At the U.S. Military Academy, cadets must stay at least four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leaders Keeping Neutral Abortion Stance
Precede WASHINGTON, D.C.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with executive council backing neutrality. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `However, the...'. SUBS 10th graf, `However, both...', with 2 grafs to clarify that description of anti-abortion forces comments as a `threat' was interpretation by some in union. Picks up 11th graf, `A pro-choice...'. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: AFL-CIO leaders wrestling with the abortion issue agreed today that the powerful labor federation should continue its decade-long path of neutrality on the divisive subject. The Executive Council of the 14.2 million-member organization voted not to take a position on abortion. ``The overwhelming view of the council was that this was a matter of deep conscience, conviction and religion'' on the part of union members, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland said. Kirkland said only two or three members of the 34-member council dissented during today's voice vote. He said the group did not think any stance taken by the union as a whole could change the minds of individual members. Three members of the council are women. Today's vote was to accept the recommendation of an 18-member panel of AFL-CIO union presidents who Monday urged the full governing council not to take sides on abortion. On Monday, one of the union leaders who had ben pushing a pro-choice stand, accused colleagues of ``dragging their feet'' on an issue crucial to luring more women and minorities into the struggling labor movement. However, the union leader, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said pro-choice forces could find solace in the fact that the resolution acknowledged ``the right of privacy and the right of people to choose based on their own conscience.'' ``I don't consider it a total defeat. ... It's not strong enough, but considering the circumstances we did about as well we could,'' the leader said. ``It's more of a standoff.'' Leaders urging neutrality contend that the abortion issue is just too divisive for the labor movement and a pro-choice stand would threaten unions' organizing efforts. Those officials complained that abortion had nothing to do with traditional collective bargaining issues, such as hours and pay, but pro-choice forces noted that the AFL-CIO has gotten involved in other social issues such as civil rights. There was no organized move afoot for the federation to condemn abortion. However, both the National Right to Life Committee and Cardinal John J. O'Connor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York had campaigned for the AFL-CIO not to take a stand. They noted that a recent Supreme Court decision gives union members the right to withhold dues spent on political issues. Many union leaders interpreted that campaign as a threat by the committee and O'Connor that they would lobby members to withhold union dues if the AFL-CIO went pro-choice. A pro-choice position would have put the federation in line with the stance taken by many of its political allies, such as the Democratic Party and various women's and civil rights groups. At a convention last fall of delegates from all 90 AFL-CIO unions, the delegates declined to adopt any of the half-dozen pro-choice resolutions submitted, and instead referred them to the Executive Council at its meeting last February in Bal Harbour, Fla. Instead of taking up the issue at that highly publicized meeting, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland appointed the 18-member committee to study the issue and make a recommendation at this meeting in Chicago, where the federation is not in as bright a spotlight.

DOC.HEAD: Togolese President To Allow Second Political Party
DOC.TEXT: President Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo promised President Bush on Tuesday that he would allow the establishment of another political party in his west African country to give his people some democracy. The two leaders also discussed the rapidly deteriorating situation in Liberia during their two-hour White House meeting, said Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen. Togo has offered asylum to Liberian President Samuel Doe, who is holding out at his palace in Monrovia against a challenge by rebels seeking his ouster. But Cohen said the asylum question was not discussed at the White House meeting. He said both leaders support a role for the United Nations in establishing a cease-fire in Liberia. Eyadema, whose country is one of the poorest in the world, also urged Bush and other friends of Africa to start a Marshall Plan for the continent, similar to the massive Western aid program for the newly emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. In departure statements on the White House's south lawn, Bush said he was encouraged by Eyadema's promise to provide his people with more political openness. Cohen said Eyadema pledged he would do away with the one-party state and allow the Togolese another political party so they could have more choice. ``The path to development and the path to democracy are one and the same,'' Bush told Eyadema in his statement. In heavily accented French, Bush also sent his best wishes to the people of Togo. Eyadema, who took power in a bloodless military coup in 1967, runs an authoritarian state. The State Department's annual human rights report says that while Togo has a serious problem of torture in its prisons, the situation has improved under the 2-year-old Togolese Human Rights Commission, which reports to Eyadema. In Eyadema's departure statement, he noted that Africa's debt will exceed $600 billion by the year 2000 and he urged that ``appropriate remedies must be found for the grave problems of our continent, which is the victim of famine and calamities.'' Eyadema is here to promote Togo's newly created Export Processing Zone, which will allow U.S. and other businessmen to produce merchandise in the West African country and to export it to Europe free of duty. Several U.S. government agencies are helping the project get started. In his meetings, Eyadema hopes to interest American businessmen in investing in Togo. In return they will get better access than they enjoy here to the large market being created in Europe by the 1992 merger of the economies of the 12-nation European Economic Community. Togo, twice the size of Maryland with a population of 3.3 million, has been largely dependent on agriculture since it gained independence in 1960. Hopes of improving the economy through the sale of phosphate in the 1970s collapsed with a drastic fall in the world price of that commodity. In return for support from the International Monetary Fund, Togo has been selling or liquidating government-controlled enterprises and offering generous incentives to foreign investors.

DOC.HEAD: Baseball Commissioner Bans Yankee Boss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Steinbrenner, 60...', to CORRECT son's age to 33 sted 31. SUBS 9-11th grafs, `Further details...', with 3 grafs to add detail. Picks up 12th graf, `Steinbrenner accepted...'. Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7, NY16; LaserColor NY11
DOC.TEXT: Baseball finally did to New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner what he'd been doing to managers for 18 years _ it showed him the door. Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent on Monday stripped Steinbrenner of control of the team for allegedly paying a gambler to dig up dirt on a ballplayer. ``For all purposes, Mr. Steinbrenner agrees that he is to be treated as if he had been placed on the permanent ineligible list,'' Vincent said. ``I hope this sad episode is now over.'' Fans rose in a 90-second standing ovation when news spread to Yankee Stadium. The decision brought shouts of ``No more George!'' ``I will not comment on the decision,'' Steinbrenner said. ``I'm very happy it was resolved. I'm very satisfied with the resolution, and that's all I'm going to say.'' As one of the most controversial _ some say hated _ names in the game's history, Steinbrenner was famous for hiring and firing managers _ five times in the case of Billy Martin. He changed managers 18 times and pitching coaches 31 times. Steinbrenner, 60, who headed a group that purchased the Yankees from CBS Inc. in 1973, can retain partial ownership but was given six months to reduce his stake to below 50 percent from 55 percent. His 33-year-old son, Hank, will become the new general partner, said Steinbrenner's lawyer, Stephen Kaufman. Vincent said it would be possible for a member of Steinbrenner's family to be the new general partner, but warned the family member would face expulsion if George Steinbrenner was found to have any involvement with the operation of the club. His son's appointment is subject to the approval of Vincent and the other major league teams. Hank Steinbrenner, the oldest of Steinbrenner's four children, has been involved in the daily operations of the club since 1986. Last year, he also was the head soccer coach at Vanguard High School in Ocala, Fla., and worked breeding horses at his father's stud farm there. Under the restrictions, George Steinbrenner will be allowed to consult on major business decisions but cannot participate in player deals. And he must get Vincent's permission, in writing, to attend major league games as anything other than an ordinary fan. He cannot, for example, sit in the owner's box or visit the clubhouse. Also, the Yankees must certify in writing to the American League president every six months that Steinbrenner has had no involvement with the team. Steinbrenner accepted the terms of his punishment and agreed not to contest the decision in court, as he had threatened to do, Vincent said. ``It's sad,'' said Yankee pitcher Dave Righetti. ``He really loved the idea of owning the Yankees, and now it's been taken away from him.'' ``The guy got exactly what he deserved,'' a Yankee fan, Trevor Bickford of Westbury, N.Y., said after word reached Yankee Stadium. ``That's what should happen to any owner that constantly makes decisions to hurt the club.'' Vincent punished Steinbrenner for starting a relationship with gambler Howard Spira and paying Spira $40,000 in January. Vincent said Steinbrenner's actions violated the ``best interests of baseball'' clause that gives the commissioner practically unlimited powers to protect the integrity of the game. Last August, Pete Rose was banished from the game for betting on baseball. Steinbrenner's downfall stemmed from a feud with Yankee Dave Winfield, whom he signed in 1980. Steinbrenner turned on his star outfielder after Winfield went 1-for-22 in the 1981 World Series loss to Los Angeles. Winfield and Steinbrenner sued each other three times in the 1980s and Winfield finally was traded to the California Angels in May. That deal came after Spira said he was paid by Steinbrenner to provide information to discredit the outfielder. Spira went public with the $40,000 payment in March and Vincent started the investigation. ``Mr. Steinbrenner has offered multiple and conflicting explanations of his decision to give $40,000 to Spira, ranging from charity to extortion,'' Vincent said. ``I am pursuaded that neither extreme was at work here. Rather, the payment was in consideration for Spira's help ....'' Steinbrenner tried to cover up the $40,000 because ``he knew the payment, if exposed, would look bad, and he knew, or at least should have known, that if the payment were exposed, it would bring disrepute to him and therefore to baseball,'' the commissioner said. Steinbrenner is the only owner to be penalized twice for major offenses. He was suspended in 1974 by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for making illegal campaign contributions to President Nixon. The two-year exile was reduced to 15 months. ``I have nothing to say,'' Spira said after the announcement. Winfield got the news during an Angels game with the Twins in Minneapolis. ``I felt quite a bit vindicated because so much had been said about me. I had so many battles, so much turmoil,'' Winfield said. ``I'm glad to get a lot of this out of the way. ... supplement its drought-reduced domestic vegetable oil supply. In addition to higher cash prices for soybeans, analysts said relatively few delivery notices were posted Tuesday at the Board of Trade. Tuesday was the first opportunity for traders to declare their intent to deliver soybeans against the August contract. A low number of notices indicates strong cash-market demand. John Frazier, director of agricultural commodity trading with Gerald Inc. in Chicago, said Continental Grain Co. was the only major commercial grain handler to post soybean delivery notices Tuesday. Frazier said the wheat market fell sharply just before the close, apparently on heavy selling by a speculative fund. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 7{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.90 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent lower with September at $2.60\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 2 cents higher with September at $1.30 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 6 cents higher with August at $5.94 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: 100,000 Troops Massed on Iraq-Kuwait Border as Talks Begin
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti and Iraqi negotiators embraced warmly Tuesday as they began talks on their oil and border dispute, sources said. Diplomats reported that Iraq had massed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border. Gulf-based diplomatic sources said the Iraqi force, triple the number earlier reported, included about 300 Soviet-made tanks, and dwarfed the entire Kuwaiti army of 20,000 troops. The diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the troops have been concentrated along the border since last week, when Iraq began threatening Kuwait. Iraq accused the small Persian Gulf state of stealing oil from a disputed border region and forcing oil prices to drop. The diplomats said the number of troops was at first difficult to determine. The delegation leaders, Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah of Kuwait, and Izzat Ibrahim, deputy chairman of Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council, met privately for two hours. There were no details on the negotiations, but sources said the meetings will continue Wednesday. Diplomatic sources have said they expect Arab mediators to push the two sides to sign a treaty of non-belligerency to be followed by protracted negotiations on borders and compensation. The Iraq-Kuwait crisis broke out on July 17 when Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of driving down oil prices by exceeding quotas set for them by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Saddam said the move cost Iraq $14 billion in lost revenue. Saddam also demanded compensation for the $2.4 billion in oil he claimed Kuwait pumped illegally from an oil field which straddles the unmarked border between the two countries. Iraq also demanded that Kuwait forgive $15 billion in loans it extended to Baghdad during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Iraq's tough talk appeared to have succeeded. Kuwait and the U.A.E agreed to stick to their oil quotas at an OPEC meeting last week. OPEC member states also agreed to a longstanding Iraqi demand to raised target crude oil prices from $18 to $21 a barrel. Kuwaiti and Iraqi officials agreed to meet in Jiddah after intensive mediation efforts by King Fahd and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. Kuwaiti leaders had insisted that Iraq pull back its troops before conciliation talks could began, but later dropped that demand. Kuwaiti officials also asked that Iraq agree to demarcate the disputed border between the nations, a move Iraq has refused. Iraq has historically laid claim to all of Kuwait and has long coveted the Kuwaiti islands of Bubiyan and Warba, which command access to Iraq's sole outlet into the Persian Gulf. The mediators have succeeded in toning down a vitriolic campaign against Kuwait by the Iraqi state-run media. On Tuesday, the Iraqi delegation left Baghdad without any public announcement. The leading Al-Thawra daily newspaper called the Jiddah meeting ``an opportunity ... for Kuwait ... to perceive Iraq's demands and respond to its rights.'' In contrast, the Kuwaiti delegation left for Jiddah with fanfare and publicity. The Kuwaiti papers said they hoped the Jiddah meeting was the start of ``a final just settlement'' of the differences between Iraq and Kuwait, in a manner ensuring the ``legitimate rights of each.''

DOC.HEAD: Refugee Loan Proposals Receive Mixed Reviews
DOC.TEXT: Americans working with refugees expressed mixed reactions Tuesday to congressional proposals to lend money to immigrants so they can establish themselves without going on welfare. The author of one measure, Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., said his plan would establish a federal program of refugee loan guarantees to encourage private lenders to give loans to employable refugees. Solarz said at a House hearing on resettlement that his goal was to make ``optimum use'' of scarce refugee resettlement dollars so that more victims of persecution and oppression can come to the United States. The Solarz plan calls for qualifying refugees to receive an average loan of $7,500 to be repaid over a decade. Even if the default rate were 30 percent, Solarz said that his estimates ``suggest that the refugee program might save as much as tens of millions of dollars per year.'' Another proposal from Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, would give some refugees interest-free loans to cover half the average cost of resettlement. The refugees would be required to repay the loans. Nicolas Dimarzio, executive director of the U.S. Catholic Conference's Migration and Refugee Services, said the group could not endorse private sponsorship proposals right now because it didn't know enough about them. ``We are concerned that, while both of these approaches seek to eventually reduce federal outlays for refugees, neither ensures that these programs would result in an increase of refugee admissions to the United States,'' he said. Moreover, he said, he could not be sure the proposals would be equitable. Gary Rubin of the American Jewish Committee, a group that promotes the rights of Jews around the world, refused to endorse the proposals and said more study is needed. ``It will obviously be a very complex task to set up a workable program...,' Rubin said. ``The proposed legislation does not yet take all of these factors into account.'' Private sponsorship initiatives are expected to allow about 15,000 refugees, primarily those from the Soviet Union and Cuba, to find new lives in the United States this year. There are some 15 million refugees around the world, and many are eager to come to the United States for a new life. About 125,000 refugees will settle in the United States in 1990, at a total cost of about $600 million.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl to Tell East Germany to Limit Weapons Purchases
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will urge East Germany to spend ``as little as possible'' on new weapons, following revelations East Berlin plans a huge new purchase of Soviet arms, officials said Tuesday. Meanwhile, East German Labor Minister Regine Hildebrandt pleaded for an emergency infusion of West German aid. East Germany ``stands before a social and financial collapse'' if new aid doesn't come soon, Ms. Hildebrandt said. Kohl's government has resisted East German requests for aid to supplement the sums Bonn is already spending to lay the economic and social groundwork for unity. West Germany contends East Berlin could do much more belt-tightening. Such contentions intensified after the East German government admitted late Monday that it plans to spend $622 million on new Soviet-made weapons. The purchases were revealed earlier in West German media reports. Kohl has been under intense pressure to scuttle East Germany's arms-buying plans. On Tuesday, the chancellor and his coalition partners agreed to tell East Germany to ``procure as few weapons as possible,'' a government official said on condition of anonymity. It was not known when Kohl would address the issue with the East Berlin government or whether he would suggest a monetary limit. West Germany's education minister, Juergen Moellemann of the liberal Free Democratic Party, had demanded the purchases be blocked. The weapons-purchasing plans have put East German Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann _ a pastor and avowed pacifist _ in an uncomfortable media spotlight. He says he is proceding with the purchases only because contracts were signed, some eight years ago. Eppelmann said that backing away from purchases would mean paying considerable financial penalties to the Soviets. But several West German politicians say the purchases are a waste of money, since the East German army will likely be disbanded by the year's end. Many West Germans are already worried that the high costs of unification will lead to financial sacrifices and higher taxes, and oppose extra expenditures by the financially beleaguered government in East Berlin. Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, a high-ranking member of West Germany's main opposition Social Democratic Party, called the weapons-purchasing plans a ``security and financial scandal.'' She also said the West German government has long known about the weapons procurements but did nothing to stop them. On Monday night, East German officials acknowledged the government planned to buy the Soviet military hardware over the next six months. The weapons include two missile-carrying vessels, anti-tank rockets, a helicopter, and machine guns, West German news media have reported. East Germany was also close to buying 32 MiG-29 fighter jets worth $628 million but that plan was scuttled when the West German Defense Ministry said it would have no use for the Soviet-made airplanes, reports said. Meanwhile, pressure mounted on West Germany to free more financial aid for East Germany. The East German labor minister said she feared the spiraling unemployment following the July 1 economic unification of the German states would breed social unrest. ``If something doesn't happen soon then much will collapse which should not be allowed to collapse,'' Ms. Hildebrandt said. More than 250,000 East Germans have lost their jobs as companies and factories try to survive the country's switch to capitalism. Some experts say joblessness could climb to 3 million. As the two Germanys bicker over money, progress seems to have been made in efforts to forge a new treaty setting out the technicalities for Dec. 2 elections for an all-German Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Envoy Says Food, Other Help Readied
With AM-Trinidad, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is preparing emergency assistance for this beleaguered Caribbean country, but there are no plans to send military reinforcements, the U.S. ambassador said Tuesday. ``We haven't been asked and we aren't considering any type of military support,'' Ambassador Charles Gargano said at the U.S. Embassy, a few blocks from the state Television House where a radical Moslem group has held hostages since Friday. The group also seized the Parliament House and is holding hostages there, including government officials. Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson was freed Tuesday, five days after being seized, the attorney general said. Because of widespread looting, Trinidad could face food shortages, and the United States is preparing emergency supplies, Gargano said. He said a force of some 200 Caribbean soldiers were standing by on Barbados to help if requested. The ambassador, who has been staying in the Embassy along with 12 other diplomatic personnel and six Marine guards, said he is in regular contact with Trinidadian officials. He said there are no signs of splintering in the government or security forces, and there is no popular support for the rebels. ``The government is in total control of the country,'' he said. Gargano, named in 1987, said the crisis ``came out of the blue for us. In fact, we were quite shocked. This country appeared to be a model of democracy.'' The U.S. stakes here are high, he said. He said there are 2,000 to 4,000 U.S. citizens in Trinidad, including many Trinidadians who hold dual citizenship. Trinidad is a major U.S. trade partner in the Caribbean and has been a pro-American democracy for its three decades of nationhood, he said. ``Things have been moving apace in terms of democratization in this hemisphere. We would like to see it continue as a strong democracy,'' Gargano said. He said the Moslem group led by former Trinidad policeman Abu Bakr has been controversial in Trinidad and has made anti-American statements. ``Our impression is that it was a tiny fanatical sect,'' he said, estimating Bakr's followers at 250 to 350 people. He said some members of the group have traveled to Libya and ``there is some evidence of training given to some members.'' He said they also have received funding from Libya. But Gargano added there was no evidence of Libyan involvement in their move against the government.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Prime Minister Freed, Others Remain Captives in Trinidad Standoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with nine grafs to CORRECT prime minister's initials, ADDS that no details of release immediately available, background. Picks up 11th pvs, `Bakr said...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson was freed by his Moslem captors today but other officials held hostage were not released, the government announced. Attorney General Anthony Smart gave no details of how and under what conditions the prime minister, who had been shot in both feet during the uprising, was freed. But the release of Robinson alone indicated the 5-day-old standoff between the government and Moslem extremists was not over. ``We continue to pray for the safe return of the rest of the hostages,'' Smart told state radio. He said Robinson was the only one of the 41 hostages released. Smart said Robinson, who was freed at 1:20 p.m. EDT, ``is in good spirits.'' The siege began Friday when radical Moslems led by Abu Bakr stormed Parliament and the government-run television station in Trinidad's capital city. Bakr has accused the government of mismanagement. The release came after a day of conflicting reports over the progress of negotiations to end the hostage siege, which has plunged this Caribbean nation of 1.3 million residents off northeast Venezuela into chaos. On Monday night, Robinson had said by telephone that he had accepted an agreement under which he would resign and Bakr and his men would be granted amnesty. But government officials said today that no such agreement existed and that Robinson had made the statement under duress. Bakr said earlier today that the rebels agreed that Winston Dookeran, the deputy prime minister, would replace Robinson when he steps down. Dookeran was released from the Parliament building Friday. The interim government would be a coalition consisting of representatives of all major political parties, along with Bakr's Jamaat al-Muslimeen group. The group, which is believed to number 250 to 300, has blamed Robinson for widespread poverty in this once-oil rich Caribbean nation near Venezuela. It has little support among the populace. Bakr is a former policeman who converted to Islam in 1980 and has long considered himself a champion of the downtrodden. He founde Jamaat al-Muslimeen, which means the Moslem Group in Arabic, in 1984. Robinson easily won parliamentary elections in 1986. Under the constitution, the next elections don't have to be held until 1991. On Monday, security forces exchanged gunfire with the rebels at Parliament and at the government television station. Three buildings in and around the TV complex were set ablaze but no injuries were reported. At least nine people _ six rebels, two police officers and a civilian _ have been killed since the siege began, and the instability has spawned massive looting in Trinidad and Tobago, a two-island nation of 1.3 million people. State radio said some looters were shot Monday but gave no details. Bakr has ties to Libya and it is believed he has received funding from that country. In a conversation with local radio today, he said he had no regrets over what he had done. ``I hope we can settle it in love,'' he said. Asked if the siege could end in violence, he said, ``Everyone will die at some time in their lives.''

DOC.HEAD: US Weighs Asking For UN Peacekeeping Force For Liberia
DOC.TEXT: As fighting raged near the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia, the Bush administration said Tuesday it may call for a U.N. peacekeeping force to bring an end to the seven-month old conflict in Liberia. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said there were no plans to evacuate the 400 Americans remaining in Liberia despite a deterioration in the security situation. A U.S. naval flotilla was waiting offshore in case evacuation is required. Boucher said there was intensive fighting that apparently left rebels in control of an area where the U.S. Embassy is located. Rocket fire was reported in that area on Tuesday but only one building was said to have been damaged. According to the latest reports, fighting was continuing but at less intensive levels than Monday. Boucher said U.S. officials have been in contact with rebel and government forces and both have indicated a willingness to abide by American admonitions to respect foreign embassies. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said bullets ricocheted off several U.S. buildings at the height of the fighting around the diplomatic enclave, but no one was hurt. ``None of the combatants have targeted our people,'' he said. The administration was facing additional pressure on Tuesday to intensify diplomatic efforts toward a peaceful solution. That pressure increased following a massacre over the weekend in which forces loyal to President Samuel K. Doe broke into a Lutheran church and killed hundreds of civilian refugees. Cohen said the rebels also were committing atrocities and the United States has reliable information that they were executing any government soldiers they capture. Boucher acknowledged that previous U.S. diplomatic efforts have not borne fruit. ``We're now examining what role the United Nations can play in resolution of this conflict,'' he said. ``Our ambassador to the United Nations has begun consultations in this regard. We have also heard from other quarters that there is possible interest in U.N. Security Council action.'' Cohen, briefing reporters at the White House, said the United States supports the formation of an international peacekeeping force. Even if Doe is dislodged from power, peace would not necessarily be assured because of a split in the rebel forces, Cohen said. On Capitol Hill, Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, said Congress has been urging the administration to put Liberia on the U.N. Security Council's agenda and to take a more active role in removing Doe from the scene. ``Our concern is to try to reduce the volatility ... stop large-scale ethnic tensions,'' said Wolpe. The administration is concerned not only about the Americans in Liberia but also the estimated 37,000 Liberians who have sought refuge at U.S. installations in Liberia. Cohen said the United States could not offer them food because it has barely enough for U.S. personnel. U.S. officials have promised to evacuate Soviet diplomats and envoys from some allied countries in the event the fighting continues to escalate.

DOC.HEAD: Skydiver Survives Fall With Partially Opened Chute
DOC.TEXT: A skydiver who survived a fall of nearly 10,000 feet with a partially opened parachute said he felt like an angel was looking out for him. Mike Butela, 30, was released Tuesday from Presbyterian-University Hospital after being treated for two broken vertebrae. ``I thought I was dead,'' Butela said. ``I had 10 seconds there to think about it, and it wasn't a real good feeling.'' Butela, who has been skydiving for seven years, said he knew he was in trouble Friday when he opened his main parachute at about 3,000 feet and one of the lines got caught, causing him to spiral downward. He jumped at about 9,500 feet above the ground. He opened the reserve chute, but the chutes tangled and he could not free them. He said he fell with his main chute only one-fourth open before landing in a cornfield in Worthington, about 35 miles northeast of Pittsburgh. ``It was like an angel let me down,'' Butela said. Butela said he plans to jump again as soon as his back heals.

DOC.HEAD: Motorists To Begin Paying Biggest Tax Hike In State History
DOC.TEXT: Motorists who clog California's freeways on Wednesday begin paying the state's biggest tax hike ever, a voter-approved nickel-a-gallon levy on fuel aimed at reducing the highway gridlock. ``This nickel is adding insult on top of injury,'' said Dennis Radabaugh, a Contra Costa sheriff's deputy who lives in Walnut Creek. He said the increase was ``one of several nickels that's obviously going to raise my whole cost of living.'' The tax rises an additional cent Jan. 1, then one more penny each subsequent New Year's Day through 1994. That will provide the majority of funding for an $18 billion-plus, 10-year highway and mass-transit rail construction program that voters approved June 5 in the form of Proposition 111. Altogether, the average California motorist will soon be paying more than a cent per mile in excise and sales taxes. Road and rail construction has not kept pace with population because of inflation and political paralysis on the issue. Drivers waste more than 400,000 hours a day because the average speed on urban freeways has fallen to about 20 mph during commuting hours. In the next decade, the number of licensed drivers is expected to rise 18 percent. Currently there are about 19 million registered drivers in California, and some 25 million vehicles. The new levies will double the current state excise tax per gallon of gas from 9 to 18 cents. There already is a federal excise tax of 9.1 cents per gallon and a sales tax per $1 of 6.25 to 7.25 cents, depending on how much the county tacks on above the state's basic 6.25 cents. The state excise tax also will go up at the same rate on diesel, aviation fuel for light airplanes, and marine gasoline. But drastic as that may seem to Californians, the state's gas tax after the initial nickel hike will rank 37th among states and 12th after the full increase goes into effect, up from 47th, said Penny Hill, a spokeswoman for the Road Information Program, a Washington-based nonprofit research organization. State excise taxes on gas range from 22.3 cents per gallon in Nebraska to 7.5 cents a gallon in Georgia, she said. Proposition 111 was supported by a bipartisan government, business and labor coalition. It was rejected by rural voters, who believed they would benefit less than cities despite plans to distribute funds throughout the state. But there was no organized opposition and the scattered critics, for the most part, see the tax as unfortunate but necessary. ``Service stations owners are not happy about the gas tax. We're usually opposed to any tax increase, but we know this one was designated for transportation improvements,'' said Art Boswell, a spokesman for the California Service Station and Automotive Repair Association. State officials said they believe motorists will take the tax hike in stride. Everyone, they said, is used to fluctuations in gas prices, which are also expected to rise because of increases in the cost of crude oil. Some service station attendants in San Francisco, Los Angeles, San Bernardino and Sacramento said it was business as usual Tuesday while others said sales were up to 25 percent brisker as people stocked up before the price went up. A few stations said they ran out of gas early because of the increased business. ``I saved a dollar,'' said Bill Morris of Concord, who filled up the 28-gallon tank of his 1969 Oldsmobile to avoid the tax hike. He owns four cars but prefers the old 10-mile-a-gallon guzzler. Not everyone was so concerned. ``Customers aren't too worried about it. When you've got a BMW you don't worry if it costs $3 more to fill up the tank,'' said Jeffrey Masko, a service station cashier in the high-rent Pacific Heights neighborhood of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Governors' Meeting Ends With Partisan Finger-Pointing Over S&Ls
With AM-Deposit Insurance, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Republican newspaper ads blaming Democrats for the savings and loan crisis triggered outrage among Democratic governors Tuesday as the National Governors' Association ended its annual meeting with a round of partisan finger-pointing. Democratic governors approved a resolution among themselves calling for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate the S&L debacle and charging that the Bush administration ``has moved slowly to prosecute'' S&L fraud. It went beyond a policy statement approved later by the full governors' association _ Democrats and Republicans _ calling on President Bush and Congress to name an independent commission to investigate the savings and loan collapse. The S&L bailout is expected to cost taxpayers as much as $500 billion. The governors accepted a Republican amendment offered by Gov. James Martin of North Carolina that softened the statement's language a bit to say the commission should not delay action on the S&L crisis and should have no power to grant immunity from prosecution for witnesses. Democratic governors were quick to denounce newspaper ads sponsored by the Republican National Committee that blamed congressional Democrats for the S&L debacle. The ads ran in the Mobile Register on Monday and Tuesday. One of the ads pictured 12 congressional Democrats, including resigned House Speaker Jim Wright and Sens. Alan Cranston of California and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. It said, ``You won't see these Democratic `leaders' around Mobile,'' and ``They're the guys who let the S&L problem explode into a $325 billion national crisis.'' Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, chairman of the Democratic governors, called the ads ``deceitful'' and ``the most outrageous distortion of the truth.'' He blamed Republicans for upsetting the normal spirit of bipartisanship at the governors' conference and said the Bush administration has failed provide leadership on the S&L crisis. In the governors' final bipartisan meeting, Democratic Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts _ the defeated 1988 presidential nominee _ called the ads ``garbage'' and said, ``We had enough of that in 1988.'' The ads were regarded by Democrats as an escalation in the growing partisan rancor over the S&L crisis as the fall elections approach. And it represented the most biting partisan dispute to erupt at a national governors' meeting in half a dozen years. Republican Gov. John McKernan of Maine said Democrats have been trying to use the S&L crisis as a political issue. ``Republicans want to make sure people realize there's enough blame to go around,' McKernan said. Democratic National Chairman Ronald Brown, in Mobile for the governors' meeting, said the ads were a sign of ``absolute panic'' by Republicans over the S&L debacle. He compared it to Bush's use of Willie Horton, the felon who attacked a Maryland couple while on furlough from a Massachusetts prison, against Dukakis in 1988. ``They're kind of Willie Hortonizing the S&L issue,'' Brown said. Celeste said, ``If there's a Willie Horton in the S&L crisis, it's Neil Bush.'' That was a reference to the president's son, who is charged with violating conflict of interest regulations while he was on the board of a Colorado savings and loan. Some Republicans criticized the ads' timing during the conference. James Thompson of Illinois said the ads ``have no place at this conference.'' Gov.
