Carroll Campbell of South Carolina, head of the Republican governors, tried to smooth over the partisan differences when meeting with his Democratic colleagues, saying ``There's enough blame to go around'' on the S&L collapse. But in an interview, Campbell angrily blamed Brown's appearance in Mobile Monday on behalf of the Democratic candidate for governor of Alabama, Paul Hubbert, and Brown's remarks critical of host Gov. Guy Hunt, the state's first-ever Republican governor who is locked in a tight re-election race. Campbell said Brown's remarks and appearance showed ``a total lack of class'' and ``opened the door'' to the GOP attack ads. Mark Gearan, director of the Democratic Governors' Association, dismissed Campbell's remarks, saying the first ad was purchased before Brown's arrival. Democrats also pointed the finger at new Republican National Committee chief spokesman Charles Black. At the RNC, spokeswoman Leslie Goodman dismissed Democratic complaints and defended the ads. ``Any time a bunch of Democrats get together in the same place there is a propensity for a lot of hot air and distortion of the facts,'' she said. ``We just want to keep giving our subtle reminders of their culpability.'' The call for an independent commission came on a near-unanimous voice vote, despite White House comments on Monday that Bush would ignore the request. The governors adjourned after a final session where Washington state Gov. Booth Gardner, a Democrat, was installed as the new chairman, and Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, a Republican, was named vice chairman. In party caucuses, Democrats selected Colorado's Roy Romer and Mississippi's Ray Mabus as chairman and vice chairman of their Democratic Governors' Association.

DOC.HEAD: Two New Members Appointed to National Science Board
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate two new members of the National Science Board of the National Science Foundation, the White House said Tuesday. They are Bernard F. Burke, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor of astrophysics, and W. Glenn Campbell, director of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University. Bush also reappoined three academics to the board: University of Michigan President James J. Duderstadt, San Diego State University President Thomas B. Day and Perry L. Adkisson, chancellor of the Texas A&M University System. The White House also announced Bush will appoint IBM Corp. Chairman John F. Akera and AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen to the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy and Negotiations. Bush also announced plans to nominate Carolyn D. Leavens of Ventura, Calif., to the board of the Overseas Private Investment Corp. She is a partner in Leavens Ranches. The White House also announced these nominations: _Robert F. Goodwin, vice president and director of governmental affairs for the Meredith Corp. of Washington, D.C., to be a commissioner of the U.S.-Canada International Joint Commission. _Army Brig. Gen. Paul Y. Chinen to the Mississippi River Commission. Chinen is the commanding general of the U.S. Army Engineer Division, Ohio River, in Cincinnati. _Holland H. Coors of Colorado to the board of trustees of the Harry S. Truman Scholarship Foundation. The White House also announced Bush will appoint Chandler R. Lindsley, a rancher from Era, Texas, to be an alternate member of the Roosevelt Campobello International Park Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Rapist Who Chopped Off Girl's Arms Back in Jail for Petty Theft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Singleton on News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: A man who spent eight years in prison for raping a teen-ager and chopping off her forearms was sentenced Tuesday to 60 days in jail for stealing a disposable camera. Lawrence Singleton changed his plea from innocent to no contest on the misdemeanor petty-theft charge. ``I don't think I can get a fair trial. I never have.'' said Singleton, 62, who was chased out of several California towns after his highly publicized 1987 release. A security guard in a suburban Brandon drug store spotted Singleton taking a $10 camera from a display on April 8 and heading for the door with it tucked under his arm. Hillsborough County Judge Debra Behnke imposed the maximum sentence after the prosecutor argued that the convicted rapist's criminal record left no other choice. Singleton was jailed Tuesday at the Hillsborough County Jail. He was convicted of raping 15-year-old runaway Mary Vincent, cutting off her forearms with an ax and then leaving her for dead in a ditch along a central California roadside in 1978. To much public protest, Singleton was freed in 1987 after serving eight years and four months of a 14-year sentence. During his one-year parole, prison authorities shuttled Singleton from city to city in California, but protests followed his every move. Singleton's home state of Florida and the state of Nevada, where he maintained a home, both refused to take him. Singleton ended up living in a mobile home on the grounds of San Quentin Prison until his parole ended in 1988. His arrival at the home of relatives in Tampa in June of that year sparked community protest and a bomb threat, and he left after a few months, returning to California. It wasn't publicly known he was back in Florida until the shoplifting arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Win Elections, Invite Opposition to Join Government
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party won a wide majority in the nation's first free legislative elections and invited opposition parties to join the cabinet, the party chairman said Tuesday. A preliminary count of Sunday's election returns indicated the Communists won about 60 percent of the 53 seats in the Small Hural, one chamber of parliament, said Hurmetbek, vice chairman of the National Election Commission. Like many Mongolians, he uses a single name. The preliminary count also indicated that the Communists won at least 343 seats in the Great Hural. Hurmetbek said new elections may be required for 28 Great Hural seats. He said there were legal errors in three or four races, and in the other cases neither candidate received ballots from a majority of eligible voters. Many voters apparently did not know how to mark the ballots because it was the first time they had to choose between candidates. A Communist victory had been guaranteed in the elections in this Soviet-bloc country because the five new opposition parties lacked the time to put up candidates for each seat. The Small Hural will meet between the Great Hural's near-annual sessions and will draft legislation and make day-to-day decisions. ``From the results, we could see that the Mongolian people have great trust in the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party,'' party leader Gombojavyn Ochirbat told a news conference, using the formal name of the Communist Party. But he also said the Communists were ready to open talks with the opposition and give them an unspecified number of seats in the new Cabinet. ``We believe that in the new government ... new political parties should be represented,'' Ochirbat said. He said no date had been set to start talks with the opposition, but ``they know about it, that we are ready to negotiate.'' He said the participation of opposition parties ``will be vital for political stability and national unity.'' He said the government's first steps should be to make the election law more democratic, and to revise the constitution and other laws to protect the media and religion. Mass protests and a hunger strike by pro-democracy demonstrators last winter and spring forced the Communists to legalize opposition parties and agree to elections after decades of authoritarian rule. Batbayar, chairman of the opposition Social Democratic Party, said the opposition's gain of about 40 percent of the seats in the Small Hural was a victory. ``For a long time our people were under the exploitation of communism,'' he said. ``Now we are just coming from the darkness into a bright future. We think that anyway this election was the end of orthodox Communism in Mongolia.'' But opposition parties have also said the balloting was not a true measure of the popular will. The parties were legalized in May, after the nominating process had begun. More weight was given to rural votes, which tended to favor the Communists. Some opposition activists said local Communist officials intimidated rural voters into supporting them. The Communists have ruled this remote, Central Asian nation of 2 million people since 1921, making it the world's second-oldest Communist state after the Soviet Union. Ochirbat maintained that the Communists are committed to the same reforms as the opposition parties, including replacing state economic planning with a market-style economy. The government tentatively plans to begin freeing price controls for non-essential goods in January.

DOC.HEAD: September Start Date Set for Databank of Bad Doctors and Dentists
DOC.TEXT: A computerized databank of actions taken against incompetent physicians and dentists will open its electronic doors Sept. 1, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said Tuesday. The National Practitioner Databank is intended to prevent physicians and dentists who have been disciplined from moving to another state and setting up new practices without detection, he said. The databank will store reports of malpractice actions, licensure disciplinary actions by state medical and dental boards and actions by professional societies, hospitals and other health care entities after a formal peer review process. The reports must be made beginning Sept. 1. Actions taken before then do not have to be reported. Hospitals will be required to check the databank when a physician or dentist applies to join the medical staff or receive clinical privileges, Sullivan said. Also, hospitals will be required to check the databank every two years concerning physicians and dentists on their medical staffs or those who have clinical privileges. State licensing boards also will have access to the information, and individual physicians, dentists and other health care professionals will be able to see their own records. Attorneys representing a physician or dentist may have access under limited conditions. Charges for use of the databank will be $2 per name for each request. However, individual practitioners will not be charged for seeing his or her own file. The Ralph Nader-founded group Public Citizen has been critical of the data bank because members of the public will not have access to the information and retroactive reporting will not be required. The Public Citizen Health Research Group recently put out its own information in a book called ``The 6,892 Questionable Doctors Disciplined by States or the Federal Government.'' It lists the names of physicians and dentists who have been disciplined.

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins Defends City as Child Slay Suspects Nabbed
With AM-Murders, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police said three suspects showed no remorse Tuesday when they were charged with murdering a 9-month-old boy by blindly firing through a door to settle a dispute with the infant's uncle. An angry Mayor David Dinkins, questioned about the fourth slaying of a child in the city in eight days, asserted that the random violence does not mean the city ``is out of control.'' ``This is not Dodge City,'' he declared. Gunmen went to an apartment in the Bronx on Monday and fired repeatedly through the door. ``Behind that door, Rayvon Jamison sat in a child's walker and was struck by at least one of those shots,'' said Police Commissioner Lee Brown. Brown said the three suspects under arrest were trying to gun down the infant's uncle, Joseph Jamison. ``He was the object of the shooting. The child was the victim of the senseless violence,'' said Brown. Jamison and eight others _ including the victim's mother and grandmother _ were inside the apartment when the baby was shot. Jamison, 29, had chastised one of the suspects last Thursday for a throwing a bottle, and animosity had escalated over the weekend, Brown said. The petty nature of the dispute ``adds to the tragedy of this shooting,'' Brown said. ``It also gives a clear message that the value or the sanctity of life means little to someone who has easy access to weapons.'' ``No remorse was shown by the three men'' when they learned of the child's death, said police Detective Ellen Hale. The suspects were charged with second-degree murder, criminal possession of a deadly weapon, and reckless endangerment, Brown said. The three previous slayings of children all occurred in the borough of Brooklyn. Veronica Corales, 9, was killed while sleeping in her parent's car; 3-year-old Ben Williams died in his sleep when 18 bullets were fired through the front door of his home; and 1-year-old Yaritimi Fruto was fatally wounded by a gunman who also killed her father. The rash of killings has put Dinkins under pressure, and the mayor reacted angrily to reporters who questioned his election-year pledge to become the toughest mayor on crime in city history. ``There is law and order. Things are not out of control and this is not Dodge City,'' said Dinkins. ``One cannot guard against the kind of random violence that occurred when they shot in these doors and took the lives of children.'' Despite Dinkins' assertion, the city is on its way to a record number of homicides for the third straight year. If projections hold up, last year's all-time high of 1,905 murders will be surpassed this year. The three under arrest were identified as Anthony Rupert, 18, and two cousins, Thane Bobie West, 18, and Mike Solomon, 22.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Tough Criminal Penalties for S&L Wrongdoers
With AM-Deposit Insurance Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The House voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to toughen criminal penalties for rip-offs by savings and loan officials and to create a special prosecutor and a national commission on the scandal. The legislation was brought hastily to the full House so lawmakers could vote tough on S&L crime before they recess for the summer at week's end. It passed 424-4. The American taxpayers have been ``terrorized by thugs whose weapons were pens, not guns,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. ``If this measure is enacted, there will be no more excuses for government inaction,'' he said. The agency overseeing the bailout of the thrift industry has said it will need up to $100 billion in fiscal 1991 alone to deal with the tidal wave of insolvencies. The bill would increase the maximum prison terms _ up to life in prison for the worst offenders _ and boost fines that could be levied against individuals and institutions convicted of savings and loan crimes. It also would create new felony categories to close loopholes for those who conceal assets from the government or who try to obstruct government inquiries into financial institutions, and give the government new authority to go after the assets of failed S&Ls. The bill would authorize adding $153 million to the federal government's law enforcement efforts, and create a ``special counsel'' within the Justice Department to oversee a new Financial Institutions Fraud Unit. It also would create a national commission, opposed by President Bush, to examine the causes of the thrift crisis and propose steps to prevent its repetition. Banking committee Chairman Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, one of the few to vote against the measure, said proponents hoped the measure would ``fool the American people'' that the crisis was being solved. ``What we have here is a bastard child with all the defects,'' he argued. Gonzalez' panel, expert on the issue, was bypassed by the House leadership in its push for swift election-year action. ``I'd say `Baloney,' but I don't even know if that word is sufficient to describe what is happening today,'' said Rep. Paul Kanjorski, D-Pa., who joined Gonzalez in his lonely criticism of the bill. Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa, acknowledged that the bill might be ``a bit overzealous,'' but Congress had to act. The S&L operators had proven, he said, that ``You don't have to break into Fort Knox to steal the government's gold.'' Only Reps. Craig Washington, D-Texas, and Philip Crane, R-Ill., joined Gonzalez and Kanjorski in voting against the bill. The Senate passed its version of a savings and loan crackdown as part of an overall crime bill. The two chambers must reconcile their differences before a bill can be sent to the president.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Lunden Denies Plans for Divorce or Having Alien Baby
DOC.TEXT: If inquiring minds really want to know, Joan Lunden is not leaving ``Good Morning America,'' or getting a divorce, or having an alien's baby. She confided all this Tuesday after telling viewers of ABC's morning show that National Enquirer reporters have been asking her colleagues if she seems troubled lately. ``It was a pre-emptive strike,'' she said afterwards. ``I told them (her colleagues), I could either do that or just be a wimp and sit back and let them make up whatever they want and print it.'' ``As far as I know, this was just something we were checking out and we've no plans to run a story,'' said Ian Calder, editor of the tabloid paper in Lantana, Fla. During Tuesday's show, Lunden, speaking with co-host Charles Gibson, said two free-lance reporters working for the Enquirer, had been calling her colleagues, and in one case one of them posed as an ABC publicist. She said the tabloid newshawks said things about her, like ``we hear she's been acting strange lately, crying on the set, depressed'' _ she mock-whimpered _ ``and we want to know what's going on in her life.'' She and her friends have been taking bets on what the Enquirer's story will be, she said, jokingly posing a multiple-choice question: ``Am I going to leave the show, leave my husband, or maybe have an alien baby? And it turns out they apparently voted for my husband and I to get a divorce.'' After the show, she said she isn't leaving her top-rated show, and she and her husband, Michael Krauss, are not getting a divorce. ``And I'm not having an alien baby.'' The Enquirer this week has a story with the headline ``Friendly Aliens Altered My Body and Changed My Life.'' Calder said the queries about Lunden concerned problems her husband, a TV producer, has had due to lawsuits stemming from production bills for ``Everyday,'' a syndicated program on which Lunden is hostess, he said. ``We had a tip that that caused some trouble between them,'' said Calder, who denied that the free-lancers checking out the tip posed as other than themselves. ``I think what we were checking out was, in the wake of the financial problems that her husband had had, if this would affect the marriage,'' he said. As far as he knows, he said, ``it never came to anything.'' There was no query about whether Lunden and her husband, who have three children, were divorcing, said Calder. ``No, I think that's going too far. As far as I know, we never got a tip they were thinking about getting a divorce.''
