DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE DEBT LIMIT ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Weather, Shorter Days Help Firefighters in Alaska
DOC.TEXT: Scattered rain, lower temperatures and shorter days helped firefighters battle more than 100 blazes that have burned more than 2 million acres of Alaskan wildlands, a spokeswoman said Tuesday. Smaller fires burned in Washington, Idaho, Oregon and California. Several days of cloudy skies and temperatures in the 50s and 60s across much of Alaska's interior have reduced the intensity of many fires, said Sue Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the Interagency Fire Information Center. ``And we're having darkness at night now, which really helps cool things down,'' she said. Earlier this summer, the sun was almost continually above the horizon and temperatures in some places were in the 90s, drying out forests and tundra. Alaska's wildfire season began on July 1, as lightning strikes ignited dozens of blazes in remote regions. On Tuesday, more than 100 fires burned across the state. More than 827 firefighters battled the Tok River fire near the town of Tok 175 miles southeast of Fairbanks. The blaze has charred about 91,200 acres. Crews have nearly surrounded the 142-square-mile fire with a fire line, Mitchell said. Using bulldozers and hand tools, crews have removed vegetation along more than 60 miles of fire line, hoping to rob the advancing fire of fuel. The state's largest fire burned across 275,000 acres along either side of the Coleen River on the southern flank of the Brooks Range, inside the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Cuts Bush Request for Star Wars, Missile Funds
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 7 grafs new with panel rejecting amendment to save B-2 bomber; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Bush, who; minor editing thereafter. Top planned after committee action on bill, expected early evening.
DOC.TEXT: The House Armed Services Committee dealt a serious blow Tuesday to President Bush's hopes of building a fleet of 75 stealth bombers, halting the program at the 15 B-2s now under construction, lawmakers said. The committee, meeting in private, rejected an attempt to save the 75-plane fleet. At nearly $865 million each, the radar-evading bomber is the costliest plane ever built. The death knells for the bomber began last week when the committee's chairman, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said he supported halting production at 15 planes. Monday night, the panel's procurement subcommittee eliminated funds for a 75-bomber fleet. The full committee voted 34-20 Tuesday to reject an amendment by Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., to reverse the subcommittee's action, Aspin told reporters. Separately, the research and development subcommittee chopped nearly $2 billion from Bush's 1991 budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative and eliminated research money for two nuclear missiles. Also meeting in private, the subcommittee approved spending $2.9 billion on SDI, commonly known as Star Wars. Later in the day, the full committee was expected to vote on the overall bill, which would allocate $283 billion for defense in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Bush, who in January proposed spending $307 billion on defense in fiscal 1991, had called for $4.7 billion for SDI, a $900 million increase over the amount Congress appropriated in fiscal 1990. Congressional support for the anti-missile shield, however, has weakened significantly as the Soviet threat fades overseas and economic problems rise at home. Earlier this month, the Senate Armed Services Committee approved a fiscal 1991 defense bill that cut almost $1 billion from Bush's SDI request. To meet the House-approved budget target of $283 billion for overall military spending, the House committee has been forced to slash $24 billion from Bush's request of early this year. Since Thursday, the six subcommittees have been making substantial reductions to meet the target, and on Tuesday the research panel focused on a handful of strategic programs. Bush had called for spending $548 million on the multiple-warhead MX missiles and on moving the missiles from silos to rail cars. The fiscal 1991 budget also included $202 million for the single-warhead Midgetman. The research subcommittee eliminated all research funds for the two missiles and, instead, created a $600 million advanced strategic missile pot for developing the next generation of missiles. The panel also called on Bush to report to the committee in 90 days on which new missile the administration wants _ MX or Midgetman _ and end the debate that has festered for years. The research subcommittee's actions came less than 24 hours after the Armed Services' subcommittee on procurement and military nuclear systems eliminated 1.3 billion for financing the MX rail-garrison program. As for the B-2, Bush had proposed a fleet of 132 bombers last January. In April, the administration scaled its proposal back to 75. While making substantial cuts in strategic programs, the panel rejected an effort by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to kill the Marine Corps' V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft that takes off like a helicopter but can fly like a plane. The subcommittee approved $238 million for the Osprey. On Monday, the procurement subcommittee added somewhat less, $165 million, for the V-22.

DOC.HEAD: Government Checks North Decision For Possible Impact on Other Cases
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is reviewing the appeals court decision that upset Oliver L. North's Iran-Contra convictions because of concern about its possible impact on future cases, officials said Tuesday. In a 2-1 decision, a panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ordered a ``witness-by-witness'' review of the evidence to determine if North's trial was influenced by congressional testimony he gave under a limited grant of immunity from prosecution. The ``use immunity'' grant meant that the detailed descriptions of the Iran-Contra affair that North gave Congress couldn't be used against him as evidence in a criminal trial. Independent Councsel Lawrence E. Walsh's office is considering whether to seek a rehearing of the case by the full 12-member appellate court or to ask the Supreme Court to review the issue. Walsh has at least a month to decide. Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said officials were concerned about the decision's impact on a limited number of cases where the government might want to prosecute someone whose congressional testimony received widespread publicity. Other department officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the new procedures could have wider implications, particularly in cases where defendants receive limited immunity from courts or grand juries. North, a former National Security Council aide, was convicted last year of three felonies, including aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress and destruction of government documents. Gesell placed North on probation and ordered him to perform 1500 hours of community service. The appellate court held that U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell should have conducted extensive hearings to determine if grand jurors, witnesses and prosecutors were influenced by North's congressional testimony, which was aired on network television. Gesell had held that the elaborate procedures that Walsh imposed to shield grand jurors and his staff from the publicity prevented the case from being influenced by North's testimony. Walsh also placed under court seal evidence his investigation found before North appeared on Capitol Hill to prove that the case was derived independently from the congressional testimony. As it stands, the decision applies only to federal courts in the nation's capital. But those courts try many of the so-called political cases, in which criminal defendants already have been subjects of congressional inquiries. Eramian said the department was conducting its own review of the July 20 decision. He stressed that the Justice Department was not necessarily contemplating participation in any appeal. Under the independent counsel law, the Justice Department could file a friend-of-the-court brief to state its legal views on the case. The appeals court panel's majority set what federal prosecutors called a very high, perhaps impossible, standard for proving that evidence was not derived from testimony that a defendant gave under a limited immunity grant. Some legal experts say the North decision radically extends a 1972 Supreme Court decision that bars prosecutors from introducing evidence that was derived in any way from testimony obtained as a result of limited immunity. ``What they did in this case was to virtually change use immunity into transactional immunity,'' under which the government agrees not to prosecute someone in return for their cooperation, said G. Robert Blakey, a Notre Dame law professor who drafted the 1970 use immunity statute. The court, in effect, created a rule that ``once anything was disseminated as widely as North's testimony, it necessarily affected the trial,'' Blakey said. Gerald Caplan, a George Washington University law professor, called the North decision ``sort of an ingenious way of overruling a Supreme Court decision from a group that would otherwise be thought to have a prosecution bias.'' President Reagan appointed the two circuit judges who joined in the ruling, Laurence H. Silberman and David Sentelle. President Carter appointed Patricia Wald, the appellate court's chief judge who dissented from the decision. ``The two majority judges simply let North off,'' Blakey said. ``This opinion harkens back to a kind of solicitude for the defendant that was characteristic of Warren Court opinions and hardly charactistic of Reagan court opinions.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Campaign Finance
Senate Bill Counts on More Public Campaign Funding
DOC.TEXT: Campaign reforms approved by the Senate envision new multimillion-dollar public contributions to Senate candidates at the same time taxpayers are cutting back donations to presidential campaigns. The Senate, still debating the measure, has approved provisions that include public financing of up to $20 million for broadcast time. The money would be available to candidates who agree to stay within a spending limit. Also approved Monday were other incentives to abide by the ceiling _ including postal discounts, help in responding to interest-group attacks and money to offset funds raised by an opponent who exceeds the spending limit. The public money for the Senate races would come from the existing and already strained fund for presidential campaigns. Taxpayers can choose to contribute to the fund by earmarking $1 from their tax returns. But contributions to the presidential campaign are dwindling. ``The presidential fund is in trouble,'' said Fred Eiland, a spokesman for the Federal Election Commission. ``We have been saying since two years ago that there is a problem, and that it's going to be more serious and that Congress needs to do something.'' Taxpayer participation in the presidential campaign fund reached an all-time high of 28.7 percent in 1980 and fell to a record low of 20.1 percent in 1988, the FEC said. Donations to the fund dwindled from $33.6 million in 1987 to $32.2 million in 1989, Eiland said. Tax returns through May 1990 brought in about $25 million, and the Internal Revenue Service says relatively few returns are still expected from taxpayers given extensions. The strain on the fund has been compounded by inflation. As participation has dropped, payouts to candidates have been rising each year to adjust for inflation. The FEC has advised the president, Congress and the treasury secretary that it expects a $202,000 shortfall in 1992, when the presidential campaign is projected to cost about $184 million. If no incumbent is seeking re-election in 1996, that could mean more candidates for both major parties. The FEC projects a $238 million shortfall that year for an election expected to cost about $270 million. The FEC paid out $178 million for the 1988 election. As of May 1990, there was a balance of $108 million in the presidential campaign fund.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leaders Keeping Stay Neutral on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO voted Tuesday to remain neutral on abortion but said it resented government intrusion into personal matters. ``The overwhelming view of the council was that this was a matter of deep conscience, conviction and religion,'' Lane Kirkland, president of the labor umbrella group, told reporters. The vote by the AFL-CIO's 35-member executive council rejected a call from some members who wanted to back abortion rights in hopes it would help recruit women and minorities into the struggling labor movement. ``We resent and resist government intrusion into matters that are essentially private...,'' the executive council said in a policy statement issued at the group's annual mid-summer meeting. ``The AFL-CIO, therefore, adopts a carefully considered policy of deferring to the individual judgments of its affiliates and their members on'' abortion, said the statement, issued by the governing board. Three members of the council dissented during the voice vote. In voting to remain neutral, the council adopted the recommendation of an 18-member panel of AFL-CIO union presidents. Kirkland declined to speculate at a news conference about whether a pro-choice vote would have helped expand the 14.2 million-member organization. The group has never in its 35-year history voted on abortion rights, he said. There was no organized move afoot for the federation to condemn abortion. However, the National Right to Life Committee and Cardinal John J. O'Connor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York had campaigned against the AFL-CIO taking a stand. They noted that a recent Supreme Court decision gives union members the right to withhold dues spent on political issues. Many union leaders interpreted that campaign as a threat by the committee and O'Connor that they would lobby members to withhold union dues if the AFL-CIO went pro-choice. ``We received a very large volume of mail on both sides of the issue...,'' Kirkland said. ``We don't regard that as pressure. You only have pressure if you feel pressure.'' On other issues, the AFL-CIO's governing body voted to: _Support President Bush's call for new taxes to raise revenue and curb the budget deficit. But new revenues ``should be sought through higher bracket rates for the wealthy and corporations, as well as higher taxes on inherited wealth,'' the union said. _Oppose proposals such as a national value-added tax or raising excise taxes on cigarettes, beer and Social Security benefits. The union also said it opposes efforts to eliminate or reduce the federal deduction for state and local taxes. _Support an individual federal campaign contribution limit of $100 per candidate and $1,000 per year coupled with a ban on all political action committees.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Introduce Bills To Improve Medical Research on Women
DOC.TEXT: A group of Democratic senators, introducing a package of bills Tuesday to improve medical research on women, said women have been ill-served in a medical system that is dominated by men. Rep. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., leader of the effort, said women have been ignored in a ``disgraceful pattern of neglect.'' She pointed to the National Institutes of Health, where she said 13 percent of funds are spent on women's health research and few women are included in clinical trials testing experimental drugs and procedures. Even though heart disease is the No. 1 killer of women, nearly all the heart disease research is done on men, she said. Also, the breast cancer death rate is rising but ``no one knows why,'' she said. ``Clearly there has been an imbalance,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. ``This gender bias must be corrected,'' said Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash. ``What we're really talking about is women's lives.'' Two proposals _ to create an NIH office for Women's Health Research and Development and require that more women be included in clinical trials _ were to be offered as amendments to a bill reauthorizing NIH. The bill was to be taken up by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee on Wednesday. Other bills in the package would broaden research on contraception, infertility, AIDS in women, breast cancer and osteoporosis; improve and broaden health education programs for women; and offer more screening for early detection of cancer. Similar legislation is pending in the House. The package would cost about $240 million, which Mikulski said was ``a very modest amount.'' But she said she did not expect all of the bills to pass this year.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Prices at Farm Unchanged in July, Says USDA
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products were unchanged from June to July, but the overall commodity index was still 2.7 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Prices were higher during the month for lettuce, apples and milk, but declines were reported for cattle, wheat and eggs, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. Most prices are mid-July averages which will be revised next month. For example, the latest report showed June prices dropped 2 percent instead of the 1.3 percent decline indicated a month ago. The report also showed prices farmers pay to meet expenses were up 0.5 percent from April, when the previous estimate was made, and 3.4 percent above July 1989. The ``prices paid'' index is computed quarterly. Meanwhile, department economists say consumer food prices are going up much faster this year than the earlier prediction of 3 percent to 5 percent. Ralph L. Parlett Jr. of the department's Economic Research Service said in a telephone interview that a new 1990 forecast due out in August will ``put us right back to the early 1980s'' when retail food prices were climbing steeply. According to USDA records, annual food price increases were 8.6 percent in 1980 and 7.9 percent in 1981 before slowing their upward rise in the next few years. Parlett did not disclose the new forecast but indicated the 1990 increase would probably exceed 6 percent. Food prices rose 5.8 percent in 1989, the most since 1981. ``It's obvious that 3-to-5 percent forecast is out in left field,'' he said. ``Beef and pork, that's what's doing it; pork, particularly.'' Recent forecasts show the net cash income of farmers in the range of $55 billion to $59 billion, compared with about $54 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $47 billion to $51 billion, compared with $49 billion last year. Based on the preliminary figures, the July price index for livestock and poultry dropped 1.2 percent from June but still averaged 8.9 percent more than a year ago. Meat animals were down 1.5 percent from June but averaged 11 percent more than in June 1989. Milk prices rose 30 cents in July to an average of $14.10 per l00 pounds. That was up $1.50 from July 1989. The farm price of milk rose to a record $16 per hundredweight in December before easing down. Crop prices, overall, rose 1.6 percent from June but averaged 4.4 percent below the year-earlier level. Vegetable prices rose 20 percent from June but were down 14 percent from a year earlier. Lettuce, tomatoes and sweet corn led the July increase. Fruit prices were up 7.9 percent from June and 13 percent above a year ago. Apples, grapefruit and peaches rose in July, while oranges, pears and lemons were down. Wheat prices, pressured by a bumper harvest, dropped 27 cents during the month to $2.81 per bushel. Feed grains declined, with corn prices down two cents from June to $2.61 per bushel. The report said: _Cattle averaged $97 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, down from $98.10 in June but up from $94.60 in July 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $60.10 per 100 pounds, unchanged from June but up from $45.90 in July 1989. _Corn, at $2.61 a bushel, was down from $2.63 in June but up from $2.47 a year earlier. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $2.81 per bushel, compared with $3.08 in June and $3.78 a year earlier. _Rice averaged $7.10 per 100 pounds, compared with $7.08 in June and $7.45 in July 1989. _Soybeans were $5.88 per bushel, unchanged from June but down from $6.83 a year earlier. _Upland cotton was reported at 63.7 cents per pound, compared with 62.3 in June and 59.5 a year earlier. _Eggs were 55.6 cents per dozen, compared with 62.7 in June and 64.9 in July 1989. _Milk was $14.10 per 100 pounds, up from $13.80 in June and the average of $12.60 a year ago. _Broilers were 36.9 cents per pound, live weight, compared with 34.1 cents in June and 38.7 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Risk of Blast at Nuclear Waste Site Worries Officials
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS after 6th graf pvs, Leo Duffy, to clarify status of other sites, picks up 7th graf pvs, Westinghouse Hanford.
DOC.TEXT: Too little is known about the risk of an explosion that could rupture nuclear waste tanks at the Hanford weapons plant in Washington state, a government advisory panel said Tuesday. The possibility of a blast may be greater than plant operators acknowledge because there is ``only sketchy information on conditions in the tanks,'' said the Energy Department's Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety. ``The Hanford tanks present a serious situation, if not an imminent hazard,'' the committee said. The 177 underground tanks at Hanford in south-central Washington state hold thousands of gallons of highly radioactive sludge from decades of plutonium production at the weapons plant. Officials last March said they were concerned because an explosion could be triggered by an accumulation of hydrogen or other unknown chemical reactions in some of the 20 double-walled tanks at the facility. Leo Duffy, who heads government cleanup efforts at atomic weapons facilities, said Tuesday the chance of an explosion is low but is still a serious problem. Highly radioactive wastes also are stored in tanks at the Savannah River weapons plant near Aiken, S.C., and at a plant near West Valley, N.Y. But those tanks contain different chemicals and do not pose the same risks as the tanks at Hanford, Energy Department officials have said. Westinghouse Hanford Co., which runs the 560-square-mile facility in south-central Washington, has played down the possibility of an explosion. But the Energy Department panel suggested in a letter to Energy Secretary James Watkins that the Hanford operators may have incomplete or incorrect information. ``The technical basis for the analysis from which the (Hanford) operator draws comfort about the safety of the tanks is weak, considering the potential consequences,'' the panel said. ``Each successive review of the Hanford tanks indicates that the situation is a little worse.'' The panel made the assessment in a July 23 letter to Watkins made public by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee on Tuesday. John Ahearne, chairman of the advisory panel, declined to characterize the risk of an explosion because of the lack of information. He said no one knows what chemical combinations are in the tanks and unreliable temperature sensors may be misleading. ``There is an urgent need to determine what is in the tanks, what are the risks and what actions should be taken to ameliorate the hazards,'' the advisory panel report said. An accident involving similarly stored wastes in the Soviet Union in 1957 released huge amounts of radiation and contaminated an area covering hundreds of square miles, forcing the evacuation of 10,000 people. To this day, children are not allowed near the areas that were heavily contaminated, and agricultural crops from the region are not allowed to be sold elsewhere, officials said. But Duffy said the Soviet site is not the same as the Hanford plant. ``We have a huge gap here. We're trying to find out what's in the existing tanks,'' Duffy said. Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., calling for more investigation, said the Energy Department and plant operators remind him of ``three witches with a bubbling caldron, saying ``bubble, bubble, toil and trouble. They're stirring it and don't seem to know what's in there.''

DOC.HEAD: Freighter to Evacuate 100 Foreign Nationals From Jaffna
DOC.TEXT: A freighter left Colombo for rebel-held Jaffna on Tuesday to evacuate about 100 foreign nationals caught in the cross fire between Tamil guerrillas and the army. Officials meanwhile reported that at least 54 people were killed in two days of fighting across this island nation off the southeast tip of India. Military officials said the freighter Lanka Siri sailed for Point Pedro at the northernmost tip of the Jaffna Peninsula, which has been severed from the mainland by the 50-day fighting. The ship was expected to return Wednesday. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 90 of those awaiting evacuation carried British passports. Most were Tamil expatriates who were visiting their homeland when fighting broke out on June 11, ending a 13-month cease-fire in the 7-year-old civil war. One person carried a Swiss passport, officials said, and they did not know the others' nationalities. Communications with Jaffna have been cut off. The evacuation was being supervised by the International Committee of the Red Cross, said the officials. Military officials said at least seven rebels and five soldiers were killed in fighting Tuesday in northwestern Mannar. On Monday night, unidentified gunmen killed 20 Tamil civilians in northeastern Kantalai village, military officials and residents said. Tamil residents of nearby Trincomalee town blamed the and said the killings were in retribution for a Tamil rebel ambush on troops two days earlier. Military officials said the assailants were Moslems who attacked to avenge Tamil raids on their community. The officials said earlier Tuesday that rebels shot 14 Moslems to death in the Ampara district, south of Trincomalee. Moslems, who comprise about 7 percent of the 16 million population, are often caught in the middle of the civil war between the minority Tamils and Sinhalese-dominated government. The rebels accuse them of siding with the army. In Jaffna, at least six rebels and two police were killed, military officials said. They said guards at Palali airfield killed the rebels and that the police were killed when air force planes accidentally dropped bombs close to Jaffna Fort. The deaths raise to more than 3,000 the number of combatants killed in the fighting, the latest phase of the war for an independent Tamil homeland. Many civilians also have died. Tamils makie up 18 percent of the million population. They complain they are discriminated against in jobs and education by the Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of Sri Lankans and who control the army and the government. More than 14,000 people have died in the Tamil revolt since it began in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Usual Suspects Top Ratings, As Summer Viewership Plummets
With AM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Roseanne'' was the most popular program on television last week. The show aired the day before its star, Roseanne Barr, was roundly criticized for her screeching rendition of the national anthem at San Diego's Jack Murphy Stadium. ``Roseanne'' led with a 14.6 rating, according to figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. A rating point represents 921,000 households. It also was No. 1 in every target demographic group, said David Marans, a vice president for media research at the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. In overall ratings, ABC pulled even with NBC, the perennial winner. Both averaged an 8.9 rating for the week. CBS was third at 8.4, but each averaged only a 17 share _ or 17 percent of the televisions in use in prime time. That meant hardly anyone was watching, Marans said. ``The three networks' share was a 51 for the week. That's among the lowest, if not the lowest ever recorded,'' he said. ``They received about half the available viewers. That has to be a cause for heartache for them.'' Another situation comedy rerun, NBC's ``Cheers,'' was No. 2, and CBS' rerun of its 1987 miniseries ``Murder Ordained'' on Sunday night tied for third place with NBC's ``The Cosby Show.'' The ``shocking four-hour miniseries'' starred Keith Carradine, JoBeth Williams and Terry Kinney in the true-life tale of a minister's adultery and two murders that rocked Emporia, Kan. NBC won the ratings on three nights: Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday, but its Sunday ratings suffered at the hands of the Fox Broadcasting Co. hits ``The Simpsons,'' ``Married ... with Children'' and ``In Living Color.'' ``They had a terrible Sunday,'' Marans said. ``An 11 share was one of the lowest nights NBC has ever recorded.'' Fox found its own woes by experimenting with two new shows and a special on Wednesday, said Tim Dempsey, another media analyst at J. Walter Thompson. ``They're not exempt from viewer defection and viewer desertion,'' Dempsey said. Fox's ``Molloy,'' ``Glory Days'' and the special ``Hollywood Dog'' were the lowest-rated programs on television, each drawing a 5 share. Curiously enough, reruns are outperforming the original programs the networks have offered this summer in hopes of keeping viewers glued to the tube, Dempsey said. ``There's always been a general feeling during the summer season that all these shows are failed pilots,'' he said. ``They're being perceived as filler, and that they weren't strong enough to make it onto the lineup permanently.'' Here are the top 10 reruns, with their networks and ratings: ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 14.6; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 14.4; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 13.3; ``CBS Sunday Movie'' (``Murder Ordained''), CBS, 13.3; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 13.1; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC, 12.9; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 12.9; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 12.3; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 12.3; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 12.2. In the battle for network evening news ratings, ABC won again with an 8.9 rating. CBS was second with a 7.8 rating, fractionally ahead of NBC's 7.6.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Lifts News Blackout on Grant-Review Sessions
DOC.TEXT: Under the pressure of a lawsuit filed by four major newspapers, the National Endowment for the Arts reversed itself Tuesday and announced that a meeting of its advisory council to review controversial grant decisions will be open to the public. Chairman John E. Frohnmayer abandoned plans for a news blackout of the council sessions later this week after the Los Angeles Times, The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Philadelphia Inquirer sued the NEA in U.S. District Court on Monday. ``It is highly unusual for any agency of the federal government to conduct application review in the glare of public scrutiny,'' Frohnmayer said in a statement. ``But I am convinced that there are significant advantages to having our citizens aware of how this small amount of their money is invested in cultural activities all Americans enjoy as a result of the endowment.'' The NEA is an independent federal agency with a budget of $171 million, most of which supports a wide variety of artists and arts institutions with federal grants that must be matched by private funds. The 26-member National Council on the Arts, the endowment's presidentially appointed advisory body, plans to begin a three-day meeting here Friday. In the past, its meetings have been open to the public except for sessions devoted to reviewing grant applications recommended by the NEA's panels of outside arts experts on theater, dance, music and other disciplines. As late as Monday, Frohnmayer had insisted that the council's grant-review sessions would be closed. But on Tuesday, he said he decided to lift the news blackout partly because a majority of council members had voted at their last meeting in May to open the sessions. In their lawsuit seeking a temporary restraining order against the NEA, the four newspapers said a news blackout would prevent the public from observing the council as it reconsiders Frohnmayer's veto of panel-approved grants to four controversial, avant-garde theater performers in late June. After Frohnmayer's announcement, the newspapers' lawyers withdrew the lawsuit. One of the lawyers, Patrick J. Carome, had said earlier that the NEA was ``acting as if they're giving away private money when in fact it's taxpayer dollars.'' Arts supporters said the public is entitled to know how its tax money is being spent. At the council meetings this weekend, Frohnmayer also was expected to ask the council to reconsider its recommendation that he reject two grants to the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia. He said the council's discussion of the grants in May was inadequate and its information was incomplete. It was the same Philadelphia institute that started the current NEA controversy when it used endowment funds to organize a traveling exhibition of sexually explicit works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. Last fall, at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other NEA critics, Congress voted to prohibit federal support for any artistic works that ``may be considered obscene'' and include depiction of sex acts, sadomasochism, homoeroticism or sexual exploitation of children. Frohnmayer told an independent commission created by Congress to study the NEA's grant-making procedures that he still opposes legislation to restrict the content of federally supported art. But the endowment's chairman said he believes that an arts project that is ``so offensive that it simply leads to confrontation and solidification of positions'' should not receive government support. Frohnmayer has issued guidelines to NEA grant applicants to refrain from using federal funds to create works that might violate the Supreme Court's 1973 obscenity standards. He told the commission Monday that he could accept a law imposing penalties on NEA grant recipients who are convicted on obscenity charges.

DOC.HEAD: Bangladesh Gives Ultimatum to Striking Doctors
DOC.TEXT: Bangladesh on Tuesday ordered 8,000 striking government doctors to return to work or be fired. The doctors, in turn, threatened to resign en masse on Aug. 15. News reports said at least 50 people died due to lack of medical care over the last three days in Dhaka, the capital; Rangapur; and Khulna. A spokesman for Dhaka Medical College Hospital, the country's largest, said about 1,100 of the hospital's 1,500 patients went home Tuesday because they were not being treated and that hundreds more left other hospitals. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Health Minister Azizur Rahman called the 4-day-old strike illegal. He said the government would not reconsider its new health policy, which seeks to ban private practice by government doctors. President Hussain Muhammad Ershad's announcement of the policy Wednesday led to doctors' protests and then to a strike Saturday at the 600 state hospitals. General Secretary Mostafa Jalal Mohiuddin of the Bangladesh Medical Association said the strike will continue because the government refused to meet doctors' demands. He said the doctors plan to resign in a group on Aug. 15. About 500 doctors have already given their resignation letters to the medical association, he said. Mohiuddin said all letters will be handed over to the Health Ministry if the government does not call off the new health policy. Parliament, dominated by Ershad's Jatiya (National) Party, endorsed the policy late Monday but delayed indefinitely making it law. The strikers demand that the government spend more money for the health sector instead of barring them from private practice. An impoverished nation of 110 million people, Bangladesh spends about one dollar per person annually for medicare. The annual per capita income is $170. The dispute has turned political. The two main opposition groups, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party and the Bangladesh Awami League, asked the government in separate statements to withdraw the health policy. About 1,000 Jatiya Party activists marched through Dhaka on Monday, chanting ``Death to the striking doctors!''

DOC.HEAD: Virginia's Copy of Bill of Rights to Tour Nation
DOC.TEXT: Virginia's copy of the Bill of Rights will go on a 50-state tour to mark the bicentennial of its ratification. Virginia approved the Bill of Rights on Dec. 15, 1791, the 11th and final state needed for ratification. Its copy was restored recently and will be on loan from the Virginia State Library and Archives. The tour, sponsored by Philip Morris Cos. Inc., begins Oct. 10 in Barre, Vt., and ends here in February 1992, the sponsors announced Tuesday. The tour is part of a $60 million campaign by the food, cigarette and beer company extolling the Bill of Rights. The campaign has also included television and print advertisements. Guy L. Smith IV, vice president for corporate affairs, denied Philip Morris launched the advertising campaign to fight proposed smoking restrictions. Six million Americans are expected to see the free exhibit, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Mexico President's Kin Convicted in DEA Slaying
DOC.TEXT: The brother-in-law of a former Mexican president was found guilty Tuesday of racketeering, kidnapping and conspiracy in the death of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. Ruben Zuno Arce, a successful Guadalajara businessman, was the third defendant to be found guilty in a trial which sought to place blame on many in the 1985 kidnap-murder of Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. He wasn't charged with murder. The case has strained relations between Mexico and the United States because of U.S. officials allegations of complicity between Mexican officials and drug dealers. Prosecutors said the slayings were revenge for Drug Enforcement Administration raids on marijuana and cocaine plantations that cost the drug barons $5 billion in profits. Zuno is the brother-in-law of Luis Echeverria, the former president of Mexico. His lawyers maintained he had nothing to do with the Camarena affair and merely had the bad luck to sell his Guadalajara home to a drug kingpin who used the place as a torture chamber. The key evidence against Zuno came from two government informants who were former Mexican policemen. One of them told of seeing Zuno at a meeting in which drug barons discussed the need to kidnap a drug enforcement agent. The other witness told of alleged drug trade activities by Zuno. His lawyers claimed he was an upstanding businessman without ties to the underworld. The same jurors previously convicted two other defendants of racketeering and kidnapping. Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican policeman, was found guilty of kidnapping but innocent of murder on Monday. Last week, reputed drug baron Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros was convicted of the Camarena kidnapping, but the jury also declined to convict him of murder. One verdict remains pending against Javier Vasquez Velasco, who is accused of murdering two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing. Jurors resumed their deliberations Tuesday afternoon following announcement of the verdicts and lawyers were told by U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie to refrain from commenting until all the verdicts were in. Rafeedie scheduled sentencing for Zuno on Sept. 18. Zuno faces a maximum sentence of life in prison. The 31-year-old Camarena was kidnapped off a Guadalajara street in February 1985. Testimony showed the agent was tortured and interrogated by drug lords before being slain along with Avelar. Their bodies were found a month later on a ranch 65 miles from Guadalajara. The trial was the second stemming from the Camarena murder, which strained U.S.-Mexican relations and embarrassed Mexico with testimony about dealings between corrupt law enforcement officers and drug dealers. In a 1988 Los Angeles federal trial, two defendants were convicted of multiple charges, including murder, in the Camarena case and a third defendant was convicted of aiding the escape of Mexican drug lord Rafael Caro Quintero. The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in the slaying. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country. Over 20 have been imprisoned in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Confirms A-12 Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's inspector general is investigating the production schedule and cost projections for the Navy's A-12 attack plane, the Defense Department spokesman said on Tuesday. The probe is the second being conducted in connection with the planned aircraft. The A-12, which is under development, is supposed to be the Navy's top priority replacement for its aging fleet of A-6 Intruder attack jets. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney wanted more information about reports he'd received on the program. ``The secretary said ... `I've got some questions, I want them answered,''' Williams said. The inspector general's office ``is conducting what I would characterize as a limited investigation of the A-12 schedule and cost projections.'' The aircraft has been the focus of some controversy since the Navy announced earlier this year that it was a year behind schedule _ a delay widely interpreted as foreshadowing extra costs. The announcement amounted to an embarrassment for Cheney because he had ordered a months-long review of the military's costliest aircraft programs, but the study had failed to turn up any such problems. Meanwhile, both the House and Senate Armed Service Committees have moved to pare funding for the program. And Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III ordered his own personnel to look into the problems. The Navy study is ``somewhat broader'' than the Pentagon's, Williams said. ``They're looking at program management techniques, they're looking at cost schedules, when this information became available, that sort of thing,'' the spokesman said. He said officials were ``closely coordinating their work'' for both studies. Officials at McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp., the plane's contractors, have reported that the first flight of the plane would be delayed until late 1991. The problems reportedly involve the plane's composite materials, which save weight and lower radar reflections but are very difficult to fabricate into aircraft parts. Following his review of aircraft programs, Cheney announced in April that he was sharply cutting the proposed A-12 purchase. Although the Navy had originally planned to buy 858 of the long-range, carrier-based aircraft, the secretary said he envisioned buying 620. No cost for the super-secret program has been made public, but it has been reported that the plane was being developed under a $4.8 billion fixed price contract and extended production could run upwards of $55 billion. ``One of the problems you're faced with from time to time in this business, is ... the problems of cost overruns and slips in schedule. But, obviously, I was not happy with the way the A-12 thing was handled,'' Cheney said in June.

DOC.HEAD: Colorado Senator Recovering from Heart Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Sen. William Armstrong has returned to work while recovering from surgery last week following ``a mild heart attack,'' his office said Tuesday. Aides to the Colorado Republican said Armstrong was released from Walter Reed Army Medical Center on Monday night. The said in a statement that last Thursday he was ``successfully treated with angioplasty'' _ a medical procedure used to clear blocked arteries to the heart. ``He has resumed driving and other normal activities,'' the statement said, ``but upon the advice of his physicians he will follow a reduced work schedule for a brief period of time.'' It said Armstrong is expected to recover fully within two to four weeks. Armstrong, 53, is up for re-election this year. He was first elected in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Sub That Sank Cruiser Belgrano to be Scrapped
DOC.TEXT: The British submarine HMS Conqueror, which sank the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano during the Falklands war, will be scrapped as part of cuts in military spending, the Ministry of Defense said Tuesday. The 19-year-old nuclear-powered submarine is one of nine vessels to be broken up or sold. The others are the frigate HMS Phoebe, two diesel-powered submarines, minehunters, patrol craft and the diving ship HMS Challenger, the ministry said. The defense ministry said cuts also will affect the army, the Royal Air Force, and research and recruitment for all the armed services. Details of the reductions released Tuesday amplify an announcement on July 25 by Defense Secretary Tom King that there would be cuts totalling $1.1 billion. The ministry said Conqueror would be scrapped because it was ready for a refitting that would cost more than $37 million. The Argentine navy lost 368 of the more than 1,000 men on board its only cruiser when Conqueror fired two conventional torpedoes at the warship on May 2, 1982. The loss of life was the worst single disaster to either side in the 74-day war. The sinking kept the Argentine navy in port for the rest of the conflict, which ended with a British task force regaining the islands from Argentine occupation.

DOC.HEAD: WGermany Bought Freedom of 33,000 EGerman Political Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: West Germany bought the freedom of 33,000 East German political prisoners from 1964 until last year's fall of the Communist government, East Germany's interior minister said Tuesday. Peter-Michael Diestel told reporters that West Germany paid $60,000 for each prisoner in later years. When the practice began in 1964, East Germany's Communist authorities requested $25,000 for the release of each prisoner, Diestel said. The price rose over the years. Diestel said the Communist government sometimes demanded payment in goods rather than money. This happened first at Christmas 1964, when ``oranges were traded for the children of the country,'' he said. The Communist government began selling political prisoners to raise badly-needed hard currency. Those released under the deals were allowed to take their families with them to the West. Starting in the 1970s, those released also included people jailed for trying to flee to the West, Diestel said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: Pilot Accused of Flying Drunk Had High Tolerance For Booze
DOC.TEXT: One of three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying while intoxicated doesn't get drunk easily because he is an alcoholic, his lawyer said Tuesday at his trial. ``A person who consumes alcohol builds up a tolerance to alcohol. Your body resists the effects of alcohol,'' attorney Peter Wold said, referring to his client, Capt. Norman ``Lyle'' Prouse. Prouse is not ``a skid row drunk'' and had no trouble flying a Boeing 727 from Fargo, N.D. to Minneapolis March 8, despite evidence that he consumed at least 17{ rum and Diet Cokes the night before, Wold said in his opening argument. Prouse, of Conyers, Ga.; 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, of Highland Ranch, Colo.; and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, of Antioch, Tenn., are charged with operating the aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. The federal felony carries a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Prouse had been drinking for 35 years and entered a treatment program after his arrest, Wold said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega said in her opening statement Tuesday that while the pilots ``may not have been staggering drunk,'' results of blood-alcohol tests will show their skills were seriously impaired. All three pilots had blood-alcohol contents exceeding .04 percent, the Federal Aviation Administration's limit for flying, according to test results admitted Tuesday as evidence. Defense attorneys said Tuesday that the flight, carrying 91 passengers, went flawlessly. ``The issue is not what his condition was the night before or what his alcohol content was the next day,'' Wold said. ``The government must show their abilities were impaired.'' ``There were no problems with altitude, no problems with direction, no problems with speed,'' said William Mauzy, the attorney for Kirchner. ``You can't fake a perfect landing.'' Wold said he would introduce as evidence radar tapes and tapes of conversations between the pilots and air traffic controllers so the jury could judge their responses. The blood tests showed Prouse still had the equivalent of eight drinks in his system after the plane departed at about 6:25 a.m. The tests found Kirchner and Balzer had the equivalent of three beers each still in their systems, said de la Vega. A bar patron tipped the FAA and Northwest that the crew drank heavily at a bar in Moorhead, Minn., adjacent to Fargo, according to court records. An FAA investigator has testified the crew smelled of alcohol when they arrived late at the departure gate. While the investigator phoned for instructions on how to handle the situation, the plane departed. An FAA official made citizen's arrests when the plane landed at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. Northwest fired the three for violating a rule prohibiting drinking within 12 hours of a scheduled flight. The FAA revoked their pilots' licenses. According to bills from the Speak Easy bar introduced as evidence, Prouse ordered 15 rum and Diet Cokes while Kirchner and Balzer shared seven pitchers of beer over about six hours. Kathryn Litch, a waitress at the bar, said other patrons bought Kirchner and Balzer another pitcher of beer and that Prouse drank at least 2{ more drinks after Kirchner and Balzer left about 10:40 p.m. The flight left about eight hours later. U.S. District Court Judge James Rosenbaum has said the trial is expected to last about two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Government Pumps $200 Million More into Student Loan Guarantee Agency
DOC.TEXT: The government-sponsored Student Loan Marketing Association said Tuesday it was pumping another $200 million into a troubled student loan guarantee agency. The loan to the Higher Education Assistance Fund, HEAF, buys time for government officials who are trying to arrange a takeover to avoid a default by the fund. The association, known as Sallie Mae, had loaned the fund $200 million previously. HEAF, based in Overland Park, Kan., is the largest of 47 state or private non-profit agencies guaranteeing student loans. A week ago, it disclosed that it was in danger of defaulting on its claims. Officials from the Education Department and the Office of Management and Budget have been trying to avoid that by arranging for another guarantee agency or Sallie Mae to take over HEAF. They had said they hoped to resolve HEAF's problems this week, but Etta Fielek, a spokeswoman for the Education Department, said the new loan will carry HEAF into the 1991 fiscal year starting Oct. 1 ``We're pleased with this arrangement because it provides a stable period during which the negotiations can continue,'' she said. Sallie Mae said in a statement it was making the loan ``as a result of discussions with the Department of Education'' and that it had received ``assurances from the department as to its continued payment of HEAF's ... claims, which provide the collateral.'' The Education Department fully reimburses most of the guarantee agencies for student loan defaults, but provides only partial reimbursement to HEAF and others with a record of guaranteeing too many bad loans. Fielek said the loan from Sallie Mae will allow HEAF to withhold about $300 million in claims until the next fiscal year. Thus, the guarantee agency will get 100 percent reimbursement from the Education Department for those claims instead of 80 percent. Sallie Mae, which is federally chartered but shareholder owned, finances about four of every 10 student loans by purchasing the loans from banks and other lenders. ``We believe the action we are taking today will be both helpful to assuring stability in the education credit market we serve and in the best interest of our shareholders,'' said Lawrence A. Hough, Sallie Mae president.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Sets Date for First Multiparty Elections
DOC.TEXT: Parliament in the central republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina on Tuesday adopted amendments to its constitution calling for free multiparty elections in November, the state news agency reported. Under the amendments passed by the regional assembly, Bosnia-Hercegovina ``has become a sovereign and democratic state of equal citizens,'' Tanjug said. Multiparty elections are scheduled to be held Nov. 30. The new parliament is likely to meet before the end of the year, Tanjug said. The adoption of the amendments enabling the holding of free elections has been in line with similar steps already taken or under way in other Yugoslav republics. The liberal republics of Slovenia and Croatia held free elections earlier this year in which center-right parties won the majority. Those elections marked the first free balloting in Yugoslavia in 50 years. Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, has so far resisted a multiparty system and Serbians recently voted in a referendum for free elections to be postponed until after a new constitution is adopted. Serbia will be the last republic to hold free elections, probably next year. A new law, adopted by the Serbian Parliament in July, permits the formation and registration of political parties in the republic but bans political activity in factories and at the workplace. The move marked the first tentative step by Yugoslavia's conservative republic toward a multiparty system. In a related development Tuesday, the assembly of the southern republic of Montenegro also adopted amendments to its constitution introducing political pluralism, Tanjug said. Elections are to be held in the republics of Montenegro and Macedonia this year.

DOC.HEAD: No Agreement on Next Summer's Cleanup From Exxon Valdez Oil Spill
With AM-Exxon-Inquiry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As the second summer of cleanup from the Exxon Valdez oil spill nears an end, disputes are arising about whether a third summer's work will be necessary. The Coast Guard's highest-ranking officer, Commandant Adm. J. William Kime, said Sunday after a visit to Prince William Sound that he saw enough oil to warrant the return of cleanup crews next summer. But Exxon officials and others in the Coast Guard think Kime's assessment is premature. ``There is a good likelihood no future work will be required in 1991,'' Exxon spokesman Karsten Rodvik said Tuesday. More than 1,000 people are working on the cleanup, according to Exxon, which counts office workers and other shore personnel in that total. The effort to mop up what's left of 11 million gallons of heavy crude oil uses 31 aircraft and 66 boats. Exxon spokesman Frank Dobbs said cleanup efforts were ahead of schedule everywhere but on Kodiak Island, where he said erratic weather had hindered crews. By Tuesday, crews had finished cleaning 488 of about 600 targeted sites, Dobbs said. Exxon plans to begin scaling back operations in Prince William Sound on Aug. 15, based on the onset of winter weather last year. It will continue working through mid-September in the Gulf of Alaska. Exxon wants to wait until after a shorline survey next spring to decide if more work is needed, Rodvik said. Based on what happend last winter, when storms and daily tides washed away much of the oil, the company said there's a chance crews won't have to return in 1991. Commissioner Dennis Kelso of the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, and Environmental Protection Agency chief William Reilly have already said the cleanup should continue next summer.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Cut Rail Supplies to Georgia in Face of Internal Blockade
With AM_Soviet-Food, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rail authorities suspended shipments to the southern republic of Georgia because a political protest and strike have halted virtually all trains traveling into the republic, Soviet media reported Tuesday. Georgian activists began blocking the key railway junction of Samtredia six days ago to protest what they see as Georgian officials' attempts to block fair, multiparty elections scheduled for October. Nearly 200 trains carrying 500,000 tons of cargo are stranded and 40,000 passengers have been kept waiting, according to the official news agency Tass and Soviet television news. On Tuesday, locomotive drivers in the Black Sea town of Sukhumi went on strike, blocking all rail traffic on the coast. The Georgian capital of Tbilisi is also blocked, the evening news show Vremya reported. As a result, officials decided to ship food, gasoline, coal and ore meant for Georgia to the other 14 republics. It is a harsh action in a country where everything is in short supply. However, rail authorities' failure to alter train shipments in the face of Azerbaijan's blockade of Armenia last year led to hundreds of trains backing up on the rails to the Caucasus. That, in turn, caused a shortage of railcars throughout the nation. Thousands of tons of food shipments rotted. The blockade also threatens the harvest in the farming areas of Georgia and Armenia, which produce much of the Soviet Union's fresh fruits and vegetables, the Interfax and Tass news agencies reported Tuesday. The Georgian blockade is particularly dangerous for Armenia. With the Georgian link disrupted, Armenia is dependent on lines through Azerbaijan, which were cut for two months last year as part of the two republics' deadly territorial dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Investigators Critical of Exxon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `March 30...,' to CORRECT that blood test didn't show Hazelwood legally drunk.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Exxon Inquiry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the nation's worst oil spill:

March 24: The 987-foot tanker Exxon Valdez runs aground on Bligh Reef some 25 miles south of Valdez, Alaska, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound. March 26: Alaska fishermen's union spokeswoman Riki Ott says the group wants full compensation for damage from the spill. More than 250 lawsuits will be filed against Exxon in the following months. March 30: Exxon fires tanker captain Joseph Hazelwood after tests taken 10 hours after the accident find his blood-alcohol level was .06 percent, above the Coast Guard's limit of .04 percent. April 4: U.S. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan calls the spill the oil industry's Three Mile Island. Oil covers 1,000 square miles, leaking out of the sound to foul beaches along the Gulf of Alaska and Cook Inlet. June 19: Exxon and other big oil companies announce plans for a voluntary network of response teams capable of handling big spills anywhere in U.S. coastal waters. Estimated cost: $250 million. Sept. 15: Exxon suspends its beach cleanup for the winter, claiming it has left 1,100 miles of oiled beaches ``environmentally stable'' and saying its 25-week cleanup involving more than 10,000 workers was a job well done. Alaska officials disagree and announce their own $21 million winter cleanup plan. Oct. 10: State officials warn people not to consume shellfish in areas affected by oil. Oct. 27: The National Wildlife Federation says Exxon has resigned from its corporate advisory board. Exxon calls the conservation group unfair in its criticism of the oil spill; the group calls Exxon ``a corporate pariah.'' Nov. 8: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill preserving states' ability to adopt stricter oil spill liability laws than the federal government. The Senate also is working on a bill, but agreement is put off until 1990. Dec. 4: U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner says Exxon's cleanup has cost the company $1.9 billion, and praises Exxon for ``a very substantial, good-faith effort.'' Dec. 31: Wildlife officials report that more than 1,000 sea otters, 140 bald eagles and nearly 36,500 seabirds have been found dead in the spill area.

Jan. 5: The Alaska Oil Spill Commission issues a report calling for an overhaul of the nation's oil transportation system. It blames the Valdez spill in part on the Coast Guard's ``unduly friendly relationship with industry,'' and a reckless rush to profits by the oil industry. Jan. 22: Hazelwood goes on trial in Anchorage on charges of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil, and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Feb. 20: The Coast Guard orders Exxon to resume its cleanup May 1 and to submit a plan by March 15. Feb. 27: A federal grand jury indicts Exxon and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts. Officials say that if convicted on all counts, the company could be fined up to $1.6 million and could be assessed an additional $700 million in penalties. March 22: Jury finds Hazelwood guilty of negligent discharge of oil but innocent of the more serious charges.

DOC.HEAD: Military Disbands Alleged `Death Squad' Unit
DOC.TEXT: The military announced Tuesday it was disbanding a controversial secret unit that opposition leaders claimed was involved in the unsolved killings of anti-apartheid activists. Opponents of the white-minority government had been demanding President F.W. de Klerk disband the military's Civil Cooperation Bureau as a signal that he was serious about curbing abuses by the country's security forces. The chief of the Defense Forces, Gen. Jannie Geldenhuys, said the Civil Cooperation Bureau was being closed down and members were being transferred to regular army units. Geldenhuys gave no reason for the decision. Opposition activists have accused the Civil Cooperation Bureau and other branches of the security forces of involvement in the killings of dozens of anti-apartheid figures in recent years. Anti-apartheid leaders welcomed the government's decision. ``The (bureau) was made up of people trained to kill, people with tremendous vested interests in the status quo, and with an interest in derailing the present (black-white) negotiating process,'' said Denis Worrall, a co-leader of the liberal Democratic Party. Murphy Morobe, spokesman for the anti-apartheid United Democratic Front, said, ``the important thing is whether (the bureau) has really been disbanded or whether it will be transformed into the same beast under another guise.'' De Klerk appointed a judicial commission in March to investigate the killings of anti-apartheid activists. During weeks of testimony, top military officials have acknowledged that the bureau, formed in the mid-1980s, bombed anti-apartheid targets. The bureau also has claimed responsibility for delivering a baboon fetus to the home of Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize. But military officials have denied bureau involvement in killings of opposition figures. The military has said the bureau had 139 members and an annual budget of $11 million, and was engaged in highly sensitive intelligence gathering operations in South Africa and abroad. However, Defense Minister Magnus Malan and other top military officials have claimed they didn't know about the bureau until last November. The judicial hearing into the unsolved killings of anti-apartheid activists was scheduled to resume Wednesday after a six-week break. In the past year, former policemen have said they were part of authorized death squads that killed anti-apartheid figures. Police have denied authorizing any killings. There has been no evidence directly linking the Civil Cooperation Bureau to the alleged police death squads. Since assuming power last year, de Klerk has downgraded the role of the security establishment, which figured far more prominently under his predecessor, P.W. Botha. De Klerk says he wants to end the country's apartheid system of racial segregation and negotiate a power-sharing agreement between the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister is Freed in Trinidad, Other Hostages Still Held
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes from attorney general that crisis ``far from over,'' U.S. ambassador's quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto POS4
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Moslem radicals freed an ailing and wounded Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson on Tuesday, four days after they took him and 40 other people hostage in a coup attempt, the attorney general said. The other hostages, including 15 government officials, were still held, Attorney General Anthony Smart said. He refused to say what conditions led to the 63-year-old Robinson's release. In Washington, White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk confirmed Robinson was freed and said, ``We hope the situation can be resolved in a quick and peaceful manner.'' But Smart told reporters, ``This crisis is far from over.'' He said the government in this Caribbean nation of 1.3 million residents was continuing efforts to win the release of the others held by former policeman Abu Bakr and his band of Moslem extremists. ``These discussions are at a very delicate stage,'' with lives at stake, he said. The hostages were seized Friday by extremists who captured the Parliament building and the government TV station about one mile away. At least nine people were yle.'' Attorneys representing the families of Raymond Belknap and James Vance claim those lines on the band's ``Stained Class'' album contain the subliminal message ``do it'' that prompted the youths to shoot themselves in a deserted church playground Dec. 23, 1985. Belknap, 18, died immediately. Vance, then 20, blew away most of his face but lived three more years, undergoing several operations, before he died on Thanksgiving Day 1988 of complications from his injuries and the various medications he was taking. The band and CBS Records deny any hidden messages exist. They counter that the supposed ``do it'' sounds are an exhalation of breath, and a combination of drums, guitars and vocals. ``The sounds I hear are essentially my own exhalation of breath at the end of the line I am singing,'' Halford testified. ``There are no subliminals of any nature'' either in the song or on the album, he said. Halford testified that the song ``Better by You, Better than Me,'' was the only song on the 1978 album that wasn't written by band members.

DOC.HEAD: Auditors Say Justice in the Dark on Debt Status
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department knows ``very little'' about the $5.5 billion of unpaid debts other government agencies have referred to 94 U.S. attorneys for collection, auditors told Congress Tuesday. A General Accounting Office review of the government's debt-collection program found that the Justice Department has yet to put in place a system to keep track of the growing number of referrals of unpaid debts by other agencies. ``Our main concern is whether Justice has adequate systems and plans for collecting this aging and growing debt,'' GAO auditor Lowell Dodge told the House Govermnent Operations subcommittee on government information, justice and agriculture. The subcommittee chairman, Rep. Robert E. Wise Jr., D-W.Va., asked Justice Department officials to consider a policy of prohibiting travel by criminal defendants who owe large fines. Wise cited the case of former deputy White House chief of staff Michael K. Deaver who received court permission earlier this year to take his family on an eight-day trip to the Bahamas. Deaver, who was convicted of lying under oath about his lobbying activities after leaving the White House, was fined $100,000 and placed on probation. He was given until April 1992 to pay the fine and has asked the court to reduce it to $25,000. When the probation department recommended that Deaver be given permission to take the trip, it noted that he had paid only $2,350 of the fine, according to court records produced by Wise's staff. Justice Department officials said they would consider working with court and probation officials to adopt a travel policy for people who owe criminal fines. In its review, GAO found that the amount of uncollected debts owed government agencies is growing rapidly. Debts that were delinquent for at least a year grew from some $12 billion in 1983 to about $28 billion last year, GAO said. During the 1989 fiscal year, the nation's U.S. attorneys collected $216 million while the department's civil division, which litigates larger debts, had collected $346 million. But GAO said it didn't know the status of most of $5.5 billion worth of debt referred for collection to U.S. attorneys. The Justice Department has information on the $1.1 billion it has entered into its debt-collection system but it ``knows very little about the $5.5 billion which has been referred to various U.S. attorneys and is still in processing or litigation,'' Dodge said. ``Justice does not have a system for tracking all referrals,'' Dodge said. The Justice Department failed to report to the Office of Management and Budget as planned during the 1989 on long-range plans for consolidating debt collection, GAO said. Justice Department officials have started to implement a ``central door'' program to keep track of all debts referred from other agencies. But Dodge said that the department does not have a written plan to make changes in its computer and accounting systems. ``We are concerned about whether Justice's informal planning approach will be successful,'' Dodge said. Robert Ford, a deputy assistant attorney general for debt-collection management, testified that the agency has collected $3.5 billion since 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Bengals' Lewis Billups Sentenced for Gun Incident
By TERRY KINNEY
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Cincinnati Bengals cornerback Lewis Billups will have to serve 30 days in jail for pointing a gun at two undercover police officers, a Cincinnati judge said Tuesday. But because of the backlog in serving misdemeanor sentences, the football player probably won't have to begin his term until late January or early February, Hamilton County Common Pleas Judge Ralph Winkler said. Winkler sentenced Billups to 30 days in the Hamilton County Justice Center on two counts of aggravated menacing, and fined him $1,000 and court costs. He also sentenced Billups to 180 days in jail _ but suspended 150 days of that sentence _ on a third misdemeanor count of improper handling of a firearm while in a motor vehicle. All three sentences will be served concurrently. Winkler said that even if jail space becomes available during the National Football League season, he would delay Billups' jail time. Billups, 25, is a four-year veteran the Bengals drafted in 1986 from North Alabama. He is involved with a contract dispute with the Bengals, and has not reported to their training camp at Wilmington College. All of the charges stem from a Jan. 4 incident when two Cincinnati police officers said that Billups pointed a pistol at them, then led them on a high-speed chase into suburban northern Kentucky, where Billups lives. Billups had pleaded guilty to the three first-degree misdemeanor charges, and Ohio prosecutors dropped a felony charge of carrying a concealed weapon.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Woman Wins Fight in Canada to Remain Unveiled
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian woman got word Tuesday she will be allowed to remain in Canada despite her refusal to obey Immigration Department orders and wear a veil for a passport photo. ``It's really great for me - it's another life for me,'' said Azita Zandian, 25. She said one reason she came to Canada a year ago was to escape harsh rules imposed upon women in Iran. ``I don't want to put on a veil. That's why I left my country,'' Ms. Zandian said. ``All the world says Canada is freedom. I come here and they tell me I must put a veil on my head. I'm really confused.'' Federal Immigration Minister Barbara McDougall made the decision to allow Ms. Zandian to remain in Canada on compassionate grounds. The Iranian woman arrived here with a false passport and faced deportation proceedings. She asked to stay here as a refugee but was turned down. Iranian women are not issued passports unless their pictures show them veiled. The Immigration Department wanted Ms. Zandian to put on the head covering so it could supply the Iranian Embassy in Ottawa with pictures for an Iranian passport and then deport her. Last week, Ms. Zandian was called to the immigration office and told to bring a veil. She showed up without one. Officials told her to return on Thursday with two pictures of herself wearing a veil. She said she wouldn't. On Tuesday, she learned she had won her fight. ``It's so nice to have a happy ending,'' said Mona Forest, director of the Women's Center of Montreal, which supported Ms. Zandian and her lawyer Gisele Saint-Pierre in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Mine Explosion Kills One, Traps At Least Two
DOC.TEXT: An explosion ripped through a coal mine Tuesday, killing three miners and injuring two, officials said. The explosion occurred as workers were blasting with dynamite to expose a coal seam in the small mine in Granny Rose Hollow in southeastern Kentucky, said Nancy Toombs, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Mines and Minerals. Miners often detonate dynamite and other explosives to expose a coal seam, she said. Five miners were underground during the explosion. The three dead were found about 500 feet underground, said county coroner Jerry Garland. Their names weren't immediately released. The two injured were listed in stable condition at Knox County General Hospital. In a radio interview from his hospital bed, David Faulkner, 32, of Siler, said he was 150 feet from the explosion and was overcome by smoke when he tried to rescue the victims. There was conflicting information Tuesday about the name of the mine. The state mining department said the explosion occurred in mine No. 1 of the Big Mama Coal Co. However, the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration listed it as the No. 3 mine of the Granny Rose Coal Co., said spokeswoman Kathy Snyder. Federal records indicated the non-union mine had a 24-inch-high coal seam and had passed recent inspections, said Snyder. Toombs said the mine was icensed by the state. The state mines department, the federal mining agency and Kentucky State Police were investigating the explosion. Kentucky's last multiple-death coal mine accident occurred in September 1989, when 10 miners were killed in a methane blast at the Pyro Mining Co.'s Wheatcroft Mine in western Kentucky. Eight men have died in mining accidents in Kentucky so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Insurance to Pay for Bone Marrow Transplant
DOC.TEXT: A state judge on Tuesday ordered an insurance company to pay for a bone marrow transplant that doctors said may save the life of a man with an AIDS-related illness. Supreme Court Justice Elliott Wilk rejected the contention by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield that the operation, used for years to treat people with impaired immune systems, was experimental when used to treat AIDS. Wilk issued a preliminary order directing Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to pay the estimated $150,000 cost of the operation for Thomas Bradley. His physician, Dr. H. Kent Holland of Johns Hopkins Oncology Center in Baltimore, said in a sworn statement that Bradley's condition was deteriorating and that the New York man could soon become too weak to survive the transplant. ``Time is therefore of the essence,'' Holland said. Bradley, 46, was about to undergo the operation earlier this month when the insurance company notified him it would not cover experimental procedures. Wilk's decision sends a message that a treatment ``doesn't become experimental all over again just because it's being used to treat AIDS,'' said Bradley's lawyer, Evan Wolfson. The insurance company said in a statement that it would consider appealing the ruling. ``Despite our real sympathy for Mr. Bradley, we have an obligation to safeguard the resources entrusted to us by millions of subscribers to cover medical care that's been proven beneficial and appropriate,'' said spokesman John Kelly. Bradley, an administrator in the Suffolk County school district of Bayport-Blue Point, wanted to have bone marrow transplant as soon as possible, said Wolfson. Bradley had a 90 percent chance of surviving the operation, which could extend his life by at least two years, Holland said in his statement. His donor is his identical twin, Bob, a teacher in the same district. Doctors said the fact that the two are identical twins should greatly enhance the chances for success. Bradley learned he was infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, in 1986 and has a severely depressed immune system. He was diagnosed with AIDS-related condition, or ARC, because he has suffered the specific opportunistic infections listed by the Centers for Disease Control as defining AIDS, Wolfson said. Johns Hopkins spokeswoman Valerie Mehl said six people with AIDS have undergone bone marrow transplants at the Baltimore center in the past 18 months. Two have since died of causes unrelated to the operation, she said.
