DOC.HEAD: The AP
Palestinians Form Committee to Deal with Killing Collaborators
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Palestinian uprising said Tuesday they were forming a ``Higher Judicial Committee'' to try to reduce the killings by Palestinians of Arabs suspected of collaborating with Israel. The announcement came in a leaflet distributed in the occupied territories and signaled the first national institution to be founded for the would-be ``State of Palestine.'' The insurgency against Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza Strip began in December 1987 and is backed by the Palestine Liberation Organization. Leaders of the uprising acted amid a rise in the murders of Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities. In July, Palestinians killed 15 fellow Arabs for informing or collaborating in other ways, according to figures compiled by The Associated Press. In contrast, three Palestinians died in July as a result of clashes with Israeli troops, and a fourth Arab was killed in a prison breakout, according to the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories. The four fatalities constitute the lowest one-month death toll since the uprising began, officials at the human right group said. During the uprising, 725 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians and 45 Israelis have been killed by Palestinians. A further 243 Palestinians were slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating. The judicial committee appeared to be a first step by local Palestinians toward creating a bureaucracy to deal with internal problems. Most Palestinians reject dealings with Israeli police and military courts, especially after the PLO declared an independent state in the occupied lands in 1988. Israel rejects formation of a Palestinian state. Many Third World countries recognize the would-be state, but not major Western governments. The leaflet said the Higher Judicial Committee ``will establish legal procedures for the State of Palestine, including those which pertain to interrogations'' of suspected collaborators. It said operating details would be announced later, but meanwhile, ``correct methods'' should be used in interrogations and members of one faction should not investigate the activities of other factions. The leaflet condemned torture in interrogations, saying ``It is incomprehensible that we should use such methods when we ourselves are the victims of such methods at the hands of the Israelis.'' Palestinians repeatedly complain of Israeli beatings, solitary confinement and other punishment to force confessions. Israel denies using torture. Many suspected collaborators were brutally killed after harsh interrogations. Radwan Abu Ayyash, chief of the Arab Journalists Association in the West Bank, said a judicial committee likely would be made up of lawyers and traditional village judges ``who would investigate incidents and determine what kind of action should be taken.'' He suggested such a panel could deal with land disputes, theft and the like, as well as cases of suspected collaborators. In other developments Tuesday: _Three Palestinian truck drivers from Jericho in the West Bank were charged in a West Bank military court with plotting to assassinate Foreign Minister David Levy. _A military court in Lod, within Israel, charged a 40-year-old mother of 12 children with carrying messages and money for the PLO's Fatah faction. _A 7-year-old Israeli boy was seriously hurt in Hebron in the West Bank when hit in the head by a stone thrown at the car he was riding in, the army said. _Army gunfire wounded at least seven Palestinians during stone-throwing clashes in the occupied territories, including a 12-year-old boy shot in the head with a plastic bullet and listed in serious condition, Arab and Israeli reports said. The army said it was checking the reports.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Four Suspected Car Thieves in Shootout
DOC.TEXT: Police killed four suspected car thieves and wounded a bystander in a shootout on the city's major north-south highway during the Tuesday afternoon rush hour. In another incident, gunmen halted a staff car of an Arab embassy and stole the embassy payroll. Such violent incidents have undermined public confidence in the government of President Corazon Aquino. The shootout occurred along Epifanio de los Santos Avenue in suburban Makati, which was packed with commuters returning home from work. Patrolman Abner Apuang said he and three other policemen were cruising down the avenue when they saw a jeep carrying men they suspected were members of a car theft ring. When the jeep sped away, the police opened fire, killing four occupants and critically wounding the driver, police said. Three other suspects escaped. Police saw a construction worker dive for cover beneath a parked truck and, thinking he was part of the gang, wounded him in the shoulder, police said. The shootout caused a huge traffic jam, and bodies lay along the median strip of the eight-lane highway. A few hours earlier, robbers armed with pistols stole more than $5,000 in U.S. and Filipino currency after stopping a car belonging to the embassy of the United Arab Emirates. Maj. Venerando Minas said the assailants' car overtook the diplomatic vehicle just after the embassy accountant had left a bank with the staff payroll.

DOC.HEAD: Caribbean Community Members Meet in Shadow of Trinidad Uprising
With AM-Trinidad
DOC.TEXT: Political leaders of the 13 Caribbean economic community members began a three-day meeting Tuesday, saying their countries were in danger of being overwhelmed by global changes. The speakers at the opening session also condemned the attempted coup in Trinidad and Tobago, a member of Caricom. Trinidad and Tobago's Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson, who was released Tuesday after being held hostage by members of a Black Muslim group for five days, was scheduled to attend the summit. His seat at the opening session was taken by Sahadeo Basdeo, the country's foreign minister. ``Any criminal violation of democracy is repugnant,'' said Barbados Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford. ``It must not happen again, and we in Caricom must ensure that it does not.'' The annual summit of Caricom began with calls by several leader for further integration of economies to provide a basis for dealing with the changes. Mexico answered the call by signing an agreement with the Caricom to promote trade and increase economic cooperation in the region, Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gotari announced Tuesday. Salinas de Gotari told the opening session of Caricom's annual Heads of Government meeting that the agreement had been signed between Caricom and Bancomext, the Mexican foreign trade bank. In addition to cooperation within the region, ``we are determined to strengthen the role we play in the work of the Caribbean Dvelopment Bank, and to identify new opportunities for cooperation,'' the Mexican leader said. The Barbados-based Development Bank provides financial support for the English-speaking Caribbean states. Mexico is a contributing member of the institution. Caricom, which was created in 1973, aims at establishing a regional common market by 1993. Its members are the English-speaking states of the Caribbean, including Belize in Central America, the Bahamas, and Guyana in South America. Mexico is not currently a member, and a Caricom secretariat official said on condition he not be named that Mexico's application for observer status would not be discussed until next year's summit.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Expels Party Central Committee Member
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's ruling Communist Party has purged Ung Phan, the former minister of transport, communications and posts who was arrested in May for trying to form a rival party. The government radio said Ung Phan was expelled from the party's policy-making Central Committee ``due to his betrayal of the party and the nation's historic tasks.'' It said his actions caused a split in the forces opposing the Khmer Rouge, the largest guerrilla group fighting the Vietnamese-installed government. A text of the Monday broadcast was seen Tuesday. The radio said the expulsion came at a Central Committee meeting from July 23 to 30. At least five other government and military officials also were arrested, the U.S. human rights group Asia Watch has said. Asia Watch said Ung Phan and the others were accused of trying to form the Liberal Social Democratic Party. In what appeared a reference to these arrests, the authorities said in June they had foiled a coup attempt. The one-party administration was installed after Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978, and ended the bloody regime of the Khmer Rouge.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Government Demonstrators Rally in Bucharest
DOC.TEXT: Scores of anti-government demonstrators rallied Tuesday night in University Square in the capital center, site of a 53-day demonstration that was violently broken up by police in mid-June. Protesters earlier roped off the square and put up a sign declaring it a ``neo-Communist free zone,'' as was the case during the previous demonstration. Police later took down the ropes, leading to a scuffle between demonstrators and a man they suspected of being a police informer. State-run TV reported the incident hours later and said a police lieutenant colonel was ``attacked'' by a group of people. The demonstrators disbanded at about 11 p.m. after painting slogans on a wall demanding the release of jailed student leader Marian Munteanu. Munteanu was a leader of the anti-Communist rally that blocked the capital's main thoroughfare during the election campaign. The demonstrators demanded the resignation of President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist official.

DOC.HEAD: State Braces for Onslought of Oil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `By Tuesday...,' and 13th graf, `Workers also...,' to CORRECT that oil washed ashore on peninsula and island sted two peninsulas.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Exxon Inquiry, Bjt; AM-Oil Spill-List
LaserPhotos HT1,3,5
DOC.TEXT: A 500,000-gallon oil spill unleashed by a ship-barge collision could be an evironmental disaster in the rich fishing grounds and teeming wildlife habitats of Galveston Bay, a state official said Tuesday. The spill began Saturday when a tanker ship struck two barges in the Houston Ship Channel, which is in part dredged though the bay. By Tuesday, a 17-mile-long slick had formed. Heavy oil had washed up on a dike in Texas City about three miles northwest of Galveston and on a nearby peninsula and island, the Coast Guard said. The deaths of two seabirds were blamed on the spill, which has already killed an undetermined number of fish. The Houston Ship Channel, closed since the spill began, partly reopened during the afternoon. Dozens of ships have been prevented from leaving or reaching Houston at an estimated cost of $1.5 million a day. Another Texas official criticized what he characterized as a lack of response to the disaster. Galveston Bay is protected from the Gulf of Mexico by barrier islands which contain delicate nesting grounds for birds and other wildlife. The bay _ the richest estuary on the Gulf Coast _ is an important fishing ground for shrimp and other commercially valuable species. Experts fear the spill will take a heavy environmental toll, both because the oil is thick and because it is unlikely to dissipate in the enclosed waters, as did the light crude spilled in the gulf by the tanker Mega Borg in June. ``The worst kind of spill you can have is one behind these barrier islands, which is what we've got,'' said Larry McKinney, director of resource protection for the Texas Department of Parks and Wildlife. McKinney predicted the spill would rank as the worst in the gulf region. At least 100 bird species, including the endangered brown pelican, and at least 75 kinds of fish inhabit the Galveston Bay area, he said. Cleanup crews used five skimmer vessels and a vacuum truck to suck up oil contained by thousands of feet of booms. By Monday night, about 20,000 gallons of oil had been cleaned up. The Coast Guard did not have an updated figure for Tuesday. Workers also began cleaning crude on the dike and at the Port Bolivar and on Pelican Island, next to Galveston Island. ``This is a mess. I have never in my 25 years being out here seen this dike look like this,'' said Darnell Vaughn of La Marque, who had her children Rachel, 8, and Jerod, 12, with her. Coast Guard Rear Adm. Jim Loy, who flew in from New Orleans to survey the spill, said a flyover convinced him the situation was under control. ``It's a very manageable situation, perhaps not being managed as well as it could be,'' Loy told a news conference. He said he saw streaks of black oil at Eagle Point, a residential development with private docks 22 miles north of Galveston, that cleanup crews should have been attacking. Heavy black oil was reported on sandy beaches there Tuesday morning. Loy said he'd suggested that cleanup contractors bring in about five more skimmers, but said barge owner Apex Towing Co. had been doing a good job generally of keeping the oil from environmentally sensitive areas. ``I want to strike while the iron's hot,'' he said. ``We're never going to get better weather conditions than we have right now.'' Coast Guard officials said a hearing to determine the cause of the accident would begin Wednesday morning. In another development, state officials urged the federal government to let them use oil-eating microbes on the spill before the oil reached the environmentally sensitive marshes. ``Once it gets to the marshland, trying to clean up the marsh is almost impossible. So why not try it?'' McKinney said. ``It's not going to hurt anything.'' U.S. Environmental Protection Agency spokesman Roger Meacham in Dallas said the technique known as bioremediation is promising, but that not enough information exists on its effectiveness or its impact on marine life to endorse its large-scale use in every situation. Texas Water Commission Chairman B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne, Texas Land Commission representative Blanton Moore and McKinney met with Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene in Galveston to discuss the proposal. Greene said the Coast Guard was hesitant to grant permission. ``We want to be careful there isn't something else introduced into the area that could cause more problems,'' he said. In Austin, Land Commissioner Garry Mauro criticized the response to the spill. ``The point is this oil spill occurred Saturday at 2:30 (p.m.). All these decisions should have been made in advance of this spill,'' Mauro told a news conference. ``We're not happy with that either,'' said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson. The Greek tanker Shinoussa collided with two of three barges being towed by the tugboat Chandy N south of Redfish Island 15 miles north of Galveston. One barge nearly sank and the other listed. Both spewed ``catfeed'' oil, a refinery oil similar to No. 5 oil, into the bay. The double-hulled tanker did not lose any of its 29,400-metric-ton load of jet fuel. No oil has spilled since Monday evening, Nelson said. Divers continued strapping slings beneath the submerged barge Tuesday so cranes could lift the vessel as water and oil were pumped off, Nelson said. The ship channel reopened to one-way, incoming barge traffic, Greene said. Up to 30 barges have been stacked up along the Intracoastal Canal near Galveston and about 70 more waited further down the canal, he said. After clearing incoming barge traffic, the Coast Guard planned to allow some one-way barge traffic out of the channel. In addition to the barges, up to 60 ships were waiting to get in the channel and about as many were waiting to leave, Greene said. The disruption is costing about $1.5 million a day, said West Gulf Maritime Association President Ted Thorjunssen. ``There is a little bit of everything out there _ oil, steel and general cargo,'' said Carl Bond, operations manager for the Marine Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Three Asphyxiated In Well
DOC.TEXT: Three men working inside a well died of asphyxiation Tuesday caused by an electrical short circuit, authorities said. The deaths occurred on a farm near this Umbrian hill town in central Italy. Police and fire officials said an electrician was fixing a pump inside the 23-foot-deep well when the short circuit occurred. Two owners of the farm who tried to rescue him were also overcome. The victims were aged 40, 36 and 34.

DOC.HEAD: Yankees' Official Wants Son to Succeed Him
DOC.TEXT: George Steinbrenner, stripped by the baseball commissioner of his right to run the Yankees, said Tuesday he wants his son to succeed him. Also Tuesday, Commissioner Fay Vincent revealed that he had planned only to suspend George Steinbrenner, but the Yankees owner asked for what amounted to a lifetime ban. The action against Steinbrenner on Monday ends a stormy 17{-year reign punctuated by numerous firings of managers and feuds with players, including onetime star outfielder Dave Winfield. Vincent punished Steinbrenner for besmirching the image of baseball by paying known gambler Howard Spira $40,000. It had been suggested the payments were in exchange for information on Winfield that Steinbrenner could use to force the player to accept a trade that his contract allows him to refuse. In a session Tuesday with several reporters, Vincent suggested the penalty he planned to impose was for a fixed term and was less severe than the punishment Steinbrenner agreed to after 11 hours of negotiations Monday. ``I have to say to you I found some aspects of yesterday strange and I still find them strange this morning,'' Vincent said. A baseball official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Vincent had proposed suspending Steinbrenner for two years and putting him on three years' probation. Steinbrenner agreed to give up control of the team and resign as general partner by Aug. 20. On Tuesday, the commissioner placed the Yankees under American League supervision for the next five years. He also barred all contact between Steinbrenner and the team without Vincent's permission. That would apply to Steinbrenner's son if he became manager. Steinbrenner confirmed Tuesday that he wants his 33-year-old son, Hank, to take over the day-to-day operations of the Yankees. The move, already cleared by Vincent, must still be approved by the team's limited partners and major league clubs. ``I have no desire to return as general partner,'' Steinbrenner said. ``That will rest with my sons. I have other endeavors which I plan to devote most of my available time to now, which are very important to me.'' Vincent ordered that for five years the Yankees must seek league approval for ``the hiring, firing, promotion, demotion or reassignment of any officer of the club.'' During that time, the team also must ask league approval to sue or file a grievance against a player and to hire lawyers and investigators involved with player dealings. Steinbrenner would be allowed to consult with team managers in four areas: television and radio contracts, concessions agreements, governmental and lease agreements and banking relationships. Vincent also barred Phil McNiff, the American Shipbuilding Co. executive who headed Steinbrenner's investigation of Winfield, from having anything to do with the Yankees. Winfield eventually was traded to California. McNiff supervised Steinbrenner's relationship with Spira, who is under an eight-count federal indictment for attempting to extort the Yankees owner and for threatening Steinbrenner and Winfield. Steinbrenner's baseball problems could affect his position as a vice president of the U.S. Olympic Committee. USOC President Robert Helmick said the organization's executive committee will review Steinbrenner's status at its next regular meeting, Aug. 22 in Colorado Springs, Colo. ``When the head of a major sport in the United States says an individual has operated contrary to the best interests of that sport, obviously we must be very concerned,'' Helmick said.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's Military Says 51 Die in Clashes with Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The military said Tuesday that 44 leftist rebels and seven soldiers were killed in three separate clashes during the past week in a coca-growing region of central Peru. On Monday, a military patrol killed 17 guerrillas from the extremist Shining Path group, a communique said. A Sunday clash left 15 guerrillas and an army sergeant dead, it said. The military said that 12 rebels and six soldiers were killed in a clash that broke out on Thursday after the guerrillas ambushed an army patrol 300 miles northeast of Lima. The secretive Shining Path guerrillas control much of central Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, the world's main source of coca leaf, the raw material used in processing cocaine. Authorities say the guerrillas participate in the drug trade. Shining Path, which says it follows the precepts of China's late Mao Tse-tung, has waged a 10-year-old insurgency to overthrow the government that has resulted in 19,000 deaths.

DOC.HEAD: South Gets Drenched Again
DOC.TEXT: Much of the South was drenched Tuesday and thunderstorm winds whipped up to 60 mph in Mississippi, ripping down trees. Heavy rain caused flooding in parts of Odessa, Texas. Three county roads were closed by flooding, and a highway road on the Val Verde county line had 6 feet of water over a northeastern portion. A flood watch over southwest Texas was extended through the night. In Mississippi, thunderstorm gusts reached 60 mph and caused tree damage north of Tupelo. There also was tree damage from thunderstorm winds west of De Kalb. Gusts up to 60 mph were reported at Riverton, Wyo., during a thunderstorm. Wind gusts at Longview, Texas, were estimated at near 65 mph. Hail three-quarters of an inch in diameter fell near Jackson, Miss., and golf-ball size hail fell at Star, Miss., and more than 1 inch of rain fell at Carthage, Miss., during 20 minutes, causing flooding. More than 2 inches of rain fell between 5:45 p.m. and 6:20 p.m. near Sheridan, Ark. Showers and thunderstorms continued into the evening, from the Plateau across the Rockies, the southern Plains, the lower Mississippi Valley, the Gulf Coast, Georgia, North and South Carolina and eastern Virginia, from Delaware across eastern New York and New England. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at 8 p.m. EDT included 1{ inches at Homestead, Fla., and 1\ inches at New York's Kennedy International Airport. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 115 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif., and Bullhead, City Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Military Spending
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a comparison of President Bush's proposed spending for various military weapons and the changes approved by the House and Senate Armed Services committees for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

Bush proposed spending $307 billion on defense. The Senate Armed Services Committee approved a $289 billion; The House panel adopted a $283 billion bill. Actual spending must be done through separate appropriations bills.

In January, Bush called for a total of $5.5 billion for five planes next year and advanced procurement money for 10 planes the following year. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced a revision in April that proposed two planes in 1991 and advanced procurement of six planes in 1992 at a cost of $4.6 billion. The Senate committee agreed with the revised plan. The House panel eliminated all procurement money and included only enough funds to cancel the program after the 15 planes currently under development.

Bush proposed $4.7 billion for the program, commonly known as Star Wars. The Senate panel cut nearly $1 billion for a total of $3.7 billion. The House committee slashed close to $2 billion for a total of $2.9 billion.

The president's request included $1.6 billion for procurement and military construction costs and $548 million for research involved with moving the MX nuclear missile from fixed silos to railroad cars. The Senate committee approved only the research money. The House panel eliminated all money for the program and instead created a fund of $600 million for advanced missile work, calling on Bush to decide in 90 days what it should be used for, the MX or the unbuilt Midgetman.

Bush proposed $202 million in research money for the mobile single-warhead missile. The Senate panel approved the request. The House committee eliminated the funds in favor of the $600 million strategic missile pot.

Bush's budget cancels the tilt-rotor aircraft that takes off like a helicopter but can fly like a plane. The Senate panel added $238 million in research money for the plane. The House committee included the research money as well as $165 million in procurement funds.

The administration proposed a reduction of about 38,000 from the current total of 2.1 million military personnel. The Senate panel adopted a cut of 100,000, including 50,000 in Europe. The House panel approved a reduction of 129,500.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Cocaine Dealer Pleads Guilty in DEA Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A young man pleaded guilty to charges he bombed a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration office, distributed cocaine and was involved in a federal witness' death, prosecutors said Tuesday. Jeffrey Alan Matthews, 23, formerly known as Jeffrey Ciganek, could face up to life in prison without parole at his sentencing set for Sept. 1 before U.S. District Judge Elizabeth Kovachevich, according to a release from the U.S. attorney's office. ``We will not permit this country to become like some others, where self-styled drug lords can bomb criminal justice facilities at their leisure,'' said Allen McCreight, the area's top FBI agent. Matthews pleaded guilty to charges of supervising a continuing criminal enterprise, homicide to further that enterprise, cocaine trafficking and the March 17 bombing in this Gulf Coast city, the release said. The charge of running a continuing criminal enterprise is the nation's most serious drug-related offense. The pleas were entered Monday, but prosecutors delayed announcing them until Tuesday for ``law enforcement purposes,'' the release said. The bombing came only two days after federal drug indictments were issued against Matthews, his brother John Lewis Ciganek and two others. Matthews was arrested at an Orlando convenience store 25 days after the bombing. He was the only person charged in the bombing, which caused damages estimated at $4 million but no injuries. Authorities said it was the first time a DEA office had been bombed in the United States. According to prosecutors, Matthews has been distributing multikilogram quantities of cocaine in the Fort Myers area for at least five years. Last January, federal witness Stephen Franken was murdered. In his plea, Matthews admitted to inducing, commanding or causing the death in furtherance of his cocaine-trafficking activities. Matthews remains jailed without bond pending his sentencing. His brother awaits trial only on the drug charges Sept. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Central American Military Leaders Meet to Discuss Arms Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Central American officials met here Tuesday to explore ways of cutting their armed forces to improve regional security. The meeting results from an accord reached by Central American presidents during an April summit in Montelimar, Nicaragua. The presidents agreed to attempt to reduce the size of their countries' armies. ``Armaments should be limited and there should be action for verification and control that can be an adequate response to the interests of all the countries,'' Costa Rican Foreign Minister Bern Niehaus said. A Costa Rican foreign ministry official, requesting anonymity, said the officials hoped to revive a regional security commission with the participation of the Organization of American States. Gen. Humberto Ortega, head of the Nicaraguan army, said before the meeting that it ``is very important for regional peace because all of us have promised to reduce our armies and create mechanisms of verification and arms control.'' He said his own country has made large cuts in its own army, considered the largest in Central America. The reductions followed the defeat of the leftist Sandinista government February's elections and a peace agreement that has led to the disarming of U.S.-backed Contra rebels. ``In the last three months, our army has been reduced from 96,000 to 46,000 men ... and we hope to cut it more,'' Ortega said. Guatemala's deputy foreign minister, Mario Rosal, said he was optimistic the meeting would ``advance the subject of security for the countries and reduction of the armies, as well as arms control.'' Other countries represented at the meeting were El Salvador and Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Cargo Door Search Believes Deep-Sea Debris From United Jet
DOC.TEXT: Debris found on the ocean floor 90 miles south of here probably fell from a United Airlines jumbo jet that ripped open last year, the leader of the deep-sea search said Tuesday. ``I would say it's a very good chance _ better than 50 percent _ it's the debris field from the jet,'' said Bob Whaley, leader of the search. The largest piece of debris, a metal object about 10 feet long, is roughly the size of the 10-by-10-foot cargo door that tore away from the Boeing 747 along with a chunk of fuselage, sweeping nine passengers to their deaths, Whaley said. The National Transportation Safety Board asked the Navy to find the cargo door in hopes an examination of it would help the agency write better aviation safety rules. It's up to the NTSB to decide if there should be an attempt to retrieve the debris. The agency hadn't made a decision by late Tuesday, said Lt. Cmdr. Bob Anderson, a Navy spokesman. Whaley said several factors make him think the debis is from United Flight 811. _ The debris was found in an area where Navy radar tracked the door falling into the ocean. _ The bottom, nearly 15,000 feet down, is flat and silty. Older objects on the ocean floor probably would have sunk into the silt. _ The largest piece roughly matches the size of the cargo door. _ The debris field, about three miles long, runs north to south, the direction the plane was traveling. Searchers aboard a 224-foot Navy tug used a small, remote-controlled, deep-sea submarine to find the debris. The sub's sonar located the debris, but searchers were unable to get a picture with the sub's video camera to help confirm whether the debris is from the jet. The jumbo jet carried 355 passengers when it left Honolulu for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989. Shortly after takeoff, a cargo door opened at 22,000 feet, tearing away a section of fuselage. Nine people were swept to their deaths and five others suffered serious injuries. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu. The NTSB inquiry determined that faulty design of the locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit light to falsely indicate the door was locked. The agency blamed United, Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to correct problems with the door. The search, which began a week ago, covered a 24-square-mile section of ocean floor.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Says Acting President Named To Fill In For Nabijullah
With AM-Baker
DOC.TEXT: Kabul Radio said Tuesday that Abdul Rahim Hatif, deputy vice president of Afghanistan, will head the government while President Najibullah is away on a brief trip to the Soviet Union. The state radio's announcement was monitored in Islamabad. Najibullah, who uses only one name, flew to Moscow on Sunday for official meetings and a medical checkup. The unexpected visit led to speculation that the United States and the Soviet Union had reached an agreement on how to end the 12-year-old war in Afghanistan. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will discuss Afghanistan during two days of talks in the Siberian city of Irkutsk beginning Wednesday. Like Najibullah's trip, Hatif's appointment as acting president took many people by surprise. Such appointments are rarely made during a short trip by the president and Hatif's selection apparently bypassed Najibullah's second-in-command, Sultan Ali Keshtmand. Keshtmand, seen as a hard-line member of the ruling party, was appointed two months ago to the newly created post of first vice president. Hatif, 64, is not a member of the ruling Hezb-e-Watan, or Party of the Homeland, which until last month was known as the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. But Hatif was brought into the Soviet-backed government in 1987 as the party sought to broaden its base of support and initiated efforts to distance itself from the bloody Marxist past. Hatif had served under former King Zahir Shah, who was overthrown by his cousin Mohammad Daoud in 1973 and has been living in exile in Italy. Daoud was killed during the 1978 coup that installed a Marxist government and brought the Red Army into Afghanistan a year later. Soviet troops remained in Afghanistan for nine years to fight Moslem guerrillas. Moscow ended direct military involvement in February 1989 but continues to supply the Kabul government with weapons and ammunition. The conflict has become a stalemate, with soldiers holding the cities and guerrillas controlling the countryside.

DOC.HEAD: Group Accuses Belgium of Hampering Release of Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The Fatah-Revolutionary Council led by Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal accused Belgium's government on Tuesday of obstructing the release of four Belgian hostages. ``We hold the Belgian government responsible for hampering and frustrating efforts to reach a happy ending for the Silco boat hostages,'' said a Fatah-RC statement issued in Beirut. The statement charged Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens was ``out to slander our movement by leaking reports of disunity amongst us that is delaying the release of the Belgians.'' The four Belgians were part of group that Fatah-RC said it seized aboard the French yacht Silco in 1987 off Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. They are Emmanuel Houtekins, 44; Godelieve Kets, 50; his son Laurent, 20; and daughter, Valerie, 18. The rest of the group, a French woman and three daughters, plus her Belgian boyfriend, have already been released.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet, U.S. Sailors Trade Stories, Garb in Goodwill Visit
LaserPhotos GO1, GO3
DOC.TEXT: Three Soviet warships steamed into San Diego Harbor on Tuesday, greeted by 21-gun salutes, curious citizenry and a Greenpeace anti-nuclear flotilla. Admirals from both sides exchanged talk of international cooperation and joint military exercises. The sailors swapped sea stories, hats and pins. ``It's great to share ideas about the things that they do and what we do,'' said Boatsmate 2 Regiald White, 23, who chatted with the Soviets through an interpreter about the price of uniforms and seamen's pay. ``They really like meeting people,'' said White, who hails from Houston. ``I think this visit will show people that we can get along together.'' Two Soviet destroyers, Admiral Vinogradov and the Boyevoy, and the supply ship Argun docked Tuesday morning, in the second such port visit of glasnost era. After a 30-minute ceremony punctuated by a flyover from the Navy's Blue Angels precision aerobatics team, U.S. and Soviet sailors mingled on a pier separating their ships. A swarm of Greenpeace groups met the ships, carrying the group's anti-nuclear message. Members of the group said they weren't protesting the visit _ though the ships presumably are capable of carrying nuclear weapons _ but were using the occasion to promote their position. Adm. Gennady Khvatov, commander of the Soviet Pacific Fleet, spoke of the benefits of warming superpower relations. ``I think we have a good prospect for cooperation between the fleets that possibly could lead to military exercises,'' Khvatov said. ``There have been changes and we are trying to view each other as friends, instead of foes.'' The thawing of the Cold War, an ongoing economic crisis in the Soviet Union and glasnost has led to a scaling down of the Soviet military that Khvatov said would reduce the size of his fleet. The visit is mostly a goodwill tour, but the Soviets will visit three U.S. Navy host ships, area military installations and tourist attractions. American and Soviet sailors also will compete in volleyball and soccer matches. The three U.S. ships hosting the Soviets are the USS Merrill, a destroyer; the USS McClusky, a guided-missile frigate; and the USS Leahy, a cruiser. The official host for the visit is Adm. Charles R. Larson, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet. ``My goal is to create a better understanding between us,'' Larson said. ``We may not agree on everything, but this gives us an opportunity to understand where we both are coming from.'' Soviet officials gave reporters, military officials and VIPs tours of the decks of their destroyers, showing off the firepower and handing out Soviet literature. Area residents have volunteered to serve as translators, and about 8,000 others were lucky enough to land free tickets to tour one of the Soviet ships Wednesday through Friday. The visit is the Soviet navy's second to the United States since Adm. William Crowe, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Marshall Sergei Akhromeyev, former Soviet chief of staff, met in 1988 to set the groundwork for the exchanges. Three Soviet ships visited Norfolk, Va., last July and three U.S. warships visited the Black Sea port of Sevastopol last August. Three ships from the U.S. Pacific Fleet are scheduled to make a similar visit Sept. 10-14 to Vladivostok, the Soviet Union's main Pacific port.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Kaifu Accepts Electoral Reform Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu accepted on Tuesday proposals to reduce the role of political parties and special-interest money in elections to the upper house of Parliament, officials said. The recommendations, offered by the Electoral Review Committee, mark a step toward political reform in Japan following scandals that caused two prime ministers to resign last year. The committee was set up in June 1989 to lessen the power of money in Japanese politics. The government plans to draw up legislation based on the proposals, but opposition is strong and analysts believe it unlikely the government will adopt the proposals without change. The report recommended keeping the mixed system of national and regional constituencies used in selecting the 252 delegates to the upper house, but suggested voters be allowed to choose candidates by name when voting in the national constituencies. That would decrease the role of parties and increase the importance of policy in campaigning, the council argued. Critics of Japan's political system frequently cite lack of substantive policy debate during electioneering. The report suggested the government provide more money for candidates to lessen their dependence on outside financing. It recommended toughening election laws and requiring stricter reporting on the use of political funds. Kaifu pledged political reform to restore the prestige of his Liberal Democratic Party and trust in the government. He became prime minister last August after his two predecessors resigned in quick succession over money and sex scandals. Earlier proposals from the committee constituted a plan to reshape the more powerful lower house. The panel suggested reformulating Japan's system of multiple-seat constitutencies to bring greater equality, to reduce politicians' ability to raise money on their own and to tighten rules on reporting political donations.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Issues Smog-Cutting Proposals Including Some Bans on Driving
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency issued a wide-ranging smog-cutting plan Tuesday that includes a proposal to ban driving on some days in the region with the nation's dirtiest air. The court-ordered plan is aimed at cutting ozone in Los Angeles to 14 percent of current levels by early next century, and is a backup to one approved in 1989 by the South Coast Air Quality Management District. Ozone is a major component of smog. The plan stemmed from an environmentalist lawsuit filed against 1982 district air quality standards, guidelines that current officials of the regional agency call timid. They were superseded by stronger local rules last year. The district's current three-year plan affects everything from lawnmowers to petroleum refineries at an estimated cost of $2.62 billion a year. Later steps of that plan include the use of technology not yet developed, making its effectiveness a guessing game. The district covers Orange County and parts of Los Angeles, San Bernardino and Riverside counties, an area where more than 12 million people live in the worst air pollution in the country. In 1988, the most recent year available, Los Angeles exceeded the national standard for ozone 150 times, compared with 20 times for New York and Chicago. The most stringent sections of the EPA plan, which doesn't become final until next year, won't go into effect until after 1995. The entire plan would take effect only if state and regional governments fail to significantly reduce smog. ``State and local authorities have been engaged in an extraordinary effort to address this problem themselves, which we all hope will render a federal plan as unnecessary,'' EPA Western Regional Administrative Director Daniel W. McGovern told a downtown news conference. Environmentalists who brought the lawsuit characterized the EPA plan as insurance to make the district deliver. ``We have been very concerned that the local district has been backsliding,'' said Coalition for Clean Air President Jan Chatten-Brown, whose organization was a plaintiff with the Sierra Club. ``This plan will send a clear message ... if the district won't do the job, the EPA will step in.'' The EPA guidelines include a reluctant proposal for no-drive days to reduce carbon monoxide. Under such a plan, motorists with odd numbers on their license plates would be permitted to drive every other day and those with even tag numbers on another. The no-drive days would be enforced from November through February, and would force affected commuters to find some other way to work, either through car pools or mass transit. ``It is in the spirit of presenting all possibilities that we are presenting the no-drive day ... it is not one we are endorsing,'' said McGovern. The no-drive plan could be used by the year 2000 if other methods fail. The federal plan takes longer to achieve goals set by the regional agency. The district plan calls for reducing current ozone averages by 86 percent in 2007; the EPA by 2010. ``It is our hope and expectation that the state plan will achieve its goals well in advance of the federal plan,'' McGovern said. The EPA will not use its proposed backup system until 1996 at the earliest because of confidence in current efforts, said David Howekamp, chief of air and toxics for the agency. He said the agency will be measuring pollution levels to determine whether the EPA should begin enforcing its proposed regulations. Some features of the EPA backup plan include: _ Mandatory reduction of emissions by 6 percent a year from pollution sources such as consumer products, industrial and commercial solvents, pesticides, commercial food preparation and ``architectural coatings'' such as paint. _ Extending pollution control standards to construction equipment, pleasure boats and off-road vehicles. _ An ``Ultra Clean Motor Vehicle Program'' that would require all new motor vehicles meet emissions limits 85 percent to 90 percent cleaner than those for vehicles now sold.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Get Federal Aid to Develop AIDS-Infection Drugs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDs seven graqfs to identify the teams
DOC.TEXT: Six teams of scientists will receive $2.8 million in federal funds to develop drugs that attack the infections killing people with AIDS, government officials announced Tuesday. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is setting up a program that will provide a formal way for basic research scientists to collaborate with drug companies to design new drugs, they said. ``The urgency of the AIDS epidemic demands innovation,'' Anthony Fauci, director of the institute, said in announcing the program. A version of this program is already being used to bring together scientists of diverse backgrounds to work on drugs that attack the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. Three drugs discovered through the program are now being tested in clinical trials and others are in the pipeline, he said. AIDS activists have been strongly critical of federal scientific research on AIDS because they say too much attention has been focused on anti-viral drugs to attack HIV and not enough on drugs to prevent and treat opportunistic infections. In its announcement of the new research, the institute said that the research program for anti-virals ``did not preclude research on opportunistic infections, but few applications for research in this area were received.'' As a result, the institute last year issued a request for applications specifically addressing opportunistic infections, the institute said. Opportunistic infections _ some rare, some ordinary _ often attack AIDS patients whose immune systems have been weakened by the disease, causing 90 percent of AIDS-related deaths. The most common infection is pneumosystis carinii pneumonia, which occurs in about 85 percent of AIDS patients. Here are the lead researchers of each team and areas of research interest: _Patrick J. Brennan, Colorado State University, Fort Collins; the bacterium Mycobacterium avium. _Paul A. Lartey, Abbott Laboratories Corp., North Chicago, Ill.; fungi-cell wall inhibitors. _Dr. Jack S. Remington, Palo Alto Medical Foundation, Palo Alto, Calif., Palo Alto, Calif.; toxoplasma organisms. _Dr. Jeffrey I. Gordon, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis; fungi-enzyme inhibitors. _James R. Piper, Southern Research Institute, Birmingham, Ala.; Pneumocystis carinii, cytomegalovirus and toxoplasma organisms. _Charles R. Sterling, Univesity of Arizona, Tucson; Cryptosporidium bacteria.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Looks for Breakthrough in Afghanistan Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with Shevardnadze expecting breakthrough on Afghanistan, other pre-meeting remarks, edits to DELETE outdated material and trim. Pickup 17th graf pvs, `Baker on...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Wednesday he expects a breakthrough toward ending the 11-year-old Afghan civil war during his talks with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``We will be able to help solve the Afghanistan question,'' Shevardnadze said minutes before meeting Baker in the first of three scheduled one-on-one meetings over two days. Shevardnadze also said he and Baker would finalize plans for a third summit between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The summit is expected to take place in Moscow around the end of this year or early 1991. Speculation that an agreement on Afghanistan, or a cease-fire, might be near was fueled when Afghanistan's Soviet-backed President Najibullah suddenly flew to Moscow on Sunday. Soviet officials initially said Najibullah had come to the Soviet Union for health reasons. But Shevardnadze, speaking to reporters in front of the concrete guest house in this eastern Siberian city, said Najibullah was ``on vacation'' in the Soviet Union. On Tuesday, official Radio Kabul reported that Deputy Vice President Abdul Rahim Hatif would temporarily act as president while Najibullah is in the Soviet Union. When asked whether Najibullah would return to Afghanistsan, Shevardnadze hesitated and then said, ``He will return to Afghanistan just like any of us return home after vacation.'' The United States backs the Pakistan-based Moslem guerrillas fighting the Afghan government. Earlier, Shevardnadze said the positions of boths sides on resolving the Afghan conflict were moving closer together and the ``issue of a settlement is now being posed differently.'' The Baker-Shevardnadze meetings were also to cover the civil war in Cambodia, U.S. economic aid to the Soviet Union, the Middle East conflict and the divided Korean peninsula. Explaining the choice of Irkutsk as the venue for the talks, Tass quoted Shevardnadze as saying such out-of-the-way locations were convenient. ``Less time is wasted on protocol and there are time and the conditions for a truly working atmosphere,'' said Shevardnadze, who arrived in Irkutsk, 2,600 miles east of Moscow, late Tuesday. Shevardnadze said arrangements were to be made during his meetings with Baker on the U.S.-Soviet summit, Tass said, quoting remarks made on his flight to Irkutsk. Baker arrived for the talks early Wednesday. Shevardnadze, in his in-flight interview, said Bush and Gorbachev had agreed on the new meeting during their December summit in Malta and that it should take place before the end of the year, Tass said. This was why there was extremely little time left to prepare the new summit, said Shevardnadze, as quoted by Tass. Gorbachev and Bush last met in June in Washington. In Washington, a White House official said a summit probably will be held in Moscow next year but could come earlier if a nuclear weapons treaty is ready for signing. ``I am not excluding or including'' the possibility of a Moscow summit by the end of the year, said Alixe Glen, White House deputy press secretary. Also on the flight, Shevardnadze hailed the recent meeting between Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on German unification as a ``breakthrough,'' Tass said. At that meeting, Gorbachev agreed to NATO membership for a united Germany. Shevardnadze said the next round of formal unification talks scheduled for September in Moscow would be the concluding one, Tass reported. Those talks will involve the four World War II Allies, plus leaders of the German states. Hope for resolving Cambodia's 12-year-old civil war remains muted. Baker on Tuesday ended a five-day trip in Southeast Asia, leaving Singapore without securing the support of the region's foreign ministers for an abrupt about-face in U.S. policy toward Cambodia. In mid-July, Baker announced the United States was ending eight years of support for the Cambodian resistance and would begin direct talks with Vietnam, which backs the Cambodian government. Those talks are scheduled for Aug. 6 in New York. The goal was to distance the U.S. government from the Khmer Rouge, the most powerful member of the resistance coalition. The Khmer Rouge killed an estimated 1 million Cambodians during its bloody 1975-78 rule. But the Cambodian question remains complicated because the United States and the Soviet Union exercise limited influence in the region. Najibullah's departure for Moscow sparked speculation that U.S. and Soviet officials had reached a tacit agreement that the Afghan president would hand over some power to a council of Afghan forces prior to a nationwide election. The last time an Afghan president took a quick trip to Moscow was in 1985. That president, Babrak Karmal, never returned to his post and was replaced by Najibullah. U.S. negotiators have dropped their demand that Najibullah step down. Now they say he could remain as president during the election, providing he cedes control of the military, state media and secret police to a neutral body. The Soviet Union is believed to have agreed to these terms and the composition of the neutral body is now at issue. Since 1979, U.S.-backed rebels have battled first Soviet troops and then Soviet-supported Afghan forces in a war that has left more than 1.5 million people dead, including 13,000 Soviet troops, and left millions more homeless. More than 115,000 Soviet soldiers withdrew from Afghanistan in 1989 after nine years of military intervention. After the talks in Irkutsk, Baker and Shevardnadze will take a cruise on Lake Baikal. On Thursday, Baker is to fly to Mongolia for talks with the government and a hunting trip.

DOC.HEAD: Social Security Puts Temporary Hold On Travel For Appeals Hearings
DOC.TEXT: The Social Security Administration will schedule no more hearings for disability benefit appeals in September if they involve travel or other outside expenses, an agency spokesman said Tuesday. The decision does not affect thousands of hearings already scheduled nor does it mean that additional hearings cannot be booked, said Philip Gambino, a Social Security spokesman. The hold on additional travel or outside expenses is temporary and happens annually as the agency approaches the end of its fiscal year in September, Gambino said. ``It's not unusual,'' Gambino said. He denied a report published in the Wednesday editions of the New York Times, saying that the agency had ``suspended'' hearings in September because of the year-end financial crunch. ``We haven't canceled any hearings,'' he said. ``We're still going to do hearings during September,'' Gambino said. ``I can't even tell you if we're going to do less in September than we are in August.'' He estimated that the agency holds some 20,000 hearings a month at more 200 locations around the country for people who are appealing decisions that deny or reduce the Social Security disability benefits they receive.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Police Chief Drops Sex Discrimination Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The first woman police chief of a large city said Tuesday that lack of money for legal fees has forced her to abandon a sex-discrimination lawsuit against Mayor Bud Clark and the city. Attorneys for Penny Harrington, who resigned as police chief in 1986, notified the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco that she had dropped her appeal of an earlier ruling on the suit. A U.S. District Court jury on March 16 rejected Harrington's claims that she was a victim of discrimination and was forced out of office. ``I would like to have been able take it on to an appeal and another court trial,'' Harrington said. ``But I exhausted all of my resources. It was just too costly in money and emotionally.'' Clark said he was pleased. ``I think she finally realized she was just wasting her time and she may as well save her energy and get on with her life,'' the mayor said. Harrington, who was the nation's first female chief of a large police department, resigned in 1986 after a special commission appointed by Clark recommended she be replaced. She served in the post for 1{ years. She filed a lawsuit that sought unspecified damages for sex discrimination, harm to her personal and professional reputation and harm to her chances for future employment in police work. She also sought damages for mental and emotional strain and compensation for some of her legal fees. Harrington resigned after a commission appointed by Clark questioned her ability to manage the department, which then had a $47 million annual budget and 1,000 employees. The commission was formed to investigate Harrington's alleged friendship with a suspect in a drug case and her elimination of drug and vice units. A city pension board decided June 12 that Harrington was entitled to increased benefits under a pension plan approved by voters in November. Under the new plan, Harrington could receive an annual pension of $36,679, plus cost-of-living increases. Portland City Attorney Jeff Rogers said it cost more than $300,000 to defend the case. He said the city agreed it wouldn't try to recover court costs from Harrington. ``This is the end of a chapter in my life and I'm glad that it is over and I don't have to think about it any more,'' Harrington said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles, where she works for the California Bar Association. ``I have no hard feelings toward Portland. I'm very happy in my job here. I am extremely disappointed in Bud Clark.''

DOC.HEAD: Senior Army Officers Freed in Zambia
DOC.TEXT: British-trained Lt. Gen. Christon Tembo, a former army commander being tried on charges of plotting to overthrow the government, was freed Tuesday on orders of President Kenneth Kaunda. Screaming supporters and jubilant relatives mobbed Tembo on the steps of the High Court in Lusaka. He and three other senior army officers whose release was announced by Kaunda on June 25 earlier appeared briefly in court to hear Judge Weston Muzyamba discharge them. Muzyamba told Tembo, purported leader of the 1988 attempt; Lt. Cols. Biswayo Nkunika and Chongo Shula; and Maj. Knight Mulenga that they were discharged from detention, but not acquitted of capital charges of treason. This meant that at any time the state can resume proceedings against them. Tembo, arrested in late 1988, appeared in court wearing a tailored gray suit. In court, he raised two fists in a victory salute and told reporters he felt ``great.'' Officials said Tembo and his three colleagues were taken to Kaunda's official residence on their way to the court. Tembo refused to disclose what he discussed with Kaunda, telling reporters the conversation was ``between me and the president.'' After their discharge, the four officers were immediately driven to the main prison in Lusaka to sign release papers. The case was widely seen as being politically damaging to Kaunda and the party in power after state witnesses cited official corruption as a major reason allegedly given by the defendants for planning Kaunda's ouster. Kaunda was accused of holding a personal fortune of more than $4 billion in foreign bank accounts. Analysts said whether it was true or not, most Zambians believed it. In June, during the worst civil unrest since Zambia's independence from British colonial rule in 1964, many demonstrators chanted ``Kaunda out! Tembo in!'' and similar slogans of support for the general. At least 26 people died in five days of rioting and looting touched off by food price increases and calls for the end of two decades of one-party rule. On Monday, four people, including former High Court commissioner Edward Shamwana, were freed by Kaunda as part of political reforms. The four were accused of plotting to overthrow the government in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Study Suggests Less Frequent Tests for Cervical Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Cervical cancer tests done every three years instead of every year are a lot less expensive, and the overall accuracy is nearly the same, a researcher says, but others strongly disagree. Previous studies show that tests every three years on women aged 20 to 65 are about 96 percent as effective at detecting cancerous or other abnormal cells as annual exams, according to Dr. David M. Eddy of Duke University. In addition, the three-year exams offer a two-thirds reduction in cost, risk and inconvenience, according to Eddy's article in Wednesday's edition of the journal Annals of Internal Medicine. But women at high risk for cervical cancer _ including those who smoke, use oral contraceptives or have multiple sex partners _ may prefer exams every one to two years, said Eddy, who reviewed studies on test frequency. Other researchers cautioned against following a recommendation based on cost, and said physicians must consider human factors when deciding how often to examine their patients for cervical cancer. ``The question is where to draw the line,'' Eddy said. ``Ideally, this should be decided by women themselves.'' While some researchers believe that women tested every three years will be more likely to forget the exam, any interval from one to four years ``will deliver virtually the same benefits,'' according to Eddy. However, Dr. George Malkasian, the immediate past president of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists warned that the death rate from cervical cancer would probably increase if Eddy's recommendation were followed. Cervical cancer strikes more than 13,000 American women a year and causes about 7,000 deaths annually. If the cancer is caught in the early stages, the survival rate after five years is about 90 percent, aid Malkasian, a senior consultant at the Mayo Clinic, said in a telephone interview. The most common test for cervical cancer is the Pap test, which detects abnormal or cancerous cells in the cervix, the opening to the womb. The test costs an average $76 per patient. Other cancer specialists argued that other factors should play a role in a woman's decision regarding Pap tests. They point out that the test is one of the main reasons the number of deaths from cervical cancer has dropped 70 percent since it was first widely used in the 1940s. Many medical organizations, including the obstetricians' and gynecologists' college and the American Cancer Society, recommend that women who are at least 18 years old or sexually active have Pap tests annually for three years. After three negative tests, women can reduce the frequency of the tests on their physicians' advice, the groups suggest. Some cancer specialists, including Dr. Robert Young, president of Philadelphia's Fox Chase Cancer Center, believe that as more women rely on their gynecologist as their only provider of health care, annual Pap tests can supply the only contact between patient and physician. Despite Eddy's contention that only anecdotal evidence suggests that physicians are more likely to discover other medical problems in women who have annual Pap tests, ``there are certain realities'' that get lost in a cost analysis, Young said in a telephone interview. He said he feared recommendations regarding Pap tests based only on cost-effectiveness would discourage some women from being examined at all. Of the 7,000 women who die each year of cervical cancer, 85 percent never had a Pap test prior to the diagnosis, according to Young. ``We need to encourage the wider use of Pap smears,'' he said. But the American College of Physicians, which publishes the Annals, supports Eddy's recommendation of testing every three years. ``All women should be given information on the expected benefits, risks and costs and be allowed to choose the screening strategy that reflects their preferences,'' according to the association.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Photo Exhibit Opens In City Where Artist Died of AIDS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf and inserts 4 grafs after 14th graf pvs, `The coverage...,' to UPDATE with photos shown on newscast.
DOC.TEXT: In the city once notorious for the label ``banned in Boston,'' a tour of Robert Mapplethorpe's controversial photographs made its final stop Tuesday, opening to strong protests and equally fervent support. One public television station showed seven sexually explicit photographs from the so-called ``X Portfolio'' on its nightly newscast. The exhibit has drawn the wrath of conservative Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C.; been canceled in Washington; inspired limits on federal arts grants; and drawn criminal charges in Cincinnati. Largely because of the uproar, the show is expected to draw at least 50,000 people in Boston. It runs through Oct. 4. A news conference in support of the show, coordinated by an eclectic group calling itself the Boston Coalition for Freedom of Expression, included speeches by artists and playwrights. A march and rally were planned for Wednesday, when the exhibit opens to the public at the Institute of Contemporary Art. Hours after that news conference, a coalition of 13 groups calling itself First Amendment Common Sense held a volatile Statehouse news conference in which it pressed public officials to halt the exhibit as obscene and unlawful. ``We're calling for a revival of common sense,'' said Evelyn Dubel. ``To protest this bizarre and illegal behavior that threatens the well-being of our citizens. We're concerned about the well-being of our neighbors, especially our children.'' Joe Reilley, a leader of Morality in Media, a group which says it favors family values and opposes pornography, alluded to upcoming legal action but refused to specify what that action would be. One protester was arrested for interrupting the Common Sense coalition news conference, which also featured heated questions from members of gay rights groups. David Ross, director of the art institute, said he was proud to have the exhibit and unafraid of the controversy surrounding the show of 124 photographs taken by Mapplethorpe from 1969 until shortly before he died of AIDS last year in Boston at the age of 42. ``What we have to fear is the suppression of these ideas,'' Ross said, pointing to a button being sold in conjunction with the show that said ``Fear No Art.'' ``We're talking about art. This isn't the Combat Zone,'' Ross said, referring to Boston's red light district. ``This is not a pornography exhibit ... This show is a celebration of beauty.'' Producers of WGBH-TV's ``Ten O'Clock News'' said they decided to focus on the controversial photographs in their newscast rather than concentrating on Mapplethorpe's portraits and flower studies. ``The coverage thus far never shows you this. All you get is what is in the mind of the (newspaper) writer. And we want our coverage to let the viewer decide, with both sides presented,'' said John VanScoyoc, the station's managing editor. Some of the most controversial photographs were shown, including those depicting sadomasochism and homoeroticism. About 24 minutes of the half-hour newscast was devoted to the exhibit and the accompanying controversy. Alan Foster, news director at the station, said at least 63 calls were received on the station's response line within 15 minutes of the show's conclusion. The line was attached to an answering machine and it would not be known until Wednesday how callers felt about the broadcast, Foster said. Another 20 callers had managed to dial the station's newsroom directly. ``Those have been universally positive,'' Foster said. ``One guy said, `brilliant show, terrific journalism.''' Mary Catherine Kilday, enforcement chief of the Federal Communications Commission in Washington, said the agency does not monitor television or radio programming and ``we do not currently have authority to enforce indecency complaints after 8 p.m.'' A Mapplethorpe exhibit scheduled in June 1989 in Washington, D.C., at the Corcoran Gallery of Art was canceled after Helms branded the artist's work obscene. Helms' objections prompted Congress to limit National Endowment for the Arts grants. Before those limits were imposed, organizers of the Mapplethorpe tour received about $30,000 from the NEA _ about 10 percent of the cost. Controversy was mild when the tour began in Philadelphia in late 1988 and it only drew about 12,000 visitors. But in Cincinnati this spring, the exhibit spurred a rally and march by supporters and opponents of the works. The Cincinnati exhibit led to an obscenity indictment against the director of The Contemporary Arts Center, but a federal judge barred police from confiscating photographs from the exhibit. Two of the disputed photographs in Cincinnati involved children. In one, a boy's genitals are exposed; in the other, a girl's genitals are exposed. Five others show homosexual acts.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Seeking to end a 4-day-old hostage siege, Prime Minister Arthur N. R. Robinson says he has agreed to resign, call elections in 90 days and grant his Moslem extremist captors amnesty. He made the announcement along with a rebel spokesman late Monday in a telephone call from inside the besieged Parliament building. However, it was not clear when Robinson and the other 40 hostages might be freed. They were seized on Friday by members of a black Moslem group, whose leader later claimed to have wired Robinson with explosives that he said would be detonated if the government tried to rescued the hostages. Robinson said Monday night that he was not coerced into the agreement, which he announced in the call to a local journalist several hours after military and government spokesmen said negotiations had broken down.

Baseball finally did to New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner what he'd been doing to managers for 18 years _ it fired him. Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent on Monday stripped Steinbrenner of control of the team for allegedly paying a gambler to dig up dirt on a ballplayer. ``For all purposes, Mr. Steinbrenner agrees that he is to be treated as if he had been placed on the permanent ineligible list,'' Vincent said. ``I hope this sad episode is now over.'' Fans rose in a 90-second standing ovation when news spread to Yankee Stadium. The decision brought shouts of ``No more George!'' ``I will not comment on the decision,'' Steinbrenner said. ``I'm very happy it was resolved. I'm very satisfied with the resolution, and that's all I'm going to say.''

This year's farm bill may take the worry out of shopping for organic cucumbers. Other provisions apparently headed for adoption in Congress would stop exports of pesticides banned domestically, expand protection of wetlands and erodible fields and encourage farmers to cut their use of chemicals that can find their way into the water supply. The legislation, which sets agricultural policy for the next five years, has at its heart a set of support programs for crops and livestock. But this year's bill focused as never before on measures intended to protect the Earth and its waters, drafted under the watchful eye of lobbyists for environmental groups, farmers and the chemical industry.

Federal safety investigators are focusing on conduct of the Exxon Valdez crew, the company that hired them and the Coast Guard in determining what caused the nation's worst oil spill. A report by the National Transportation Safety Board staff was getting a final look at a public meeting today. The board then planned to vote on the probable cause of the March 24, 1989, spill of 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound. The panel also was considering other possible conclusions stemming from the disaster that led to a $1 billion cleanup effort by Exxon Corp. Safety board reports are not made public until after the panel votes. With one vacancy on the five-member NTSB, the possibility of a deadlock loomed on some issues, although reports normally are not brought to the final stage until members have had a chance to read them and discuss any disagreements with staff investigators.

A coroner who dropped a dead infant head-first onto the floor as part of his research into skull fractures is being sued by the child's parents for $2 million in a case that has divided doctors over such practices. Some coroners say such research has been carried out in morgues for years. Others say the permission of the next of kin should be required. In the trial, which began last month, District Judge Hugh Brunson must decide whether state law allows coroners to conduct experiments not needed to determine the cause of death and whether approval from relatives is needed. No state court has previously ruled on the issue. But state Assistant Attorney General Chuck Yeager said in an opinion last year that the law does not authorize such experiments without the permission of the next of kin.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R.-dated item to RECAST lead to drop reference to summit being held by year's end; ADDS new Shevardnadze remarks on summit to clarify Soviet position.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III and his Soviet counterpart Eduard Shevardnadze will lay the groundwork for a Soviet-U.S. summit, the Tass news agency said Tuesday. Arrangements were to be made during two days of meetings in the eastern Siberian city of Irkutsk, the official Soviet news agency said quoting Shevardnadze, who spoke on the flight to Irkutsk. Baker arrived for the talks early Wednesday. Shevardnadze, in his in-flight interview, said President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev had agreed on the new meeting during their December summit in Malta and that it should take place before the end of the year, Tass said. This was why there was extremely little time left to prepare the new summit, said Shevardnadze, as quoted by Tass. Gorbachev and Bush last met in June in Washington. A Soviet foreign ministry source told Tass the next summit would be held in the Soviet Union. In Washington, a White House official said a summit probably will be held in Moscow next year but could come earlier if a nuclear weapons treaty is ready for signing.

DOC.HEAD: Ninja Turtles: Small, Green and Irish Too
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``Shamrock,'' says the poster, ``isn't the only thing that's green and comes from Ireland.'' Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles do, too. Their fans may not realize it, but some of the Turtle cartoons invading the world's TV screens are made by an often-tedious process in Ireland, a country that makes up with humor and motivation for its lack of any background in cartoon-making. The Irish may be unfamiliar with ``cowabunga,'' but they know a job-creating export opportunity when they see one, which is why the Industrial Development Authority of Ireland is willing to help pay its way. Working from rough comic-strip storyboards drawn at Murakami Wolf Swenson, the Burbank, Calif., owner of the animation rights, dozens of artists and technicians hunch over drawing boards and photography machines, producing 35mm films that will be sent back to Burbank to be made into videocassettes. Housed in a functional office block in the center of the city, Murakami Wolf Dublin Ltd. turns out a 22-minute cartoon every month or so to feed the global appetite for ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' Each cartoon requires some 13,000 separate drawings, and the work that falls to the junior animators is tedious. But for Ireland, with its chronic double-digit unemployment, anything that creates jobs is worth a try, and the Industrial Development Authority sees the Turtles as Ireland's ticket to becoming ``a key player in animation for television.'' ``One of the advantages of Ireland is a well educated, young population. It hasn't got a background in animation as such ... but the people are very trainable,'' says Eamonn Lawless, the Dublin account who manages the studio. ``As well as that, they're culturally compatible with the United States and with Europe.'' ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' in case anyone hasn't heard, are four terrapins who were dropped into a radioactive brew and mutated into talking, pizza-scoffing teen-age wisecrackers. A rat named Splinter trained them in the ancient Oriental art of Ninja combat, and loosed them on America's streets to battle for justice. Americans may take such amiable nonsense in their stride, but some Europeans have found it a trifle too manic. The British Broadcasting Co. insists on the title ``Teenage Mutant HERO Turtles,'' apparently believing that British audiences may have difficulty with ``Ninja.'' ``As far as they were concerned, it was too violent-sounding,'' said Lawless in an interview at his Spartan office desk. Lawless hadn't heard of the Turtles until he was approached two years ago to head the Dublin operation. But he says he quickly caught the bug. ``Irish generally are fairly nonconformist in their attitude, and they're laidback to most things,'' he said. Besides, ``I'd not regard myself as a stereotype accountant. I have always liked cartoons.'' The Dublin connection is a tribute to the Industrial Development Authority's broadminded approach, and to Jimmy Murakami, an accomplished American animator who has lived here for 17 years dreaming of bringing the cartoon industry to Ireland. The IDA pays the studio a one-time grant of up to 9,000 pounds ($14,700) for each new job created _ half when the employee starts work, and the rest if the job is still there six months later. The studio opened in February 1989, having promised to create 126 new jobs. It has, in fact, created 130, according to IDA spokesman Michael Flood. It produced seven cartoons in 1989, and will make 10 this year. It also illustrates the globalization of the entertainment industry. Stories are created in California, animation is done in Ireland and South Korea and the cartoons are shown worldwide. South Korea produces far more Turtle cartoons than Ireland, but Murakami and Lawless believe the Irish have the advantage of language and humor. ``They're easier to work with and they know what you're talking about,'' says Chuck Swenson, a partner in the California studio who has been here for eight months helping oversee the operation. Half the charm of the Turtles is their laidback, subversive dialogue _ what Swenson calls ``that inane Californian slang.'' That makes it all the more important for animators to have a feel for English and an acute sense of timing. For instance, Lawless cites a cartoon in which a Turtle has run out of pizza money and turns to the camera saying: ``This means I'm gonna have to (gulp) get a job!'' It takes a subtle hand to match the gulp to the phrase. Also, adds Swenson, ``The idea of not being very excited over getting a job doesn't really translate in Eastern Asian societies, where everybody would love to have a job.''
