DOC.HEAD: TV Service Being Launched in Pediatrician's Waiting Rooms
DOC.TEXT: Patients in dozens of pediatrician's offices are going to be exposed to special video programs with commercials starting this week. The service is called Healthlink Television. The executive overseeing it, David Moore, said Monday that TV sets and video disc players for showing the program would be in operation by Wednesday in 100 pediatricians' offices in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Plans are to expand nationally to 2,500 doctors' offices by the end of August, 5,000 by the end of September and 20,000 by early 1991, he said. Doctors will be given a one-hour program on a laserdisc that is to be played continuously on the TV system during the business day. The program will focus on health care topics with up to nine minutes of commercials _ each two to four minutes long _ per hour between program segments. Healthlink Television is the first of two commercially-sponsored video programs that are being produced for audiences in medical waiting rooms. Healthlink is a subsidiary of Hearst-ABC-Viacom Entertainment Services, a joint venture of Capital Cities-ABC Inc., the Hearst Corp. and Viacom International Inc. The other video program is Special Reports Television, being produced by Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., and debuting in October. Whittle is 50 percent-owned by the entertainment giant Time Warner Inc. Both services are aimed principally at mothers visiting the doctor either for themselves or with their children. They are the latest example of media vehicles developed to enable advertisers to reach narrowly defined audiences. Other commercial targeted programming includes the Channel One news program for teens in the classroom, programs for women at the beauty parlor and a news show for shoppers in the grocery checkout line. These efforts are contributing to the erosion of the audience for network television and are being blamed partly for the weakness in advertising for mass media such as the consumer magazines. Moore said Healthlink TV will be installed in September in offices of obstetricians and gynecologists as well as those of pediatricians and said that family practitioners will start getting the service a month later. Separate programs, developed with advice from doctors in each medical specialty, will be created each month for each type of office. On the first Healthlink program, the only paid commercials are for Tylenol, the pain reliever from Johnson & Johnson. Public service messages also were included. Moore said two other advertisers he declined to identify have made firm commitments to sponsor the programs for family practitioners. Healthlink also announced that it has signed three physicians with experience in television as hosts for its three programs. Dr. Nancy Snyderman, a medical correspondent for ABC's ``Good Morning America and KPIX-TV in San Francisco, will host the pediatrics program. Dr. Holly Atkinson, vice president of programming and medical affairs at the cable channel Lifetime Medical Television, will host the programs for patients of obstetricians and gynecologists. Dr. Tim Johnson, medical editor for ABC News and Entertainment, will host the family practice show. Whittle announced earlier this month that Joan Lunden, co-host of ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' had signed a three-year contract to host Special Reports TV shows.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Reports Profit Dropped 47.2 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said today its second-quarter profit plunged 47.2 percent from last year, mainly because of incentive costs. The company said it earned $180 million, or 81 cents a share, during the April through June period compared with $341 million, or $1.46 a share, during the same period last year. Second-quarter earnings last year were inflated by $8 million from the sale of Chrysler's Gulfstream Aerospace Inc. subsidiary. Without the Gulfstream sale, its profit would be off only 46 percent from results of $333 million, or $1.42 a share, a year ago. Revenues fell 11.1 percent to $8.8 billion from $9.9 billion during the April-June period last year. ``If not for the huge year-to-year increase in per-unit incentive costs, we would have made more money this quarter than we did in the second quarter of 1989,'' Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca said. The company will not say specificialy how much it spent on incentives during the quarter, but spokesman Tom Houston said it was more than $1,000 for every car and truck sold. Chrysler's earnings were in line with Wall Street analysts' expectations. For the first half of this year, Chrysler's earnings fell 63.7 percent to $251 million, or $1.13 a share, from $692 million, or $2.96 a share, last year. Revenue for the first half dropped 15.8 percent to $16.5 billion from $19.6 billion. Last Thursday, General Motors Corp. said its second-quarter profit fell 40 percent to $990.1 million, and Ford Motor Co. said it made $770.7 million, down 45 percent from a year ago. GM and Ford blamed part of their decreases on economic problems in Brazil, where both companies have large manufacturing factories. Chrysler has a small overseas presence. Incentives ate into profits for each of the Big Three during the second quarter. Ford Treasurer David McCammon said incentives cost the automaker an average of $1,025 per vehicle sold during the period. GM refused to release per-car incentive costs. Chrysler has been more bullish about using incentives to boost sales than the other two companies. In January, for the first time in history, Chrysler offered a $1,000 rebate on its popular minivans and sales soared. But when the incentives expired, sales plummeted. Chrysler's car and truck sales through the first half of this year ran 13 percent behind last year's pace. GM's were down 3.5 percent and Ford's were off 7.8 percent. Chrysler's profit in the first quarter dropped 80 percent, to $71 million, compared with last year. Analysts and company officials have estimated that the company won't make any money in the third quarter, mainly because of retooling at its two minivan plants, which interrupts production of some of the company's most profitable vehicles. Automakers are wholesalers that make money on cars and trucks sold to dealers. Consequently, when production stops, the company loses money. The effects of production halts usually show up in retail sales figures within three months, depending on inventory of unsold vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Delegation Deflects EC Commissioner's Surprise Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with meeting ending, ministers' quotes. Minor editing throughout; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: NEWMARKET-ON-FERGUS, Ireland (AP) _ The world's most powerful agriculture ministers today played down a surprise proposal by the European Community to cut global farm support by 30 percent over a decade. The EC proposal was ``only a start,'' U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. He made his comments at a news conference at the conclusion of a two-day private meeting of the senior agriculture officials of the United States, the EC, Japan, Canada and Australia. Japanese Agriculture Minister Tomio Yamamoto said the gathering was ``not the place for negotiations.'' ``We did not discuss substance and details,'' Yamamoto said. Canadian Agriculture Minister Donald Mazankowski told reporters earlier: ``If you start from a distorted playing field and you apply the 30 percent cuts ... you'd still end up with a distorted playing field.'' The EC commissioner, Ray MacSharry, made the proposal early Monday at the so-called Quint meeting, which was held at Dromoland Castle near Shannon in western Ireland. A dispute over Europe's huge farm subsidies is threatening the successful conclusion of current global trade liberalization talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The United States and 14 other farm exporting countries want the 12-nation EC to end its export credits system and cut direct subsidies for farmers, which the critics say distort trade. European Commission spokesman John Cooney, said that MacSharry's proposal was an ``important initiative.'' ``People have been saying the commission has been stalling,'' he said Monday. ``The proposal has taken the lead in these talks.'' But Mazankowski said, ``It's hard to really get a real fix on it. Until we really see all the details it's very difficult to make an accurate assessment.'' He said the United States and Canada already may have implemented such cuts. Mazankowski said ``What we're really after is specific reductions in the three specific areas'' of market access, internal support and export refunds. The Canadian minister added, ``We're going to enter into more intense negotiations as we move forward.'' The U.S. delegation said it would be inappropriate to negotiate a proposal outside GATT's current Uruguay Round of talks. Ms. Shipp noted that MacSharry, Yeutter and their colleagues were not the actual GATT negotiators. MacSharry's proposed figure ``of course needs great clarification and articulation,'' she said. However, the U.S. and EC teams continued to express confidence that, with hard work, an overall GATT agreement would be reached on time in December. MacSharry's proposed overall, 30 percent cut in farm support covers the period 1986 to 1996 and includes EC cuts which already have been implemented, Cooney said. Cooney cited achieved reductions of 10 percent in support for crops and a 15 percent cut in livestock support. Details will be worked out and the proposal will be presented to the European Commission in September, Cooney said. The commission would have to approve the plan before it could be presented at GATT, he said. GATT negoitators are to meet again in Geneva, Switzerland in late August. They agreed at a meeting last week to compile lists and costs of their farm support by Oct. 1. Complicating the negotiations are disagreements about how to measure support. The developed world's farm subsidies cost consumers and taxpayers $245 billion last year, according to the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The cost to EC consumers and taxpayers' was $93 billion, to Japan's $68 billion and the to United States' $46 billion, the 24-nation OECD said.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures Gain On Soybean Strength, Lagging Crops
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The early strength was centered in the soybean pit and rooted in two factors: a strong cash market for soybeans and a weekly government report that showed corn and soybean development still lagging far behind the normal pace. In addition to higher cash prices for soybeans, analysts said relatively few delivery notices were posted this morning at the Board of Trade. Today is the first opportunity for traders to declare their intent to deliver soybeans against the August contract. A low number of notices indicates strong cash-market demand. Monday's weekly Agriculture Department crop-progress report showed corn and soybean development still lagging far behind the normal pace, although the crops were rated in very good condition. The slow pace of crop development is a function of heavy spring rains, which delayed planting in some areas. An early frost in the Midwest, which is considered unlikely, could damage late-maturing soybeans, analysts said. ``That's the only thing the bulls can hang their hats on and it won't mean much if we get a normal frost date,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.94\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 1\ cents higher with September at $2.62\ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents higher with September at $1.28} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 5 cents higher with August at $5.93 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent to .43 cent higher with August at 78.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 89.25 cents a pound; live hogs were .55 cent to .45 cent higher with August at 61.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.65 cents to the limit 2 cents higher with August at 51.10 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures ended mostly higher on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Penny Stock Brokerage Files For Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: Blinder, Robinson & Co., once the largest penny-stock brokerage in the world, has filed for protection from its creditors while it reorganizes under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws. Blinder, Robinson said in a statement issued Monday that it has ceased to do business as a brokerage. It said it intends to transfer its 250,000 customer accounts and brokerage operations to another, unidentified brokerage firm. Founder and President Meyer Blinder was not immediately available for comment. Robert Davenport, head of the Security and Exchange Commission's regional office in Denver, said the SEC has been aware of Blinder, Robinson's teetering finances in recent weeks, but did not know of the bankruptcy until Monday night. Once the largest penny-stock firm in the world, Blinder, Robinson had shrunk to one-third its former size amid investigations by federal regulators and investor lawsuits. It recorded a loss of $14.8 million in 1988 and $11.7 million in 1989. Penny stocks are low cost, high risk securities, usually trading for less than $3 per share. They are not listed on stock exchanges and typically are used to raise capital for new or small companies. According to a filing made Monday with the SEC, Blinder, Robinson owed its customers $4.8 million in cash and other brokerage firms $400,000. The brokerage also owed customers and other brokerage firms $70 million in securities, the filing said. Blinder, Robinson was the target of numerous state and federal investigations. Blinder himself faces charges of racketeering and wire fraud in indictments handed down earlier this year by a grand jury in Nevada. Although the government lawsuits cost Blinder, Robinson millions in legal fees over the past decade, a civil lawsuit won by one-time Denver stockbroker Donald Walford may have been the last straw. Walford won a judgment worth about $5.7 million earlier this month when the Colorado Supreme Court refused to hear any more appeals from Blinder, Robinson. That judgment, which has not been fully paid by the firm, had prompted Meyer Blinder to threaten bankruptcy in recent weeks. In a state Supreme Court filing last week, Walford's attorney, Steve Miller, told the court Blinder had threatened bankruptcy and had told him, ``You took me out even though the SEC couldn't for years _ you can tell that to the press.'' Miller said Monday the bankruptcy might mean part of the $5.7 million judgment never will be paid. But he added, it also means ``my civil lawsuit has closed the doors to Blinder, Robinson.'' Blinder _ who in 1987 paid himself $9.4 million while the brokerage brought in about $138 million in revenues _ has taken a battering this year from government regulators as well. On July 13 the SEC filed a $24 million lawsuit against the self-proclaimed king of the penny stocks, just three days after he lost the Supreme Court appeal to the Walford lawsuit. On April 27, the SEC ordered Blinder out of the brokerage business and his firm to be shut for 45 days. The order was stayed, however, pending appeals. In the most critical blow delivered by the government, a federal grand jury in Las Vegas, Nev., handed down an 11-count criminal indictment in February. The indictment charged Blinder and four other men with racketeering, securities fraud and conspiracy to violate racketeering laws. In November 1988, Internal Revenue Service agents, along with the SEC, staged a four-day raid at the Blinder Building looking for evidence of money laundering and stock fraud. The evidence from that raid served in the grand jury investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Most Consumers Ill-Equipped to Evaluate Health of Banks, S&Ls: Seidman
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOP 7 grafs new, picks up 3rd graf pvs, Even the ... Editing throughout. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: A top federal regulator said today the fund protecting commercial bank deposits is under ``very substantial stress'' and probably will suffer a third consecutive loss this year. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said, ``We may well have another loss in the current year.'' He told the Senate Banking Committee the loss could drop reserves in the fund to between 50 cents and 60 cents per $100 in bank deposits. Speaking to reporters during a break in the hearing, Seidman said ``it would not be unreasonable'' to predict a $2 billion loss in the bank insurance fund, lowering reserves to roughly $11 billion. The fund has lost money in every year since 1988, when it began with reserves of $18 billion. The fund is declining despite increases in the insurance premiums paid by banks. Seidman said after a review of more than 1,000 problem banks in the country his agency believes the fund is still adequate to handle bank failures. ``At this point we believe we can handle anything we can see,'' he said. Seidman also said most bank and thrift customers are ill-equipped to evaluate the health of the institutions where they deposit their money. ``Only a small proportion of depositors have the resources and ability to make informed judgments about the condition of a bank,'' he said. ``Even the best regulators, Wall Street types and financial gurus have a very poor record of foreseeing banking problems much in advance,'' he said in testimony prepared for the Senate Banking Committee. Seidman, whose agency insures deposits at commercial banks and thrifts, avoided commenting on specific proposals to revise deposit insurance laws. But, he said any proposals designed to increase depositor oversight of banks ``have their limitations.'' In the wake of the S&L debacle, many conservative economists advocate scaling back deposit insurance. They argue that depositors, knowing their money was protected by the government, didn't care if they were putting it into institutions run by high flyers. However, Seidman stressed requiring bank and thrift owners to risk more of their own capital as a way to reduce managers' temptation to take excessive risks. ``It seems appropriate that serious consideration should be given to phasing in higher capital requirements for banks,'' he said. Seidman's views are broadly consistent with those offered in recent weeks by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan. Both expressed reluctance to lower the current $100,000-per-account limit on deposit insurance, but commented favorably on strong capital standards. However, both Brady and Greenspan expressed interest in trying to limit deposit insurance to one account per person, a subject Seidman did not address in his prepared remarks. The Treasury Department is studying the deposit insurance system and is expected to offer recommendations for change by the end of the year. Meanwhile, lobbyist Robert J. Thompson said he would refuse to honor a subpoena from Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, for testimony before the Senate Judiciary antitrust committee today about his role in arranging the purchase of a failed S&L by Arizona insurance executive James M. Fail. Thompson, a former aide to then-Vice President George Bush, said in a two-hour interview with The Washington Post that he arranged meetings for Fail and his associates with various federal officials and was paid his regular fee, received backing for a $150,000 loan and was promised 2 percent of the profits on the deal. The paper quoted Thompson as calling the subcommittee hearing ``a rigged game'' and saying: ``Senator Metzenbaum is not interested in fair play or he truth about the Bluebonnet transaction. He is interested only in headlines.'' Thompson's lawyer, Stanley M. Brand, former chief counsel for the House of Representatives, said Thompson is refusing to comply with the subpoena because Metzenbaum's subcommittee is exceeding its jurisdiction by probing Thompson's personal and business finances and has violated his privacy by leaking confidential information to the news media. Metzenbaum has asked Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee to schedule a vote for Thursday on compelling Thompson to comply with the subcommittee subpoena. Separately, a senior Treasury Department official suggested Monday that Congress could avoid voting on a $100 billion savings and loan bailout for 1991 until next year by passing a stopgap bill for no more than $10 billion. The proposal, which would postpone action on the larger appropriation until after the November election, was raised by Treasury Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber.

DOC.HEAD: Interco, Creditors Agree on Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Interco Inc., which has been struggling to pay off its large junk-bond debt, has reached a basic restructuring agreement with its creditors, a company spokesman announced Tuesday. The deal between the footwear and furniture maker and its banks, medium term noteholders and subordinated debenture holders apparently will keep the company from going into bankruptcy. Although no details of the agreement were released Tuesday, the company did say it will not be required to make any principal or interest payments on its bonds until October as part of the agreement. The waiver of payments includes a $3.8 million interest payment that was due Monday and also allows Interco to make an $8.6 million interest payment that was due July 16 sometime before Aug. 15. ``As we have stated previously, Interco has four successful core companies. However, Interco's debt is much larger than these companies can support. We believe that the financial restructuring under discussion will alleviate the problems caused by Interco's excessive debt levels ...,'' said Richard Loynd, chairman and chief executive officer. Negotiations on the restructuring are continuing, Loynd said, and more details will be released soon. Interco, based in St. Louis, was a diversified manufacturer until 1988 when it was forced to borrow $1.65 billion to fend off a hostile takeover attempt. Since then, the company has been selling off subsidiaries in an attempt to repay its debts. It has retained four companies: Converse Inc., Florsheim shoes, Lane Co. and Broyhill Furniture Industries. However, Interco's debt repayment plan faltered when Interco subsidiaries brought far less than the company had anticipated and company officials began looking for ways to restructure its debts. In June, the company told subordinated debenture holders that it wouldn't be able to make a scheduled interst payment and instead asked bondholders to convert their bonds to common stock. Under that plan, which is still pending before the Securities Exchange Commission, the holders of Interco's senior subordinated debentures due in 2000 were asked to exchange $1,000 principle amount of those bonds for 70 shares of Interco common stock and $900 principle amount of a new issue of 6 percent accrual convertible debentures.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: London stock prices finished higher at the close of a quiet session Tuesaday. There was little company news to move the market, but prices moved higher from the opening on optimistic performances in markets abroad. At the closing bell, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-shares index was up 9.7 points, or 0.41 percent, at 2,326.2, The more narrowly based Financial Times 30-share index was up 6.4 points at 1,844.5. Volume registered 301.5 million shares compared with 341.7 million issues changing hands Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Government Report Says Japan Should Share More Technology
DOC.TEXT: The trade ministry said Tuesday the nation should begin sharing its technical prowess with the rest of the world, partly to help ease foreign trade friction. An advisory report released by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said Japan should sell more technology overseas and should welcome increased numbers of foreign researchers at government and private institutes. It said Japanese companies' voracious appetite for new technology causes the country to import more foreign technology than it exports in the form of patent royalties and proprietary rights, despite its growing technological prowess. ``It's time to look to see what are the root causes of trade irritation, and as a country which now produces 15 percent of the world's gross national product, to cope with them as quickly as possible,'' said Hidetoshi Nishimura, director of the ministry's Machinery and Information Industries Bureau. ``After attaining economic growth on the basis of technology imported from the West, it is time for Japan to export its technology to the rest of the world,'' he said. He said the ministry would try to encourage transfers of technology by creating ``favorable conditions,'' including tax credits, in a program being formulated. Private companies pay for about 80 percent of Japan's research and development, compared with less than 50 percent in the United States, and carefully guard their technology from rival businesses. This has led to questions about whether they would be willing to share their most advanced technology with foreign interests. Last year, Japanese companies were the top four recipients of patents in the United States and reportedly filed nearly half the patents in the world. In the 1960s and 1970s, before the development of extensive private Japanese research capabilities, the trade ministry played an important role in guiding Japanese research efforts for developing key technologies in areas such as computers and semiconductors. But as trade friction has intensified in recent years, especially with the United States, the ministry has begun pursuing a reversal of its export-first orientation. The report said Japan bought $439 million more technology from overseas in 1988 than it sold, while the United States sold $7.3 billion more than it acquired. The ratio of Japanese technology exports to imports has increased but remains at a deficit, Nishimura said. About 87,000 Japanese researchers were working aboard in other industrialized nations during 1988, while only about 9,000 researchers from those countries were in Japan, the report said. Nishimura said the growing costs of research in basic science also have increased the need for international cooperative research programs and for Japan, as a wealthy country, to take a stronger role. ``In the past, Western nations took a leading role in the exchange of research. Now is the time for Japan to do so,'' he said. The ministry is preparing budget requests for implementation of the report, which was prepared by a committee of academics and officials from companies such as Sony, Hitachi and Toyota, Nishimura said.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: First Phase of Phone Company Sale Planned By December
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to sell a 20.4 percent stake in the national telephone company by Dec. 20, the first stage in Mexico's largest privatization effort, newspapers reported Tuesday. The current value of Telefonos de Mexico shares is more than $8 billion About half of them are held by the government, which would give up control of the company with its sale of the 20.4 percent stake. The reports said the ministry of finance and the Banco Internacional, financial agent for the sale, said that while foreign investors could participate, control of the company would remain in Mexican hands. The daily newspaper El Financiero quoted officials as saying the government intended to sell 10.4 percent to Mexicans and 10 percent to foreign investors. The finance ministry said the overall price for the 20.4 percent stake would be between $1.4 billion and $1.8 billion. It said that within a year, the government would sell all of its shares, valued at more than $4 billion. El Financiero said foreign interest is coming from Telefonia Espanola, Bell Canada, Britain's Cable and Wireless, France Telephone and the former Bell System companies US West and Southwestern Bell in the United States. The reports said Banco Internacional plans to announce terms of the auction between Aug. 13 and Sept. 7 as well as principles for qualifying purchasers. They said the bank planned to make bids be due on Nov. 15 after a period for visits to Telmex facilities and questions by potential buyers and winning bidders would be notified and payment of guarantees arranged between Dec. 4 and Dec. 20. Banco Internacional said the sale would be designed to insure Mexican control, guarantee rights of workers and their participation in capital, improve service, encourage continued growth and strengthen technological investment.

DOC.HEAD: New Director Named For European Rocket Program
DOC.TEXT: Arianespace named Director-General Charles Bigot to the post of president on Tuesday, replacing Frederic d'Allest as head of Europe's successful commercial satellite launch program. D'Allest announced his retirement last Wednesday after an Ariane rocket placed West German and French television satellites into orbit. It marked the 37th Ariane mission and the first since Feb. 22, when a rocket carrying two Japanese satellites exploded shortly after liftoff above the Ariane launchpad at Kourou, French Guiana. ``It's a great responsibility vis-a-vis the international community of space users, almost all of whom are our clients,'' said Bigot in accepting the promotion from the Arianespace board of directors. Bigot, 58, had served in the consortium's second highest post since 1982. He and d'Allest won more than half the world's lucrative satellite launch business for Ariane's unmanned rockets. A graduate of the Ecole Polytechnique, Bigot worked as a research chief on rocket engines at the National Center of Space Studies on the first French civil rocket, the Diamant-B. He headed the development department of the domestic airline Air Inter from 1971-75 and served as the commercial director at Aerospatiale before coming to Arianespace eight years ago. D'Allest had led Arianspace since its creation in 1980 as the commercial partner of the European Space Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Trading Halted on Five Commodity Exchanges
DOC.TEXT: Trading on New York's five commodity exchanges was halted four times Tuesday with the longest outage about 40 minutes because of a data transmission problem, officials said. An American Telephone & Telegraph Co. spokswoman said a wire problem at AT&T's central office in Manhattan prevented data from being disseminated to customers off the trading floor. Trading was halted at the Commodity Exchange, the nation's main metals market; the New York Mercantile Exchange, the main oil trading market; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; the Cotton Exchange; and the New York Futures Exchange. Action first came to a standstill at 11:03 a.m. EDT, when the exchanges discovered that no price quotes were leaving the building, and resumed at 11:42 a.m. Trading was halted again at 11:52 a.m. and resumed seven minutes later. Two more stoppages, lasting one minute and two minutes, occurred within the next half hour, said a Commodity Exchange official who asked not to be named. ``We're investigating why it happened,'' AT&T spokeswoman Carol Alrbight said. The five exchanges share a trading floor in the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan. Trading information was not interrupted within the building, officials said. The glitch affected futures wires but not options wires, the Comex official said, though trading in all products at the exchanges were interrupted. Officials said the stoppage and trading resumption was orderly. In April, the five New York futures and options markets shut down about four hours early after a communications glitch prevented thousands of traders, brokers and investors from receiving price data.

DOC.HEAD: White House Threatens Veto of Junk Mail Legislation
DOC.TEXT: The White House today threatened to veto legislation making its way through Congress aimed at curbing ``junk mail'' on fax machines and telephone-answering devices. White House deputy press secretary Alixe Glen said the measure was unnecessary. ``The number of complaints are small and there are already systems and infrastructures in place to deal'' with the problem, she said. By voice vote, the House approved legislation Monday to authorize the Federal Communications Commission to set up a national clearinghouse for listing telephone subscribers who object to the endless faxes and unsolicited messages. The Senate has not yet acted on the bill. ``This legislation empowers consumers and businesses with the ability to `just say no' to unsolicited telephone advertisements,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on telecommunications and finance. Under the bill, the FCC also would establish penalties for advertisers who fail to abide by the clearinghouse list. Solicitations by charitable and political organizations would be exempt from the ban. Consumers, either private individuals or businesses, could specify that they do not wish to receive advertising by fax machines or automatically dialed, prerecorded telephone solicitations. The legislation was crafted with help from the FCC, the telephone industry and the direct marketing industry, Markey said.

DOC.HEAD: EC Commission Allows British Steel, Usinor-Sacilor To Grow
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Commission said Tuesday it cleared the way for the trade bloc's two largest steel producers, France's Usinor-Sacilor SA and British Steel PLC, to expand into specialist markets. The Commission said in a statement Usinor-Sacilor's Sollac unit can purchase Societe des Forges de Basse-Indre and CMB Acier from their parent company, Anglo-French packaging specialist CMB SA. It would make Sollac the largest EC producer of tin plate. The Commission said that in 1988 Sollac made 685,000 tons of tin plate for the packaging industry. CMB Acier made 323,000 tons. It did not say how much of the tin plate market Sollac would now command, but in 1988 Sollac made 23.1 percent of tin plate in the Community. In allowing the acquisition, the Commission noted the growing competition from aluminum, paper, plastic and glass makers in the packaging industry. The Commission also said British Steel could acquire ``certain assets and debts'' of Klockner Stahl GmbH of West Germany, raising its share of the EC market to 24 percent from 22 percent. In other decisions on the steel sector Tuesday the Commission approved a joint venture between Belgian steel maker Arbed SA and Preussag Salzgitter AG of West Germany. Although Arbed and Preussag make about 23 percent of reinforced steel in the EC, they only control between 0.5 percent and 2.2 percent of the British market, where they plan to set up their joint venture. AP Steel UK Ltd. will sell the two companies reinforced steel products in Britain. The Commission said the two steel makers would not be able to create an ``artificially privileged'' position for the new company in Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Leader Says Settlement Near on Golf Course Dispute
Precede BURBANK, Calif.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with civil rights leader saying settlement near. ADDS abyline. No pickup. Should stand for PMs. Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: A civil rights leader indicated today that an agreement was near that would lead him to call off protests during next week's PGA Championship at a heretofore all-white country club. The Rev. Abraham Woods, Birmingham president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said, ``it seems as if we may be able to put this thing behind us.'' Woods said an announcement on the matter would be made later in the day and that a Shoal Creek country club representative would attend. Woods had threatened to lead protests during the Aug. 9-12 PGA stop because the founder of the all-white Shoal Creek club, Hall Thompson, said last month that the private club south of Birmingham would not be pressured into accepting black members. Thompson later apologized, saying his remark had been taken out of context, and the city's black mayor and others have been working behind the scenes for days to try to defuse the issue. His office had no immediate comment today on the report of a possible settlement. Woods said in a telephone interview that he was asking that Shoal Creek immediately take in the mayor, Richard Arrington, who is black, as an honorary member ``with all rights and privileges,'' and start the process of accepting two other Birmingham blacks who have said they wanted to join as regular members. ``We are hopeful that their response will be such that they will accept it and we can put this thing behind us,'' he said. The Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Atlanta-based SCLC, was to attend the news conference in City Hill along with Arrington; Jim Awtrey, executive director of the PGA; and an unnamed Shoal Creek official, Woods said. An honorary membership for Arrington and a start on accepting the two others ``would be practical steps,'' Woods said. ``We're not fishing for policy steps on paper. Mayor Arrington as an honorary member would break the color barrier. Then they can start the process on other blacks and we can let the process run its course.'' It takes about six months for a proposed member to be accepted by Shoal Creek on an expedited basis. Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Lee Trevino, who won the 1984 PGA at Shoal Creek, said he has decided to take part in this year's tournament after saying last week he was having second thoughts about it. ``He is planning on being there,'' Judy Pierre of Lee Trevino Enterprises said today from Dallas. On Monday, the NBC-owned TV station for Los Angeles had joined the protest, saying it would not show highlights of the championship. And Spalding Sports Worldwide, the nation's largest golf ball manufacturer, said it was pulling its ads, as several other companies did last week. Burbank, Calif.-based KNBC, the network's second-largest affiliate, would report only the results of the tournament, said the station's sports director, Fred Roggin. ``We're not trying to ignore the golfers or the fans of golf,'' said Jeff Hoffman, a sports producer at KNBC. ``Our stance is directed at the course. We're not interested in publicizing or showing the course on our station.'' The tournament will be televised on ABC and on ESPN, the cable sports network.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 7.7 Percent Profit Increase in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Borden Inc. said Tuesday its profit rose 7.7 percent in the second quarter despite a sharp decline in results from its dairy business. The company's other division, which are grocery and specialty products, snacks and international consumer products and packaging and industrial products, each posted higher operating results for the period. Borden said it earned $90.4 million, or 61 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $83.9 million, or 57 cents a share, a year ago. Second-quarter revenue rose 0.7 percent to $1.90 billion from $1.89 billion a year earlier. The company said operating income fell 35 percent in its dairy division as Borden continued to withdraw from the depressed fluid milk markets and to reconfigure production in its remaining regional markets. By the end of the quarter, it had closed or sold 12 dairy plants and was working on the sale of six others. But operating income rose 17.2 percent in the grocery products division, which includes brands such as Prince pasta, Borden cheeses, Wyler's bouillon and Mrs. Grass dry soup mixes, and 18.4 percent in snacks which include Wise Foods and Moore's snacks. Operating income also rose 7.7 percent in the packaging and industrial products business. For the first half, Borden said it earned $153.5 million, or $1.04 per share, up 7.4 percent from $143.0 million, or 97 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.4 percent to $3.8 billion from $3.71 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Profits Up on Strong Sale of Bananas
DOC.TEXT: Chiquita Brands International on Tuesday said second-quarter earnings increased to $46.4 million compared with $43.9 million a year ago, due to the company's fresh foods operations. Per share earnings increased to $1.10 from $1.08, while sales for the quarter ending June 30 were $1.1 billion, up from $1 billion a year ago. The company attributed the sales and earnings increases to favorable pricing and volume in its fresh foods operations, primarily the sale of bananas in Europe. Chiquita, which exports 50 million cases of bananas a year from Honduras, or about two-thirds of that nation's banana crop, announced a settlement Monday in a month-long strike by 10,000 banana workers. Chiquita said it agreed to a 25.4 percent raise in the basic wage for workers, increasing their wages by $62.50 to $308.50 a month. The earnings announcement by Chiquita said profits for the first half of the year were $89.3 million, or $2.12 a share, compared with $53.6 million, or $1.32 a share, during the first half of 1989. Sales were $2.2 billion, compared with $1.9 billion. President Keith E. Lindner said although the company usually earns 85 percent of its annual profits in the first half of the year, first-half profits already have exceeded the projections for the entire year.

DOC.HEAD: Interco, Creditors Agree on Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Interco Inc., the manufacturing firm that nearly destroyed itself by using junk bonds to fend off a hostile takeover attempt, apparently has solved its nagging debt woes. The company, which owns Converse and Florsheim footwear companies along with furniture manufacturers Lane Co. and Broyhill Industries, announced a basic restructuring agreement with its creditors Tuesday. The deal between the St. Louis-based company and its banks, medium-term noteholders and subordinated debenture holders apparently will keep the company from entering bankruptcy proceedings. It was reached after four days of marathon meetings in New York involving 50 to 60 people representing the various creditors. ``We all felt that Interco was basically a very sound operation that had the terrible misfortune of getting trapped with a terrible balance sheet,'' said Wilbur Ross, senior managing director of Rothschild Inc., which served as chief negotiator for subordinated debenture holders. ``This was a situation that deserved a peaceful ending rather than a contentious one.'' The agreement involves restructuring about $1.9 billion in bank loans, bonds and other corporate notes. Interco took on $1.65 billion in debt in 1988 in an effort to protect itself from a takeover attempt by corporate raiders Steven and Michael Rales of Washington. At the time, the company made men's and women's apparel, operated 201 retail stores such as do-it-yourself hardware stores and discount clothing stores, and owned footwear and furniture companies. To pay off its debt, the company announced plans to sell off all of its companies except the four it currently operates. However, the plan faltered when Interco subsidiaries brought far less than the company had anticipated. That, coupled with the junk-bond market collapse, left the company with more debt than it started with. Company officials were forced to look for another solution. Although no details of the restructuring agreement were released Tuesday, the company did say it will not be required to make any principal or interest payments on its bonds until October. The waiver of payments includes a $3.8 million interest payment that was due Monday and also allows Interco to make an $8.6 million interest payment that was due July 16 sometime before Aug. 15. ``As we have stated previously, Interco has four successful core companies. However, Interco's debt is much larger than these companies can support. We believe that the financial restructuring under discussion will alleviate the problems caused by Interco's excessive debt levels,'' said Richard Loynd, chairman and chief executive officer. Additional details will be released after the various parties review and approve the basic agreement, Interco officials said. ``We're now putting everything on paper and making sure that everything that we put down is actually what we agreed to,'' Ross said. ``But the main accomplishment is that we've reached an agreement that will put the company in a very good position to move forward.'' Ross said Tuesday's agreement will include general provisions of a proposal made by the company in June that asked bondholders to accept common stock in exchange for their bonds.

Prices were narrowly mixed in uncertain trading on Wall Street today as the stock market remained apprehensive about the future of the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average, which reversed course several times through the day, was down 1.98 to 2,915.35 as of 3 p.m. EDT. Advancing issues held a margin of 8 to 7 over decliners, with 781 stocks rising, 696 falling and 486 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 137.71 million shares with an hour of trading left. Analysts said the market was playing it safe with several big economic reports due out this week. The government was announcing its index of leading economic indicators on Wednesday. The National Association of Purchasing Management was also releasing its monthly survey on the manfacturing economy Wednesday. Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co., said many investors stayed out of market because of growing concern that the country might be heading into a recession. ``When in doubt, do nothing'' was the attitude on Wall Street, Metz said. UAL, which fell more than 6 points Monday amid signs its latest employee buyout plan was in trouble, plunged another 16~ to 140. Oil stocks were one of the bright spots, benefiting from a rise in crude prices. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate oil was up 49 cents to $20.70 a barrel in late afternoon. Atlantic Richfield rose 2\ to 130, Chevron gained 1{ to 79|, Exxon was up 1 to 51}, and Texaco was up 1[ at 64. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was up 0.33 to 194.51. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 0.46 to 353.19.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, Fiat In Agricultural Joint Venture
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Fiat Group, Italy's largest industrial company, and Ford Motor Co. formed a joint venture Tuesday to merge their agricultural subsidiaries into a new company controlled by Fiat. The move further's Ford's goal of ridding itself of its non-automotive operations. Last week, Ford announced it was entering final negotiations with the Loral Corp. of New York over the sale of Ford Aerospace Corp. In the agreement announced Tuesday, which must be approved by the Italian and U.S. governments, FiatGeotech would merge with Ford New Holland. Ford would receive an undisclosed amount of cash and own 20 percent of the joint venture, while FiatGeotech would own the other 80 percent. ``Our primary objective in creating this new company is to profit from the existing strengths of the two subsidiaries,'' said Cesare Romiti, Fiat's president and chief executive officer. ``We recognize that these two organizations, when combined, will complement each other remarkably well with a truly global presence in virtually every world market.'' The two parent companies have been involved in negotiations over the agricultural operations merger for months. The subsidiaries make agricultural implements, such as tractors and combines. FiatGeotech has more than 13,000 employees in Italy, Brazil, France and the United States, and reported 1989 revenues of $2.3 billion. Ford New Holland has about 18,000 workers in plants and offices in the United States, Canada, Great Britain, Belgium and Brazil, and collected $2.8 billion in revenues last year. The parent companies said Fiat would continue current pay and benefits for Ford New Holland employees, who are covered by contracts negotiated by the United Auto Workers union. The companies also said the subsidiaries' worldwide markets and identities would be preserved in the joint venture. The Ford-Fiat deal is the first overseas venture announced by Ford since the U.S. automaker bought the British luxury carmaker Jaguar PLC late last year for $2.5 billion. So far this year, General Motors Corp. has announced deals in Hungary, East Germany and the Soviet Union. Chrysler Corp. has linked up with an Austrian company in a minivan program. Ford has said it is discussing with Fiat a deal separate from Tuesday's joint venture that would involve the two companies' heavy truck businesses. There has been speculation in Italy and the United States that Fiat may be talking with Chrysler Corp. about Fiat possibly buying a stake in the financially struggling U.S. automaker. Officials from Fiat and Chrysler have declined to comment on the speculation.

DOC.HEAD: Second-Quarter Profit Falls at USX, Wheeling-Pittsburgh
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. said Tuesday its second-quarter profit fell 15 percent, while another steel maker, Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp., reported a 33 percent drop in earnings for the same period. Pittsburgh-based USX cited reduced steel earnings and a loss on the sale of Texas Oil & Gas Corp. assets. Wheeling-Pittsburgh, based Wheeling, W. Va., and operating under federal bankruptcy protection, said reduced shipments and a market glut contributed to its profit decline.
DOC.HEAD: USX Corp.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest steel maker said its net income totaled $212 million, or 81 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with $250 million, or 91 cents per share, a year earlier. Sales fell 8 percent to $4.63 billion from $5 billion, USX said. The current quarter included special pre-tax charges totaling $99 million, in part to cover the loss from the sale of three Texas Oil & Gas packages the company expects to sell by the end of September. The charges also included the cost of a proxy solicitation on investor Carl Icahn's bid to spin off the company's steel division. The proposal was defeated by shareholders. Operating income fell nearly 12 percent to $400 million from $452 million in the quarter. Nonetheless, USX Chairman Charles A. Corry said ``operating income has maintained the pace of 1989's record earnings, excluding last year's special items and operating profits from businesses sold.'' ``The long-term outlook for both energy and steel continues to improve,'' he said. The steel segment reported operating income fell 53 percent to $80 million from $171 million. Sales fell to $1.4 billion from $1.6 billion. The steel decline was due to lower steel prices and the absence of operating income due to the sale of the Lorain, Ohio, works to a 50 percent owned joint venture in the second quarter of 1989, the company said. The company's energy segment reported operating income increased 17 percent to $285 million in the second quarter from $244 million in the year-ago period. For the first half of the year, USX said net income fell 29 percent to $388 million, or $1.48 per share, compared with $546 million, or $2 per share. First-half revenue dipped to $9.32 billion from $9.42 billion a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Wheeling-Pittsburgh
DOC.TEXT: Wheeling-Pittsburgh said its net income totaled $38.5 million, or $7.04 per share, for the three months ended June 30 compared with $57.5 million, or $10.76 per share, a year earlier. Sales for the second quarter were $287.1 million on shipments of 575,271 tons, compared with sales of $301.1 million on shipments of 591,657 tons in the year-ago quarter. Operating income fell 31 percent to $33.3 million from $48.4 million in the quarter, the steelmaker said. ``We were down in our shipments and our price is softer,'' said company spokesman Ray Johnson. ``The market isn't as good as it was a year ago.'' For January-June 1990, net income was $74.1 million, or $13.52 per share, down 28 percent from $103.3 million, or $19.25 per share, in the year-ago period, the company said. Sales for the first six months were $544 million on shipments of 1.08 million tons compared with sales of $588.6 million on shipments of 1.17 million tons a year earlier. Wheeling-Pittsburgh filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors in April 1985. The negotiating committee for 5,500 United Steelworkers union members has said it would ask union chief Lynn R. Williams to authorize a strike Aug. 16. The USW members are making steel under a concessionary contract they accepted after a three-month strike in 1985. The accord expires 10 days after a reorganization plan is confirmed. The Wheeling-based company employs 5,500 union and 1,600 non-union workers in western Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio.

Stock prices fell sharply in the last half-hour of trading today as pessimism over the planned employee buyout of UAL Corp. undermined other stocks. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 24.26 at 2,893.07.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Firm Buys Famous Toy Store Chain
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A prestigious Dutch retailer on Tuesday announced it is buying FAO Schwarz, a venerable old American toy store chain known to generations of shoppers as the ultimate place to browse for playthings. The U.S. subsidiary of NV Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer (KBB) will acquire the 17 stores operated by FAO Schwarz as well as its catalog business for an unannounced price. Officials disclosed few details of the deal with FAO Schwarz's present owners, an investment group that includes the chain's two highest ranking executives. The acquisition will give KBB an entry into American retailing and provide the Dutch company with a springboard from which to expand in the United States. ``FAO Schwarz is the pre-eminent retailer of fine toys in the world and we are committed to building on FAO's tradition of excellence,'' Arie Maas, chairman of KBB, said in a news release. Peter L. Harris, president and chief executive officer of FAO Schwarz, said in an interview that he foresees the chain moving into Europe and Japan after the acquisition. Harris said he and his management team will continue in their current roles. But Chairman Peter C. Morse, who along with Harris led the investment group that bought FAO Schwarz in 1986, is leaving. The New York-based toy store company, which was founded in 1862, was family owned for about its first 100 years. After a succession of corporate owners, it was bought by Swiss retailer Franz Carl Weber in the late 1970s. Although its reputation didn't suffer much among casual customers, FAO Schwarz lost some of its luster in the early '80s, analysts say. Harris said annual sales were below $20 million when the investment group bought it in the mid-1980s. He said the chain's sales are expected to exceed $50 million this year. Analysts credit the current management with restoring FAO Schwarz's stature within the industry and say the chain again is highly regarded for innovative merchandising. FAO Schwarz has managed to prosper in a difficult retailing environment by emphasizing service and taking a creative approach to displaying merchandise, Harris said. The merchandise itself, such as an eight-foot stuffed giraffe that sells for $4,500, also sets the store apart from other toy retailers. FAO Schwarz operates two big stores, one in New York and the other in San Francisco. The store on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue is a major tourist attraction. Much smaller branches are located in urban settings, including Boston, Chicago and Palm Beach, Fla., as well as in suburban malls. A new store opened recently in Beverly Hills, Calif., and openings are planned for later this year in Denver and Short Hills, N.J. Harris said FAO Schwarz soon will announce plans for a much larger store in Chicago, on a scale with the flagships in New York and San Francisco. He said the company is in lease negotiations for a bigger store in Boston as well. KBB has more than a dozen department store chains, including one that specializes in elaborate toys like those sold by FAO Schwarz. That chain, the Bijenkorf chain, is at the luxury end of its operations, selling exclusive fashions, cosmetics and furniture as well as toys. Its flagship store is a landmark in the center of Amsterdam, right across the street from the city's royal palace. In recent years, the Bijenkorf _ beehive in Dutch _ has diversified into fancy foods and established one of the Netherlands' largest specialty cosmetics departments. KBB also owns the low-priced HEMA chain known for its serviceable household goods and clothing on the model of an American variety store. All together, the holdings of the $2.2 billion retailer in its home country and elsewhere in Europe included 1,200 stores at the end of last year.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Mix
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to reflect official Dow Jones revision; ADDS overline.
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed mixed on Wall Street today amid continued apprehension about the economy and pessimism about takeover stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average fluctuated in a narrow range for much of the day as investors traded cautiously in advance of several big economic reports due out this week. But in the last half-hour of trading, stocks took a sharp dive, with the Dow Jones average dropping nearly 39 points, as computer-program traders began to sell heavily. The average recovered some ground, but closed down 12.13 at 2,905.20. A steep decline in the price of UAL Corp. stock set off the drop. The trade publication American Banker said today that Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp. representatives did not attend a meeting Friday on possible bank financing for the planned $4.38 billion employee buyout of the parent of United Airlines. The report cast doubt on the viability of the deal. Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co., said many investors stayed out of market because of growing concern that the country might be heading into a recession. ``When in doubt, do nothing'' was the attitude on Wall Street, Metz said. The government was announcing its index of leading economic indicators on Wednesday, the same day that the National Association of Purchasing Management was releasing its monthly survey on the manfacturing economy.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Ministers Express Reservations About Aid Cut Proposal
DOC.TEXT: NEWMARKET-ON-FERGUS, Ireland (AP) _ The world's leading agriculture ministers Tuesday expressed reservations about a surprise European proposal to cut farm aid worldwide but said it was a step forward. The European Community's agriculture commissioner, Ray MacSharry of Ireland, on Monday proposed cutting world farm aid by 30 percent over a decade, intensifying the debate over Europe's huge farm subsidies. The dispute over Europe's support for its farmers will not, as feared, block the successful conclusion in December of current global trade liberalization talks, the senior officials said. MacSharry and the agriculture ministers of the United States, Japan, Canada and Australia made their comments at a news conference at the conclusion of a two-day private meeting. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said the proposal is ``only a start in the negotiating process.'' ``Much of the rest of the world is in my judgment prepared to go much further down the road of agricultural trade reform than what is implied by Mr. MacSharry's proposal,'' he said. ``We have a lot of negotiating ahead to bridge those gaps.'' Canada's agriculture minister, Donald Mazankowski, said: ``It's certainly a welcome step.'' But he added: ``It is very difficult to determine in fact whether export subsidies will be cut (under the proposal) at all.'' Trade negotiations are being held in Geneva under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The United States and 14 other farm exporting countries want the 12-nation EC to end its export credits system and cut direct subsidies for farmers, which the critics say distort trade. MacSharry said his proposal was serious and balanced but conceded that ``We have a number of important differences. These remain to be resolved.'' Mazankowski told reporters earlier that the United States and Canada already may have implemented cuts such as those proposed. MacSharry's proposed 30 percent cut in farm support extends from 1986 to 1996. It includes already implemented EC reductions of 10 percent in support for crops and 15 percent for livestock. A final proposal is to be presented in September to the European Community, which must approve the plan before it could be tabled at GATT. GATT negotiators are to meet again in Geneva in late August. They agreed at a meeting last week to compile lists and costs of their farm support by Oct. 1. The agriculture ministers meeting was held at Dromoland Castle near Shannon in western Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Procter & Gamble Sues Again Over Satanism Allegation
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble Co. said Tuesday it had sued a southeast Kansas couple for allegedly spreading rumors _ which it has denied for years _ that the company was associated with satanism. The suit filed late Monday in U.S. District Court, alleges that James and Linda Newton of Parsons have made libelous and malicious statements about Procter & Gamble by saying it supports ``the church of Satan.'' The couple also allegedly urged people to boycott Procter & Gamble products. A company news release said the Newtons are distributors of household items for rival Amway Home Products, ``as were several individuals who previously admitted spreading these lies.'' ``It appears they are trying to enhance their own business,'' said Topeka attorney Edwin Smith, representing Procter & Gamble. The company is seeking more than $50,000 in damages, and is asking the court to order the Newtons to stop circulating the stories. Mrs. Newton, reached at her home, declined to comment. The suit is one of a number the Cincinnati-based company has filed over the years in an attempt to fight persistent rumors that its ``moon and stars'' trademark is a satanic symbol. The 108-year-old trademark features a man-in-the-moon figure, a popular design of the 1800s, overlooking a field of 13 stars the company says are to honor the original American colonies. ``We're very proud of our company trademark symbolizing Procter & Gamble quality and excellence,'' Edwin L. Artzt, chairman and chief executive officer, said in a news release. ``These lies have persisted now for 10 years, and we will file further suits if necessary,'' he said. The suit alleges that in a circular, the Newtons said the moon and stars trademark is a satanic symbol. They said the symbol is actually a ``tiny ram's horn with three sets of stars placed in such a way that if the stars in each set are joined they form the number 666, known as the devil's number.'' ``Christians should always remember that if they buy any product with this symbol they will be taking part in the support of the Church of Satan,'' according to the flyer, which was included in the suit as an exhibit. The suit also alleges the Newtons have falsely told people that senior Procter & Gamble officials have appeared on nationally televised talk shows acknowledging the company's ties to satanism. Over the past three months, the company has received 300 to 350 calls a day asking about the allegations, primarily from southeastern United States, company officials said. Procter & Gamble products include Pampers disposable diapers, Crest toothpaste, Scope mouthwash, Ivory soap, Tide laundry detergent, Folgers coffee and Head and Shoulders shampoo. In 1985, the company filed lawsuits in Lynchburg, Va., Scranton, Pa., and Wichita, Kan., against people it accused of spreading similar rumors associated the company with Satan. Procter & Gamble also at the time began phasing out the use of the trademark on company products, hired private investigators to probe the spread of the rumors and established a national toll-free telephone line to handle inquiries.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices strengthened in moderate trading Tuesday, while prices for wholesale unleaded gasoline and heating oil turned mixed. Traders said the markets were showing continued confidence the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will stick to last week's production-curbing accord. The cartel's 13 oil ministers, meeting in Geneva, agreed to raise their minimum reference price to $21 from $18 a barrel _ the first increase in four years. ``There's a lot of nervous energy out there,'' Brian Tagler, an oil trader with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said of the reaction to OPEC's agreement. ``That was one of the most bullish OPEC meetings.'' The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, settled at $20.69 a 42-gallon barrel Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up 48 cents from Monday. Other contract months also rose. In Monday trading the September contract was up 17 cents. WTI had traded as high as $20.77 a barrel Tuesday, but it couldn't maintain that level after trading was shut down for about 30 minutes due to technical problems with the computerized price-display system, according to traders. Helping strengthen crude prices, Tagler said, was a report of a 500,000-gallon oil spill into Galveston Bay in Texas. The spill occurred Saturday after a tanker collided with two barges in the Houston Ship Channel off the bay. In addition, Tagler said, the markets reacted bullishly to news of a threatend strike by oil maintenance workers in the North Sea. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, unleaded gasoline for August delivery settled down 0.28 cent to 65.60 cents a gallon, after gaining a penny on Monday. August home heating oil, which lost 0.04 cent Monday, gained 0.18 cent to settle at 57.11 cents a gallon. Dealers said trading in oil and gasoline was volatile since both August contracts were set to expire at the end of Tuesday's session. In natural gas trading, the September contract settled at $1.411 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.430 Monday. Later contracts also declined.

DOC.HEAD: Platinum Futures Surge on Japanese Buying
DOC.TEXT: Platinum futures prices surged more than $10 an ounce Tuesday amid a bevy of bullish factors, including signs of buying by the world's biggest platinum jewelry consumers _ the Japanese. On other commodity markets, other precious metals were mixed; energy futures rose; livestock and meat futures advanced; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Trading on New York's five commodity exchanges was halted four times during the day because of a data transmission problem. Trading was halted at the Commodity Exchange, the nation's main metals market; the New York Mercantile Exchange, the main oil trading market; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; the Cotton Exchange; and the New York Futures Exchange. Platinum futures settled $10.80 higher across the board on the New York Merc with the contract for delivery in October at $485.20 a troy ounce. The powerful rally did not extend to gold and silver futures, which are traded on the Commodity Exchange. Gold settled $2.20 to $2.60 higher with August at $370 a troy ounce; silver was 1.5 cents to 1.8 cents lower with August at $4.787 a troy ounce. The platinum market opened strongly on indications the Japanese bought platinum bullion overnight, analysts said. Platinum is the jewelry and investment metal of choice in Japan, making the Japanese key players in the market. ``We've seen a bit of lag on their part, but they came back today,'' said William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch. Strength in the oil market further supported the precious metals, analysts said. The dollar's weakness against other major currencies also was bullish for the metals, as were reports of renewed tension between Iraq and Kuwait. Analyst Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the potential for violence-related platinum supply disruptions from South Africa remained a bullish ``underlying factor.'' Gold rallied strongly at the opening but encountered strong resistance as the spot delivery price approached $375 an ounce. Silver futures were depressed by weak demand and plentiful supplies, analysts said. Crude oil for near-term delivery rose strongly on the New York Merc on reports that Iraq had amassed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border. Iraq has accused its small Persian Gulf neighbor of stealing oil from a disputed border region and causing oil prices to drop. After the close, the American Petroleum Institute released a weekly report that showed far more crude oil on hand than analysts had expected. The API reported a 2.9 million-barrel increase in U.S. crude stocks last week as opposed to expectations for a 2 million barrel decline. The API said gasoline supplies fell by 720,000 barrels against expectations for a 1 million barrel increase; distillate stocks rose 1.5 million barrels, which was near expectations. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 9 cents lower to 48 cents higher with September at $20.69 a barrel; heating oil was .05 cent to .50 cent higher with August at 57.11 cents gallon; unleaded gasoline was .28 cent lower to .76 cent higher with August at 65.60 cents a gallon. Strong cash markets gave cattle and pork futures a boost on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. All deliveries of frozen pork bellies rose the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound. Live cattle futures ended .35 cent to .75 cent higher with August at 78.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent to .65 cent higher with August at 89.82 cents a pound; live hogs were .42 cent to .95 cent higher with August at 61.22 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with August at 51.22 cents a pound. Soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade amid continuing signs of strength in the cash market. Wheat and corn futures fell. Wheat futures settled 3{ cents to 6 cents lower with September at $2.88\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent lower with September at $2.60\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents higher with September at $1.29{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 6{ cents higher with August at $5.94{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower; Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar extended its steep descent Tuesday against major foreign currencies in selling related to a weak U.S. economic outlook, which is expected to drive down domestic interest rates. It tumbled to a 2{-year low against the German mark in periodically hectic European trading. The mark has benefitted from the belief that German unification will foster faster economic growth there. Gold prices gained in world trading. Currency dealers said the dollar's decline accelerated when it slid below thresholds considered technically significant. It dropped to 1.5960 marks on the Frankfurt Foreign Exchange. That was the lowest fixing since Jan. 4, 1988, when the dollar was officially priced at 1.5816 marks. The dollar's record low at the Frankfurt fixing had come a few days earlier, on Dec. 31, 1987, when it was priced at 1.5815 marks. On Monday, the U.S. currency was officially priced at 1.6126 marks in Frankfurt. The dollar lost more ground in the United States and ended the day near its lowest levels. It was quoted at 1.58555 German marks late in New York, down from 1.6040 late Monday. Thomas Palladino, a vice president at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's office in New York, said speculation that the Federal Reserve will try to revive the flagging American economy by easing monetary policy has caused investors to dump dollars. A decline in U.S. interest rates while foreign rates remain steady or rise would make returns on dollar-denominated investments less attractive than foreign alternatives. This would curb demand for dollars. ``The trend for the dollar is still lower,'' Palladino said. Evidence of a severe slowdown in U.S. economic statistics due Wednesday and Friday could further depress the dollar. The U.S. index of leading economic indicators will be issued Wednesday and the June employment report is scheduled for release Friday. The dollar took a significant dive against the Japanese yen, falling to 145.835 yen late in New York from 147.83 late Monday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar declined to 147.50 Japanese yen from 148.60. In London late Tuesday, the dollar traded lower at 146.08 yen. British sterling continued to climb against the dollar. The pound rose to $1.8635 late in New York from $1.8465 late Monday. In London, one British pound cost $1.8595 lateTuesday, up from Monday's late $1.8440 and its best level since Dec. 6, 1988, when it stood at $1.8675. Britain's high 15 percent interest rate to counter inflation is the underlying reason for the pound's strength. Other dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.34475 Swiss francs, down from 1.3602; 5.3195 French francs, down from 5.3725; 1,162.00 Italian lire, down from 1,174.25; and 1.15165 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15245. Selected dollar rates late in Europe, compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.5875 German marks, down from 1.6085; 1.3475 Swiss francs, down from 1.3653; 5.3210 French francs, down from 5.3885; 1.7880 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8125; 1,162.00 Italian lire, down from 1,177.50; and 1.1530 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1523. The dollar's weakness encouraged gold buying. Gold for August delivery added $2.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York and settled at $370 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $370.20 for an ounce of gold bullion, up $2.50. In London, the late bid for a troy ounce of gold was $372.05, up from $367.25. The late bid in Zurich was $371.50, up from $367.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $369.15, up from $367.95. Silver for current delivery slipped to $4.787 a troy ounce on New York's Comex from $4.803 Monday. In London, silver traded late in London at a bid of $4.85 a troy ounce, up from $4.83.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Airline to Begin Service Wednesday Between Boston and Atlantic City
DOC.TEXT: The Trump Shuttle on Wednesday will become the second major carrier to fly into Atlantic City International Airport with daily roundtrips from Boston. The 65-minute flight into the city where Trump owns three casinos will be offered daily, leaving Boston at 8:10 a.m. and leaving Atlantic City at 9:20 p.m. One-way fares on the 163-seat plane are $110 and a roundtrip will cost $220, said Trump Shuttle spokeswoman Joan Fudula. She said it was too early to speculate if the service to Atlantic City would be extended to other cities, but added that company officials are considering Detroit as another possible route. Only 523,000 of Atlantic City's 32.1 million visitors come to the city by air. Atlantic City International Airport manager Steve Williams said the other major carrier to fly into Atlantic City International Airport is USAir.

DOC.HEAD: Companies Will Make Vacuums in Kentucky
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. said they formed a joint venture Tuesday to operate Whirlpool's 750-employee vacuum cleaner plant in Danville, Ky. In a signing ceremony at Whirlpool's Benton Harbor headquarters, the companies finalized a tentative agreement announced June 5 to form Matsushita Floor Care Co. Terms weren't disclosed. In its third-quarter earnings, Whirlpool will report a gain from sale of an interest in the plant to Matsushita, and will retain a significant minority interest, said spokeswoman Carol Sizer. Whirlpool manufactures canister, upright and central vacuum cleaners at the plant under the Kenmore name for Sears, Roebuck & Co., and the venture will continue that business. Matsushita imports Panasonic brand vacuum cleaners to the United States and is expected to use the venture to expand production and marketing of that brand. Matsushita is the world's leading maker of consumer and industrial electronics products, with production plants and sales offices in 38 countries and annual sales of nearly $38 billion. Whirlpool is the world's leading maker of major home appliances, manufacturing products in 10 countries and marketing them in more than 45. Whirlpool had 1989 revenues of $6.29 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Close Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street turned in its second straight mixed performance Tuesday as worries about the economy and the planned employee buyout of UAL Corp. bogged the market down. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 12.13 at 2,905.20 after fluctuating throughout the session and plunging nearly 39 points in the last half-hour of trading. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 817 up, 731 down and 455 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 173.81 million shares, up from 146.47 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 208.11 million shares. The market traded in a narrow range for much of the day as many investors, uneasy about the economy, either stayed on the sidelines or tread very lightly. With several big economic reports due out in the next few days, the axiom on Wall Street was, ``When in doubt, do nothing,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. The government was announcing its index of leading economic indicators on Wednesday, the same day that the National Association of Purchasing Management was releasing its monthly survey on the manfacturing economy. Uncertainty about the economy contributed to a mixed showing on Wall Street Monday. The market is still coping with the government's report last Friday that the gross national product grew at a paltry 1.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter. There was one particular sore spot throughout Tuesday's trading: UAL, which had fallen more than 6 points on Monday amid signs that the planned $4.38 billion employee buyout of the parent of United Airlines was in trouble. The outlook for the deal turned bleaker Tuesday when the trade publication American Banker said Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp. representatives did not attend a meeting Friday on possible bank financing for the deal. UAL plunged lower through the day and eventually closed down 16~ at 140. But late in the session, UAL's drop set off a wave of across-the-board selling that took the Dow Jones average to its low of the day. For a while, the market's reaction to UAL resembled Wall Street's plunge of last Oct. 13, which had been sparked by the failure of an earlier UAL buyout plan. But the market recovered Tuesday, and did not even approach the Dow Jones average's 190-point Friday the 13th slide. The bright spot of Tuesday's session was the oil sector, which was sharply higher throughout the day and kept the Dow Jones average from sinking further. Atlantic Richfield rose 1| to 129], Exxon picked up 1[ to close at 51~, and Pennzoil surged 1~ to 83{. The energy stocks rose, as they also had done Monday, on anticipation of higher oil prices. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate crude was up 48 cents to $20.69 a barrel. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $4.159 billion, or 0.12 percent, in value.
