The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.42 to 194.60. Standard & Poor's industrial index was up 0.37 to 420.60, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 0.60 to 356.15. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 1.14 to 438.24. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 353.60, down 0.05.

DOC.HEAD: Another Management Change At Trump Taj Mahal
DOC.TEXT: Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort named former Resorts International executive I.G. ``Jack'' Davis as president on Tuesday, the resort's third president since it opened April 2. Davis was named to replace Bucky Howard, who had replaced Walter Haybert during the Taj Mahal's first week of operations amid problems with the casino's 3,000 slot machines. ``Jack is one of the most experienced operators in this industry,'' said Ed Tracy, president of Donald Trump's three casino hotels and one non-casino hotel in Atlantic City. ``His leadership will prove invaluable.'' Davis, 65, was the chief executive officer of the neighboring Resorts International casino while construction developed at the Taj Mahal, then under Resorts' control. Trump obtained the Taj Mahal in November 1988 in a swap with entertainer Merv Griffin, who retained the Resorts International casino. ``I'm very happy to be back in Atlantic City,'' Davis said in a statement. ``The property has always been special to me.'' Since its April opening, the Taj Mahal has made between $1.1 million and $1.2 million a day in gross gaming revenue. Casino analysts said the casino needs to make about $1.3 million a day to meet obligations on the debt used to finance construction of the casino. The casino's performance has taken on increased significance because of Trump's financial problems. The developer in June reached a deal with his bank lenders to give up broad control of his holdings in return for a major debt restructuring to avoid a possible bankruptcy filing. Howard will return to his previous position as executive vice president of casino operations for Trump Taj Mahal. Haybert, after being replaced by Howard, became vice president of finance for the casino. He had become president last October after then-president Mark Etess died in a helicopter crash. The casino also announced Tuesday the appointment of Howard Klein as senior vice president of marketing. Davis became president of Resorts in 1960 when it was a small paint company. He saw the company through location of Atlantic City's first casino in 1978 and through the death of its founder, James Crosby, in 1986. He was fired last September from his $1 million-a-year job as a consultant to Resorts. Resorts now is attempting to reorganize under bankruptcy court protection from creditors. Davis will be the only one of Trump's three casino presidents who had prior experience in a similar post. Trump Plaza president Gary Selesner took that post April 27 from his executive vice president's job after former president Jack O'Donnell said he no longer wanted to work for Trump. Trump Castle president Anthony Calandra, who replaced Tracy in that post after Tracy was promoted to head of all Trump's Atlantic City holdings, was a marketing executive in the Trump Organization in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Drop 27 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third graf, Revenue edged ... year earlier, with one graf to give more precise numbers, CORRECT percentage increase. PICK UP fourth graf pvs, Second-quarter ...
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. reported on Tuesday a 27 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, blaming declines in its insurance business. For the second quarter, after-tax profit totaled $130 million, or $1.16 per share, compared with $179 million, or $1.67 per share, a year earlier. Revenue edged up about 3 percent to $4.52 billion from $4.38 billion a year earlier. Second-quarter revenue from insurance and other financial services was $1.2 billion, down 4 percent from $1.3 billion a year ago. Income from document processing, the company's core business, was $128 million in the second quarter, a 5 percent increase from the 1989 level of $123 million. Revenue increased 6 percent to $3.3 billion, from $3.1 billion in the second quarter of 1989. ``While demand for business equipment remained soft in the quarter, our revenue growth was supported by strong growth in our annuity streams from rental, service and financing of equipment sales,'' said Xerox President Paul A. Allaire. For the first six months of the year, Xerox said it lost $124 million, or $1.77 a share, in contrast to a profit of $337 million, or $3.14 per share, for the same 1989 period. The latest results reflected a $375 million after-tax provision from discontinued operations for a writedown involving its stake in VMS Realty Partners. Revenue in the first half totaled $8.8 billion, up 3 percent from $8.5 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Postpone Vote on Big S&L Bailout, Administration Hints
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-9: In a,'' Thompson to decline subpoena. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congress could avoid voting on a $100 billion savings and loan bailout for 1991 until next year by passing a stopgap bill for no more than $10 billion, a Bush administration official said Monday. The proposal, which would postpone action on the larger appropriation until after the November election, was raised by Treasury Undersecretary Robert R. Glauber. He told the House Banking Committee that $5 billion to $10 billion would keep the bailout going through January or February. He stopped short of endorsing the idea. The apparent trial balloon was floated as committee members noted angry voters are pressuring them to oppose more bailout funding. ``Perception is reality ... and it's the perception on the part of the American people _ `Give me a break, I'm not paying,''' said Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio. In another development, lobbyist Robert J. Thompson said he would refuse to honor a subpoena from Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, for testimony before the Senate Judiciary antitrust committee on Tuesday about his role in arranging the purchase of a failed S&L by Arizona insurance executive James M. Fail. Thompson, a former aide to then-Vice President George Bush, said in an interview with The Washington Post he arranged meetings for Fail with Washington officials and was paid his regular fee, won arrangement of a $150,000 loan and was promised 2 percent of the profits on the deal. Fail's S&L, now the Bluebonnet Bank of Dallas, stands to receive $1.8 billion in federal subsidies. Fail put up only $1,000 of his own money. According to the interview report in Tuesday editions of the newspaper, Fail said Metzenbaum's committee was exceeding its jurisdiction. Rep. Toby Roth, R-Wis., predicted Congress would refuse to go along with more money for the S&L bailout. The administration is not disputing regulators' estimates that as much as $100 billion in new bailout money is needed for all of 1991. Glauber said that under the stopgap plan Congress and the administration would have to agree to exploit an error in last year's bailout bill that would allow $18.8 billion more in bailout borrowing than Congress originally intended. The S&L bailout is an important issue in budget summit talks between the White House and congressional leaders, who are trying to fashion a package before Congress leaves Washington in October to campaign. The stopgap plan would let Congress and the administration postpone until next year long-term funding for the Resolution Trust Corp. (RTC), a year-old agency created to close and sell failed thrifts, along with a proposal to reform the deposit insurance system. Glauber also repeated two previous alternatives: giving the administration unlimited authority to spend whatever is needed to finish the bailout or providing what is needed for 1991. RTC Chairman L. William Seidman told the panel his agency would need to spend $80 billion to $100 billion in fiscal year 1991, including $30 billion to $40 billion from taxpayers to cover S&L losses. That's in addition to the $50 billion authorized in the 1989 bailout bill. The trust corporation would need to borrow another $50 billion to $60 billion, which would be repaid as the government sells real estate and other assets inherited from failed thrifts. Another installment on the bailout will be needed in 1992, Seidman said. ``Eighteen months from now, we will have a good hold on the overall look of things, but this is a moving target,'' he said. By the end of September, the RTC will have spent $97 billion _ $37 billion to cover losses and the rest to pay for S&L assets which will be sold, he said. The agency will need more money early in the October-December quarter, he said. Glauber, in response to a question from Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, the committee chairman, refused to say how much the administration wanted appropriated for S&Ls in 1991. He warned that failure to act could erode depositor confidence and push up the ultimate cost of the bailout by keeping money-losing institutions open. ``We've got to press this to the end and it's going to cost what it will cost,'' he said. On another subject, Seidman said weak real estate markets, once a problem only in certain regions such as the Southwest and New England, have spread to almost every area of the country. He said the fund insuring commercial bank deposits was ``under stress.'' But, he added, ``I do not think it's appropriate to say there is another S&L debacle ahead for banks.'' Seidman said the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. he also heads will decide ``in the reasonably near future'' whether to sue Neil Bush and other officers of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver. Bush, one of President Bush's sons, and other Silverado officers could be found liable for a portion of the $1 billion loss taxpayers suffered in the institution's December 1988 collapse.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Giant Buys Technology From Startup Laptop Company
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. said Tuesday it has agreed to buy technology from Outbound Systems, a small startup company that has made a Macintosh-compatible laptop computer. The agreement allows Outbound Systems, based in Boulder, Colo., to offer its products without violating Apple's intellectual property rights, Apple said. Specific details of the agreement were not disclosed. Apple, the world's second-largest personal computer maker, is expected to use the technology to produce its own lightweight portable computer next year, unidentified company sources told the San Francisco Chronicle. Macintosh fans hoped Apple would introduce a laptop last fall and were disappointed when the company introduced a 16-pound Macintosh Portable in October. The portable has been one of Apple's least successful products, and Apple cut the price in May in an attempt to boost sales. Outbound Systems introduced its nine-pound laptop computer in March despite concerns that Apple might sue the company for allegedly copying Macintosh technology. Outbound Systems began negotiations with Apple in an attempt to obtain a license to Macintosh technology or agree on a way to alter its computer system so it would not violate Apple's patents and copyrights.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler 2nd Quarter Profits Down 47.2 Percent; Big Three's Off 42.2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, The figures... to UPDATE with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp.'s second-quarter earnings dropped 47.2 percent compared with last year as incentives absorbed a huge chunk of profits, the automaker said Tuesday. The results, when combined with earnings reported last Thursday by General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., showed profits for the Big Three tumbled 42.2 percent in the April-June quarter this year compared with the same period last year. The figures were generally in line with what Wall Street analysts had predicted. Chrysler's stock closed unchanged at $15.12{ a share. Chrysler, like GM and Ford, blamed incentive costs during the quarter for dragging down earnings. The effects of the incentives were more noticeable at Chrysler than at Ford or GM. ``If not for the huge year-to-year increase in per-unit incentive costs,'' Chairman Lee Iacocca said, ``we would have made more money this quarter than we did in the second quarter of 1989.'' Iacocca and analysts said the company's cost-cutting program, designed to carve $1.5 billion out of $26 billion in annual costs by the end of this year, contributed to the company's profits. Chrysler said it earned $180 million, or 81 cents a share, during the quarter this year, compared with $341 million, or $1.46 a share, during the same period last year. Revenues fell to $8.8 billion from $9.9 billion. Chrysler declined to say precisely what its incentive costs were, but spokesman Tom Houston said they were more than $1,000 per vehicle during the second quarter. Auto analyst Douglas Laughlin of Bear, Stearns & Co. of New York estimated that Chrysler spent about $1,400 on incentives per vehicle. That's up sharply from his estimate of about $800 per vehicle during the same period last year. Analysts have said and Chrysler has acknowledged that the company may show a loss in the third quarter as it stops production at its two minivan plants for retooling for the 1991 model year. Minivans are among Chrysler's most profitable products. Laughlin said Chrysler will increase its cost savings by putting more efficient manufacturing methods into operation for the '91 models. Ford Vice President and Treasurer David McCammon said last week that his company spent about $1,050 on incentives for each car and truck sold during the period. GM, like Chrysler, declines to say how much it spends on incentives. Ford said it made $770.7 million in the second quarter, down 45 percent from last year, while GM reported second-quarter earnings fell 40 percent to $900.1 million. GM and Ford also blamed economic instability in Brazil for cutting their profits, and Ford added that lingering effects of strikes in the United Kingdom and Belgium further dented earnings. The auto industry has been in a slump since the fourth quarter of last year, when vehicle sales took a dive and inventories of unsold vehicles rose sharply. To get rid of the inventory, automakers boosted their incentive programs during the first quarter. The tactic worked, but the companies are finding it tough to wean consumers from the cash-back or low-interest financing deals. For the first half of the year, Chrysler said earnings were down 63.7 percent to $251 million. Ford's first-half earnings were down 56.7 percent to $1.4 billion and GM's were off 46.5 percent to $1.6 billion. Combined, the Big Three earned $3.1 billion in the first six months, down 53.5 percent from last year.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Add $322 Billion to Debt; Budget Talks Stall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New lede, picking up 2nd graf pvs; inserts 3 grafs after 12th graf pvs, Should the, with two sides working on post-recess schedule of completing budget pact. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Tuesday to let the government go $322 billion deeper into debt next year, while White House and congressional negotiators all but agreed to wait until after the August congressional recess to finalize a deficit-cutting deal. The extension of the government's authority to borrow money _ which should see it through the next year _ came on a 221-205 vote. If adopted by the Senate and signed into law, the provision would allow total federal red ink to swell to $3.44 trillion by Sept. 30, 1991. Sweetening the measure was an overwhelmingly popular amendment to stop using the Social Security system's huge surpluses to make the annual federal deficit look smaller. That provision _ approved 413-15 _ would take effect in 1992, when the program that provides benefits to the elderly and disabled is expected to run an $88 billion surplus. It would not affect next year's federal deficit, now projected to reach $169 billion, not including the costs of the federal bailout of the savings and loan industry. If not for the expected $76 billion surplus Social Security should amass next year, the 1991 budget shortfall would be $245 billion. The Social Security measure's sponsor, Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said the provision would force lawmakers to make ``awful choices, wrenching choices'' to confront the government's mounting deficits. ``I understand that,'' he said. ``But the choice we've always made in the last decade is to do nothing.'' Opponents said the provision would merely complicate the work of budget summit negotators. House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said it dismisses the budget talks ``a sideshow, something to circumvent, a farce.'' There is pressure for Congress to approve the debt limit extension before leaving town for the August recess because the administration says the government would otherwise run out of cash by Aug. 15. But the measure's fate in the Senate is uncertain because several controversial amendments are lurking there. One is a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the 6.2 percent payroll tax paid by employees by 1 percentage point. The measure is popular with many Democrats, but opposed by many congressional leaders because it would increase the deficit. Should the legislation bog down in the Senate, congressional leaders are prepared to introduce a short-term borrowing measure that would tide the government over until Congress returns in September. Meanwhile, congressional leaders and White House officials said they were working toward a schedule to complete a budget pact after Congress' month-long August recess. Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., said they were working toward ``a mutually agreed-upon timetable.'' An administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the two sides could agree by week's end to a post-recess schedule for votes on a budget pact. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. Budget talks, which began 12 weeks ago, will continue intermittently during the August break, Democrats have said. As the ouse debated the debt limit measure, House and Senate leaders met again with President Bush to discuss their stalled budget talks. When the session ended, the two sides remained divided in their search for $50 billion in tax increases and spending cuts for next year and $500 billion over five years. Democrats said they remained willing to begin the August recess without advancing a deficit-reduction proposal. Republicans renewed their demand that Democrats produce a budget offer, but House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said Bush made no threats. ``The mood of these talks is candid, open, very civilized,'' said Foley, D-Wash. ``There are no threatening, angry denunciations on either side.'' White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said ``everyone is frustrated'' over Democratic refusal to quickly produce a plan. Elements of a Bush administration proposal surfaced last week, including higher alcohol taxes and cuts in the deductibility of state and local income taxes. Republicans themselves have criticized those ideas. ``It becomes increasingly difficult to negotiate with people suffering from budgetary schizophrenia,'' said the No. 3 House Democrat, Rep. William Gray of Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Merger Approved
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday approved the $1.25 billion merger of long-distance telephone companies MCI Communications Corp. and Telecom USA Inc. The merger is expected to help MCI make greater inroads into the long-distance telephone market dominated by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. MCI spokeswoman Kathleen Keegan said the company expects the merger to be completed before the end of August pending state regulatory approvals. MCI announced last April it would acquire all outstanding shares of Telecom common stock for $42 a share, for a total purchase price of about $1.25 billion. MCI, which has headquarters in Washington, is the nation's second largest provider of long-distance service. It has 19,500 employees and had revenue in 1989 of $6.5 billion. MCI serves residential and commercial customers with long distance, voice and data services in the United States and overseas. Telecom USA is the fourth largest U.S. long distance company. Based in Atlanta, it has 5,000 employees and had 1989 revenue of $713 million.

DOC.HEAD: Crew, Exxon, Coast Guard, State Faulted in Alaskan Oil Spill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Edits thruout with additional detail, conclusions, name of third mate, comment from Hazelwood's lawyer. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators spread blame widely for the Exxon Valdez oil spill Tuesday, faulting Exxon Corp. for not providing ``a fit master and a rested and sufficient crew'' and also blaming the captain, his third mate, the Coast Guard and local authorities. The National Transportation Safety Board voted 4-0 in determining a five-part probable cause for the nation's worst oil spill, the dumping of 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound by the grounding of the tanker Exxon Valdez on MArch 24, 1989. The board said the third mate failed to properly maneuver the vessel, the alcohol-impaired captain failed to give proper supervision, Exxon failed to provide a crew up to its task, the Coast Guard failed in marine traffic control and the state of Alaska failed to provide adequate piloting rules. The board, concluding a 16-month investigation, criticized Exxon Valdez Capt. Joseph Hazelwood for leaving his third mate, Gregory Cousins, at the helm before the ship ran aground. It also said witnesses, medical tests and an unusual study of Hazelwood's speech indicated he was drunk when the ship ran aground, even though an Alaska jury acquitted the captain of being intoxicated and the Coast Guard dropped a drunkenness charge. Hazelwood's attorney, Thomas Russo, who attended the board meeting, said the board members acted ``like they dropped off the moon'' in accusing Hazelwood of being drunk. Twenty-one witnesses testified at his trial that he was sober, Russo said, and authorities botched blood tests, taken more than 10 hours after the accident, that showed the presence of alcohol. ``Their conclusions are not founded in the evidence,'' Russo said. Hazelwood was convicted of one misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. He was fined $50,000 and ordered to spend 1,000 hours cleaning Alaskan beaches. He has appealed. Last week, the Coast Guard dismissed charges of drunkenness and misconduct against Hazelwood but suspended his license as a ship's master for nine months after he pleaded no contest to breaking Coast Guard rules. The violations included drinking within four hours before taking command of the vessel and leaving the bridge to the other officer while the tanker was headed for jagged Bligh Reef, where it split open. Board Chairman James Kolstad said the board hopes its report, which included 36 safety recommendations, will help prevent future spills. Its analysis carries no force of law and, by statute, cannot be used in court cases. ``This is the largest and costliest accident the safety board has ever investigated,'' said Kolstad in opening the meeting. He said $2 billion had been spent cleaning up the spill. The board's conclusions included: _The decision by Hazelwood to leave his third mate in charge as the boat was being maneuvered around a massive ice floe was improper and against Exxon policies and Coast Guard rules. _The third mate was impaired by fatigue, which contributed to his failure to guide the 987-foot vessel around the ice. _Similar conditions of deck officers with inadequate rest exist on other Exxon tankers due to a company policy of operating with reduced crews. _Exxon offers incentives for crews who work long hours and has ``manipulated'' shipboard reporting of overtime and workload. _The Coast Guard has been ``unduly narrow in perspective'' in allowing Exxon ships to operate with inadequate crews, failing to consider the amount of work required in loading the ships before they go out to sea. _Exxon has no program for dealing with drug and alcohol abuse. _The Coast Guard is not prepared to take tests for drug and alcohol use after accidents. _The Transportation Department's post-accident testing policies are inadequate. _The Coast Guard should have access to national driving records to help it assess the fitness of ship's officers to hold federal licenses. Hazelwood had at least two prior convictions for drunken driving. _The Coast Guard should more closely monitor ships and ice conditions in Prince William Sound, where its traffic service remains ineffective.. _Limited supervision of the Coast Guard's vessel traffic system contributed to the service's lack of knowledge that ice was forcing ships to move near the reef where the Exxon Valdez hung up. Two months after the Exxon Valdez ran aground, the board held a week-long public hearing in Alaska, interviewing 27 witnesses and collecting 115 exhibits. Since the spill, the tanker has been repaired and renamed the Exxon Mediterranean and has been undergoing tests for service on routes in the Mediterranean Sea or the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says He Was Not Aware of S&L Figure's Guilt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS graf 8: ``The New,'' report that Thompson reviewed documents
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Deposit Insurance, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A federal regulator said Tuesday he would not have recommended the taxpayer-subsidized sale of 15 Texas savings and loan associations to an Arizona businessman had he known of the buyer's guilty plea to a fraud charge. ``I would have objected,'' George M. Barclay, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas, told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee. Having no knowledge of the guilty plea by James Fail, Barclay said, ``I was very comfortable'' with a decision not to object to Fail's purchase of what now is known as Bluebonnet Savings Bank. The sale of the failing S&Ls is under investigation by the business rights subcommittee on three grounds: _Evidence that Fail put up only $1,000 cash for the 15 banks and was promised at least $1.85 billion in federal subsidies. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, chairman of the subcommittee, said $3 billion is a better estimate and called the deal scandalous. _Fail's plea bargain on one fraud count, which resulted in dismissal of the indictment, and his guilty plea on behalf of his United Security Holding Co. to another felony charge. _Suspicions by Metzenbaum that a former aide to then-Vice President Bush improperly intervened with federal officials on Fail's behalf. That aide, Robert J. Thompson, refused to testify before the subcommittee Tuesday because, his attorney said, the panel has no jurisdiction over the banking industry and has systematically handed over Thompson's private documents to reporters. The New York Times said in Wednesday editions that documents made available by the committee showed Thompson was able to review and suggest modifications to government documents affecting his clients' interests, in particular helping officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board prepare a response to an inspector general's report that found that Fail should have been precluded from buying the 15 S&Ls. Metzenbaum said the subcommittee will ask the Judiciary Committee to compel Thompson to comply with a subpoena. ``My own view is that we should proceed forthwith with the strongest means of enforcement'' of the subpoena, said Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa. Stanley M. Brand, Thompson's lawyer, told the subcommittee: ``During the Bluebonnet transactions ... my client simply and forthrightly represented his client, and scrupulously followed the rules and regulations established by duly authorized federal regulatory agencies.'' Thompson said in an interview in The Washington Post on Tuesday that in exchange for helping Fail, he was paid a lobbying fee, given a $150,000 loan and promised 2 percent of profits from Bluebonnet. Thompson told the Post he acted as a ``project manager'' helping Fail work with regulators in Washington, Dallas, Atlanta and New York. M. Danny Wall, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which approved the Bluebonnet sale, said his records show he met only three times with Thompson _ never to discuss the takeover. Stuart D. Root, who at the time of the sale headed the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., said he would not know Thompson if he walked into the room. Barclay said when the sale was approved in December 1988, he was aware that Fail and signed a plea bargain that resulted in the dropping of a 1976 Alabama indictment for securities fraud. Since that offense had occurred more than 10 years in the past, it was not considered a bar to the S&L purchase. However, Barclay added, ``I do not recall having been told ... that an affiliate company of Mr. Fail's had pleaded guilty to a felony,'' which would have been a ``presumptive disqualifier'' against Fail. Wall rejected allegations that regulators, in selling the S&Ls to Fail, turned down a bid that would have been $97 million better for taxpayers. ``That's not true at all,'' Wall said. If the two bids were compared on the same basis, Fail's would have been at least equal, and probably better, than the other, he said.
